Militarie Gun ::: B A D I D E A ::: desc.name: B A D I D E A
Militarie Gun ::: B A D I D E A ::: desc.extracted_quote: turning his bad decisions into shout-along triumphs
Militarie Gun ::: B A D I D E A ::: desc.review: It's a "HOT TO GO!" moment for the power-pop-meets-hardcore group, with vocalist Ian Shelton turning his bad decisions into shout-along triumphs. — P. Ragusa

Militarie Gun ::: B A D I D E A ::: desc.name: B A D I D E A
Militarie Gun ::: B A D I D E A ::: desc.review: Hey kids, spelling is fun! The lead single from Militarie Gun's God Save The Gun joins "Respect," "Glamorous," and "Hot To Go!" in the spelling song hall of fame. It’s a little difficult to accompany with a dance á la Chappell, but it's better suited to spitting out mid-crowdsurf anyway. This is peak adrenaline-shot, fuck-you Militarie Gun, and while a hardcore-aligned band bringing out the synths is always divisive, it feels appropriately fun here. — Spencer Hughes

DEBBY FRIDAY ::: 1/17 ::: description_pa.extracted_quote: "1/17" glows with the kind of passion one feels when everything lines up just right
DEBBY FRIDAY ::: 1/17 ::: description_pa.review: Last time we heard from Canada’s DEBBY FRIDAY, she hinted at a softer side while showcasing her club-ready punk and industrial signatures. It worked exceedingly well for her, landing her a spot in our Best Debut Albums list in 2023 and a Polaris Prize. Her follow-up, The Starrr of the Queen of Life sands down some of those edges, prioritizing the restorative possibilities of electro-pop, while leaving FRIDAY plenty of room to showcase her infectious bravado. “1/17” is a trance pop journey, one where her vocals soar while she repeats “I swear you’re a sign” over glistening, skittering synths that grow and grow until they erupt with the drums into a proper dance break. Before then, FRIDAY locks in: “Poetry and nude selfies / Love the way that you know me / Touch the back of my right knee / Tongue you down just like Delphi,” then “Skin to skin with no buffer / Write your name on my bumper / Call you ‘babe’ and ‘my lover’ / Kiss you hard in the summer.” It’s erotic, but beyond that, “1/17” glows with the kind of passion one feels when everything lines up just right. — Devon Chodzin

Cardboard ::: Wouldn't Let You Realise :.name: Wouldn't Let You Realise
Cardboard ::: Wouldn't Let You Realise :.extracted_quote: a relatable vibe turned addictive thanks to all those guitars
Cardboard ::: Wouldn't Let You Realise :.review: The British quartet blasts its way through a song about toxic relationships, and how much it sucks to witness them happening from the outside — a relatable vibe turned addictive thanks to all those guitars. — L.S. Miller

David Byrne & Ghost Train Orchestra :::.name: The Avant Garde
David Byrne & Ghost Train Orchestra :::.extracted_quote: David Byrne sure can write a weirdly catchy ditty
David Byrne & Ghost Train Orchestra :::.review: For someone who is constantly on the edge of the avant garde, David Byrne sure can write a weirdly catchy ditty about how it "doesn't mean shit." — B. Kaye

CMAT ::: When A Good Man Cries ::: descr.name: When A Good Man Cries
CMAT ::: When A Good Man Cries ::: descr.extracted_quote: a slow fiddle-fringed do-si-do that nods to her love of country, telling a rich, racked story of a breakup
CMAT ::: When A Good Man Cries ::: descr.review: In her true breakthrough year, the Irish singer-songwriter was so popular with our voters that she had three entries in the Top 20 (combined here). Together they show the breadth of her talents: like a light entertainer who appeals to kids and grandparents alike while hymning the horrors of confronting one’s self-worth. Take a Sexy Picture of Me made a TikTok craze out of a multilayered examination of body image; Jamie Oliver catches a stray as CMAT has an existential freakout after seeing his massive face on a poster; and When a Good Man Cries is a slow fiddle-fringed do-si-do that nods to her love of country, telling a rich, racked story of a breakup as she wonders: am I the baddie? BBT

Rema ::: Baby (Is it a Crime) ::: descri.name: Baby (Is it a Crime)
Rema ::: Baby (Is it a Crime) ::: descri.review: “Baby (Is It a Crime)” is Rema’s first solo single since the success of his second album, Heis , and it’s uber cool and nonchalant compared with the frenetic, brooding album. Fans had been clamoring for the Sade-sampling song since he teased a snippet last November. The full version finds Rema at his sensual best. “I just had the biggest debut in my career,” he told Rolling Stone the day it dropped. Indeed, the song earned nearly 3 million streams on its first day. — M.C

Amaarae, Bree Runway, & Starkillers :::.name: Starkilla (with Bree Runway & Starkillers)
Amaarae, Bree Runway, & Starkillers :::.extracted_quote: this song is a drug in and of itself
Amaarae, Bree Runway, & Starkillers :::.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of August 2025 : “Amaarae has one of my favorite projects this year with her new album BLACK STAR, and while there are many standout tracks, the most intoxicating one comes early with ‘Starkilla.’ Amaarae may mention a trio of illicit substances, but this song is a drug in and of itself.” —SM

Amaarae, Bree Runway, & Starkillers :::.name: Starkilla (with Bree Runway & Starkillers)
Amaarae, Bree Runway, & Starkillers :::.extracted_quote: empowering "bad bitch" anthem made to be blasted on the way to the party
Amaarae, Bree Runway, & Starkillers :::.review: This empowering “bad bitch” anthem was made to be blasted on the way to the party. — S. Noor

Jasm\u00edn ::: Bite the Hand ::: descri.name: Bite the Hand
Jasm\u00edn ::: Bite the Hand ::: descri.extracted_quote: leaning on intricate percussion to set the tempo until an unmistakably massive, almost disrespectfully gully bassline evokes the glory days of dubstep
Jasm\u00edn ::: Bite the Hand ::: descri.review: Ever since Hessle Audio released their first record 18 years ago, the crew has had a knack for burning mostly unknown, precocious talent directly into the core of dance music’s consciousness. Think Bruce , Anz , Ploy , Toumba , Shanti Celeste , Objekt , James Blake … the list goes on. Fitting, then, that their 50th recording is helmed by yet another fast-rising star – Amsterdam’s Jasmín . In classic Hessle style, Bite the Hand is difficult to genre-fy, leaning on intricate percussion to set the tempo until an unmistakably massive, almost disrespectfully gully bassline evokes the glory days of dubstep. Over the course of the track, variations are layered and elongated – wobbling, purring, meowing and roaring – until it all gradually falls back to the same percussion that opened it minutes before. -- Isaac Muk

Sudan Archives ::: A BUG'S LIFE ::: desc.name: A BUG'S LIFE
Sudan Archives ::: A BUG'S LIFE ::: desc.extracted_quote: Sudan Archives gives that old framework a fresh and playful urgency
Sudan Archives ::: A BUG'S LIFE ::: desc.review: Vintage Chicago house throwbacks have been thick on the ground ever since Renaissance dropped. But Sudan Archives gives that old framework a fresh and playful urgency. On paper, “A Bug’s Life” describes a rocky relationship with someone who’s “so relentless … She never looks back/’Cause she can’t go home.” In the air, the Italo-house piano, hypnotically shuffling hi-hats, and soaring vocal-sample patchwork behind the chorus all work to make the song’s bittersweet tone even more tangible. — M.Matos

Sudan Archives ::: A BUG'S LIFE ::: desc.name: A BUG'S LIFE
Sudan Archives ::: A BUG'S LIFE ::: desc.extracted_quote: "A BUG'S LIFE" leaves me ecstatic ... I wouldn't be able to stay still
Sudan Archives ::: A BUG'S LIFE ::: desc.review: “A BUG’S LIFE” is such a prize, and I want whatever Brittney Parks was on when she wrote it. “Just hit a scam over ninety bands,” she sings. “Did the running man with like twenty grand. Brand new tits, but they grew her ass. Thirty-inch bust down to her ass. Boss bitch, but she want a better half.” The beat is a trance, as is the chopped-up “oh-oh-oh” vocal sample threaded into the drum programming. Saying that Sudan Archives is one of the best living performers is probably too obvious. But you have to know this: “A BUG’S LIFE” leaves me ecstatic. Even if I was strapped to a table while listening to it I wouldn’t be able to stay still. — Matt Mitchell

Big Thief & Laraaji ::: Grandmother :::.name: Grandmother
Big Thief & Laraaji ::: Grandmother :::.extracted_quote: creates a wide-open space where big questions can land gently
Big Thief & Laraaji ::: Grandmother :::.review: Few songs sit so calmly with the vastness of being as Big Thief’s “Grandmother.” Over delicate acoustics and looping samples, the band creates a wide-open space where big questions can land gently. The track feels infinite and unhurried, unfolding like someone thinking out loud about a life that refuses to make sense, sitting right on the edge between bittersweet reflection and hopeful acceptance. “Gonna turn it all into rock and roll,” Adrianne Lenker sings. What else can you do with feelings that big? Seip

Rachel Chinouriri ::: Can we talk about.name: Can we talk about Isaac?
Rachel Chinouriri ::: Can we talk about.extracted_quote: an indie-pop hit ... that she can capture the highs just as succinctly as she's detailed the lows without sacrificing her signature grit, complexities, and honesty
Rachel Chinouriri ::: Can we talk about.review: Rachel Chinouriri turns her first-date nerves into an indie-pop hit and lasting romance on “Can We Talk About Isaac?” The anthemic, upbeat love song makes a case for the rare times when butterflies don’t turn out to be warning signs. It’s a new side of the British pop star, who proves here that she can capture the highs just as succinctly as she’s detailed the lows without sacrificing her signature grit, complexities, and honesty. Falling head over heels put Chinouriri on top of the world. — L.P.

VALORANT, templuv, & 347aidan ::: Last S.name: Last Shot
VALORANT, templuv, & 347aidan ::: Last S.extracted_quote: one of the year's most moving pop songs — living somewhere between new wave and SoundCloud rap
VALORANT, templuv, & 347aidan ::: Last S.review: Why wouldn’t one of the year’s most moving pop songs — living somewhere between new wave and SoundCloud rap — come from a video game competition ?

Little Simz ::: Thief ::: description_nm.name: Thief
Little Simz ::: Thief ::: description_nm.extracted_quote: Driven by a propulsive rhythm that bores deep into your brain ... she takes ruthless aim at a "person I've known my whole life coming like the devil in disguise"
Little Simz ::: Thief ::: description_nm.review: With ‘Thief’, Little Simz comes out swinging. Driven by a propulsive rhythm that bores deep into your brain, as if it’s stealing some vital information Inception -style, she takes ruthless aim at a “person I’ve known my whole life coming like the devil in disguise.” An electrifying knock-out blow . TM

Lorde ::: David ::: description_billboar.name: David
Lorde ::: David ::: description_billboar.extracted_quote: taking a block of raw material and carving away everything that isn't the masterpiece awaiting discovery underneath
Lorde ::: David ::: description_billboar.review: Named after Michaelangelo’s famous sculpture, “David” finds Lorde using the same technique as the famed Renaissance figure — taking a block of raw material and carving away everything that isn’t the masterpiece awaiting discovery underneath. Beyond sifting through musical elements to reach a catharsis of evocative piano and razor-toothed synths, the singer’s Virgin closer chips away at all the pains of life, career and heartbreak that have led up to one sacred realization: “I don’t belong to anyone.” — H.D.

Little Simz ::: Thief ::: description_ro.name: Thief
Little Simz ::: Thief ::: description_ro.extracted_quote: a sleek, swaggering reminder of Simz' unmatched musical instinct
Little Simz ::: Thief ::: description_ro.review: A fearless exercise in autonomy, it’s a sleek, swaggering reminder of Simz ’ unmatched musical instinct. Thief is effortlessly cool, technically tight and entirely her own. -- Emily, Rough Trade Office

Lorde ::: David ::: description_pitchfor.name: David
Lorde ::: David ::: description_pitchfor.extracted_quote: a gutting thesis for an album consumed with agency
Lorde ::: David ::: description_pitchfor.review: “Was I just someone to dominate?” Lorde wails on “David,” a gutting thesis for an album consumed with agency. The track is sparse, translucent—“playing with shadows,” as Lorde sings, Jim-E Stack’s synths only grazing the song’s gaps. After interrogating her own desires, she turns the gaze on her ex: Did he think she was weak? Did he just want “young blood?” So much of Virgin focuses on the power struggle baked into every compulsion—the urge to sleep with a man just to prove she can, to purge and punish herself, to swallow someone’s spit. On “David,” she finally asks the question she’s strived for throughout the album: “Why do we run to the ones we do?” –Dani Blum

Audrey Hobert ::: Sex and the city ::: d.name: Sex and the city
Audrey Hobert ::: Sex and the city ::: d.extracted_quote: an addictive mix of meta moments, social observations and commentary on terrible trysts
Audrey Hobert ::: Sex and the city ::: d.review: Audrey Hobert never intended to become a musician growing up, but thank god that’s where life’s taken her. This year the New Yorker emerged as one of indie-pop’s smartest new voices, as evidenced on ‘Sex And The City’ – an addictive mix of meta moments, social observations and commentary on terrible trysts. RD

kimj, SEBii, The Deep, & Effie ::: MY UN.name: MY UNNIES
kimj, SEBii, The Deep, & Effie ::: MY UN.extracted_quote: the culmination of this movement ... told with the DIY language of today's musical outsiders
kimj, SEBii, The Deep, & Effie ::: MY UN.review: Over the past year, across East Asia, a number of young artists have been rewriting the rules of pop music, and, in many ways, “My Unnies” featuring South Korean vocalists The Deep and Effie, Korean-American producer Kimj, and Chinese-American producer-vocalist Sebii, is the culmination of this movement. It’s K-pop in its expansiveness: some catchy melody lines, a hint of rap, and a kaleidoscopic electronic beat that opens up into an explosive, almost tear-out dubstep bassline; but it’s told with the DIY language of today’s musical outsiders. Much like the track’s music video, which sees the cohort link up on the beaches of Thailand, “My Unnies” is a mission statement: having honed their talents in various cities across East Asia, they are now ready to take over the world. (SPM)

Audrey Hobert ::: Sex and the city ::: d.name: Sex and the city
Audrey Hobert ::: Sex and the city ::: d.extracted_quote: fights against the romance of a Carrie Bradshaw-esque lifestyle while immortalizing the single female experience with a candor and humor that's as cutting as it is relatable
Audrey Hobert ::: Sex and the city ::: d.review: “In ‘Sex and the City,’ Hobert fights against the romance of a Carrie Bradshaw-esque lifestyle while immortalizing the single female experience with a candor and humor that’s as cutting as it is relatable. An incredible recounting of what it’s like to put yourself out there to no avail, then going home with a lackluster man for the sake of saying you did, all while battling your own insecurities, Hobert’s diaristic lyricism is everything and more.” —BT

Morgan Wallen ::: Just In Case ::: descr.name: Just In Case
Morgan Wallen ::: Just In Case ::: descr.extracted_quote: stands out for its delicate acoustics, knockout chorus and flawed-but-focused honesty
Morgan Wallen ::: Just In Case ::: descr.review: After a breakup, Morgan Wallen isn’t exactly sitting at home just waiting for his girl to come back (he’s doing some “midnight movin’ on,” of course), but even if he’s going all the way, his heart isn’t. This midtempo I’m the Problem single stands out for its delicate acoustics, knockout chorus and flawed-but-focused honesty: Morgan is acknowledging that the next girl isn’t going to get all of him, because he’s leaving the door open for his lost love… just in case. – K.A.

Macario Mart\u00ednez ::: sue\u00f1a lin.name: sueña lindo, corazón
Macario Mart\u00ednez ::: sue\u00f1a lin.extracted_quote: sweet and assuming serenade positioned him as a promising new voice in the Mexican folk-music scene
Macario Mart\u00ednez ::: sue\u00f1a lin.review: Macario Martínez gave us one of the year’s most heartening viral success stories. The former street sweeper from Mexico City captivated the world with an acoustic performance of the heartfelt “Sueña Lindo, Corazón” on TikTok. Martínez’s sweet and assuming serenade positioned him as a promising new voice in the Mexican folk-music scene, and he spent the rest of the year following up on that promise. By dreaming out loud, he transcended the algorithm and became a star. — Lucas Villa

Miley Cyrus & Brittany Howard ::: Walk o.name: Walk of Fame (feat. Brittany Howard)
Miley Cyrus & Brittany Howard ::: Walk o.extracted_quote: marries the operatic bluster of Lady Gaga's Born This Way with the disco splendor of Donna Summer's Bad Girls
Miley Cyrus & Brittany Howard ::: Walk o.review: The six-minute “Walk of Fame,” which features a blistering backing vocal from Alabama Shakes’s Brittany Howard that nods to Bronski Beat’s “Smalltown Boy,” marries the operatic bluster of Lady Gaga’s Born This Way with the disco splendor of Donna Summer’s Bad Girls . The song conjures neon-tinged snapshots of a ’70s-era Sunset Strip so vivid that even the musical film that accompanies Something Beautiful can’t live up to them. Cinquemani

Saya Gray ::: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON\u201.name: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON’T SPRING 4 LOVE )
Saya Gray ::: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON\u201.extracted_quote: "You woke up yesterday," [she] sings of heartbreak on this folk-pop song. "I watched the seasons change."
Saya Gray ::: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON\u201.review: The start of spring isn't always romantic: To get vibrant blooms and golden leaves, you sometimes have to endure dark days and freezing rain. But if you stay present through it all, you can learn something about commitment. "You woke up yesterday," the inventive artist Saya Gray sings of heartbreak on this folk-pop song. "I watched the seasons change." —Elle Mannion, NPR

Saya Gray ::: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON\u201.name: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON’T SPRING 4 LOVE )
Saya Gray ::: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON\u201.extracted_quote: puts her experimental sounds and genre-spanning sensibility—electronic, alternative, rock, and more—on full display
Saya Gray ::: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON\u201.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of February 2025 : “I wish I had a better way to describe Saya Gray’s debut album, SAYA, but I just have to put it plainly: It’s really freaking cool. And it opens with this track, which puts her experimental sounds and genre-spanning sensibility—electronic, alternative, rock, and more—on full display. With layered vocals, she delivers an unexpected, buoyant melody over fuzzy guitars as she sings, ‘This is why I don’t fall in love in springtime.’” —EG

Anna von Hausswolff ::: The Iconoclast :.name: The Iconoclast
Anna von Hausswolff ::: The Iconoclast :.extracted_quote: sprawling icy soundscapes are propelled by AVH's earth-shaking organ and Otis Sandsjö's dazzling, dusty saxophone solos
Anna von Hausswolff ::: The Iconoclast :.review: On her first full band album in seven years, Anna Von Hausswolff assembles a crack team to turn her foreboding darkwave compositions into maximalist gothic power ballads. ‘The Iconoclast’ is perhaps the high water mark, as sprawling icy soundscapes are propelled by AVH’s earth-shaking organ and Otis Sandsjö’s dazzling, dusty saxophone solos.

LATIN MAFIA & Omar Apollo ::: Hecho para.name: Hecho para ti
LATIN MAFIA & Omar Apollo ::: Hecho para.extracted_quote: beautifully harmonize ... about being migajeros, a person that's madly in love with someone who doesn't feel the same way
LATIN MAFIA & Omar Apollo ::: Hecho para.review: In a show of Mexican solidarity from both sides of the border, LATIN MAFIA joined forces with Omar Apollo for the hypnotic "Hecho Para Ti." LATIN MAFIA's Milton and Emilio de la Rosa beautifully harmonize with Apollo about being migajeros, a person that's madly in love with someone who doesn't feel the same way. In Spanish, the sad boy squad laments, "I was too much for you, but I'm made for you, my love." — LV

Lily Allen ::: Tennis ::: description_ny.name: Tennis
Lily Allen ::: Tennis ::: description_ny.extracted_quote: alive with paranoid detail ... and smiling-through-the-tears pathos
Lily Allen ::: Tennis ::: description_ny.review: Not every song works on Lily Allen’s headline-grabbing, fearlessly confessional breakup album “West End Girl,” but everything clicks on this catchy standout, which is alive with paranoid detail (“Then you showed me a photo on Instagram / It was how you grabbed your phone back right out of my hands”) and smiling-through-the-tears pathos.

AJ Tracey & Jorja Smith ::: Crush (feat..name: Crush (feat. Jorja Smith)
AJ Tracey & Jorja Smith ::: Crush (feat..extracted_quote: it's Smith who delivers a show-stealing performance ... making snarky rap repartee look easy
AJ Tracey & Jorja Smith ::: Crush (feat..review: If flirting is a racket sport, it really helps to have a rally partner like Jorja Smith. No shade to Tracey, one of U.K. rap's pack leaders, who toughens up a sparkling, chipmunk'd Brandy flip as he makes his move. And yet it's Smith who delivers a show-stealing performance, not just shooing him off with her searing soul, but making snarky rap repartee look easy, too. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

AJ Tracey & Jorja Smith ::: Crush (feat..name: Crush (feat. Jorja Smith)
AJ Tracey & Jorja Smith ::: Crush (feat..extracted_quote: flip Brandy's 2002 deep cut into a grime hit
AJ Tracey & Jorja Smith ::: Crush (feat..review: For their first official collaboration, U.K. staples AJ Tracey and Jorja Smith flip Brandy’s 2002 deep cut “Love Wouldn’t Count Me Out” into a grime hit. The London rapper and R&B star trade verses about second chances throughout the track, including one in which Smith slips into a silky-smooth rap cadence herself, crafted in her distinct Walsall accent. Tracey matches his collaborator’s reluctant tone with clever, streamlined bars that make a pretty undeniable case for hitting repeat. — L.P.

Saba & No ID ::: Woes of The World ::: d.name: Woes of The World
Saba & No ID ::: Woes of The World ::: d.extracted_quote: an emotional dissonance laid bare over a trance-like beat
Saba & No ID ::: Woes of The World ::: d.review: This highlight from the long-anticipated joint album From the Private Collection of Saba and No ID takes us on a journey of self-reliance against a fraught backdrop. Saba confronts the reality of known hardship while looking his own success in the eye, an emotional dissonance laid bare over a trance-like beat from fellow Chicago native No ID. —Sonali Mehta, NPR

Saba & No ID ::: Woes of The World ::: d.name: Woes of The World
Saba & No ID ::: Woes of The World ::: d.extracted_quote: No ID provides haunting production ... [and] Saba attacks it with aplomb
Saba & No ID ::: Woes of The World ::: d.review: Saba has long been one of the most perspicacious MCs working in hip-hop, and "Woes of the World" is further evidence of his discerning abilities. No ID provides haunting production, complete with high-pitched, angelic-adjacent harmonies set against prowling bass, and Saba attacks it with aplomb. As the title suggests, Saba is wrestling with his place on Earth throughout the song: "When you used to the woes of the world/ Everything a woe in the world," he raps. Soul-searching is at the top of Saba's to-do list, and this song is one of his latest and greatest attempts. — K. Fitzgerald

Esther Rose ::: New Bad ::: description_.name: New Bad
Esther Rose ::: New Bad ::: description_.extracted_quote: it's an exploratory, gut-following, new-direction road song that still sounds just like Esther
Esther Rose ::: New Bad ::: description_.review: With its static pop and frantic jangle, “New Bad” is the standout from country-folk artist and noted Sagittarian Esther Rose’s Want , a psychedelia-tinged album written after quitting drinking and starting ketamine therapy. An instant Rose classic, it's an exploratory, gut-following, new-direction road song that still sounds just like Esther, like an old friend you pick right back up with even when life is so full of changes. It’s a song about desire, about wanting to be free: "From the lakes of Michigan / To my friend Louisianne / And to old New Mexico / It's my heart that I follow." <3! — LM

Lucrecia Dalt & David Sylvian ::: cosa r.name: cosa rara
Lucrecia Dalt & David Sylvian ::: cosa r.extracted_quote: Half love song, half noir, baked by the desert sun, "cosa rara" is a delirious collision of lust and violence
Lucrecia Dalt & David Sylvian ::: cosa r.review: Lucrecia Dalt’s “cosa rara” cuts between a speeding car and a steamy hotel room. A pair of lovers inhabits both, and they’re in trouble. Alex Lázaro’s tense percussion and David Sylvian’s disquieting guitar color Dalt’s Spanish narration blood red—they’re going 150, the conspiracy’s in pieces, their luck is horrible. Still, they're in love, they’re in heaven. Then the crash: Screeching tires and shattering glass announce they’ve gone too far, too fast. Sylvian ends the track in a menacing baritone: “The walls are thin, my nerves are shot/I’m vulnerable and I know it/Is that door locked?” Half love song, half noir, baked by the desert sun, “cosa rara” is a delirious collision of lust and violence. –Matthew Blackwell

Lucrecia Dalt & David Sylvian ::: cosa r.name: cosa rara
Lucrecia Dalt & David Sylvian ::: cosa r.extracted_quote: Dalt's beguiling vocals and finely programmed textures based on Colombian rhythms ... add to the foreboding mystery and drama
Lucrecia Dalt & David Sylvian ::: cosa r.review: This double-life escapade emerges as an invitation that suddenly gives way to the eerie undertones of the album's name, A Danger to Ourselves . Dalt's beguiling vocals and finely programmed textures based on Colombian rhythms, joined by co-producer Sylvian's targeted, spoken-word vocals, add to the foreboding mystery and drama. — Liz Warner , WDET

Rene\u00e9 Rapp ::: Shy ::: description_.name: Shy
Rene\u00e9 Rapp ::: Shy ::: description_.extracted_quote: songs like "Shy" have that "x-factor" where you can remember every note after a single listen
Rene\u00e9 Rapp ::: Shy ::: description_.review: Reneé’s vocals never cease to amaze me, and she absolutely sings her face off on "Shy." I can't remember the last time a chorus was stuck in my head for so long; songs like "Shy" have that "x-factor" where you can remember every note after a single listen. Hearing it live on the Bite Me Tour at Madison Square Garden was easily one of the highlights of my year.

Big Thief ::: Los Angeles ::: descriptio.name: Los Angeles
Big Thief ::: Los Angeles ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: a love that transcends time, space, speech and sight
Big Thief ::: Los Angeles ::: descriptio.review: On this sunkissed and unhurried rocker, Adrianne Lenker sings of a love that transcends time, space, speech and sight. It's a warmth tinged with regret, an understanding colored by experience, a feeling that can't be described with words. Good thing the sweet vocal harmonies and bright layers of guitar on this track can do it for us. — Lukas Harnisch , WBUR

Big Thief ::: Los Angeles ::: descriptio.name: Los Angeles
Big Thief ::: Los Angeles ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: write about love in a way that feels both untouchable and familiar
Big Thief ::: Los Angeles ::: descriptio.review: Bristol, we're so back. Big Thief continue to write about love in a way that feels both untouchable and familiar, and just as heartbreaking as their earlier work. We love you Adrianne Lenker . -- Josie and Connor, Rough Trade Bristol

Fust ::: Spangled ::: description_npr ::.name: Spangled
Fust ::: Spangled ::: description_npr ::.extracted_quote: goes fully anthemic in this elegy for a torn-down hospital ... invisible and transcendent, as the guitars rise like a monument
Fust ::: Spangled ::: description_npr ::.review: The ghost buildings of the American South, disappeared by redevelopment, echo with lost voices. North Carolina's Fust goes fully anthemic in this elegy for a torn-down hospital sung by a soul who once lay in one of its adjustable beds. "I feel like a sparkler that's been thrown off a roof," he wails, invisible and transcendent, as the guitars rise like a monument. —Ann Powers, NPR

S.G. Goodman ::: Snapping Turtle ::: des.name: Snapping Turtle
S.G. Goodman ::: Snapping Turtle ::: des.extracted_quote: takes Laurel Canyon-style confessional songwriting to the hollers of Kentucky
S.G. Goodman ::: Snapping Turtle ::: des.review: No song this year was more brutally honest, or more sublime, than this one, which takes Laurel Canyon-style confessional songwriting to the hollers of Kentucky. A childhood scene of cruelty and punishment underpins a rageful lament about what and who gets stuck in the small towns whose exit lanes lead nowhere. "Small town is where my mind gets stuck," sings Goodman, surveying the damage, wondering what it takes to heal. —Ann Powers, NPR

R!R!Riot & ATM Hanson ::: Run Riot Run :.name: Run Riot Run
R!R!Riot & ATM Hanson ::: Run Riot Run :.extracted_quote: a pluggnb collaboration between producer ATM Hanson – the so-called 'Metro Boomin of China' – and vocalist R!R!Riot, who sounds like if Avril Lavigne and Playboi Carti had a baby
R!R!Riot & ATM Hanson ::: Run Riot Run :.review: This one’s certified platinum on WeChat; you’re late. It’s a pluggnb collaboration between producer ATM Hanson – the so-called ‘Metro Boomin of China’ – and vocalist R!R!Riot, who sounds like if Avril Lavigne and Playboi Carti had a baby, and that baby was a bilingual English-Mandarin speaker. “Run Riot Run” is also somewhat of a title track for R!R!Riot herself, whose name is a portmanteau of her birthname, Riya, and the word ‘riot’, lifted from Raf Simons ’ “Riot! Riot! Riot!” 2001 Autumn/Winter menswear collection. (SPM)

Zach Top ::: Between The Ditches ::: des.name: Between The Ditches
Zach Top ::: Between The Ditches ::: des.extracted_quote: delivers sentiment that transcends the years in a simple, emotive and meaningful telling of a hard-lived life
Zach Top ::: Between The Ditches ::: des.review: The latest addition to country music's time-honored confessional canon. Like George Strait and Keith Whitley before him, Top delivers sentiment that transcends the years in a simple, emotive and meaningful telling of a hard-lived life ("I've been woke up by more than one guard rail"). — Jessie Scott , WMOT

yeule ::: Dudu ::: description_npr ::: c.name: Dudu
yeule ::: Dudu ::: description_npr ::: c.extracted_quote: vocals raw and out front ... singing a childlike hook with a Casio's cold resolve, smearing messy heartbreak scenes into the shape of a nursery rhyme
yeule ::: Dudu ::: description_npr ::: c.review: Nat Ćmiel has always been an enigma on-mic, their emotional identity merged hazily with the machines that warp and crush their voice. "Dudu" inverts the formula: vocals raw and out front, but singing a childlike hook with a Casio's cold resolve, smearing messy heartbreak scenes into the shape of a nursery rhyme. —Daoud Tyler-Ameen, NPR

John Oswald & Marc-Andr\u00e9 Hamelin ::.name: Tip
John Oswald & Marc-Andr\u00e9 Hamelin ::.extracted_quote: seamlessly stitched several dozen colorful threads of classical, pop and jazz themes
John Oswald & Marc-Andr\u00e9 Hamelin ::.review: This brilliantly executed musical puzzler asks us to "name that tune" throughout its gently rollicking nine minutes. With utmost taste and a sly, precise performance by pianist Marc-André Hamelin, composer John Oswald has seamlessly stitched several dozen colorful threads of classical, pop and jazz themes into this piece. From Beethoven's "Moonlight" sonata to "Nature Boy," I spot around 20 references, but it seems like just the tip of the iceberg. How many do you hear? —Tom Huizenga, NPR

Hearts2Hearts ::: FOCUS ::: description_.name: FOCUS
Hearts2Hearts ::: FOCUS ::: description_.extracted_quote: a classic four-on-the-floor track built around a vintage piano riff and an addicting house beat that rewards repeat listening
Hearts2Hearts ::: FOCUS ::: description_.review: When f(x) came out with “4 Walls” in ye olde 2015, the deep house single begot a new era of K-pop, laying the groundwork for dance tracks like aespa’s “Whiplash” and LE SSERAFIM’s “Crazy.” Hearts2Hearts’ “FOCUS” is the latest in that lineage, a classic four-on-the-floor track built around a vintage piano riff and an addicting house beat that rewards repeat listening. — HY

Carmel Smickersgill ::: Build the Habit.name: Build the Habit
Carmel Smickersgill ::: Build the Habit.extracted_quote: an unnerving, clattery four minutes of music, full of pounding beats, pitch-shifted voices and crispy-fried synth textures
Carmel Smickersgill ::: Build the Habit.review: ‘Build The Habit’ is an unnerving, clattery four minutes of music, full of pounding beats, pitch-shifted voices and crispy-fried synth textures. Carmel Smickersgill is a composer based in Manchester who is just as comfortable writing chamber operas, symphonic music or theatrical sound design as she is creating bewitching albums of electronic music for PRAH Recordings (her last record, 2022’s We Get What We Get And We Don’t Get Upset was a tQ Album of the Week). This single, the opening track on her May EP Unsolicited Advice , whips all that compositional talent and arty sonic wizardry into a nightmarish banger liable to send you spiralling direct from the dancefloor to the nearest k-hole.

Madison McFerrin ::: Ain't It Nice ::: d.name: Ain't It Nice
Madison McFerrin ::: Ain't It Nice ::: d.extracted_quote: [The] sensual house beat, paired with her unmistakable vocals, layered harmonies and seductive lyrics get your body moving
Madison McFerrin ::: Ain't It Nice ::: d.review: On her sophomore album, independent artist Madison McFerrin encompasses the passion, transformation and rebirth that Scorpio season is known for. The sensual house beat, paired with her unmistakable vocals, layered harmonies and seductive lyrics get your body moving and make you notice that Madison made it through "on the other side." — Margarita Azucar , KALW

Rico Nasty ::: ON THE LOW ::: descriptio.name: ON THE LOW
Rico Nasty ::: ON THE LOW ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: a pop-punk-rap song that feels like a new chemical compound
Rico Nasty ::: ON THE LOW ::: descriptio.review: Has there been a more potent combo of a G-rated chorus and blush-worthy bars? The DMV rapper, who has been known to call herself "Trap Lavigne," is Disney material one second and Skinemax the next. Throw in the hook's Satriani synths and you have a pop-punk-rap song that feels like a new chemical compound. —Otis Hart, NPR

Ledisi ::: BLKWMN ::: description_npr ::.name: BLKWMN
Ledisi ::: BLKWMN ::: description_npr ::.extracted_quote: A powerful anthem honoring the strength, resilience and emotional depth of Black women
Ledisi ::: BLKWMN ::: description_npr ::.review: A powerful anthem honoring the strength, resilience and emotional depth of Black women. Ledisi celebrates the historic and ongoing fight for dignity, love and visibility, acknowledging both pain and triumph. The song insists that Black women deserve respect, recognition and freedom to exist fully, boldly and unapologetically. —Bella Scratch, The Drop (Rocky Mountain Public Media)

Brandee Younger ::: Gadabout Season :::.name: Gadabout Season
Brandee Younger ::: Gadabout Season :::.extracted_quote: merges Alice Coltrane-inspired cosmic swirls with precise, pop-like bursts
Brandee Younger ::: Gadabout Season :::.review: In a continually updated interpretation of jazz — and of the harp within that context — this lilting tidal flow displays that of a restless seeker set on the discovery of new frontiers. Younger merges Alice Coltrane-inspired cosmic swirls with precise, pop-like bursts to boldly tip-toe around a modern framework. — Liz Warner , WDET

OHYUNG ::: no good ::: description_paste.name: no good
OHYUNG ::: no good ::: description_paste.extracted_quote: an experimental, rave-influenced pop reinvention that ... sits in its own well-paced, blown-out rapture of color
OHYUNG ::: no good ::: description_paste.review: “no good” is not just a detour from OHYUNG’s recent CV of film scores (notably Julio Torres’ Problemista and Neo Sora’s Happyend ), but a total 180 from their two-hour, ambient 2023 masterclass imagine naked! . But don’t let that stop you from cherishing the awe-striking decadence of a track like “no good.” It’s an experimental, rave-influenced pop reinvention that, rather than fully climaxing, sits in its own well-paced, blown-out rapture of color. You Are Always On My Mind is OHYUNG’s “trans self and [their] former self in conversation, from both perspectives,” and the way “no good” oscillate between ecstatic, bantam gestures of synthesizer collages and these loping, symphonic torrents sounds like an exchange. I quote the poem OHYUNG cites in the description of the song’s music video: “[ / I trust these stars I do ] / there before I was there.” An avant collision of phasings and light shifts, “no good” sounds as if it’s always been alive in me. — Matt Mitchell

Natalia Lafourcade & El David Aguilar ::.name: Como Quisiera Quererte
Natalia Lafourcade & El David Aguilar ::.extracted_quote: "Como Quisiera Quererte" pulses along to a classic Mexican waltz, and this story of tragic love is so artfully done that Lafourcade's name should now be mentioned alongside the most iconic of Mexican bolero songwriters
Natalia Lafourcade & El David Aguilar ::.review: Cancionera translates to "singer," but it's also the name of Natalia Lafourcade's alter ego and an achingly beautiful collection of songs that sway between jazz ballads and Mexican boleros. "Como Quisiera Quererte" pulses along to a classic Mexican waltz, and this story of tragic love is so artfully done that Lafourcade's name should now be mentioned alongside the most iconic of Mexican bolero songwriters. —Felix Contreras, NPR

Alex G ::: June Guitar ::: description_s.name: June Guitar
Alex G ::: June Guitar ::: description_s.extracted_quote: the heartwarming "June Guitar" cuts through with an almost startling clarity
Alex G ::: June Guitar ::: description_s.review: For years, Alex G has been contorting his sound into strange shapes, but the heartwarming “June Guitar” cuts through with an almost startling clarity. The track doesn’t need his usual aural tricks or wacky vocal distortion to knock listeners flat—just an accordion that wheezes like it’s carrying years of dissolution in its lungs, each labored breath widening until the song breaks wide open. Kohner

Ninajirachi ::: Fuck My Computer ::: des.name: Fuck My Computer
Ninajirachi ::: Fuck My Computer ::: des.extracted_quote: an anthem that was simultaneously extremely online and also made for the club
Ninajirachi ::: Fuck My Computer ::: des.review: Yes, the advancement of technology is scary, but what if we took a break from the existential dread and partied along to an electronic banger about wanting to fuck your computer? ヾ( ˃ᴗ˂ )◞ • *✰ Who knew it was possible to make an anthem that was simultaneously extremely online and also made for the club? "Fuck My Computer" is true Gen Z genius. — Danielle Chelosky

The Berries ::: Angelus ::: description_.name: Angelus
The Berries ::: Angelus ::: description_.extracted_quote: uses five minutes to build into a swaggy guitar rupture not unlike one of the Boss' famous runouts
The Berries ::: Angelus ::: description_.review: Bruce Springsteen is my favorite musician of all time, but I am not resistant to Bruce Springsteen soundalikes. The Berries, the moniker of Hotline TNT, Happy Diving, and Big Bite collaborator Matthew Berry (no, not that one), uses five minutes to build into a swaggy guitar rupture not unlike one of the Boss’ famous runouts on “Angelus.” The cover of The Berries has already been likened to Born to Run , and “Angelus” certainly sprawls like the similarly blasé “Backstreets.” But Berry doesn’t growl through any chorus. Instead, he injects a loping, Wild Pink-style quaver into his take on Heartland gusto. The “band” here features Kora Puckett of Narrow Head, Ethel Cain drummer Bryan De Leon, Corey Madden of Color Green, and poet Julia Lans Nowak, but it’s Berry and his rambling guitar front and center. — Matt Mitchell

Rochelle Jordan ::: Ladida ::: descripti.name: Ladida
Rochelle Jordan ::: Ladida ::: descripti.extracted_quote: effortlessly commingle house music with R&B and pop ... she commands everything with subtle but unmistakable aplomb
Rochelle Jordan ::: Ladida ::: descripti.review: Rochelle Jordan never lets you see her sweat. She nimbly navigates rhythm tracks that effortlessly commingle house music with R&B and pop, and this track may be her peak to date. It chimes with the year’s dance-floor swerve toward vintage U.K. garage — the snares skip suavely, and Jordan’s syllables are cut up over the coda — and whether she’s semi-rapping the verses or infusing the chorus with grainy soul, she commands everything with subtle but unmistakable aplomb. — M.Matos

The Berries ::: Angelus ::: description_.name: Angelus
The Berries ::: Angelus ::: description_.extracted_quote: "Angelus" ends up feeling like a half-remembered Tom Petty classic
The Berries ::: Angelus ::: description_.review: Matthew Berry is a touring guitarist for Hotline TNT, but his music as the Berries forgoes fuzzed-out pop for different kinds of retro pleasures. Specifically, this year's self-titled LP rewardingly taps into the dreamy heartland rock that has proven so fertile for bands like Wild Pink and the War On Drugs. Between those huge chords, that slow, steady backbeat, Berry's drowsy vocal, and vibes that stretch the jangling twang to infinity, "Angelus" ends up feeling like a half-remembered Tom Petty classic. — Chris DeVille

Rochelle Jordan ::: Ladida ::: descripti.name: Ladida
Rochelle Jordan ::: Ladida ::: descripti.extracted_quote: A maven of the dancefloor, Jordan knows how to keep bodies in motion.
Rochelle Jordan ::: Ladida ::: descripti.review: Through the Wall , the latest album from Toronto vocalist Rochelle Jordan, opens on a high note. Following a brief introductory track, KLSH’s propulsive house beat ascends like a scuba diver nearing the surface, and Jordan comes in full force. “Met KLSH back in ’09 in around / Threw me beats and I just hit ’em out / One by one, yeah, bitch, I been around / Not just one, I birthed a good amount,” she half-raps, half-sings, ending each stanza on the downbeat of the next measure. A maven of the dancefloor, Jordan knows how to keep bodies in motion. That’s why she has us all singing la-di-da. — Grant Sharples

caroline ::: Coldplay cover ::: descript.name: Coldplay cover
caroline ::: Coldplay cover ::: descript.extracted_quote: what began as one song thrillingly fractures into two happening at once, mind-bendingly bleeding into one another
caroline ::: Coldplay cover ::: descript.review: There’s a jarring moment halfway through Caroline’s Caroline 2 where the boundaries of what a song is and what it’s supposed to do start to dissolve. The misleadingly titled “Coldplay Cover” begins with half of the London eight piece playing in a living room and then, midway through, the engineer picks up the mic and walks into the kitchen, where the other half begins to play. Footsteps creak, distant voices blur, and what began as one song thrillingly fractures into two happening at once, mind-bendingly bleeding into one another. Seip

Easykid & Dysbit ::: Shiny ::: descripti.name: Shiny
Easykid & Dysbit ::: Shiny ::: descripti.extracted_quote: the calling card of the former emo-trap star who's now leading Chile's emerging reggaeton scene
Easykid & Dysbit ::: Shiny ::: descripti.review: Easykid's "Shiny" is so much more than a popular Tiktok sound; it's the calling card of the former emo-trap star who's now leading Chile's emerging reggaeton scene. Backed by perreo-ready beats with elements of electronica, he likens finding romance to shiny hunting in Pokémon: "Always changing / Always someone else like an Eevee." The future of Chilean reggaeton is bright in Easykid's clutches. — LV

Burial ::: Comafields ::: description_qu.name: Comafields
Burial ::: Comafields ::: description_qu.extracted_quote: 'Comafields' is a particularly beautiful exercise in imagining Susumu Yokota producing trancey post-garage
Burial ::: Comafields ::: description_qu.review: One can understand William Bevan’s reticence in putting out a third album; his legacy as one of the most important musicians of the 21st century is already assured, so why even risk it? And for the rest of us who can’t get enough of his scintillating murk and ecstatic grime, there is his ever growing library of EPs and singles. ‘Comafields’ is a particularly beautiful exercise in imagining Susumu Yokota producing trancey post-garage for some imagined utopian rural festival that I, for one, would love to visit.

Graham Barham ::: OIL MONEY ::: descript.name: OIL MONEY
Graham Barham ::: OIL MONEY ::: descript.extracted_quote: a wild blast of down-South bluster
Graham Barham ::: OIL MONEY ::: descript.review: The logical apex of years of country-rap fusion is this reimagining of hip-hop’s beloved excesses through the lens of a landman who’s struck it big. It’s a wild blast of down-South bluster.

ROSAL\u00cdA & Dougie F ::: Porcelana ::.name: Porcelana
ROSAL\u00cdA & Dougie F ::: Porcelana ::.extracted_quote: the heart-skips I experience when listening to the orchestral swells, starts, and stops of "Porcelana"
ROSAL\u00cdA & Dougie F ::: Porcelana ::.review: I'm not Spanish, nor do I speak the language. I'm not Catholic nor do I know much about saints — let alone female saints. So in the most literal sense, perhaps Rosalía's fourth album Lux is lost on me. Luckily, music never has to be literal, and I imagine that the heart-skips I experience when listening to the orchestral swells, starts, and stops of "Porcelana" are at least in the ballpark of an album being a somewhat religious experience. Long as you're feeling something, right? And here, it doesn't require subtitles, Bible pages, or anything even remotely textual. Literalism would probably just dilute it. — D. Caffrey

Guitarricadelafuente ::: Port Pelegr\u00.name: Port Pelegrí
Guitarricadelafuente ::: Port Pelegr\u00.extracted_quote: the carefree, sun-dappled "Port Pelegrí" ... detonates into a dance-worthy pop gem
Guitarricadelafuente ::: Port Pelegr\u00.review: Guiturricadelafuente burst onto the scene with heartfelt folk elegies, drawing on traditions from his native Spain on his stunning 2022 album, La Cantera. But his latest, Spanish Leather , focuses instead on the present, and perhaps no song on the LP captures that feeling like the carefree, sun-dappled “Port Pelegrí.” He lays out his ethereal voice over upbeat guitars — but quickly contrasts it with pitched-down backup vocals, building the energy before the song detonates into a dance-worthy pop gem. — J.L.

Water From Your Eyes ::: Life Signs :::.name: Life Signs
Water From Your Eyes ::: Life Signs :::.extracted_quote: echoes those aimless strolls you prescribe yourself when secluding idly at home finally gets boring
Water From Your Eyes ::: Life Signs :::.review: "Life Signs," a career-defining single from punk-ish Brooklyn duo Water From Your Eyes, echoes those aimless strolls you prescribe yourself when secluding idly at home finally gets boring. Nate Amos' wandering guitar lines contrast Rachel Brown's deadpan, tongue-twister observations on the world around them and their place within it: "Tick tick, you're alive, sunlit sick sky scraped by bright-eyed short sight online for thy," they pseudo-rap, seemingly offhandedly. "It's so sad in this beautiful place/ I need you here right now in this beautiful place." "Life Signs" doesn’t necessarily find any resolution between life's innate beauty and suffering, instead coming to terms with the discordance. Some days, that's enough relief to keep on trekking. — Abby Jones

Fontaines D.C. ::: It's Amazing To Be Yo.name: It's Amazing To Be Young
Fontaines D.C. ::: It's Amazing To Be Yo.extracted_quote: Fontaines D.C. can never fully extract the snarl from their unabashedly Irish post-punk
Fontaines D.C. ::: It's Amazing To Be Yo.review: The latest in an endless lineage of "I-had-a-kid-and-will-now-write-a-happy-song" subgenre, "It's Amazing to Be Young" might be as cheesy as its sungazing PR angle, if not for its sincerity and the fact that Fontaines D.C. can never fully extract the snarl from their unabashedly Irish post-punk (thank God). — D. Caffrey

Water From Your Eyes ::: Life Signs :::.name: Life Signs
Water From Your Eyes ::: Life Signs :::.extracted_quote: holy shit can they lay down some exhilarating guitar parts
Water From Your Eyes ::: Life Signs :::.review: For all of the wonderful genre-bending and off-kilter grooves that define Water from Your Eyes, holy shit can they lay down some exhilarating guitar parts. — J. Krueger

Fontaines D.C. ::: It's Amazing To Be Yo.name: It's Amazing To Be Young
Fontaines D.C. ::: It's Amazing To Be Yo.extracted_quote: sighs with a pure, innocent euphoria and optimism
Fontaines D.C. ::: It's Amazing To Be Yo.review: Just when you thought they’d left it all on the field with 2024’s career-high ‘Romance’ , Dublin’s finest went the extra mile with this deluxe-edition bonus track. Inspired by guitarist Carlos O’Connell’s newborn child, ‘It’s Amazing To Be Young’ sighs with a pure, innocent euphoria and optimism. Enjoy these days while you can. AT

Freddie Gibbs, The Alchemist, & Anderson.name: Ensalada (feat. Anderson .Paak)
Freddie Gibbs, The Alchemist, & Anderson.extracted_quote: the beat incorporating multiple rhythms ... pushes Gibbs into his best performance on the record
Freddie Gibbs, The Alchemist, & Anderson.review:
By this point, Freddie Gibbs and The Alchemist have the formula down. Alfredo 2 is at i ts best when the duo add variables and curveballs to the tried and true blend of throwback, sample-heavy beats and blustery shit talk.

“Ensalada” is one such sterling example, the beat incorporating multiple rhythms, a choice by Al that pushes Gibbs into his best performance on the record. Toss in an excellent chorus from Anderson .Paak and you’ve got one of the best rap songs of the year. —Will Schube

Freddie Gibbs, The Alchemist, & Anderson.name: Ensalada (feat. Anderson .Paak)
Freddie Gibbs, The Alchemist, & Anderson.extracted_quote: milks a sublime Alchemist loop to survey the ills of hustling
Freddie Gibbs, The Alchemist, & Anderson.review: Only Pusha T has rapped more prolifically about cocaine than Freddie Gibbs over the last 15 years, but the former can't match his junior for pathos. Case in point: "Ensalada," which milks a sublime Alchemist loop to survey the ills of hustling, his rapidfire cadences seeming to betray an underlying skittishness or remorse. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Marie Davidson ::: Demolition ::: descri.name: Demolition
Marie Davidson ::: Demolition ::: descri.extracted_quote: [Davidson] is laying out commands and she is taking pleasure in your pain. It is sexy as hell
Marie Davidson ::: Demolition ::: descri.review: On “Demolition,” Marie Davidson is a dominatrix. But the way she wants to humiliate her subjects, her pathetic listeners, disciples, and zombified club kids nodding their heads to the beat, is to seize their data and also the means of production. “I don’t want your cash now,” she sings, “I want your data!” “Demolition” is Davidson at her most devious, her most diabolically funny. She sing-speaks all of this over darkwave synths and dentist-drill drum machines. She’s laying out commands and she is taking pleasure in your pain. It is sexy as hell, and in a world of voluntary surveillance by way of our myriad electronic devices, all too real. –Sophie Kemp

Geese ::: Trinidad ::: description_nyt_c.name: Trinidad
Geese ::: Trinidad ::: description_nyt_c.extracted_quote: a blistering, erratic yet curiously grounded jam that constantly threatens to implode but is too cool to actually do so
Geese ::: Trinidad ::: description_nyt_c.review: Talking Heads + Grateful Dead + James Chance + Neil Young = a blistering, erratic yet curiously grounded jam that constantly threatens to implode but is too cool to actually do so.

Facta ::: Jets ::: description_crack :::.name: Jets
Facta ::: Jets ::: description_crack :::.extracted_quote: a heater with the space and heft to move a White Isle superclub, while retaining the detail and drive to shake basement raves
Facta ::: Jets ::: description_crack :::.review: When Facta – who you’ll probably know as K-Lone’s Wisdom Teeth co-pilot – first arrived on our dance music scene over a decade ago, he turned heads with a leftfield yet clubby take on post-dubstep and the bass music emerging out of Bristol. Naturally, his style has evolved, pulling in everything from house, UKG and minimal to dembow and drum ’n’ bass, and his 2025 album GULP hones this long-forged palette into a sharp, distinct sound. Standout track Jets is the most dancefloor-ready of the seven, opening with a fuzzy pad that melts into a subtle, shuffling groove, pitching up somewhere between 2-step and turn-of-the-millennium tech house. Its bassline growls and synth line twinkles, creating a heater with the space and heft to move a White Isle superclub, while retaining the detail and drive to shake basement raves. -- Isaac Muk

Playboi Carti ::: OPM BABI ::: descripti.name: OPM BABI
Playboi Carti ::: OPM BABI ::: descripti.extracted_quote: the logical conclusion of bowling ball 808s and the baby voice, of bass-boosting and bag-chasing, of goth chaos agents shaping modern rap
Playboi Carti ::: OPM BABI ::: descripti.review: You can plunge your head in ice water or you can listen to “OPM BABI.” This is the logical conclusion of bowling ball 808s and the baby voice, of bass-boosting and bag-chasing, of goth chaos agents shaping modern rap and soundtracking our rotten feeds, spamming gunshot sounds like they figured out the unlimited ammo glitch. This is the high-water mark of Atlanta retrofuturism, of creeping into the red and finding sacred scrolls on Datpiff. He really is the music. –Mano Sundaresan

Lorde ::: Current Affairs ::: descriptio.name: Current Affairs
Lorde ::: Current Affairs ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: flip a bawdy Dexta Daps sample into a melancholic meditation on the grotesque vulnerability of the body
Lorde ::: Current Affairs ::: descriptio.review: On the soul-bearing “Current Affairs,” Lorde and producer Jim-E Stack flip a bawdy Dexta Daps sample into a melancholic meditation on the grotesque vulnerability of the body and the lines people cross when they’re lonely and overcome by desire. “My bed is on fire/Mama, I’m so scared,” Lorde sings, lust having mutated into something shameful and aching. The song’s cavernous electronics, which slowly tease each masterful deployment of the Daps sample, are a seductive whirlpool drawing us right to the edge. Mason

YHWH Nailgun ::: Sickle Walk ::: descrip.name: Sickle Walk
YHWH Nailgun ::: Sickle Walk ::: descrip.extracted_quote: manages to construct something bizarrely danceable from the skeleton of no-wave, creating rhythms that feel like they were excavated from the ruins of a post-apocalyptic disco
YHWH Nailgun ::: Sickle Walk ::: descrip.review: In “Sickle Walk,” Brooklyn’s YHWH Nailgun  serves up a sonic goulash that tastes like someone dropped their iPhone in a blender with a handful of vintage drum machines and David Byrne’s anxiety medication and pressed a button. The song, from their debut record 45 Pounds , manages to construct something bizarrely danceable from the skeleton of no-wave, creating rhythms that feel like they were excavated from the ruins of a post-apocalyptic disco. Frontman Zack Borzone delivers his lines like a sleep-deprived street prophet who just discovered his refrigerator has gained sentience, while the band conjures a backdrop that sounds like industrial machinery learning to dance. In just under four minutes, the experimental rock quartet builds a world that feels both wholly alien and unnervingly familiar—like finding your childhood teddy bear rebuilt as a cyborg. It’s gloriously unsettling, and I’m here for every twisted second of it. — Casey Epstein-Gross

Tyler, The Creator ::: Don't Tap That Gl.name: Don't Tap That Glass / Tweakin'
Tyler, The Creator ::: Don't Tap That Gl.extracted_quote: arguably the two most ecstatically danceable beats in his discography
Tyler, The Creator ::: Don't Tap That Gl.review: The centerpiece of Tyler, the Creator’s excellent new album is a two-part, three-minute banger. Part I, “Don’t Tap That Glass,” finds him stunting, dancing, and protecting his space. “Don’t tap that glass/ There’s a monster in it!” he howls, conjuring at once a private life lived publicly and the dire consequences of being disturbed. Part II is an ode to movement, whether that’s on the open road (ideally in his “Detroit Red” Ferrari) or sexually (I fucked her, her friend, her friend, her n***a, and his bitch, I know I’m wrong“). It’s tied together by minor-key keyboards and arguably the two most ecstatically danceable beats in his discography. — W. Graves

YHWH Nailgun ::: Sickle Walk ::: descrip.name: Sickle Walk
YHWH Nailgun ::: Sickle Walk ::: descrip.extracted_quote: a flash of punishing drums and aching guitars ... delivers his hyperminimalist poetry in pained, haunting moans
YHWH Nailgun ::: Sickle Walk ::: descrip.review: New York’s most visceral rockers create music that’s somehow pulverising yet transcendental . ‘Sickle Walk’ is a flash of punishing drums and aching guitars, while frontman Zack Borzone delivers his hyperminimalist poetry in pained, haunting moans: “ Still shiver when I’m unclean ”. Bone-chilling and boundary-pushing. AR

Sam Fender & Olivia Dean ::: Rein Me In.name: Rein Me In (with Olivia Dean)
Sam Fender & Olivia Dean ::: Rein Me In.extracted_quote: Dean's rich vocals floated over the Geordie's trademark guitar riffs like honey on gravel
Sam Fender & Olivia Dean ::: Rein Me In.review: As soon as clips of Sam Fender bringing out Olivia Dean at the London Stadium for a then-unreleased collaboration hit social media, I was hooked. Dean’s rich vocals floated over the Geordie’s trademark guitar riffs like honey on gravel, sending tingles down my spine. As the views and likes for “Rein Me In” racked up on Instagram, I was, presumably, among the throngs of fans checking Spotify daily for its official release. I don’t think it’s a stretch to credit the feature as the spark that lit the fuse for Dean’s explosion in popularity this summer , cemented by her omnipresent bop, “Man I Need”. That track, too, could easily have been my song of the year, but for the perfect harmony of rock and soul, “Rein Me In” has remained my most-played. Tom Murray

Jawnino ::: LivFlare (broadway market) :.name: LivFlare (broadway market)
Jawnino ::: LivFlare (broadway market) :.extracted_quote: bottles the mood of the city in winter, delivering an atmospheric vignette as elusive as it is vivid
Jawnino ::: LivFlare (broadway market) :.review: The myth of Jawnino is beginning to eclipse the man himself, and LivFlare (Broadway Market) only thickens the fog around him. Here, the London rapper bottles the mood of the city in winter, delivering an atmospheric vignette as elusive as it is vivid. LivFlare… plays like a love letter to late-night London: chipmunked vocals drifting over a buzzing, minimal bassline. Jawnino’s writing remains his sharpest tool, packing entire stories into a handful of bars, while producers Tony Seltzer and Laron give the track its cold, crystalline edge. The visuals, courtesy of Frost County, mirror that rawness, capturing the buzz of Broadway Market and the city at large. Jawnino’s pull is magnetic – he sketches worlds in half-breaths, letting the atmosphere do the heavy lifting. The whispers that emerged around his name last year are only going to get louder now. -- Sik Frydas

Mystery Tiime, The Maghreban, & Emanativ.name: Everything
Mystery Tiime, The Maghreban, & Emanativ.extracted_quote: Rostom's influences of jazz and new wave fuse together for a refreshing, danceable ride
Mystery Tiime, The Maghreban, & Emanativ.review: Ayman Rostom (aka The Maghreban) takes the plunge and sings for the first time under his new alias, Mystery Tiime. Featuring percussion from Emanative and saxophone by Kotoa, "Everything" is a sentimental take on death and escape. Rostom's influences of jazz and new wave fuse together for a refreshing, danceable ride. — Barry Leonhard , WYSO

Brandi Carlile ::: Returning To Myself :.name: Returning To Myself
Brandi Carlile ::: Returning To Myself :.extracted_quote: a resplendent anthem of strength for those grappling with finding their sense of self amid life's external noise and chaos
Brandi Carlile ::: Returning To Myself :.review: The guitar intro of “Returning to Myself,” the first single from Brandi Carlile’s latest studio album of the same name, has an ethereal feel; it’s not immediately clear where the tune is headed. But when the melody starts in, a steady calm emerges, enhanced by Carlile’s crooning. The lyrics pose mighty questions without a singular answer, and have been dancing around my head since mid-October: “Why is it heroic to untether? / How is alone some holy grail?” and “Is it evolving turning inward? / Oh, what an easy way to be / Only kneeling at the altar of / The great and mighty me.” It’s a resplendent anthem of strength for those grappling with finding their sense of self amid life’s external noise and chaos. Carlile reminds us that looking inward and evolving as individuals without relying on others is both strong and necessary. It’s no wonder I find myself listening on repeat. Caitlin Hornik

Moses Sumney, Syd, & Meshell Ndegeocello.name: Hey Girl(s)
Moses Sumney, Syd, & Meshell Ndegeocello.extracted_quote: a flirty, blushworthy wink that leans into the delicious tension between passion, restraint and consent
Moses Sumney, Syd, & Meshell Ndegeocello.review: With desire dripping from every sultry syllable, this unexpected trio conjures a scene where trust and patience promise pleasure fulfilled. It's a flirty, blushworthy wink that leans into the delicious tension between passion, restraint and consent by delicately interweaving the signature styles of these three inimitable artists. —Nikki Birch, NPR

Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.name: The Subway
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.extracted_quote: a dreamy '90s pop-rock feel, reminiscent of The Cranberries
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of August 2025 : “Finally, ‘The Subway’ is out in the world! Chappell Roan dropped her long-awaited single, about struggling to move on from an ex, after about a year of teasing it and even performing it on festival stages. It’s got a dreamy ’90s pop-rock feel, reminiscent of The Cranberries. Roan’s got a way of making the vintage sound modern and the heartbreaking sound romantic.” —EG

Bad Bunny ::: LO QUE LE PAS\u00d3 A HAWA.name: LO QUE LE PASÓ A HAWAii
Bad Bunny ::: LO QUE LE PAS\u00d3 A HAWA.extracted_quote: a rallying cry for Puerto Rico's cultural autonomy in an era of neocolonialization
Bad Bunny ::: LO QUE LE PAS\u00d3 A HAWA.review: Selecting just one song from Bad Bunny’s pivotal 2025 album “Debí Tirar Más Fotos” is a fool’s errand. Most would likely select one of the ubiquitous, up-tempo hits: “DtMF,” “Baile Inolvidable,” “NuevaYol.” And they’d be just as right. But at its heart, this album is both Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio’s love letter to Puerto Rico and his fierce protection of it. Nowhere is that made more apparent than on “Lo que le pasó a Hawaii” (“What happened to Hawaii”), a rallying cry for Puerto Rico’s cultural autonomy in an era of neocolonialization. It begins with a somber Bad Bunny lamenting over the scrape of a güiro — a folkloric percussive instrument made of a hollow gourd. It sounds like inherited history and modernity all in one, a kind of political, timeless tune from an artist so accustomed to being the sound of the moment.

Sharp Pins ::: I Can\u2019t Stop ::: des.name: I Can’t Stop
Sharp Pins ::: I Can\u2019t Stop ::: des.extracted_quote: Heart-warmingly retro and refreshingly modern; expertly-crafted, yet never too fussy
Sharp Pins ::: I Can\u2019t Stop ::: des.review: Sharp Pins is the jangly GBV-esque project of Chicago's Kai Slater (also of post-punk project Lifeguard). This song comes from the expanded version of the glum-yet-glimmering Radio DDR , where Slater's "home-punk" songs roll just right. Heart-warmingly retro and refreshingly modern; expertly-crafted, yet never too fussy. — Erin Wolf , Radio Milwaukee

Greazy Alice ::: Just Another One ::: de.name: Just Another One
Greazy Alice ::: Just Another One ::: de.extracted_quote: the way the two singers' voices wind and curl around each other ... elevates this to something close to holy
Greazy Alice ::: Just Another One ::: de.review: “Just Another One” was the first tune I heard by the New Orleans country blues band Greazy Alice, and I was immediately snared by frontman Alex Pianovich’s rambling, lackadaisical storytelling style. Then, about 30 seconds in, the sweet, melancholy voice of singer Jo Morris came in, echoing Pianovich’s line about not feeling much like dancing, and I realised I was in the presence of a special magic. It’s a song about a man debating whether to upend his whole life to take a shot at true love, and one that finds time to drily reflect on the cowardice of Humphrey Bogart in Casablanca when faced with a similar dilemma. The lyrics are wry and witty, calling to mind John Prine or Townes Van Zandt, but it’s the way the two singers’ voices wind and curl around each other that elevates this to something close to holy. I later learned Pianovich wrote the song about falling for Morris, and while it’s not necessary to know that in order to appreciate the couple’s fine musicianship, the backstory does add another layer of romance to proceedings. Greazy Alice are set to release their debut record in January. I’ll be first in line to hear it. Kevin EG Perry

Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.name: The Subway
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.extracted_quote: a lovely, anthemic coda ... It's melancholy but somehow at peace, and totally sublime
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.review: My fellow New Yorkers can bitch about it, but our much-maligned subway is still the beating heart of our sui generis city. It's a place where anything can happen, like, say, uncomfortably catching sight of that ex you haven't gotten over. That scenario frames "The Subway," Chappell Roan's ode to a former flame with green hair and a beauty mark by her mouth. In this urban fever dream, the Midwest Princess is still down bad — triggered by smelling her ex's perfume on someone else, "counting down the days" until the breakup pangs fade and her former lover is "just another girl on the subway." Several minutes of gorgeous duress build to the real payoff: a lovely, anthemic coda that alternates the lyric "She's got a way" with "She got away." It's melancholy but somehow at peace, and totally sublime. — John Norris

Natalie Bergman ::: Lonely Road ::: desc.name: Lonely Road
Natalie Bergman ::: Lonely Road ::: desc.extracted_quote: goes full retro in this '60s sad-girl ballad swinging with the groove of bottomless yearning
Natalie Bergman ::: Lonely Road ::: desc.review: The other half of Wild Belle, Natalie Bergman goes full retro in this '60s sad-girl ballad swinging with the groove of bottomless yearning. As the promise to never love another gets more assured, the keys, strings and stacks of vocals rise atop the bass to fulfill her words with a satisfying, ascending-into-heaven ending. — Tshego Letsoalo , KALW

Noname & Devin Morrison ::: Hundred Acre.name: Hundred Acres
Noname & Devin Morrison ::: Hundred Acre.extracted_quote: a liberatory bop for colored folk sick of compromising their get up and go
Noname & Devin Morrison ::: Hundred Acre.review: Ain't no freeing the land without breaking free of the shackles on our imagination. For Noname, touching grass, raising a blunt and "eating honey with Winnie on Hundred Acre Woods" is the ultimate escapist manifesto. Blurring the line between fantasy and friction on the first single from her forthcoming album, Cartoon Radio , she delivers a liberatory bop for colored folk sick of compromising their get up and go. We outside. —Rodney Carmichael, NPR

Carter Felker ::: Losing Hand ::: descri.name: Losing Hand
Carter Felker ::: Losing Hand ::: descri.extracted_quote: a beautifully produced ballad of the highest order with a melody to die for
Carter Felker ::: Losing Hand ::: descri.review: There’s a beautiful simplicity to my favourite song of 2025, in which Carter Felker runs through all the reasons he doesn’t deserve the love of his life. “I should bring you flowers, baby, I should bring you gold/ I should take you someplace warm when the weather gets cold,” the Canadian musician croons, his voice tinged with knowing regret and a desire to do better. If that sounds too self-loathing for your tastes, don’t fret; it’s a beautifully produced ballad of the highest order with a melody to die for and a bass line inspired by Angelo Badalamenti’s Twin Peaks theme. What’s not to love? Jacob Stolworthy

Kingfishr ::: I Cried, I Wept ::: descri.name: I Cried, I Wept
Kingfishr ::: I Cried, I Wept ::: descri.extracted_quote: one of the most moving, nuanced depictions of artistic ambition ... encapsulating the pressures musicians put on themselves in this brutal industry
Kingfishr ::: I Cried, I Wept ::: descri.review: I’m not going to lie, my most-played song this year was in fact “Sports Car” by Tate McRae. It’s a completely unabashed Pop with a capital P song: slickly produced, impossibly catchy and completely vapid. I adore it. But thinking about what I’ve loved about this year in music, one of the things that stands out is the explosion of incredible music coming out of Ireland , from the alluring outlaw rock of rising band Cardinals to the garage punk of Dublin’s Sprints; Kneecap’s bristling, politicised hip-hop to Fontaines DC’s triumphant performance at Finsbury Park in July. Blowing up with less of the media hype (although that feels imminent) are the folk-rock band Kingfishr, who charted in the top 10 in the UK in August with their debut album Halcyon. The racing song “I Cried, I Wept” is one of the most moving, nuanced depictions of artistic ambition I’ve heard in some time, encapsulating the pressures musicians put on themselves in this brutal industry. Yet it’s subtle, too – frontman Eddie Keogh’s songwriting is poetic and he’s a gripping storyteller, with his barrel-chested brogue – while banjo player Eoghan “McGoo” McGrath plays with astonishing dexterity. It’s a rousing, defiant battle cry. Roisin O’Connor

Saint Levant ::: WAZIRA / \u0648\u0632\u.name: WAZIRA / وزيرة
Saint Levant ::: WAZIRA / \u0648\u0632\u.extracted_quote: blends Palestinian rhythms and a shake of desert blues into a romantic celebration infused with the joy of returning from exile
Saint Levant ::: WAZIRA / \u0648\u0632\u.review: After 2024's explicitly political album, Diera , the Palestinian Algerian pop star Saint Levant returned to his loverboy roots this year, but with new depth and awareness. Cowritten with Palestinian percussionist Fares Anbar and Egyptian guitarist Khafage, this ode to a female "ambassador but for feelings" blends Palestinian rhythms and a shake of desert blues into a romantic celebration infused with the joy of returning from exile. —Ann Powers, NPR

Addison Rae ::: High Fashion ::: descrip.name: High Fashion
Addison Rae ::: High Fashion ::: descrip.extracted_quote: Rae whispers and coos over the breathy synth-pop rush, dreaming of chic clothes
Addison Rae ::: High Fashion ::: descrip.review: “Have you ever dreamt of being seen?” Addison Rae asks in her hit “High Fashion.” “Not by someone/More like in a magazine?” “High Fashion” was a crucial part of her amazing 2025 rise, as Rae whispers and coos over the breathy synth-pop rush, dreaming of chic clothes. Dressing up — or undressing — satisfies her more than any lover or drug could. “I’d rather feel the sun kiss on my skin/With a cigarette pressed between my tits,” she sings, sounding deliriously lost in her own glam fantasy world. — R.S.

Patrick Watson ::: Peter and the Wolf ::.name: Peter and the Wolf
Patrick Watson ::: Peter and the Wolf ::.extracted_quote: flutters about in magical ways, full of wondrous sounds and a fairytale narrative, bristling with both a creeping unease and profound beauty
Patrick Watson ::: Peter and the Wolf ::.review: After suffering a vocal chord hemorrhage at the end of 2022, Patrick Watson was told he might never speak again, let alone sing. But after a year and a half of uncertainty, his voice came back — and it sounds as beguiling as ever. "Peter and the Wolf," like much of his music, flutters about in magical ways, full of wondrous sounds and a fairytale narrative, bristling with both a creeping unease and profound beauty. —Robin Hilton, NPR

Resavoir, Matt Gold, & Mei Semones ::: D.name: Diversey Beach
Resavoir, Matt Gold, & Mei Semones ::: D.extracted_quote: mundane worries ... evoke the lovely ebb and flow of a vast freshwater sea
Resavoir, Matt Gold, & Mei Semones ::: D.review: Resavoir is Chicago producer, trumpeter and composer Will Miller. In this jazzy, Latin-tinged groove, mundane worries like "buying a couch" evoke the lovely ebb and flow of a vast freshwater sea (in this case, Lake Michigan, where you can find the song's namesake harbor). The suggested scale makes most problems feel small. — Ayana Contreras , KUVO Jazz

FKA twigs ::: Striptease ::: description.name: Striptease
FKA twigs ::: Striptease ::: description.extracted_quote: her vocals soar and drag against the track's closing twitchy breakbeats
FKA twigs ::: Striptease ::: description.review: On “Striptease,” FKA twigs—a gifted dancer—sings in an almost shockingly mush-mouthed cadence about her “arched spine…eyes [and] sternum stretched wide.” The way her vocals soar and drag against the track’s closing twitchy breakbeats recall her closest peer in R&B-electronic fusion: Kelela, someone also interested in the relationship between beats and body. Lyons-Burt

Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.name: The Subway
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.extracted_quote: A midtempo dream-pop ballad—replete with crisp, teary-eyed guitars—that finds Chappell Roan achingly pining for the one that got away
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.review: A midtempo dream-pop ballad—replete with crisp, teary-eyed guitars—that finds Chappell Roan achingly pining for the one that got away, “The Subway” was almost the hit that got away. The singer was reportedly hesitant to record a studio version for fear that she wouldn’t be able to replicate her live vocal performance, but those concerns are largely assuaged, especially during the track’s cathartic outro: “She’s got, she’s got a way/She got, she got away,” Roan declares, the lilting crack in her voice recalling that of Cocteau Twins’s Elizabeth Fraser. Cinquemani

Robert Forster ::: Tell It Back to Me ::.name: Tell It Back to Me
Robert Forster ::: Tell It Back to Me ::.extracted_quote: a jangly pop gem with taut guitar melodies and the nuance of an entire romantic life sketched in minutes
Robert Forster ::: Tell It Back to Me ::.review: Nearly five decades into his career, Forster has written dozens upon dozens of great songs in The Go-Betweens and solo, some of them even perfect. Count this among the latter — a jangly pop gem with taut guitar melodies and the nuance of an entire romantic life sketched in minutes. —Lars Gotrich, NPR

Jai'Len Josey ::: New Girl ::: descripti.name: New Girl
Jai'Len Josey ::: New Girl ::: descripti.extracted_quote: a U.K. garage beat ... with R&B flair, making for unexpected yet consistently satiating musical turns
Jai'Len Josey ::: New Girl ::: descripti.review: Clocking in at just over two minutes, Jai’Len Josey’s “New Girl” instantly thrust open the doors of a more-than-promising new era for the former Broadway star. Now signed to Def Jam after releasing a few EPs, Josey sidles up to a U.K. garage beat on “New Girl” with R&B flair, making for unexpected yet consistently satiating musical turns. Synths cartwheel behind her as she welcomes come-ons from a suitor — “Closed mouths don’t get fed ’round here,” she sings — as the track whips and careens towards a chorus where the instrumentation pulls almost entirely back, leaving her harmonies exposed. It’s one of the most unexpected yet alluring songs this year, just a taste of what Josey has to offer on her upcoming debut album, “Serial Romantic.” — Horowitz

Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.name: The Subway
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.extracted_quote: a throwback to the '90s jangle-pop of The Cranberries and The Sundays ... Roan's voice aches with heartbreak
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.review: It didn’t come attached to a new album, but the standalone single from pop’s most charismatic enigma spotlights her lyrical potency. The music is a throwback to the ‘90s jangle-pop of The Cranberries and The Sundays and Roan’s voice aches with heartbreak about a moment that might – or might not have - been meant to be. We understand the desire to move to Saskatchewan.

Jai'Len Josey ::: New Girl ::: descripti.name: New Girl
Jai'Len Josey ::: New Girl ::: descripti.extracted_quote: alchemizes that sensation into the melody
Jai'Len Josey ::: New Girl ::: descripti.review: It’s rare to find a record that doesn’t just speak toward the electric feeling of budding romance but successfully alchemizes that sensation into the melody. Newcomer Josey’s bawdy track captures the early frissons of attraction, enlisting hitmaker Tricky Stewart to produce a song that effortlessly imbues the playful bounce of U.K. Garage with the soulful melodies of '90s R&B. — Shamira Ibrahim

Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.name: The Subway
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.extracted_quote: The vocal performance of the year.
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.review: The vocal performance of the year. — Mikael Wood

Bassvictim ::: 27a Pitfield St ::: descr.name: 27a Pitfield St
Bassvictim ::: 27a Pitfield St ::: descr.extracted_quote: gentle vocals ... spiral into chaos as they reminisce
Bassvictim ::: 27a Pitfield St ::: descr.review: This brooding electroclash track from the chaotic duo’s Forever album is an ode to the Shoreditch house now slated for demolition. In the track, gentle vocals from Maria Manow and production from Ike Clateman spiral into chaos as they reminisce over lines like “ Smokey little flat, always full where we all hanged out ,” recalling the space where the duo and friends partied and produced much of their debut album. Long live “27a Pitfield St”! (™)

The Beths ::: Mother, Pray For Me ::: de.name: Mother, Pray For Me
