Nothing has been able to knock her debut album, “The Art of Loving,” out of the top 10 lately — not even December’s traditional influx of charting Christmas albums. “Man I Need” has been the big hit to date, but “Nice to Each Other” goes even further in showing why we feel confident in counting Dean as a keeper among this season’s Grammy best new artist nominees. It includes the kind of writing about an “it’s complicated” romance that is so specific in its complications, you know it can’t have been made up out of whole cloth. Specifically, Dead sings about a relationship that is on the casual side, and being fine with accepting that probably tentative status, even as the partners still seem to have some issues to work out that aren’t entirely clicking. It’s not clear whether Dean is writing with a little bit of ironic detachment or is really trying to talk herself into accepting this situation. But regardless, what is most remarkable about the tune is her vocal, which sounds just a little different from anyone else’s out there right now. It’s a voice so appealing smooth that you just want to keep riding it like a gentle wave. If she has the ability to make great singing sound so effortless, you may be thinking, why does her relationship have to be such hard work? — Willman

Cash Cobain, Bay Swag, & Rob49 ::: Tripp.name: Trippin on a Yacht (feat. Bay Swag & Rob49)
Cash Cobain, Bay Swag, & Rob49 ::: Tripp.extracted_quote: a sexy drill bounce music masterpiece ... the type of song that makes you do unruly things while drinking on a yacht
Cash Cobain, Bay Swag, & Rob49 ::: Tripp.review: The only crime this song committed was that it was released in February, and not in the middle of the summer. New York’s Cash Cobain and Bay Swag shot down to New Orleans to link with Rob49, and made a sexy drill bounce music masterpiece. It’s the type of song that makes you do unruly things while drinking on a yacht, and awakens the demon inside once that beat drops. Cash is starting to solidify himself as the King of the Summer — though we’ll have to see if yet another Slizzy Summer will be upon us in 2026. — A.D.

Amaarae ::: S.M.O. ::: description_quiet.name: S.M.O.
Amaarae ::: S.M.O. ::: description_quiet.extracted_quote: an absorbing blend of Ghanaian highlife, kpanlogo, zouk, R&B and bass music
Amaarae ::: S.M.O. ::: description_quiet.review: The lead track to Amaarae’s excellent 2025 album, Black Star , is an absorbing blend of Ghanaian highlife, kpanlogo, zouk, R&B and bass music. Boldly embracing sexual liberation (S.M.O. stands for ‘Slut Me Out’) while taking pride in the artist’s Ghanaian heritage, it’s littered with unapologetically upfront pick-up lines (“Won’t you come blow on my fire?,” “I wanna meet the God that made you.”). Perhaps the horniest that pop music sounded in 2025, ‘S.M.O.’ oozes lust and desire, with Amaarae delivering it all with just the right amount of playfulness.

Olivia Dean ::: Nice To Each Other ::: d.name: Nice To Each Other
Olivia Dean ::: Nice To Each Other ::: d.extracted_quote: has a dreamy, folksy quality perfect for driving with the sunroof open on a summer day
Olivia Dean ::: Nice To Each Other ::: d.review: Few artists have had a bigger year than Olivia Dean, who delivered the breakout hit “Man I Need," released the critically acclaimed album The Art of Loving , and scored a Grammy nomination for Best New Artist. Lead single, “Nice to Each Other,” has a dreamy, folksy quality perfect for driving with the sunroof open on a summer day. The future certainly looks bright for this rising star.

Marianne Faithfull ::: Burning Moonlight.name: Burning Moonlight
Marianne Faithfull ::: Burning Moonlight.extracted_quote: vulnerable confessions ... sung over moody guitar that's equal parts Leonard Cohen and Angelo Badalamenti
Marianne Faithfull ::: Burning Moonlight.review: “Burning Moonlight,” Marianne Faithfull’s posthumously released final bow, captures everything great about her stunning third act: vulnerable confessions like “Wherever I go, I’m alone,” sung over moody guitar that’s equal parts Leonard Cohen and Angelo Badalamenti. “Burning moonlight to survive,” she sings, “Walking in fire is my life.” It’s a moving reminder of how her passion could burn so brightly through her darkest times. — Kory Grow

Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.name: Doot Doot (6 7)
Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.extracted_quote: drill dressed up in a Jason Voorhees mask
Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.review: Surely you've heard of "6 7," even if you haven't heard "Doot Doot (6 7)." The in-joke of the year originates here, with Philly trap so inescapable it spawned an unkillable monster, with Skrilla even popping up as the special guest at a Natasha Bedingfield show. However you feel about the trend, the song is undeniable, and honestly probably intrinsic to whatever humor may be derived from the meme itself — campy and creepy, like the best classic horror cinema, it's drill dressed up in a Jason Voorhees mask. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Blood Orange ::: Somewhere in Between ::.name: Somewhere in Between
Blood Orange ::: Somewhere in Between ::.extracted_quote: paints a raw and honest portrait of grief, tracing its echoes through time and memory
Blood Orange ::: Somewhere in Between ::.review: Dev Hynes paints a raw and honest portrait of grief, tracing its echoes through time and memory. — S. Noor

Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.name: It's a Mirror
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.extracted_quote: few more intimate depictions of such seclusion: as twinged Americana opens upon a self-lacerating performance
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.review: Mike Hadreas wrote this song in a headspace of self-isolating loops, retreating into dark thoughts that only made him want to withdraw further from the world. Rinse and repeat, until the loop becomes an ouroboros. There are few more intimate depictions of such seclusion: as twinged Americana opens upon a self-lacerating performance. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.name: Doot Doot (6 7)
Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.extracted_quote: "Doot Doot" is unapologetically Skrilla: violent, with that dramatic Philly drill sound
Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.review:
When you hear “6 7,” a lot of images come to mind: Starbucks cups, botched In-N-Out orders, LaMelo Ball highlights, arms moving up and down, armies of grinning boys sheepishly staring at you. What people often forget, though, is Skrilla , the rapper who created the song that birthed the meme that drove hundreds of teachers into early retirement.

He’s one of the least likely rappers to have a song turn into a viral meme. “Doot Doot” is unapologetically Skrilla: violent, with that dramatic Philly drill sound and lyrics treating both the addicted and those serving the addicted in the same unflinching manner. — Dimas Sanfiorenzo

Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.name: It's a Mirror
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.extracted_quote: transform that heavy pain into something luminous and vital
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.review: Perfume Genius' Michael Hadreas knew what he was doing when he called this song "It's a Mirror." For himself, the track reflects how the cyclical patterns of intrusive thoughts and isolation can become their own self-sustaining ecosystem. For the listener, drowning in the algorithmic tide of bad news and compulsive scrolling, it resonates as a shared reality. What Hadreas is able to continue to do so remarkably is transform that heavy pain into something luminous and vital. Push-pull arrangements echo the very spiral being sung about, while also serving as a reminder that downward trajectories don't have to be never-ending. Though Hadreas' voice may be aching in that distinctly haunted vibrato of his, the energy of that chorus – anxious though it is – suggests he will find the strength to open the door once more. – B. Kaye

Esau Ortiz ::: Triple Lavada ::: descrip.name: Triple Lavada
Esau Ortiz ::: Triple Lavada ::: descrip.extracted_quote: scored a viral smash that followed precious few of the trends powering most current Latin pop hits, but which was such an undeniable party-starter
Esau Ortiz ::: Triple Lavada ::: descrip.review: With a swaggering slow-disco bass line and one of the year’s most brain-sticking sing-song melodies, Esau Ortiz pulled off quite the feat by landing his “Triple Lavada” — scoring a viral smash that followed precious few of the trends powering most current Latin pop hits, but which was such an undeniable party-starter that a whole bunch of hitmaker peers jumped on their own versions. Some of them also ended up on the song’s delightfully overstuffed remix , but the original is the one that leaves you wanting more, then taunts you with the “Arabian riff” while you reach to start it over. — ANDREW UNTERBERGER

Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.name: Doot Doot (6 7)
Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.extracted_quote: Skrilla managed to do the impossible: create one of the last instances of monoculture
Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.review: What other song from this year captured the current moment of content slop and utter nonsensicality better than this: Skrilla’s biblical text that birthed 2025's most annoying and inexplicably enduring meme (to the point Dictionary.com has anointed it the “word” of the year ). By now, his phrase has lived so many iterations and traveled so far beyond that we wanted to honorably mention the original here, another cultural artifact derived from rap that has irreparably changed the lives and brain chemistry of teens, teachers, frat bros, and clueless Boomers everywhere; Skrilla managed to do the impossible: create one of the last instances of monoculture besides Taylor Swift. — SW

Corbin ::: Come Down ::: description_ste.name: Come Down
Corbin ::: Come Down ::: description_ste.extracted_quote: a gut-wrenching glimpse at the SoundCloud oddball in adulthood
Corbin ::: Come Down ::: description_ste.review: Emerging at the dawn of the sad boy era, Corbin's music has always been dismal. On Crisis Kid, the reclusive artist — formerly known as Spooky Black — ponders sobriety, paranoia, and belief atop coldwave instrumentals. "Come Down" is beleaguered. "I admit that it's tiring, I'm running out of hope/ And my noose is tightening, the devil holds the rope," he deadpans over a frosty guitar riff. It is a gut-wrenching glimpse at the SoundCloud oddball in adulthood. — Ted Davis

Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.name: It's a Mirror
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.extracted_quote: embraces the grain of guitars on this sumptuous, ever-escalating single ... confronting a swirling maelstrom of fears with a self-assured swagger
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.review: Mike Hadreas embraces the grain of guitars on this sumptuous, ever-escalating single from his latest album as Perfume Genius, “Glory,” confronting a swirling maelstrom of fears with a self-assured swagger.

ROLE MODEL ::: Sally, When The Wine Runs.name: Sally, When The Wine Runs Out
ROLE MODEL ::: Sally, When The Wine Runs.extracted_quote: one of the year's most irresistible singles
ROLE MODEL ::: Sally, When The Wine Runs.review: This fun singalong was one of the year’s most irresistible singles. Role Model co-wrote the breezy, acoustic-led single, which was a hit at a wide range of radio formats, including pop and adult alternative. The song took off when he started calling out “Where’s my Sally tonight?” during live performances and welcoming a fan onstage to dance during the song’s bridge — which became enough of a phenomenon that later “Sallys” included such celebs as Olivia Rodrigo (at Lollapalooza) and Charli xcx (on SNL ). The video , in which Role Model goofs off at a local mall, is as playful and engaging as the song. — P.G.

Ovrkast. & MAVI ::: MAVKAST! ::: descrip.name: MAVKAST!
Ovrkast. & MAVI ::: MAVKAST! ::: descrip.extracted_quote: their voices clashing and complimenting each other
Ovrkast. & MAVI ::: MAVKAST! ::: descrip.review: For anyone wondering where all the great rap duos went, Ovrkast. and MAVI have entered the chat. The two indie rap stalwarts have torn up before, but not like on “MAVKAST!,” on which Kast is relishing conversations about success with family and MAVI is accepting he’ll never receive full credit for being a North Carolina trailblazer. Seeing them dap each other up in the video, their voices clashing and complimenting each other, only makes the kinship sweeter. — Dylan Green

ROLE MODEL ::: Sally, When The Wine Runs.name: Sally, When The Wine Runs Out
ROLE MODEL ::: Sally, When The Wine Runs.extracted_quote: an indie pop hit with country twang
ROLE MODEL ::: Sally, When The Wine Runs.review: Role Model brings us along for a wild ride on “Sally, When the Wine Runs Out,” an indie pop hit with country twang. The singer-songwriter settles in at a dive bar and narrates his run-in with the main character in his real-life rom-com. Sally, he tells us, is a born-again wild child, something of a diva, and definitely not a lightweight. Role Model, meanwhile, is falling headfirst and stumbling toward heartbreak on an epic bridge. “Ankles hit the two-step,” he sings. “Sally makes my head hurt.” — L.P.

Mavis Staples ::: Sad and Beautiful Worl.name: Sad and Beautiful World
Mavis Staples ::: Sad and Beautiful Worl.extracted_quote: her voice transforms the original's existential ennui into awed resilience, confronting the contradictions of modern living with a glint of hope
Mavis Staples ::: Sad and Beautiful Worl.review: In Mavis Staples’ inimitable voice—still synonymous with freedom struggles, heaven on Earth, and the promise of American music—a six-word refrain clarifies the human condition. “It’s a sad and beautiful world,” she sings, grounding a phrase Mark Linkous borrowed from Jim Jarmusch in 1996. Staples’ Sparklehorse cover, produced by Brad Cook, quakes gently. Joined on guitar and backing vocals by MJ Lenderman, her voice transforms the original’s existential ennui into awed resilience, confronting the contradictions of modern living with a glint of hope. A country in freefall cannot be said to have a national mood, but one frequency of it is contained in this resonant, elemental song. –Jenn Pelly

Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.name: It's a Mirror
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.extracted_quote: picks at the seam where world-historical turmoil starts to inflame private neuroses
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.review: How do you chart the line between your own brain and the rest of the universe? With “It’s a Mirror,” Mike Hadreas picks at the seam where world-historical turmoil (like a global pandemic) starts to inflame private neuroses. The song sprawls at a magnificent scale, all crashing drums, rolling guitars, and weighted silences, while Hadreas’ voice burrows into some of the softest questions you can ask yourself: Am I haunting myself like always, bound up in depressive states and intrusive thoughts, or has the state of things actually caught up to the terror I feel all the time? Maybe there is no clear seam; maybe we’re ultimately conduits in a vast web of experience, where hurt and triumph flow through us on their way to someone else. In other words: Even our most cloistered feelings still connect us to the world outside. –Sasha Geffen

Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.name: Sex Life
Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.extracted_quote: erotica by numbers never sounded so good
Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.review: “Sex Life,” the standout song from anonymous London collective Tracey’s debut EP, is a sex jam fashioned from machine-tooled parts. Before an energizing guest verse from grime pioneer Riko Dan, a robot-like voice speaks precisely over a humming dubstep beat, punctuating its bassy ebbs and flows with a mission statement cut and spliced into the track: “All I wanna do is fuck.” The sentiment is so straightforward it turns obscure, cloaking unvarnished lust in enough layers of abstraction to render it procedural noise; erotica by numbers never sounded so good. –Maxie Younger

Wednesday ::: Townies ::: description_co.name: Townies
Wednesday ::: Townies ::: description_co.extracted_quote: the ultimate Wednesday song ... offers up one of the best examples of their countrygaze stylings
Wednesday ::: Townies ::: description_co.review: "Townies" may very well be the ultimate Wednesday song. It's tuneful, well-structured, and, between the twangy verses and distorted choruses, offers up one of the best examples of their countrygaze stylings. Perhaps even more true to Wednesday's spirit, however, is the emotional core of frontwoman Karly Hartzman's universal-by-way-of-specificity songwriting. You might not have experienced the exact situations Hartzman sings her way through on the tune, but you know the feeling of walking around your old hometown, or the complicated emotions that arise when someone who wronged you die,s or the recontextualization of teenage memories. You bleed alongside Hartzman and Wednesday with each listen. — J. Krueger

Saja Boys, Andrew Choi, Neckwav, Danny C.artist: Saja Boys, Andrew Choi, Neckwav, Danny Chung, KEVIN WOO, samUIL Lee, & KPop Demon Hunters Cast
Saja Boys, Andrew Choi, Neckwav, Danny C.name: Your Idol
Saja Boys, Andrew Choi, Neckwav, Danny C.extracted_quote: the team behind "Your Idol" ... absolutely nails both assignments
Saja Boys, Andrew Choi, Neckwav, Danny C.review: “Villain songs” are a difficult medium to perfect, made even harder when songwriters are also trying to make a hit record. Yet the team behind “Your Idol,” the Saja Boys’ eerie enchantment at the climax of KPop Demon Hunters , absolutely nails both assignments. The composition incorporates the infamous “Dies Irae” and plays every twist on the word “idol” (a celebrity? An object of devotion? A god ? Yes, yes and yes), while the performers keep the song firmly in irresistible pop territory — making a compelling case for why it could, in fact, be the song to hypnotize the world. — STEPHEN DAW

Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.name: Sex Life
Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.extracted_quote: skull-rattling subs and celestial synths are what hi-res audio was made for
Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.review: We've chosen the slightly less profane version of this carnal mantra for all you pearl-clutchers out there. While the salacious lyrics elevate "Sex Life" from tune to chuuuune! , the anonymous electronic duo from London earned a spot on this list thanks to their production skills. These skull-rattling subs and celestial synths are what hi-res audio was made for. —Otis Hart, NPR

Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.name: luther (with sza)
Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.extracted_quote: He and SZA team up like a modern-day Marvin and Tammi on this slow-burn duet, trading sweet nothings in harmony over a butter-soft Luther Vandross sample.
Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.review: Last year, Kendrick Lamar reminded us all how much fun it can be when he lets the hate flow through him; his biggest hit in 2025, though, was all about the love. He and SZA team up like a modern-day Marvin and Tammi on this slow-burn duet, trading sweet nothings in harmony over a butter-soft Luther Vandross sample. Night after night on the Grand National Tour, “Luther” was the showstopper that had whole stadiums full of fans in their feelings. — S.V.L.

Blood Orange, Eva Tolkin, & Liam Benzvi.artist: Blood Orange, Eva Tolkin, & Liam Benzvi
Blood Orange, Eva Tolkin, & Liam Benzvi.name: Westerberg (feat. Eva Tolkin & Liam Benzvi)
Blood Orange, Eva Tolkin, & Liam Benzvi.extracted_quote: a dazzling pop-historical fantasy ... sounding like Scritti Politti's Green Gartside getting on his keyboard after a long night listening to Pleased to Meet Me
Blood Orange, Eva Tolkin, & Liam Benzvi.review: Think you’ve heard every possible Eighties nostalgia permutation? Here Blood Orange’s Dev Hynes comes through with a dazzling pop-historical fantasy. “Westerberg” honors the beloved Replacements frontman by quoting the ‘Mats’ 1987 classic “Alex Chilton,” cleverly creating a tribute to a tribute; the song’s dreamy synth-pop lushness adds another sweet retro wrinkle, sounding like Scritti Politti’s Green Gartside getting on his keyboard after a long night listening to Pleased to Meet Me. — J.D.

Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.name: luther (with sza)
Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.extracted_quote: a masterclass in restoring hope for lovestruck dreamers clinging to connection
Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.review: A reimagination of Luther Vandross and Cheryl Lynn’s 1982 rendition of “If This World Were Mine,” “Luther” is an amorous tale co-starring Kendrick Lamar and SZA. Anchored by the velvety sample and SZA’s warm, whispery touch, Lamar’s usual bloodthirsty intentions fade into the background. With affirmations like “I just wanna see you win” and “I’d take the pain away” serving as Lamar’s compass, “Luther” is a masterclass in restoring hope for lovestruck dreamers clinging to connection in this new dark world. For the superstar duo, the single was a slam dunk, topping the Billboard Hot 100 for 13 weeks after they brought it to halftime at Super Bowl LIX, and earning Grammy nominations for song and record of the year. — C.L.

Lifeguard ::: It Will Get Worse ::: desc.name: It Will Get Worse
Lifeguard ::: It Will Get Worse ::: desc.extracted_quote: The song sounds like the Cleaners From Venus covering Pavement, as metallic, thrashing guitars vibrate through lo-fi, distorted hooks
Lifeguard ::: It Will Get Worse ::: desc.review: There’s a new musical vanguard in Chicago: Lifeguard have been together since pre-COVID, when they were teens transforming the city’s youthful DIY scene. Their two previous EPs, Dressed in Trenches and Crowd Can Talk , quickly established them as torchbearers of a storied, multi-generational musical legacy. Inspired by Television and Dredd Foole, Ripped and Torn is renaissance post-punk with a twist of anthemic, post-Y2K bombast. “It Will Get Worse” ought to be everyone else’s wake-up moment. The song sounds like the Cleaners From Venus covering Pavement, as metallic, thrashing guitars vibrate through lo-fi, distorted hooks. And, truth be told, who wouldn’t want every song in existence to sound exactly like that? You better get hip to Lifeguard now; the moon is firmly in their sights. — Matt Mitchell

Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.name: Sex Life
Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.extracted_quote: The London duo's breakout track is propulsive and confrontational ... leaving dancefloors gasping for air
Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.review: From the moment the spliced-up vocal rushes in on Tracey ’s Sex Life, there is nowhere to hide. The London duo’s breakout track is propulsive and confrontational, sprinting through its two-and-a-half-minute runtime at full speed, leaving dancefloors gasping for air. The brutally frank opening refrain, “ All I wanna do is fuck, ” is immediately swallowed by glitchy dubstep with a deep, wobbling bassline, an urgent, repetitive siren heightening the track’s sense of uneasy tension, while Jersey club-infused textures add subtle contrast. Songs about sex are nothing new, but on Sex Life , there is no sexual healing in sight. Rather than soft sensuality or brazen self-assurance, the atmosphere is jarring and dissociative – until, that is, grime MC Riko Dan bursts in with his raw bravado and rapid-fire flow, injecting the cold main verse with carnal lust. Compulsion or desire? As always, it’s complex. -- Sophie Lou Wilson

Blondshell ::: T&A ::: description_rs ::.name: T&A
Blondshell ::: T&A ::: description_rs ::.extracted_quote: the intoxication of being wanted by someone you maybe shouldn't want
Blondshell ::: T&A ::: description_rs ::.review: Blondshell’s Sabrina Teitelbaum has one not-so-simple question on this single: “Why don’t the good ones love me?” She spends the rest of “T&A” detailing the type of bad — or maybe just wrong — one who has fallen for her. Brimming with shame and self-destruction, the track explores the intoxication of being wanted by someone you maybe shouldn’t want. Like the Nineties alt-rock heroes that imbue so much of her sound, Teitelbaum delivers the tale of this complicated love over a crunchy guitar, creating the perfect anti-heroine rock anthem in the process. — B.S.

Ayra Starr & Wizkid ::: Gimme Dat (feat..name: Gimme Dat (feat. Wizkid)
Ayra Starr & Wizkid ::: Gimme Dat (feat..extracted_quote: hits are determined by what gets the parties jumping, which the 23-year-old singer delivers on the WizKid-supported club banger "Gimme Dat."
Ayra Starr & Wizkid ::: Gimme Dat (feat..review: Rising Nigerian star Ayra Starr’s ascent has been rapid and sudden, making her arresting tunes about heartbreak and coming of age all the more compelling. In Afrobeats, hits are determined by what gets the parties jumping, which the 23-year-old singer delivers on the WizKid-supported club banger “Gimme Dat.” Riding the tropical percussion, her smoky voice sounds fit for sensual slowdown dances on sun-filled rooftops. Starr had great songs before, but “Gimme Dat” teases a future of household name status. She’s predestined. — Josh Svetz

Car\u00edn Le\u00f3n & Kacey Musgraves :.name: Lost In Translation
Car\u00edn Le\u00f3n & Kacey Musgraves :.extracted_quote: blends norteño and rancheras, creating a bilingual duet that intertwines Musgraves' soft country tones with León's Mexican roots
Car\u00edn Le\u00f3n & Kacey Musgraves :.review: Carin León and Kacey Musgraves’ “Lost in Translation” blends norteño and rancheras, creating a bilingual duet that intertwines Musgraves’ soft country tones with León’s Mexican roots, layered with strings and tubas. “Yo te quiero yo … robarte un pedacito de corazón,” León sings in Spanish. “I want you, I want to steal a piece of your heart.” A sweet, cross-cultural moment, the track feels like a gentle counterpoint to our tense political climate. — Tomas Mier

Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.name: It's a Mirror
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.extracted_quote: a shift from extravagance to a grungy groundedness befitting the song's claustrophobic lyrics
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.review: Mike Hadreas has, in recent years, displayed a penchant for the baroque, and his lush and eclectic songs have conveyed a romantic grandiosity. When “It’s a Mirror” kicks off with acoustic guitar, it’s not just a deft stylistic heel turn, but a shift from extravagance to a grungy groundedness befitting the song’s claustrophobic lyrics. “It’s a siren, muffled crying/Breaking me down soft and slow,” Hadreas sings of life outside his front door, finding both comfort and torture in existing as a recluse. Mason

Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.name: luther (with sza)
Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.extracted_quote: a true ballad for the ages in a way that only Lamar and SZA can deliver
Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.review: Kendrick Lamar and SZA can build a bridge across hip-hop and R&B in a way that recalls the magic of the turn-of-the-millennium pop, when an R&B hook rarely felt out of place on a rap song and vice versa. Yet they’ve redefined that approach regularly over the past decade with their growing discography of collaborations, making space for each other on duets in ways that rarely feel formulaic. “Luther,” their chart-topping single from late 2024’s “GNX,” pingpongs from one artist to the other as they sing of giving someone the world they deserve. It’s lush and lovely, a true ballad for the ages in a way that only Lamar and SZA can deliver. — Steven J. Horowitz

Blondshell ::: T&A ::: description_varie.name: T&A
Blondshell ::: T&A ::: description_varie.extracted_quote: the kind of song you want to scream in a crowd full of other women scorned
Blondshell ::: T&A ::: description_varie.review: Sabrina Teitelbaum’s second full-length album as Blondshell, “If You Asked for a Picture,” proves that she’s one of the best singer-songwriters in indie-rock right now. No song better exemplifies this than “T&A,” a friends-to-lovers-to-strangers anthem full of disdain for the actions of a man and self-loathing in equal measure. Amid fuzzy guitars and a driving drumline, the reason for the title is revealed — “I asked him why he had these feelings / He said your tits and ass don’t really hurt” — just ahead of an explosive chorus, with Teitelbaum asking in a controlled wail: “Letting him in / Why don’t the good ones love me?” It’s punchy and relatable, the kind of song you want to scream in a crowd full of other women scorned. — Shafer

GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_billboa.name: Tweaker
GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_billboa.extracted_quote: a scalding anthem ... with shades of prime Master P flowing through his blood
GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_billboa.review: LiAngelo Ball starred in one of hip-hop’s biggest plot twists in the early months of 2025, when he stepped into the booth and unleashed “Tweaker.” With shades of prime Master P flowing through his blood, the hooper-turned-rapper doled out a scalding anthem that had social media and the sports world in a tizzy. An ode to late-‘90s Southern rap, “Tweaker” not only reportedly earned G3LO a whopping $13 million deal with Def Jam, but also the 2025 Billboard Hip-Hop Rookie of the Year Award last September. — CARL LAMARRE

Puscifer ::: Self Evident ::: descriptio.name: Self Evident
Puscifer ::: Self Evident ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: a hypnotic track featuring captivating call-and-response vocals from Maynard James Keenan and Carina Round
Puscifer ::: Self Evident ::: descriptio.review: By far the best song ever with the word "bunghole" in its lyrics, but also a hypnotic track featuring captivating call-and-response vocals from Maynard James Keenan and Carina Round. — S. Kaufman

Kassi Valazza ::: Weight Of The Wheel ::.name: Weight Of The Wheel
Kassi Valazza ::: Weight Of The Wheel ::.extracted_quote: a gorgeous song about the cycles we can't seem to break
Kassi Valazza ::: Weight Of The Wheel ::.review: The first sound you hear on "Weight Of The Wheel" is drummer Ned Folkerth counting the band off. That's a small detail, but it's indicative of the lived-in quality of this gorgeous song about the cycles we can't seem to break. Across four unhurried minutes of pedal steel, acoustic guitar, and clarion, Sandy Denny-like vocals, Kassi Valazza recounts life in an endless in-between with a poet’s precision and a barstool companion’s candidness. — Brad Sanders

Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_r.name: father
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_r.extracted_quote: the track fills an entire universe, the kind of tight narrative structure they teach in writing programs
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_r.review: The first single from Jim Legxacy’s mixtape Black British Music samples George Smallwood’s “I Love My Father” and has a video where Legxacy ruminates on his absent dad. Clocking in at just under 90 seconds, the track fills an entire universe, the kind of tight narrative structure they teach in writing programs. “She said she grew up all alone, had no father,” he raps, conjuring the sample’s emotional frequency for the last word. “She’s independent, wanna spend my monеy on her/She said I shouldn’t bother.” — J.I.

GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_stereog.name: Tweaker
GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_stereog.extracted_quote: sliding into the kind of pocket that very few full-time rappers find
GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_stereog.review: Three days into 2025, an infamous NBA washout got ahold of a beat that sounds like something Mouse On Tha Track made for Lil Boosie in 2007, sliding into the kind of pocket that very few full-time rappers find. When actual Louisiana rap all-star Lil Wayne jumped on a remix, the track lost its magic. It always needed to be just LiAngelo Ball. How? Why? Don't worry about it. It doesn't matter. Nothing matters. — Tom Breihan

Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.name: luther (with sza)
Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.extracted_quote: Kendrick's semi-monotone delivery contrasts perfectly with SZA's sweeter tone, creating the kind of synergy that earns the track a place on the Mount Rushmore of great rap-and-R&B duets
Kendrick Lamar & SZA ::: luther (with sz.review:
Kendrick and SZA already had a long creative history—from “Babylon,” to “All the Stars,” to “30 for 30.” But on “Luther,” one of the most commercially successful rap songs of all time, the duo proves they’ve fully mastered their dynamic.

Sampling Luther Vandross and Cheryl Lynn’s rendition of “If This World Were Mine,” the track has the pair trading verses about devotion, sacrifice, and recognizing the beauty in the person you love.

Part of its appeal comes from how evenly matched they feel. Kendrick’s semi-monotone delivery contrasts perfectly with SZA’s sweeter tone, creating the kind of synergy that earns the track a place on the Mount Rushmore o f great rap-and-R&B duets . — Kia Turner

Eliana Glass ::: Good Friends Call Me E.name: Good Friends Call Me E
Eliana Glass ::: Good Friends Call Me E.extracted_quote: finds comfort in the connections that last through loss, and who we become in their wake
Eliana Glass ::: Good Friends Call Me E.review: In the middle of an album haunted by the sounds of singers and composers past, Eliana Glass finds her own voice on “Good Friends Call Me E.” Dangling her silvery alto over shadow-strewn piano chords like a young Billie Holiday, she recounts her life in broad strokes: the street she grew up on, the boy she knew who “grew up a bad man.” Time passes, friends and lovers are lost. Those still close enough to know her well need to call her by just one letter. “Good Friends Call Me E” finds comfort in the connections that last through loss, and who we become in their wake. –Sam Goldner

GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_nyt_car.name: Tweaker
GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_nyt_car.extracted_quote: turns a drudging appearance on a livestream into evanescent hip-hop gold
GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_nyt_car.review: A hilarious curio of the current online moment: An N.B.A. washout with family name recognition turns a drudging appearance on a livestream into evanescent hip-hop gold. Nothing meaningful has followed, nor does it have to.

Alison Brown, Steve Martin, Jackson Brow.artist: Alison Brown, Steve Martin, Jackson Browne, & Jeff Hanna
Alison Brown, Steve Martin, Jackson Brow.name: Dear Time
Alison Brown, Steve Martin, Jackson Brow.extracted_quote: a bluegrass reverie on aging ... beautifully evokes musical history
Alison Brown, Steve Martin, Jackson Brow.review: A bluegrass reverie on aging, “Dear Time,” from Alison Brown and Steve Martin’s Safe, Sensible and Sane album beautifully evokes musical history. Jackson Browne’s lead vocals are complimented by harmonies from Jeff Hanna, recalling when the two co-founded the Nitty Gritty Dirty Band in 1966. A video for the song finds Browne and Martin onstage at the Troubadour club in West Hollywood, where both began their careers. “Dear Time,” sings Browne, “thank you for the extra heartbeats/ I’m not so sure I earned them.” The song took on new poignancy last month when Browne announced the death of his eldest son, actor Ethan Browe, at age 52. — THOM DUFFY

Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_p.name: father
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_p.extracted_quote: microscopically packed with feeling ... all the right ingredients for a surprise, nostalgia-powered breakout hit
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_p.review: When Jim Legxacy splashed onto London’s hip-hop scene, he brought with him a tornado of inspirations. Midwest emo, drill, UK garage, afrobeat—all of it was fair turf for his aching, fleetingly short tracks. At under two minutes, “Father” is microscopically packed with feeling. Wrapped up in chipmunk samples, jerk drums, and DJ tags, it has all the right ingredients for a surprise, nostalgia-powered breakout hit. But there’s more than just aughts-colored glasses happening here, as Legxacy ponders that absent, titular figure, and his flexes start feeling like a mask for a deeper pain. He may be celebrating how far he’s come, but his toast to success comes with a reminder of the things it still can’t buy. –Sam Goldner

Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_n.name: father
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_n.extracted_quote: He flips longing into electricity, memory into motion ... [showing] exactly why the UK underground rallies around him
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_n.review: Over pitched-up soul and jerky 808s, Jim Legxacy confronts the bruises of growing up without a dad. He flips longing into electricity, memory into motion, unravelling absence with a poet’s honesty and a producer’s chaotic spark. It’s grief made kinetic – a raw, riotous track that shows exactly why the UK underground rallies around him. KSW

GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_complex.name: Tweaker
GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_complex.extracted_quote: a single so good it earned him a record deal with Def Jam
GELO ::: Tweaker ::: description_complex.review:
There’s still a chance LiAngelo ends up being the most successful Ball brother , despite not being able to hoop like Lonzo—who has limitless talent but can’t stay on the court—or LaMelo, who also has limitless talent… but can be a knucklehead.

Gelo was quick to notice that he wasn’t cut out for a career in basketball, but landed on top regardless. The momentum kicked off in early 2025 with “ Tweaker ,” a single so good it earned him a record deal with Def Jam. Its effortlessly catchy hook became a hit among rap fans everywhere, and scored devotees both in the rap world and the NBA . — Will Schube

Lord Sko & Curren$y ::: Understand ::: d.name: Understand
Lord Sko & Curren$y ::: Understand ::: d.extracted_quote: outrageously chill pilot talk ... over languid, jazzy keys
Lord Sko & Curren$y ::: Understand ::: d.review: Charismatically blunted uptown-Manhattan rhymer Lord Sko links with one of his clearest stylistic inspirations for three minutes of outrageously chill pilot talk. The two heads float at sky-high altitudes over languid, jazzy keys, with Curren$y dispensing laconic wisdom (“Scan the parking lot, I got the oldest or the newest car out”) and Sko playing the young dreamer: “How’s it feel to be a millionaire? Don’t even know/Couple thousand-dollar sweaters smell like reefer smoke.” — Simon Vozick-Levinson

Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_c.name: father
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_c.extracted_quote: made real strides in the States, taking a deeply introspective turn as he raps and sings about his experience with an absent parent
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_c.review: Jim Legxacy has been moving around in the UK underground for a while. But with “father,” he made real strides in the States, taking a deeply introspective turn as he raps and sings about his experience with an absent parent. (In an interview with Kids Take Over , he mentioned that the song represented him “rewriting” his history.) Built around a sample of the 1980 song “I Love My Father” by George F. Smallwood & Marshmellow Band , Jim writes his lines so that “father” lands at the end of each one as he tells his story.— Antonio Johri

PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.name: Stateside + Zara Larsson
PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.extracted_quote: "Stateside" effortlessly conjures DJs and dance floors, and it reaches cruising altitude with both its percolating beats and its obsessive-crush double entendres
PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.review: From her first singles and viral hits up through this year’s Fancy That mixtape, no one conjures what we can now call classic EDM like this British popper. With its nod to Estelle’s “American Boy,” itself a gem from that earlier time, “Stateside” effortlessly conjures DJs and dance floors, and it reaches cruising altitude with both its percolating beats and its obsessive-crush double entendres (“I’m going intercontinental for you”). Push-button pop that pushes all the right buttons. — David Browne

Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_s.name: father
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_s.extracted_quote: twisting a sample of George Smallwood's "I Love My Father" to bridge the gap between his fatherlessness and that of a girl
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_s.review: Jim Legxacy’s unexpectedly moving “Father”—which doesn’t reach two minutes and would be considered midtempo, if not outright brisk, by past standards—is what passes for ruminative and introspective these days. Good thing Legxacy, who blends genres with ease and has a sneaky ear for melody, is at the helm, twisting a sample of George Smallwood’s “I Love My Father” to bridge the gap between his fatherlessness and that of a girl. Maybe the only thing patriarchy is good for is taking care of someone else. Lyons-Burt

Loe Shimmy & YTB Fatt ::: Two Faced :::.name: Two Faced
Loe Shimmy & YTB Fatt ::: Two Faced :::.extracted_quote: rambles deliriously ... careening from bulletproof Bentleys to mafia vignettes ... the song transforms from moody slow jam into something brawnier
Loe Shimmy & YTB Fatt ::: Two Faced :::.review: Loe Shimmy rambles deliriously for 90 seconds on “Two Faced,” careening from bulletproof Bentleys to mafia vignettes to beautiful women working on their tan at Nikki Beach. His cadence is legit mumble rap that belies his tangled lyricism within. Then, the song transforms from moody slow jam into something brawnier. “The shit I just overcame, they ain’t have no choice but make me big homie,” raps YTB Fatt in a self-fulfilling prophecy. Less than six months later, Justin Bieber popped up on his IG Story, engineering a 4 a.m. recording session. — VM

PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.name: Stateside + Zara Larsson
PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.extracted_quote: The song is the most dance floor-ready single in her catalog
PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.review: PinkPantheress began as a url pop star, but you could think of "Stateside" marking a crossing of the threshold: from #veryonline to fully out in the open. The effect is twofold: The song is the most dance floor-ready single in her catalog, the artist usually fiddling with club sounds for bedroom listening, and it's literally about flying someone out (transatlantic, no less). Nothing gets you outside quite like being down bad can. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_d.name: father
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_d.extracted_quote: "father" manages to manifest all of these simultaneously ... lyrical allusions to alt-pop trailblazer Mitski ... jerk percussion patterns central to the UK underground today
Jim Legxacy ::: father ::: description_d.review: It’s no secret that Jim Legxacy’s music comprises a diverse range of influences, and, in less than two minutes, “father” manages to manifest all of these simultaneously. There’s the chipmunk vocal sample harking back to that strange time in UK music where grime artists ‘went pop’, lyrical allusions to alt-pop trailblazer Mitski, and the jerk percussion patterns central to the UK underground today. Thematically, “father” is equally impressive, chronicling both a childhood lost to absent male role models, as well as a salvation found in music. The lead single from his Black British Music mixtape ( read: album ), “father” is exactly the kind of song that makes Jim Legxacy a national treasure. (SPM)

PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.name: Stateside + Zara Larsson
PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.extracted_quote: a collage of wobbly bass lines, club drums and Y2K guitar stylings
PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.review: A cross-Atlantic fling has never seemed so fun in PinkPantheress’ ode to American boys, “Stateside.” Her unbothered facade is cracked by a new love interest abroad, as she plots in that cool British monotone: “It sounds insane, right? / I’ll take the same flight / Wait at your bedside / I’ll land right next to you.” With a producing assist from the Dare, the song is a collage of wobbly bass lines, club drums and Y2K guitar stylings. But the most fun part is a play on the Estelle and Kanye West classic, as Pink floats cheekily: “You could be my American — ha, ha — boy.” — Shanfeld

De La Soul ::: The Package ::: descripti.name: The Package
De La Soul ::: The Package ::: descripti.extracted_quote: features Posdnuos and Dave trading verses over a triumphant, horn-centric Pete Rock beat
De La Soul ::: The Package ::: descripti.review: Trugoy the Dove, who died in 2023 , only appears on a handful of songs across De La Soul’s Cabin in the Sky . But his spiritual presence is felt throughout the album, which functions as a celebration of his life. Lead single “The Package” features Posdnuos and Dave trading verses over a triumphant, horn-centric Pete Rock beat. Pos sums it up perfectly when he raps: “Those who wanna try us, play it right here/Step to us with a Goliath, got a David right here.” — Mr. Wavvy

Planta Industrial, aka the darknight, &.artist: Planta Industrial, aka the darknight, & Saso
Planta Industrial, aka the darknight, &.name: Teteo in The Bronx
Planta Industrial, aka the darknight, &.extracted_quote: blurring genre lines to make this sancocho of Dominican post-punk rap
Planta Industrial, aka the darknight, &.review: Nobody is doing it like the Industry Plants out of The Bronx right now. The duo, consisting of aka the darknight and Saso, are blurring genre lines to make this sancocho of Dominican post-punk rap, where they effortlessly slide on tracks in Spanglish and street slang in a way only made possible by growing up in NYC. I mean, who among us hasn’t cut someone off that we were dating because they showed up to a date wearing something weird, like a black nasty Yankee fitted? — ANGEL DIAZ

Olivia Dean ::: Man I Need ::: descripti.name: Man I Need
Olivia Dean ::: Man I Need ::: descripti.extracted_quote: a forceful yet inviting sense of personality, transcending pop trends to deliver a breakthrough unstuck in time
Olivia Dean ::: Man I Need ::: descripti.review: “Talk to me, talk to me” — it should be that easy, right? Olivia Dean’s smash hit exists in a world where communication with a crush is as simple as a warm three-note keyboard riff, and a deep yearning can be solved with the straightforward declaration: “Come be the man I need.” With its soft textures and immediate melodies, “Man I Need” recalls the soul-pop of the mid-’00s — a sound that’s long been out of vogue in popular music. And while Dean’s influences are clear, the British singer-songwriter imbues the song with a forceful yet inviting sense of personality, transcending pop trends to deliver a breakthrough unstuck in time. “Man I Need” is familiar but fresh, the sound of a new star stating her intentions plainly and scoring. — J. Lipshutz

Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.name: Elderberry Wine
Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.extracted_quote: a lovely country-rock tune, steeped in pedal steel and patient jangle
Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.review: North Carolina’s Wednesday got their start as a bracingly loud guitar band with Southern-fried shoegaze leanings. “Elderberry Wine,” from their insanely great Bleeds , shows how far they’ve come. It’s a lovely country-rock tune, steeped in pedal steel and patient jangle, with Karly Hartzman dropping so-good-they-hurt lines like “Say I wanna have your baby/’Cause I freckle and you tan/I find comfort that angels don’t give a damn.” Add this to the pile of reasons why Wednesday rule. — J.D.

PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.name: Stateside + Zara Larsson
PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.extracted_quote: Her version of "Stateside" has become the definitive one, easily one of the hardest-hitting across the 31-song tracklist.
PinkPantheress & Zara Larsson ::: States.review: I’ve been loving what the pop girlies are doing with their deluxes this year. In the spirit of Charli XCX, PinkPantheress released Fancy Some More? , the deluxe edition of her Fancy That mixtape, which basically triples the tracklist with remixed and featured versions of each song. When it was announced that the standout single “Stateside” would be getting renditions featuring both Zara Larsson and Kylie Minogue, the world held its breath to see whether Larsson would usurp the old pop guard. And folks, the Swedish pop princess did it. Her version of “Stateside” has become the definitive one, easily one of the hardest-hitting across the 31-song tracklist. The collab comes at the perfect time for both Larsson and PinkPantheress, as each musician steps into their pop-stardom moment—each with some of the most distinct and realized creative visions out there (Larsson’s 2000s Lisa Frank neon haze; Pink’s plaid-clad, Y2K-preppy chic), and each scoring noms in the Best Dance Pop Recording Grammy category this year. The original “Stateside” beat is blown out to headphone-shattering levels in Larsson’s care, adding an overt strutworthiness to the mix. And Larsson’s verse has become nothing short of a vocal stim for me; every line rolls off the tongue in the most satisfying way. “Boots, that’s my ego boost!” C’mon now! Serotonin at its finest. Two pop stars on their supersonic rises coming together to maximize their joint stardom… What more could you need? — Cassidy Sollazzo

Lady Gaga ::: Abracadabra ::: descriptio.name: Abracadabra
Lady Gaga ::: Abracadabra ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: Whatever witchcraft Lady Gaga put in 'Abracadabra,' it's working
Lady Gaga ::: Abracadabra ::: descriptio.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of February 2025 : “Whatever witchcraft Lady Gaga put in ‘Abracadabra,’ it’s working, and I want more. Ever since the song debuted in a (checks notes) Mastercard commercial at the Grammys, I have been under its spell, unable to go about my day without chanting a little ‘ooh nana’ and ‘morta-ooh-Gaga’ under my breath. Its hypnotic quality is so Gaga: the made-up language, the gothic folklore themes, the sublime melody. It’s the Mother Monster you know and love, but also evolved, making this the perfect lead-up to Mayhem . Everyone’s saying Gaga is so back, but in my house? She never left.” —Erica Gonzales, deputy editor, digital content

Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.name: Elderberry Wine
Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.extracted_quote: beneath all the twang and sway lay a fairly devastating account of the distance elapsed between two people
Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.review: Miles from their usual crush of hay-bale southern punk and screaming, the North Carolina band returned with this disarmingly pretty tear-catcher. But beneath all the twang and sway lay a fairly devastating account of the distance elapsed between two people – from knowing the niche things that make someone cry, like fairground rides and TV ads, to driving them to the airport in silence and simply wanting to give up on life – and their pained attempts to keep bobbing along like everything’s OK, like life still tastes the same. LS

Destroyer & Fiver ::: Bologna ::: descri.name: Bologna
Destroyer & Fiver ::: Bologna ::: descri.extracted_quote: songs whose depth can be measured by the questions they leave us asking
Destroyer & Fiver ::: Bologna ::: descri.review: Like the art-house directors who inspire him, Dan Bejar writes songs whose depth can be measured by the questions they leave us asking. What role does guest vocalist Simone Schmidt play in the cryptic espionage of “Bologna”? What are the two doing in the Italian city they keep naming? What exactly is the difference between “listening” and “listening… in ,” and why is Bejar so adamant and emphatic that the latter is happening? “There’s an outside chance you’ll never see me again,” Schmidt sings, and it’s one of the only lyrics that needs no explanation. As soon as you think you’re onto these people, they’re off to the next town. –Sam Sodomsky

Ethel Cain ::: Nettles ::: description_p.name: Nettles
Ethel Cain ::: Nettles ::: description_p.extracted_quote: a beautifully frothy country-pop/adult-contempo number that sounds like Sarah McLachlan crooning on a rickety porch
Ethel Cain ::: Nettles ::: description_p.review: If Hayden Anhedönia lived in the world that most singer-songwriters of her ability occupy, there’s no way in hell “Nettles” would last for eight minutes. It’s a beautifully frothy country-pop/adult-contempo number that sounds like Sarah McLachlan crooning on a rickety porch, her face smeared with sunblock and motor oil. It also tells a story about tragic love and death, the widescreen melodrama cut with lines of rare truth like “Time passes slower in the flicker of the hospital light.” If a bossy label were looking over her shoulder, they would have asked her to cut it in half. But fortunately, Anhedönia lives in a world all her own, one where narratives unfold at the unpredictable speed of life and gorgeous swells of pedal steel guitar last longer than they need to. –Mark Richardson

Alex Warren ::: Ordinary ::: description.name: Ordinary
Alex Warren ::: Ordinary ::: description.extracted_quote: resonated widely because of its vivid lyricism and striking vulnerability
Alex Warren ::: Ordinary ::: description.review: Alex Warren’s deeply emotional ballad (and Billboard ‘s official Song of the Summer) is an intimate tribute to the love he shares with his wife, and resonated widely because of its vivid lyricism and striking vulnerability. Through rich metaphors and heartfelt storytelling, Warren compares the overwhelming intensity of real love to moments that felt anything but ordinary. The song’s honesty, paired with its sweeping melodies, captures the bittersweet beauty of loving someone so completely that even the smallest, everyday moments with them become extraordinary. — KRISTEN WISNESKI

Ethel Cain ::: Nettles ::: description_d.name: Nettles
Ethel Cain ::: Nettles ::: description_d.extracted_quote: she delivers a heart-wrenching portrait of love in slow decline
Ethel Cain ::: Nettles ::: description_d.review: There aren’t many artists who can get away with long songs in the age of dwindling attention spans – but Ethel Cain is one of them. In June, she released “Nettles”, an eight-minute, three-second epic and the lead single from her upcoming second studio album, Willoughby Tucker, I’ll Always Love You . Inspired by Twin Peaks , the track introduces the tortured relationship between Ethel and her childhood sweetheart Willoughby. Cain has described it as “a dream of losing the one you love, asking them to reassure you that it won’t come true and to dream, instead, of all the time you’ll have together as you grow old side by side.” After a melancholic, 90-second instrumental opening, she delivers a heart-wrenching portrait of love in slow decline. Both lyrically and sonically, it’s Ethel at her best – but it’s her voice on the line “ to love me is to suffe r” that somehow manages to break my heart every time. (HD)

The Kid LAROI ::: HOW DOES IT FEEL? :::.name: HOW DOES IT FEEL?
The Kid LAROI ::: HOW DOES IT FEEL? :::.extracted_quote: There are echoes of the Neptunes in the mid-verse melody switches that keep the rhythm and groove flowing into a vocal showcase on the track's slick R&B chorus.
The Kid LAROI ::: HOW DOES IT FEEL? :::.review: Two decades ago, the Kid Laroi would have topped the Billboard Hot 100 with “How Does It Feel?” Back then, it would have been a hit from Justin Timberlake, a clear influence the younger musician wears with charm and flirtation on the smooth single. There are echoes of the Neptunes in the mid-verse melody switches that keep the rhythm and groove flowing into a vocal showcase on the track’s slick R&B chorus. The Kid Laroi has been searching for his lane for a while. He finds it on “How Does It Feel?” — Larisha Paul

Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.name: Elderberry Wine
Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.extracted_quote: a lovely, fermented rumination on a relationship gone sour, stuffed with poetic wisdom
Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.review: The best country song of the year comes courtesy an indie rock band. North Carolina’s Wednesday knows a thing or two about evocative songwriting — their latest album, “Bleeds,” is a sharpening of those oft-mimicked and never-recreated tools. But where their tracks tend to blend different styles, “Elderberry Wine” is as close to classic country as they’ve come. Stripped of their familiar distortions, this is a lovely, fermented rumination on a relationship gone sour, stuffed with poetic wisdom. “Say I wanna have your baby / ’Cause I freckle and you tan,” Wednesday’s leader, singer and songwriter Karly Hartzman sings in her enviable twang. “I find comfort that angels don’t give a damn.”

Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.name: Sue me
Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.extracted_quote: a fun, flirty and unapologetically crass pop song that's just as funny as it is catchy
Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.review: After finding her footing as a songwriter collaborating with childhood best friend Gracie Abrams, Audrey Hobert broke through as a soloist in her own right with the fun, flirty and unapologetically crass “Sue Me” — a straightforward pop song that’s just as funny as it is catchy. The lead single to Hobert’s debut album Who’s the Clown? , this track serves as a priceless introduction to the hilarious, unfiltered mind of a young rising star who’s making being awkward cool again. — H.D.

Tate McRae ::: Revolving door ::: descri.name: Revolving door
Tate McRae ::: Revolving door ::: descri.extracted_quote: "Revolving Door" captures that exhaustion with each hook feeling like another lap around the mistake
Tate McRae ::: Revolving door ::: descri.review: Over a dancehall beat, in breathy pleas, Tate McRae decries the cycle of returning to the same toxic relationship over and over again. “Revolving Door” captures that exhaustion with each hook feeling like another lap around the mistake, the beat jolting forward while she admits, again, that she just can’t leave. — HY

Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.name: Elderberry Wine
Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.extracted_quote: exudes such pleasant vibes ... it's actually a bittersweet breakup song
Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.review: Abetted by Xandy Chelmis’s honey-sweet pedal steel, the breezy “Elderberry Wine” exudes such pleasant vibes that it’s easy to miss that it’s actually a bittersweet breakup song. “Said, ‘I wanna have your baby’/’Cause I freckle and you tan,” Karly Hartzman sings with none of her usual acerbity. It may sound romantic, but sometimes the differences that draw us together can eventually prove too much to overcome. Winograd

Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.name: Elderberry Wine
Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.extracted_quote: jam-packed with metaphors, imagery, and turns of phrase that it's practically a novel in miniature
Wednesday ::: Elderberry Wine ::: descri.review: An almost too sweet-sounding song about indie rock’s famous breakup, "Elderberry Wine" is jam-packed with metaphors, imagery, and turns of phrase that it’s practically a novel in miniature. Harzman gives away the trick up front: "Sweet song is a long con," she sings at the open. When we get to its central, rotten pink eggs and teeth-sucking bubbly metaphor, we understand what’s sour beneath. — LM

Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.name: Sue me
Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.extracted_quote: introduces itself with a swaggering beat and organ-grinder synths, laying the ground for her defiant declaration of her needs
Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.review: Los Angeles singer-songwriter Audrey Hobert’s debut single introduces itself with a swaggering beat and organ-grinder synths, laying the ground for her defiant declaration of her needs. “Sue me, I wanna be wanted,” the frequent Gracie Abrams collaborator repeats in a sing-song tone. She not only brings her desired target home, she arranges a ménage à trois — although by the song’s end, she’s alone with her desire once more, navigating twinges of guilt while getting ready to move on to the next. — Maura Johnston

Four Tet ::: Into Dust (Still Falling) :.name: Into Dust (Still Falling)
Four Tet ::: Into Dust (Still Falling) :.extracted_quote: tracks that hover beguilingly, keeping the listener and/or dancer in an alert state so that when the drums land, they really land
Four Tet ::: Into Dust (Still Falling) :.review: Another Four Tet track that’s tailor-made for headphones and stadiums? You don’t say! That’s become Kieran Hebden’s stock in trade, tracks that hover beguilingly, keeping the listener and/or dancer in an alert state so that when the drums land, they really land. They certainly did when Four Tet dropped this track into his headlining sets this year, whether as a change-up from the bonkier tracks at Lost Village in August or to climax his epic performance at Lightning in a Bottle in May. — Michaelangelo Matos

Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_bi.name: Spike Island
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_bi.extracted_quote: a fist-pumping-and-hip-swinging return to form for Britpop greats Pulp
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_bi.review: “I was born to perform/ It’s a calling/ I exist to do this/ Shouting and pointing,” Jarvis Cocker sings in his Sheffield steel voice on “Spike Island,” and thank the gods he realized this. The band’s first single in almost 25 years — inspired by a legendary 1990 Stone Roses concert that took place on that artificial isle in Cheshire, England — is a fist-pumping-and-hip-swinging return to form for Britpop greats Pulp, and would be at home on the band’s 1995 masterpiece, Different Class . “And by the way/ This time I’ll get it right,” goes the chorus over disco-rock melange of deep bass, guitar, synth and cymbal. Really, Pulp had it right from the beginning, and it’s good to have them back. — FRANK DIGIACOMO

Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.name: Sue me
Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.extracted_quote: a pulsing beat that somehow makes a line like "sue me I wanna be UH! / sue me I wanna be YEAH!" hit so hard
Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.review: As any good rule follower knows, "Being a saint is exhausting." Avant-garde pop newcomer Audrey Hobert sings that line in the "Sue me" pre-chorus before detailing her messy desires. The cheeky verses are delivered stream-of-consciousness style over a pulsing beat that somehow makes a line like "sue me I wanna be UH! / sue me I wanna be YEAH!" hit so hard. —Elle Mannion, NPR

Holy Palmers' Kiss & Melody English :::.name: Horribly
Holy Palmers' Kiss & Melody English :::.extracted_quote: English's syrupy vocals over see-saw synths feel so blissfully sweet
Holy Palmers' Kiss & Melody English :::.review: I’ve been into a lot of new music this year, from Lifeguard to Addison Rae, but there is no song I’ve revisited more than Holy Palmers’ Kiss and Melody English’s “Horribly.” It’s a song that reminds me of the early 2010s indie pop I loved growing up, in the vein of Passion Pit and Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeroes, while not feeling like it’s intentionally going for the nostalgia factor. English’s syrupy vocals over see-saw synths feel so blissfully sweet that I find myself needing more, hitting play again and again. It was self-released without much fanfare, but I’m convinced that it’ll experience a similar fate to their contemporary The Dare’s now-hit “Girls”: it’s only about time until people outside of the New York City DIY bubble find it and become as enamored with it as I have. It’s vastly different from the rest of Holy Palmers’ Kiss and English’s other work, but one can hope that at some point they team up again for more releases in this direction. — Tatiana Tenreyro

Sam Fender ::: People Watching ::: descr.name: People Watching
Sam Fender ::: People Watching ::: descr.extracted_quote: steeped in grief and anger – yet it bursts with emotional euphoria
Sam Fender ::: People Watching ::: descr.review: Easily the best song on the Mercury Prize winner’s third album, ‘People Watching’ is steeped in grief and anger – yet it bursts with emotional euphoria as Sam Fender cries “I people-watch on the way back home” over jangly guitars and a spine-tingling saxophone. A stadium-slayer for the ages. DJ

Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.name: Sue me
Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.extracted_quote: a waterfall of lyrics about hooking up with an ex and not feeling guilty ... her witty attention to detail ... and quirky songwriting feels fresh
Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.review: After co-writing many of the songs on childhood friend Gracie Abrams’ blockbuster album “The Secret of Us,” Hobert stepped out with her strong debut record, “Who’s the Clown?” Over a big, bright synth, Hobert quickly tosses off a waterfall of lyrics about hooking up with an ex and not feeling guilty. The topic, the delivery, her witty attention to detail (“Just me or does he look amazing / When he’s all in his Amazon Basics?”) and quirky songwriting feels fresh, and is a fitting introduction to her unique style. — Earl

Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_pi.name: Spike Island
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_pi.extracted_quote: rummaging through the cultural remains, wondering what it all meant
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_pi.review: “Spike Island” finds Pulp returning to the scene of the crime, the site of a Stone Roses concert where the Britpop era began, according to the lore of Cool Britannia. Jarvis Cocker isn’t leading his reunited band through an exercise in nostalgia; he’s rummaging through the cultural remains, wondering what it all meant. As the band pulsates to a second-hand indie-disco beat, he discovers, “I was born to perform/It’s a calling,” a manifesto that allows Pulp to reconnect with the spirit of 1993, shying away from the insurgent anthems of Different Class in favor of something quieter and artier but no less urgent and affecting. –Stephen Thomas Erlewine

Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_gu.name: Spike Island
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_gu.extracted_quote: it has a disco rhythm that's done with real affection rather than ironic affectation
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_gu.review: This was the single that heralded the first Pulp album since 2001, and the band matched the sense of occasion with an anthem. Like so many of their hits, it has a disco rhythm that’s done with real affection rather than ironic affectation, and while Jarvis Cocker might not quite have Barry Gibb’s pipes, he’s so good when he lets his voice soar. “I was born to perform, it’s a calling / I exist to do this shouting and pointing,” he sings, exulting in Pulp’s return, as well as pre-emptively batting away any suggestions they’re past it: “No one will ever have the last word / Because it’s not something you could ever say / So swivel!” BBT

Amaarae & PinkPantheress ::: Kiss Me Thr.name: Kiss Me Thru The Phone pt 2 (with PinkPantheress)
Amaarae & PinkPantheress ::: Kiss Me Thr.extracted_quote: an amorous and infectious pop reverie ... providing a standout moment on Amaarae's excellent album "Black Star"
Amaarae & PinkPantheress ::: Kiss Me Thr.review: This amorous and infectious pop reverie playfully riffs on a 2008 Soulja Boy hit, providing a standout moment on Amaarae’s excellent album “Black Star,” and further cementing a year of subtle reinvention for PinkPantheress.

Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_st.name: Spike Island
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_st.extracted_quote: he locks right back into his lounge-disco shimmy-strut
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_st.review: Some 30,000 people came out to the Stone Roses' 1990 Spike Island concert, and the legendary clusterfuck became a symbol for the highs and lows of the Madchester moment. Jarvis Cocker wasn't one of those 30,000, but he gets it, man. On Pulp's first single in many years, he locks right back into his lounge-disco shimmy-strut. He was born to perform. It's a calling. He exists to do this: shouting and pointing. So swivel. — Tom Breihan

Amaarae & PinkPantheress ::: Kiss Me Thr.name: Kiss Me Thru The Phone pt 2 (with PinkPantheress)
Amaarae & PinkPantheress ::: Kiss Me Thr.extracted_quote: In this homage to Y2K club music, Amaarae and PinkPantheress beg to differ.
Amaarae & PinkPantheress ::: Kiss Me Thr.review: They always say the sequel is never as good as the first one. In this homage to Y2K club music, Amaarae and PinkPantheress beg to differ. — C.D.

Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_nm.name: Spike Island
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_nm.extracted_quote: charm and delight with the kind of nuanced, uber-entertaining art-pop
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_nm.review: “ I exist to do this: shouting and pointing ,” sings Jarvis Cocker with intent on this lead track from Pulp’s long-awaited comeback album ‘More’ . He knows what he was put on this earth to do: charm and delight with the kind of nuanced, uber-entertaining art-pop that could have dropped in ’95 but we’re oh-so-lucky is happening now. AT

ear ::: Real Life ::: description_fader.name: Real Life
ear ::: Real Life ::: description_fader.extracted_quote: the soft beginning belies the anxiety bubbling underneath the surface
ear ::: Real Life ::: description_fader.review: As the opening track to their debut album, “Real Life” feels like ear’s way of saying “hello world.” It begins gently, shy vocals ease over a lilting, sing-song synth: “If I let you in, will we start again?” But the soft beginning belies the anxiety bubbling underneath the surface, evinced in stuttering electronic chords that never quite explode to full-out dissonance. — Hajin Yoo

Miles Caton & Sinners Movie ::: I Lied t.name: I Lied to You
Miles Caton & Sinners Movie ::: I Lied t.extracted_quote: traces the evolution of Black music through an ever-evolving soundscape rooted in the earthy earnestness of 1930s Delta blues
Miles Caton & Sinners Movie ::: I Lied t.review: “I Lied to You,” the integral Sinners original song performed in the blockbuster horror film by rising star Miles Caton, didn’t touch a single Billboard chart — but it’s still one of the best songs of 2025, thanks to its simple lyrics and the gravitational pull of the young actor’s anointed vocal. Penned by cross-genre savant Raphael Saadiq and acclaimed composer Ludwig Göransson, “Lied” traces the evolution of Black music through an ever-evolving soundscape rooted in the earthy earnestness of 1930s Delta blues. Complete with lyrics that recount both the film’s specific plot and the precarious relationship between Black folk and the U.S., “Lied” conjures up a kind of magic American popular music been desperately missing. — KYLE DENIS

Juana Molina ::: siestas ah\u00ed ::: de.name: siestas ahí
Juana Molina ::: siestas ah\u00ed ::: de.extracted_quote: records the vanishingly brief moment when a kiss dissolves you to a cellular level
Juana Molina ::: siestas ah\u00ed ::: de.review: Eight years after her last studio album, Juana Molina’s first single from DOGA arrived as if out of a long sleep. Accordingly, Molina’s first verse is a series of “ nonsense words ” that by the second verse transform into actual lyrics, though they remain lost in processing, approximating a language where words don’t suffice. Against this primordial backdrop of synthesizer and acoustic loops, “siestas ahí” records the vanishingly brief moment when a kiss dissolves you to a cellular level. –Stefanie Fernández

Addison Rae ::: Times Like These ::: des.name: Times Like These
Addison Rae ::: Times Like These ::: des.extracted_quote: dreamy, sun-drenched, exquisitely produced ... while still sounding like something new, rather than a mere regurgitation
Addison Rae ::: Times Like These ::: des.review: It seems like most end-of-year lists have opted for “Headphones On” as Addison Rae’s finest song of 2025 – and, with respect, they are mistaken. It’s “Times Like These” which best embodies the spirit and sonic landscape of her debut album: dreamy, sun-drenched, exquisitely produced and wearing its influences on its sleeve (trip-hop, 90s Madonna, early 00’s chill-out) while still sounding like something new, rather than a mere regurgitation. The lyrics are unexpectedly angsty, riven with doubt and self-criticism ( “am I too young to be this mad? Am I too old to hate my dad? It’s so confusing ”), but the song is a burst of transcendence, an ode to Zen-like acceptance which hits just as hard in the depths of a wet, dreary winter. In times like these, it really do be how it has to be… (JG)

Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_ro.name: Spike Island
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_ro.extracted_quote: A song that easily could have been on Different Class
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_ro.review: First new material in 12 years and they release this banger?! A song that easily could have been on Different Class ! Who hasn't wrestled with a coat hanger? " And by the way, Spike Island come alive". -- Rich, Rough Trade Office

Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_billboar.name: NOKIA
Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_billboar.extracted_quote: a vintage performance by The Boy, as he offers breezy one-liners and a slithery beat-switch that feeds the feet of dance-happy listeners
Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_billboar.review: After his lyrical skirmish with Kendrick Lamar overwhelmed his 2024, Drake sought retribution in 2025 for those eager to write his obituary. Not only did he carve out his 14th Billboard 200 No. 1 album with his PARTYNEXTDOOR collab, $ome $exy $ongs 4 U , but he silenced doubters with this immediately unforgettable earworm, “NOKIA.” It’s a vintage performance by The Boy, as he offers breezy one-liners (“Imma ice both of y’all like Gretsky”) and a slithery beat-switch that feeds the feet of dance-happy listeners — and hooked enough of ’em to climb to No. 2 on the Hot 100. — C.L.

Addison Rae ::: Times Like These ::: des.name: Times Like These
Addison Rae ::: Times Like These ::: des.extracted_quote: "Times Like These" has a floaty, ambient quality highlighting her angelic vocals and sharp production choices
Addison Rae ::: Times Like These ::: des.review: Ever since “Diet Pepsi,” I’ve been a fan of Addison’s ethereal synth-pop (my top Spotify artist of the year!). Her June debut, Addison, stands as one of the year’s finest pop releases and does an impressive job defining her sound and artistic identity. My favorite track, "Times Like These," has a floaty, ambient quality highlighting her angelic vocals and sharp production choices. I’m truly excited to see what’s next for the Grammy-nominated Best New Artist.

Jeff Tweedy ::: Enough ::: description_p.name: Enough
Jeff Tweedy ::: Enough ::: description_p.extracted_quote: after all that searching, he winds up right where Quinlan started: still trying to love the world harder than it'll ever love him back—but, crucially, somehow finding peace in that imbalance
Jeff Tweedy ::: Enough ::: description_p.review: The lines that come to mind when I think of “Enough” aren’t actually Tweedy’s, but Frances Quinlan’s: “People of the world / Nobody loves you / Half as much as I am trying to.” There’s that same mix of exhaustion and devotion in the air—the desperate attempt to keep showing up, keep trying, keep loving, long after the well should have, by all accounts, run dry. The song opens on a deceptively bright ’60s-ish riff (almost certainly an homage to “Waterloo Sunset”), and it immediately feels like a deep breath after Twilight Override ’s long wandering—sunlight breaking through after a triple album’s worth of dusk. The band sounds loose and alive: Spencer’s drums nudging the beat forward, guitars chiming and fraying at the edges. But inside that warmth, Tweedy’s still turning the same questions over like stones: “Has it ever been enough? / Has it ever been okay?” The verses tumble between the heart and the mind until everything collapses into that simple refrain: “It’s hard to stay in love with everyone.”  It’s funny, really; after all that searching, he winds up right where Quinlan started: still trying to love the world harder than it’ll ever love him back—but, crucially, somehow finding peace in that imbalance. There will never be enough life to satisfy a lifetime, but that doesn’t mean that living isn’t worth it. — Casey Epstein-Gross

Wolf Alice ::: White Horses ::: descript.name: White Horses
Wolf Alice ::: White Horses ::: descript.extracted_quote: one of the best constructed bridge-chorus moments of the year is transcendent
Wolf Alice ::: White Horses ::: descript.review: A deeply personal story of identity is moving, but one of the best constructed bridge-chorus moments of the year is transcendent. — B. Kaye

Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_rs ::: c.name: NOKIA
Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_rs ::: c.extracted_quote: "Nokia" ... lends itself to the lightheartedness of a good function
Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_rs ::: c.review: We will probably be re-litigating Drake versus Kendrick Lamar well into the next century. Thankfully for Drake, not everyone is taking it so seriously. Plenty of us just want to have fun in the club to some hits, and “Nokia” — from Drake and PartyNextDoor’s Some Sexy Songs 4 U — is precisely that. With a vibrant funk-infused beat, the earworm of a track lends itself to the lightheartedness of a good function , where serious conversations — Drake’s weak spot right now — are put on pause . — J.I.

2hollis ::: flash ::: description_pitchf.name: flash
2hollis ::: flash ::: description_pitchf.extracted_quote: Backlit by the blinding strobes of his blistering synthwork—think EBM, pushed to Adderall-addled extremes—he details a lifestyle teetering out of control
2hollis ::: flash ::: description_pitchf.review: When 2hollis’ mother returned to the wreckage of his childhood home in Altadena after it was burned by a wildfire in early 2025, she sent him a photo of one of the items that survived: a tarot card, The Star. The songwriter and producer, who’d recorded the majority of his forthcoming album in that house, started to cry and took it as a sign that this was his moment—he named the record star . On “flash,” one of the record’s standout moments, 2hollis celebrates the late nights and high-speed living that now follow him as an underground artist on the cusp of, yes, stardom. Backlit by the blinding strobes of his blistering synthwork—think EBM, pushed to Adderall-addled extremes—he details a lifestyle teetering out of control, details blurred by white wine and the afterimage of all the spotlights in his eyes. The recurring refrain is that he wants to “be a star,” but on “flash,” he’s already there—you can feel the energy radiating off of him. –Colin Joyce

Neko Case ::: Wreck ::: description_pitc.name: Wreck
Neko Case ::: Wreck ::: description_pitc.extracted_quote: With giddy violins and dreamy vocal harmonies, [Case] lights the wildfire of offering up your heart as a postmenopausal woman
Neko Case ::: Wreck ::: description_pitc.review: It’s a tale as old as time: first crush, first love, first partner. “Wreck,” somehow, is not one of those tales—or at least not in song, where falling head-over-heels in your fifties is uncommon fodder.
