With giddy violins and dreamy vocal harmonies, Neko Case lights the wildfire of offering up your heart as a postmenopausal woman, casting herself as an enormous fireworks display and her loved one as the sun. Yet, when she repeats, “So please/Don’t be afraid of me or my love,” it’s not out of fear, but trust. Reinvigorated by seeing the world anew from the top of love’s perch, Case reveals that the freefall of loving deeply when you no longer care what anyone else thinks is the most beautiful part. There’s no time for the insecurities of adolescence or the overthinking of adulthood; just the blurry ride from thousands of feet in the sky, where not even a fear of heights could make your heart beat faster than love itself. –Nina Corcoran

Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_nyt_cara.name: NOKIA
Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_nyt_cara.extracted_quote: lyrics designed to sooth and caress, in the sense of music that summons a warm-weather listening clime
Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_nyt_cara.review: This is balmy Drake — in the sense of lyrics designed to sooth and caress, in the sense of music that summons a warm-weather listening clime, and in the sense that after all the kerfuffles of 2024 (which continued to resonate this year), he remains capable of accessing a version of himself that’s prettily (and perhaps pettily) blithe.

2hollis ::: flash ::: description_comple.name: flash
2hollis ::: flash ::: description_comple.extracted_quote: he harnesses this chaos with precision—personifying the star he was always meant to become
2hollis ::: flash ::: description_comple.review:
2hollis manifested his stardom from the start; on “flash,” those dreams became reality.

“Holli wanna be a star,” he raps on the propulsive, EDM-rage cut. The track itself is a slow burn; Hollis draws you in with rapid hi-hats and intimate “flash” ad-libs that methodically swells towards a head-banging, unruly drop.

Distortion is Hollis’ best friend, and on “flash,” he harnesses this chaos with precision—personifying the star he was always meant to become. Sure, tracks “crush,” “poster boy,” and “jeans” made 2hollis a name to watch for but “flash” offers something more—a deeper lens into his ascent as one of this generation’s most innovative artists. — Jon Barlas

2hollis ::: flash ::: description_dazed.name: flash
2hollis ::: flash ::: description_dazed.extracted_quote: In its pulsing electroclash beat, relentless percussion and soaring vocals, all building into an explosive crescendo, "flash" speaks far more to the charts of the future
2hollis ::: flash ::: description_dazed.review: Anyone who’s seen the memes about 2hollis performing “jeans” seven times in a row in Toronto earlier this year knows the visceral reactions that his music can produce. While the younger 2hollis (and preceding alias Drippysoup) was described as a trap artist, 2025 was the year that he became a pop star through and through – and “flash” is the perfect example. In its pulsing electroclash beat, relentless percussion and soaring vocals, all building into an explosive crescendo, “flash” speaks far more to the charts of the future than the heydays of Chicago and Atlanta rap music. “ Holli wanna be a star ,” 2hollis sings on the track, and it seems he has already become one. (SPM)

Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_nyt_zola.name: NOKIA
Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_nyt_zola.extracted_quote: Drake always seems to manage at least one undisputed bop
Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_nyt_zola.review: Even in his off years, Drake always seems to manage at least one undisputed bop. On this one, produced by the young Sierra Leonean musician Elkan, a mildly self-deprecating Drizzy flips through his digital Rolodex — might his life need a little bit of Stacy? Becky? Keisha? Ashley? Dani? — and gives the world his own Mambo No. 2025.

fakemink, Ecco2k, & Mechatok ::: MAKKA :.name: MAKKA
fakemink, Ecco2k, & Mechatok ::: MAKKA :.extracted_quote: Swerving between indie euphoria and cloud-rap mystique, the track lands with a hook from Drain Gang's Ecco2k, his voice drifting through the mix like smoke
fakemink, Ecco2k, & Mechatok ::: MAKKA :.review: This year, Fakemink levelled up. His once lo-fi world now feels expansive, filled with his newfound star power and the unmistakable glow of MAKKA . Swerving between indie euphoria and cloud-rap mystique, the track lands with a hook from Drain Gang’s Ecco2k, his voice drifting through the mix like smoke, while Fakemink rides the beat with bratty swagger and bright-eyed braggadocio. The production, courtesy of Mechatok and Deer Park, is absolutely electric: motorised percussion, wiry guitar lines and pulsing synths create a sense of motion that Fakemink matches bar for bar. At 20, he’s outgrowing his underground beginnings – and he knows it. With lines about high-end fashion and the dizzying thrill of his ascent (“ Really smokin’ flavours in Bottega, got my bag up ”), he captures the thrill of the moment. MAKKA feels like the perfect anthem for this generation’s underground – a little reckless, a little nostalgic and completely rooted in the now. -- Sik Frydas

fakemink, Ecco2k, & Mechatok ::: MAKKA :.name: MAKKA
fakemink, Ecco2k, & Mechatok ::: MAKKA :.review: “Makka” is lightning in a bottle. Originating in a chance meeting between new-gen pop producer Mechatok and Fakemink in the corridor of a studio complex they both happened to be recording in, with the music video being shot outside on the same day, it’s all about spontaneity. Who cares if the same Fakemink verses also appear on “Snow White”? After all, running throughout the entire track is an adlib layer of Fakemink mumbling what appears to be absolute nonsense. Add Mechatok’s plodding lead guitar riff and Ecco2k’s breathless chorus built around a slang word for cough syrup to the mix and you get a pretty wild ride, but, somehow, it all works together beautifully. (SPM)

Rochelle Jordan ::: Bite The Bait ::: de.name: Bite The Bait
Rochelle Jordan ::: Bite The Bait ::: de.extracted_quote: the song sparkles most when Jordan moves far beyond inspiration and into the territory of a confident, original diva
Rochelle Jordan ::: Bite The Bait ::: de.review: The skittering snare and gauzy atmosphere of Rochelle Jordan's "Bite the Bait" favorably brings to mind Timbaland's work with the late Aaliyah, but the song sparkles most when Jordan moves far beyond inspiration and into the territory of a confident, original diva. — K. Fitzgerald

Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_complex.name: NOKIA
Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_complex.review: We’re far enough removed from the all-encompassing Drake and Kendrick Lamar beef to recognize, once again, that a banger is a banger. PARTYNEXTDOOR and Drake’s $ome $exy $ongs 4 U is quintessential bachelor-core, no matter how much they want to posture themselves as being for the ladies. Nonetheless, the government mandated Drake dance track hits. Reminiscent of ‘80s freestyle and Miami bass, Drake leans into the cheesiness. One can’t help but exaggerate the “Who’s calling my phone?” call and response or do their worst Southern drawl when the “Babygurl” part comes up. — Jade Gomez

Justin Bieber ::: DAISIES ::: descriptio.name: DAISIES
Justin Bieber ::: DAISIES ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: simplicity is king in both the track's spare guitar-and-drums production and its straightforward lyrics
Justin Bieber ::: DAISIES ::: descriptio.review: This lo-fi pop song is emblematic of Justin Bieber’s whole Swag era, where simplicity is king in both the track’s spare guitar-and-drums production and its straightforward lyrics. Wanting clarity on how your romantic interest feels about you is timeless, but this is a love song built specifically for 2025, as Justin sings: “You leave me on read, babe, but I still get the message.” (Shakespeare himself would have likely had a lot to write about those “three dots” if he were still around too.) – K.A.

kwn & FLO ::: talk you through it (feat..name: talk you through it (feat. FLO)
kwn & FLO ::: talk you through it (feat..extracted_quote: FLO's honeyed harmonies coil around her in intimate tangles
kwn & FLO ::: talk you through it (feat..review: With this bedroom hymn, Kwn pulls her sapphic congregation deeper into her orbit. Tantalising piano and jittery 808s trace the curve of the east Londoner’s clenched jaw, while FLO’s honeyed harmonies coil around her in intimate tangles. Your every nerve will be thrumming long after the track ends. KSW

FKA twigs ::: HARD ::: description_pitch.name: HARD
FKA twigs ::: HARD ::: description_pitch.extracted_quote: twigs' voice sounds smothered in cotton ... She weaves together anxiety and assertiveness, friction and fear
FKA twigs ::: HARD ::: description_pitch.review: twigs shines when she fixates on small, sharp moments: the chaos of losing your friends in the club , the rush of steeping in strangers’ sweat . On “Hard,” she zooms in on pressurized eye contact across a dancefloor, on the breath that snags in your throat before you ask, Wanna get out of here? The song is a shimmery sleight-of-hand: Yes, the chorus is brash, the synths are glossy, and the track pulses like a damp hand wedged against yours, leading you to the exit. But “Hard” curls into something stranger and sneakier. On the second verse, twigs’ voice sounds smothered in cotton, like she’s hiding, even from herself, the urge to ask, “Would you do it if I didn’t ask you?” The drums judder and twitch. She weaves together anxiety and assertiveness, friction and fear—the shiver of oh, shit that comes just before, oh, wow . –Dani Blum

Kieran Hebden & William Tyler ::: Secret.name: Secret City
Kieran Hebden & William Tyler ::: Secret.extracted_quote: "Secret City" is more Pink Floyd B-sides and watching the clouds on a sunny day
Kieran Hebden & William Tyler ::: Secret.review: There’s something oddly punk to “Secret City,” the irresistible closing track of Kieran Hebden and William Tyler’s collaborative album 41 Longfield Street Late ’80s : just three chords and attitude. Not that the song sounds like punk—“Secret City” is more Pink Floyd B-sides and watching the clouds on a sunny day—but its ultra-reductive production, just guitar strum and radiant electronic drone, suggests punk’s anyone-can-do-it, stomach-pit energy, the kind of almost effortless brilliance that only hard toil and pure musical instinct can provide. –Ben Cardew

Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.name: Pussy Palace
Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.review: This is Lily Allen at her sharpest. The aptly titled Pussy Palace is deeply personal, darkly comedic and devastating in equal measure, turning heartbreak into pop gold. Endlessly playable and unapologetically bold, it just might be the revenge record of the decade? -- Emily, Rough Trade Office

kwn ::: do what i say ::: description_fa.name: do what i say
kwn ::: do what i say ::: description_fa.extracted_quote: a song so steamy, you might need to open a window after you play it
kwn ::: do what i say ::: description_fa.review: kwn knows how to lay desire out on the table. “Paint your nails the way I like ‘em / I might paint mine, too / ‘cause I know a place I could hide ‘em,” she says over a booming self-produced beat, sounding effortlessly suave. “Do what i say," is a song so steamy, you might need to open a window after you play it. Bedframes will shake and lights will stay on so everything can be captured in the mirror. — DG

Cameron Winter ::: Love Takes Miles :::.name: Love Takes Miles
Cameron Winter ::: Love Takes Miles :::.extracted_quote: the wheezes and gurgles of Winter's guttural tone push upward, toward a surprisingly heartfelt hook
Cameron Winter ::: Love Takes Miles :::.review: It’d be easy to pigeonhole Heavy Metal , the solo debut of Geese frontman Cameron Winter, as a collection of shambolic, idiosyncratic musings that make his main gig sound more accessible by comparison. And while that description is largely accurate, it also overlooks the best pop song that Winter has written to date. On “Love Takes Miles,” the wheezes and gurgles of Winter’s guttural tone push upward, toward a surprisingly heartfelt hook — one that sounds designed to haunt piano bars for years to come. — J. Lipshutz

Neton Vega & Peso Pluma ::: Morena ::: d.name: Morena
Neton Vega & Peso Pluma ::: Morena ::: d.extracted_quote: wrapped in a gauzy, slo-mo sheen of spiraling trombone riffs and pulsating bass that adds a near spiritual vibe
Neton Vega & Peso Pluma ::: Morena ::: d.review: The party that Netón Vega and Peso Pluma attend on “Morena” is a lavish affair — with Balenciaga, tequila of the Cruz Azul variety, and a bit of white powder to get the blood flowing. Hopelessly hedonistic, right? And yet, this música mexicana gem is wrapped in a gauzy, slo-mo sheen of spiraling trombone riffs and pulsating bass that adds a near spiritual vibe to the story of the title’s captivating beauty. Melancholy to the core, and achingly beautiful. — E.L.

dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.name: Special
dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.extracted_quote: dexter sings with such conviction that all you can do is bask in the beauty
dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.review: Love songs have long been the lingua franca of pop music. So when a new love song comes along that captures that timeworn feeling anew, it feels transcendent. Such is the case with “Special,” a paean to love-as-human-necessity from South London’s dexter in the newsagent. The subject of the singer’s affection is so entrancing that she needs them like coffee in the morning and sleeping in the evening. Over finger-picked acoustic guitars and swelling synth pads, dexter sings with such conviction that all you can do is bask in the beauty. Guileless and gorgeous, “Special” delivers on its namesake. — Grant Sharples

dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.name: Special
dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.extracted_quote: Heartbreak here sounds both resigned and hopeful
dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.review: The British singer-songwriter forgoes dense metaphors for simple expressions of heartache and longing (“I can love you like you want me to/I can't be on my own”). Heartbreak here sounds both resigned and hopeful. Like the turning of the page, it’s resolute, yet future facing. — TH

dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.name: Special
dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.extracted_quote: catchy and effervescent, like a vintage R&B cut but undeniably contemporary in its slow, romantic production
dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.review: Fans of Frank Ocean, run — don’t walk — to press play on “Special,” the best single from dexter in the newsagent, the musical moniker of English soul singer Charmaine Ayoku. The song, like much of Ayoku’s discography, is breezy and transient — catchy and effervescent, like a vintage R&B cut but undeniably contemporary in its slow, romantic production. Maybe you heard it on TikTok, maybe this is your first introduction. Whatever the case, let it last.

Wendy Eisenberg ::: Will You Dare ::: de.name: Will You Dare
Wendy Eisenberg ::: Will You Dare ::: de.extracted_quote: Rubio's pedal steel tone ... scores a vastness of a hair-silvering love and the time passing through it
Wendy Eisenberg ::: Will You Dare ::: de.review: A year ago, Wendy Eisenberg made a record that I ached into. Viewfinder was beautiful at all of its angles, be it the flakes of piano decorated by strange and streaking jazz ideas in “Two Times Water,” or the inventive, guitar keepsakes filling “Lasik.” Eisenberg’s moves are so often improvisational, and their guitar playing knows not boundaries but sensations. In more eaze’s Mari Rubio, Eisenberg has found a sublime dance partner, and Rubio’s pedal steel tone on “Will You Dare” scores a vastness of a hair-silvering love and the time passing through it: “It shapes you, and scrapes you, and makes you ask, ‘Why did I try? Did I try?’” The twang in Eisenberg’s voice snakes up the fretboard behind their fingers; Ryan Sawyer’s drumming grins in the delicate obviousness, where one stick brushes along the snare and the other taps the ride cymbal. I think music like this, the type that pulls you into its tangles and keeps you there beautifully, is worth sticking around to hear. “Will You Dare” is a question mark shaped like a ghost. — Matt Mitchell

Tate McRae ::: Sports car ::: descriptio.name: Sports car
Tate McRae ::: Sports car ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: all thump and sigh and slither and head tilt and exhale
Tate McRae ::: Sports car ::: descriptio.review: The Canadian would-be diva excelled on this return to the old-fashioned burlesque pop of two decades ago, all thump and sigh and slither and head tilt and exhale.

Tate McRae ::: Sports car ::: descriptio.name: Sports car
Tate McRae ::: Sports car ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: a thoroughly tactile hit that sounds like slick bare skin on a leather seat
Tate McRae ::: Sports car ::: descriptio.review: The Canadian phenom Tate McRae offers her take on one of pop music’s most tried and true topics: fogging up the windows of a very expensive vehicle. With its chorus chanted in a carnal whisper, McRae loosens up her buttons and effectively mines the sweatiest early-aughts pop, resulting in a thoroughly tactile hit that sounds like slick bare skin on a leather seat.

This Is Lorelei & MJ Lenderman ::: Danci.name: Dancing in the Club - MJ Lenderman Version
This Is Lorelei & MJ Lenderman ::: Danci.extracted_quote: Lenderman's version takes the full plunge into despair, delivering twangy, turbulent lines that rattle in every note
This Is Lorelei & MJ Lenderman ::: Danci.review: When This Is Lorelei’s Nate Amos released “Dancing in the Club” last year, he said it was “dreamt up for others to sing.” Those dreams came true on the new deluxe edition, when our favorite guitar hero , MJ Lenderman, was put to the task. If the original was a glittering Auto-Tune adventure into heartbreak, Lenderman’s version takes the full plunge into despair, delivering twangy, turbulent lines that rattle in every note: “A loser never wins/And I’m a loser, always been.” It’s a devastatingly great collaboration and a highlight within a massive year of highlights for Lenderman that also included a tour behind his breakthrough album, Manning Fireworks (the finale was a headlining slot at a Rolling Stone showcase), a fantastic record with Wednesday, and playing drums for the Crutchfield sisters . When it comes to Lenderman, the loser wins. — A.M.

Smerz ::: You got time and I got money :.name: You got time and I got money
Smerz ::: You got time and I got money :.extracted_quote: from a chintzy click track and a treacly string motif that's instantly familiar yet untraceable, it sounds like the Norwegian duo ... is slipping into a plush eiderdown
Smerz ::: You got time and I got money :.review: When Smerz perform “You got time and I got money,” they stand in front of a big fan and transform into Victoria’s Secret supermodels. Big city life ’s bradycardic beating heart is a slow jam in a Shein top. From a chintzy click track and a treacly string motif that’s instantly familiar yet untraceable, it sounds like the Norwegian duo of Catharina Stoltenberg and Henriette Motzfeldt is slipping into a plush eiderdown. “I am yours and your boy only,” Stoltenberg sings, as if the song were written for someone else to sing and she’s just holding their spot on the stage, “So put your hands around me.” Her plainspoken observations of a lover trigger profound sense memories—the smell of laundry detergent, every song you’ve ever made out to playing at the same time. “You got time and I got money” reminds me of another pair of angels, these ones sketched by the painter Paul Klee in 1931. Their heavenly bodies conjoin on the page, hastily scribbled in an eternal embrace. –Walden Green

This Is Lorelei & MJ Lenderman ::: Danci.name: Dancing in the Club - MJ Lenderman Version
This Is Lorelei & MJ Lenderman ::: Danci.extracted_quote: swaps the depressive Auto-Tune for a lonesome alt-country lament and sounds like he was born to sing this indelible tune
This Is Lorelei & MJ Lenderman ::: Danci.review: Remember when the indie darlings of the ’80s and ’90s covered each other’s songs in real time? Back then, before the business of pop became a publishing arms race, covers were a vehicle for buzzy acts to throw respect on their contemporaries, dirty up a breakthrough hit, maybe even let their growing fanbase in on a little secret. It was in that storied tradition that MJ Lenderman stripped This is Lorelei’s “Dancing in the Club” down to its forlorn essence—first as a live cover , then a collaborative bonus cut on the deluxe edition of the Water From Your Eyes member’s solo album. Lenderman swaps the depressive Auto-Tune for a lonesome alt-country lament and sounds like he was born to sing this indelible tune about being down bad but not so down bad that you won’t sing along to Steely Dan . –Zach Schonfeld

Fiona Apple ::: Pretrial (Let Her Go Hom.name: Pretrial (Let Her Go Home)
Fiona Apple ::: Pretrial (Let Her Go Hom.extracted_quote: Powerfully percussion-driven ... Advocacy for women trapped by the justice system because of their inability to make bail
Fiona Apple ::: Pretrial (Let Her Go Hom.review: Powerfully percussion-driven (you can hear hands slap those drums), "Pretrial (Let Her Go Home)" gets its subtitle from its key message: Advocacy for women trapped by the justice system because of their inability to make bail. Fiona Apple ended her five-year hiatus from music for this immediate earworm of a song, inspired by two years as a court watcher in Maryland . As powerful as the song is, the story behind it is even more affecting. — L.S. Miller

Addison Rae ::: Fame is a Gun ::: descri.name: Fame is a Gun
Addison Rae ::: Fame is a Gun ::: descri.review: Want to know how this TikToker became an internet It girl overnight? She spells it out clearly in this pop-star manifesto. — C.D.

ROSAL\u00cdA & Yahritza Y Su Esencia :::.name: La Perla
ROSAL\u00cdA & Yahritza Y Su Esencia :::.extracted_quote: juxtaposition of a waltz arrangement against lyrics that lambast her former lover
ROSAL\u00cdA & Yahritza Y Su Esencia :::.review: Rosalía took a sledgehammer to much of global popular music — and the rise of generative AI within that space — with Lux , her grandiose fourth studio album, on which she prioritizes both human instrumentalists and humanity itself. “La Perla” is one of the set’s clearest standouts, marked by the Grammy winner’s juxtaposition of a waltz arrangement against lyrics that lambast her former lover. Witty in both composition and structure, “La Perla” forces listeners to reimagine the boundaries of pop music in an era in which they have become dreadfully predictable.  — K.D.

This Is Lorelei & MJ Lenderman ::: Danci.name: Dancing in the Club - MJ Lenderman Version
This Is Lorelei & MJ Lenderman ::: Danci.extracted_quote: strips down the original song's hyperpop disposition in a way that gives it a brand-new meaning
This Is Lorelei & MJ Lenderman ::: Danci.review: Indie Rock Dudes had a great 2025, and what’s better than a collab between two of the genre’s reigning champions? On this track from the deluxe edition of This Is Lorelei’s stellar 2024 record “Box for Buddy, Box for Star,” dad-rock torchbearer Lenderman strips down the original song’s hyperpop disposition in a way that gives it a brand-new meaning. Played acoustically, “Dancing in the Club”’s lyricism stands out, anchored by a subtle yet brilliant metaphor: “And I know it’s only cards / But love I feel your heart in spades / While you were dancing in the club / I gave my diamonds all away.” Lenderman’s crackly voice and penchant for yearning give those words the quietly heartbreaking delivery they deserve. — Shafer

Ichiko Aoba ::: Lucif\u00e9rine ::: desc.name: Luciférine
Ichiko Aoba ::: Lucif\u00e9rine ::: desc.extracted_quote: Ethereal and uncanny, the piano arpeggios ... belong squarely in a Tim Burton dream sequence
Ichiko Aoba ::: Lucif\u00e9rine ::: desc.review: Ethereal and uncanny, the piano arpeggios around minute two of Ichiko Aoba’s “Luciférine” belong squarely in a Tim Burton dream sequence. Over orchestral swells and lush, cinematic arrangements, Aoba’s Japanese lyrics describe “a place for our stars to sleep” inside each of us, before “a child of the future opens its eyes.” Wondrousness awaits in the bridge as the tempo builds, the strings get louder, and twinkling keys evoke a velvety, starlit sky. “Luciférine” is all swirling instrumentation, an invitation to astral project. –Linnie Greene

Playboi Carti ::: LIKE WEEZY ::: descrip.name: LIKE WEEZY
Playboi Carti ::: LIKE WEEZY ::: descrip.extracted_quote: scrambles "Bend Over," a 2010 mixtape cut by onetime baby-faced duo Rich Kidz, into a chirpy and hypnotic bop for a new viral age
Playboi Carti ::: LIKE WEEZY ::: descrip.review: Many commentators viewed Playboi Carti’s long-awaited new album, MUSIC , as the ultimate triumph of rage and meme-fueled styles in mainstream hip-hop. But his chart-topping album also has unexpected layers: “Like Weezy” scrambles “Bend Over,” a 2010 mixtape cut by onetime baby-faced duo Rich Kidz, into a chirpy and hypnotic bop for a new viral age. “Spit on a bitch like Pac,” chants Carti in reference to a notorious 1994 face-off between 2Pac and courthouse reporters . — M.R.

Alessia Cara ::: Clean ::: description_b.name: Clean
Alessia Cara ::: Clean ::: description_b.extracted_quote: her voice truly shines ... [with] deliberate choices she makes, softening or intensifying her delivery in each line to match the emotion of the song
Alessia Cara ::: Clean ::: description_b.review: "Clean" is a song that grabbed my attention within the first three seconds, and from the opening guitar riff, I knew it would be on repeat. Alessia is an underrated vocalist, and her voice truly shines. You can hear the deliberate choices she makes, softening or intensifying her delivery in each line to match the emotion of the song.

Playboi Carti ::: LIKE WEEZY ::: descrip.name: LIKE WEEZY
Playboi Carti ::: LIKE WEEZY ::: descrip.extracted_quote: a carnival-like warmth, complete with looping, whimsical synths
Playboi Carti ::: LIKE WEEZY ::: descrip.review: “Like Weezy,” the best song off of MUSIC , features a surprising shift from Carti’s usual vamped-out, distorted Opium sound. The track is bright and upbeat, paying homage to Evil Jordan’s youth in Atlanta by sampling Rich Kidz’s “Bend Over.” It’s a song that’s more self-titled than it is Whole Lotta Red . The beat, crafted by Ojivolta and Kelvin Krash, drives the song with a carnival-like warmth, complete with looping, whimsical synths. Carti’s delivery is playful and loose, perfectly capturing the spirited, experimental vibe of late-2010s mixtapes. — Antonio Johri

Smerz ::: You got time and I got money :.name: You got time and I got money
Smerz ::: You got time and I got money :.extracted_quote: a woozy, ardently romantic ballad about how transformative it feels for true love to exceed all expectations
Smerz ::: You got time and I got money :.review: The ironic distance on Smerz’s great second album Big City Life, with its savage assessments of a scene’s parties and fashions, put off some listeners: it’s hard not to wonder what scathing take the Norwegian duo might have on your cooked outfit and drink of choice. But their exacting eye made them gripping company – and the sincerity of their discernment was born out in this woozy, ardently romantic ballad about how transformative it feels for true love to exceed all expectations. The looping hook “put your hands around my body / I am yours and your only” feels as though it should have existed since the heyday of girl groups, coupled with strings that sound like Bitter Sweet Symphony given the Disintegration Loops treatment. LS

PARTYNEXTDOOR & Drake ::: SOMEBODY LOVES.name: SOMEBODY LOVES ME
PARTYNEXTDOOR & Drake ::: SOMEBODY LOVES.extracted_quote: "Somebody Loves Me" wraps you up like a warm hug on a cold night
PARTYNEXTDOOR & Drake ::: SOMEBODY LOVES.review:
“SOMEBODY LOVES ME” has become $ome $exy $ongs 4 U’s runaway hit for the two for a reason: It’s built for any setting. Whether that be in the throes of the club or a late-night drive, “Somebody Loves Me” wraps you up like a warm hug on a cold night.

Drake has always had a knack for crafting quotables made for IG captions—“her name is Angel, but she’s must’ve forgot (from God)”—but here, he delivers them through Loverboy -era melodies, emphatically crooning “Who’s out there for me?” into the void in hopes that someone responds (oh, Aubrey). PND keeps the party alive with a hook that’s not only infectious, but ever-so relatable: “I know there’s somebody who loves me… and that’s all I need.” There’s love in the air, and “Somebody Loves Me” was the spark that set it off. — Jon Barlas

Playboi Carti ::: LIKE WEEZY ::: descrip.name: LIKE WEEZY
Playboi Carti ::: LIKE WEEZY ::: descrip.extracted_quote: the track proves that Carti is just as debauched and unhinged as ever
Playboi Carti ::: LIKE WEEZY ::: descrip.review: With “Like Weezy,” Playboi Carti pulls off the rap trick of constructing a track’s architecture against, on top of, and in relation to a number of cultural precedents, with the song still emerging as its own unique creation. In this case, producers Ojivolta and Kelvin Krash sample Rich Kidz’s “Bend Over,” and Carti’s single manic verse and two choruses nod to the riotous unholy trinity of Lil Wayne, Justin Bieber, and 2Pac. Tonally and temperamentally, it’s one of the sweeter and poppier tracks on Music , but at its core, the track proves that Carti is just as debauched and unhinged as ever. Lyons-Burt

Carli & Seinabo Sey ::: The Runner ::: d.name: The Runner
Carli & Seinabo Sey ::: The Runner ::: d.extracted_quote: "The Runner," an endorphin rush whirling around an existential plea
Carli & Seinabo Sey ::: The Runner ::: d.review: For the better part of the past two decades, Carli Löf has been a pillar of the Stockholm dance community as DJ, breakdancer, and member of the Studio Barnhus supergroup Off The Meds. On his long-awaited debut, Sea of Love , all of these paths converge to create an instant soft-rave classic. It peaks with “The Runner,” an endorphin rush whirling around an existential plea. — Salvatore Maicki

Bad Bunny ::: DtMF ::: description_paste.name: DtMF
Bad Bunny ::: DtMF ::: description_paste.extracted_quote: the slow burn of those quiet synths, which gallop towards a dembow and culminates in the best singalong chorus in pop music since "Mr. Brightside"
Bad Bunny ::: DtMF ::: description_paste.review: I first heard “DtMF” sung by a hundred voices gathered for Pride in New York City, and the magic of Bad Bunny’s best song has not escaped me since. It’s the slow burn of those quiet synths, which gallop towards a dembow and culminates in the best singalong chorus in pop music since “Mr. Brightside”—at least for those open-minded enough to learn a few Spanish dozen words. “DtMF” perfectly embodies a sorely needed collectivism uncommonly found in this all-eyes-on-me era, a quality that’s left many enraged and millions more celebrating. — Benny Sun

Qing Madi ::: Ali Bomaye ::: description.name: Ali Bomaye
Qing Madi ::: Ali Bomaye ::: description.extracted_quote: mixing some traditional Afrobeats drum patterns with a deep and fluid baseline underscoring her soaring vocals and lilting melodies
Qing Madi ::: Ali Bomaye ::: description.review: The young singer-songwriter from Nigeria burst onto the scene with this single off her debut full-length album, mixing some traditional Afrobeats drum patterns with a deep and fluid baseline underscoring her soaring vocals and lilting melodies. She feels simultaneously part of the tradition of African R&B while also pushing it forward — fitting for an artist who managed to mesmerize this year despite still being just 19 years old. This will be a set closer for her for years to come. — D.R.

Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.artist: Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell Williams, Pusha T, & Malice
Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.name: Chains & Whips
Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.extracted_quote: A double entendre on materialism and the illusion of true freedom, Pharrell's menacing melodies amplify the Thornton brothers' sharp lyrical wizardry
Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.review: Still drying the damp eyes from the heartbreak of Let God Sort Em Out opener “The Birds Don’t Sing,” Clipse wastes no time smacking listeners in the face with the bristling “Chains & Whips,” featuring an assist from Kendrick Lamar. A double entendre on materialism and the illusion of true freedom, Pharrell’s menacing melodies amplify the Thornton brothers’ sharp lyrical wizardry between “This is culturally inappropriate” ad-libs. King Push flexes his watch collection and voices his disgust with reality TV while preaching that not all money is good money. And if the last 18 months didn’t make it clear enough, K. Dot’s verse here should leave no doubt that his callousness hasn’t given an inch, and neither has his grip on the rap game. — M.S.

Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_stereogu.name: Taxes
Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_stereogu.extracted_quote: a metaphysical pop epic in just over three minutes, packed with musical epiphanies and philosophical gauntlets
Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_stereogu.review: The loosely shaking groove. The bleating vocal. The searching bass. The soft acoustic strums. The tender, wordless coos. The killer lyric conflating the only two sure things in this life. It's all leading up to that transcendent moment when the chiming guitars soar into the frame and the full band achieves liftoff, a spine-tingling climax that confirmed the ascendance of a generational band. As a specimen of songcraft, few tracks functioned more powerfully or efficiently than "Taxes" this year: a metaphysical pop epic in just over three minutes, packed with musical epiphanies and philosophical gauntlets, ready to send Geese fans skyward for decades to come. — Chris DeVille

Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.artist: Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell Williams, Pusha T, & Malice
Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.name: Chains & Whips
Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.extracted_quote: an out-of-his-mind Kendrick elevates this to the status of cultural event
Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.review: To hear Pusha T tell it, Clipse could've ditched the Kendrick Lamar verse and kept their Def Jam deal. In that scenario, "Chains & Whips" would still be colossal – Pusha's theatrical disgust for Jim Jones, Malice's biblical bloodthirst, Lenny Kravitz's angry-sludgy riffage, Pharrell Williams' falsetto threats and organ squelches. But an out-of-his-mind Kendrick elevates this to the status of cultural event. Something like that is worth breaking a few contracts. — Tom Breihan

Bad Bunny ::: DtMF ::: description_slant.name: DtMF
Bad Bunny ::: DtMF ::: description_slant.extracted_quote: a subtle, wistful combination of plena and reggaeton ... like a bar room singalong
Bad Bunny ::: DtMF ::: description_slant.review: Bad Bunny continues his steadfast mission of honoring his home of Puerto Rico on “DTMF,” a subtle, wistful combination of plena and reggaeton (pitched at a gentler pace than usual for the artist). When a chorus of other voices joins him on the song’s hook, it feels communal and raucous, like a bar room singalong that happens to be led by one of the most skillful popsmiths currently working. Lyons-Burt

Cardi B ::: Outside ::: description_bill.name: Outside
Cardi B ::: Outside ::: description_bill.extracted_quote: Sampling the well-known "Triggerman" beat, Cardi declared her official return with plenty of her signature attitude
Cardi B ::: Outside ::: description_bill.review: Following her seven-year album drought, Cardi B reigned over her peers with No. 1-debuting sophomore set Am I the Drama? , whose arrival was preceded by the June release of lead single “Outside.” Sampling the well-known “Triggerman” beat, Cardi declared her official return with plenty of her signature attitude, referencing both her estranged husband Offset and her new romance with Stefon Diggs. Circling the wagons, fans drove “Outside” to a No. 10 debut on the Hot 100, giving the rapper her 13th top 10 hit. — G.M.

Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.artist: Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell Williams, Pusha T, & Malice
Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.name: Chains & Whips
Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.extracted_quote: a cypher of self-assured flexing ... the peak of this growth
Clipse, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell William.review:
It might have been a rough year for mainstream rap on the charts, but at least we got the Clipse back . Returning with the seminal Let God Sort ’Em Out, Malice and Pusha T assert their legacies with braggadocious bravado, while also redefining what the Clipse can be. The album’s strongest point is “Chains & Whips,” which marks the peak of this growth—a cypher of self-assured flexing on every opponent Pusha, Malice, and guest star Kendrick Lamar have conquered.

The trio meticulously dismantles anyone who dares to challenge them. It’s a rap Olympics at the highest level, with each verse deserving of “verse of the year” honors. Their signature slick wordplay is fused with the wiser introspection that only comes with experience. — Josh Svetz

Monaleo ::: Putting Ya Dine ::: descript.name: Putting Ya Dine
Monaleo ::: Putting Ya Dine ::: descript.extracted_quote: shines with an infectious synth melody that toes the line between catchy and cheesy, while the droning bass line gives the track early-trap vibes
Monaleo ::: Putting Ya Dine ::: descript.review: Monaleo, the better half of rap’s hottest power couple alongside her husband Stunna 4 Vegas, is reviving some of Houston’s best styles on what might be her biggest single of 2025. “Putting Ya Dine” shines with an infectious synth melody that toes the line between catchy and cheesy, while the droning bass line gives the track early-trap vibes. Monaleo also manages to drop a Bun B reference, which is an automatic passing grade in and of itself. — Will Schube

Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_billb.name: Dopamine
Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_billb.extracted_quote: dissecting her own complicated emotions set to a pulsing beat that just keeps building
Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_billb.review: Robyn once again has us in our feels on the dance floor with her first new song in seven years, dissecting her own complicated emotions (“I know it’s just dopamine/ But it feels so real to me”) set to a pulsing beat that just keeps building… kind of like a dopamine-fueled crush. In the end, is it true love or just a rush of chemicals? Does it matter? – KATIE ATKINSON

Rema ::: Bout U ::: description_fader ::.name: Bout U
Rema ::: Bout U ::: description_fader ::.extracted_quote: an Afrobeats ode to a blazing woman
Rema ::: Bout U ::: description_fader ::.review: Rema’s 2025 was a wild ride as he released single after single, banger after banger. Picking a favorite felt torturous, but I landed on the most addicting: an Afrobeats ode to a blazing woman he swears is his favorite. — KW

Justin Bieber ::: YUKON ::: description_.name: YUKON
Justin Bieber ::: YUKON ::: description_.extracted_quote: sway gently in the breeze, set only to sparingly strummed guitar
Justin Bieber ::: YUKON ::: description_.review: Justin Bieber’s “Yukon” seems to sway gently in the breeze, set only to sparingly strummed guitar. In a choice that rubs fascinatingly against the would-be naturalism of the music, the singer’s voice is pitched way up while his less altered vocals can only be heard in the background and on the second chorus. This sly modulation is one of several reasons that “Yukon” is more than its modest first blush. Lyons-Burt

Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_npr :.name: Dopamine
Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_npr :.extracted_quote: the Swedish fembot sounds like she's rebooting, fired up by romantic chemistry, ready to give us something to dance to
Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_npr :.review: In a year of stomp-clap hits like Alex Warren's "Ordinary" and the doldrums of Taylor Swift's "The Fate of Ophelia," it might seem wrong to release pop music that, I don't know, at least attempts to raise a listener's heartbeat. But not to Robyn. On the slow-building "Dopamine," her first solo song in seven years, the Swedish fembot sounds like she's rebooting, fired up by romantic chemistry, ready to give us something to dance to. —Hazel Cills, NPR

Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.name: Pussy Palace
Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.extracted_quote: Utterly grim but spellbindingly beautiful ... Pussy Palace may be the apex of Allen's trademark for mingling sweet and tongue-curlingly sour
Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.review: Every single detail of Lily Allen’s possibly-fictional-quite-possibly-not discovery of a cheating husband’s sex den – “Duane Reade bag with the handles tied / Sex toys, butt plugs, lube inside” – cuts like a savage little knife with a pearly handle. Utterly grim but spellbindingly beautiful, its synths as prettily detailed as they are cosmically atmospheric, Pussy Palace may be the apex of Allen’s trademark for mingling sweet and tongue-curlingly sour. LS

Greyson Chance ::: Savanna ::: descripti.name: Savanna
Greyson Chance ::: Savanna ::: descripti.extracted_quote: He has one of pop music's most compelling voices, and "Savanna" is a perfect showcase.
Greyson Chance ::: Savanna ::: descripti.review: I love a piano ballad, and Greyson Chance knows exactly how to deliver. He has one of pop music’s most compelling voices, and "Savanna" is a perfect showcase. The song builds beautifully over time, starting with delicate piano and falsetto, then gradually adding drums and blending chest and head voice. By the end a full choir joins in, which is definitely a unique element to hear in current pop music.

Life Without Buildings ::: Love Trinity.name: Love Trinity
Life Without Buildings ::: Love Trinity.extracted_quote: it builds into the kind of epic climax they'd rarely attempt
Life Without Buildings ::: Love Trinity.review: There’s a reason Life Without Buildings endured long after their breakup: Sue Tompkins’ beguiling lyrics were the perfect backdrop to the band’s precisely structured sound. But their final song, “Love Trinity,” originally captured on their 2007 live album and released officially in October, is actually the most straightforward track the band ever made. Still, it’s no less captivating as it builds into the kind of epic climax they’d rarely attempt on Any Other City . Robert Johnson’s delay-heavy guitars and Sue Tompkins’ multitracked vocals suggest a more ambitious direction they never pursued. It feels appropriate that this is their last released song, as it has an unusually literal lyric, “don’t leave the visual world,” that seemed to foreshadow Tompkins’ decision to commit to visual art. Even 24 years after it was recorded, “Love Trinity” fits right in with the modern post-punk bands who built on their sound. –Hannah Jocelyn

Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_elle.name: Dopamine
Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_elle.extracted_quote: she delivers feel-good pop energy that we've been desperately needing
Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_elle.review: “A Robyn comeback before the end of the year? Maybe 2025 wasn’t as terrible as it seemed. On this new single, which she produced with Klas Åhlund, her ‘Call Your Girlfriend’ collaborator, she delivers feel-good pop energy that we’ve been desperately needing.” —EG

Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.name: Pussy Palace
Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.review: The best takedown on an album rife with killer takedowns is an odd, explicit, revealing earworm. — B. Kaye

Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_dazed.name: Dopamine
Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_dazed.extracted_quote: the sovereign of sad-happy songs has returned with another cathartic club anthem
Robyn ::: Dopamine ::: description_dazed.review: Finally, the sovereign of sad-happy songs has returned with another cathartic club anthem. Back with her first solo release in seven years, last month, Robyn dropped “Dopamine” – adding to her list of songs engineered for the 4am closing set. Following in the footsteps of its predecessors, “Dancing On My Own”, “With Every Heartbeat” and “Be Mine”, “Dopamine” is sonically uplifting, yet carries emotional weight, with anxiety lying beneath the excitement. It includes all the magic ingredients that made us fall in love with Robyn in the first place: namely, the desire to thrash about in the rain (à la Flashdance ), exactly like the Swedish singer does in the music video. (See also: the Jamie xx remix of this track ). (IVD)

Deafheaven ::: Body Behavior ::: descrip.name: Body Behavior
Deafheaven ::: Body Behavior ::: descrip.extracted_quote: menacing and stirring in a way Deafheaven have never been
Deafheaven ::: Body Behavior ::: descrip.review: Maybe we've gotten Deafheaven wrong all along. Sure, we figured out their simultaneous heaviness and sublimity early on, but we're still learning how far they can take that balance. Hell, maybe Deafheaven are still learning that too. How else to explain "Body Behavior," one of the many outliers-as-new-normals dotting Lonely People With Power ? George Clarke shakes his typical screech for a register like Alice Cooper choking on a lit cigarette, the lyrics on objectification as learned behavior are jarringly lucid, and the track's back half — all lurking bass and pseudo-viola howls — could even read as Godspeed You! Black Emperor worship. It's menacing and stirring in a way Deafheaven have never been, but, then again, they’ve never been ones to take the same road to that destination twice. — Natalie Marlin

Mariah the Scientist ::: Burning Blue ::.name: Burning Blue
Mariah the Scientist ::: Burning Blue ::.extracted_quote: flipped a Jetski Purp beat she found on YouTube into one of the catchiest R&B ballads of the year
Mariah the Scientist ::: Burning Blue ::.review: Mariah the Scientist lit the spark to her explosive 2025 with “Burning Blue,” which earned a top 25 debut on the BIllboard Hot 100, the highest entry of her career to date. The R&B singer-songwriter continued to fan the flame, and the smoldering “Burning Blue” spent 20-plus weeks in the top 40, while rising to the top of the Rhythmic Airplay chart. Proving not all hits are birthed the same, Mariah flipped a Jetski Purp beat she found on YouTube into one of the catchiest R&B ballads of the year, unlocking another level of her songwriting while tapping into the fragility of romance. — M.S.

Bad Bunny ::: NUEVAYoL ::: description_b.name: NUEVAYoL
Bad Bunny ::: NUEVAYoL ::: description_b.extracted_quote: exporting a new sound to the world, by throwing genres like reggaetón and dembow into a blender to make infectious music that moves the body and stirs up the souls of Latinos across the globe
Bad Bunny ::: NUEVAYoL ::: description_b.review: It’s hard to sample a classic like El Gran Combo’s “Un Verano en Nueva York” and make another classic, but Bad Bunny pulled it off. This song and music video (directed by the talented Renell Medrano) have been able to bring different generations together with their depictions of the Latin diaspora in NYC. However, Bunny’s s—t-talking is what makes this song: He brings up legends like Big Pun and Lápiz Conciente as he refers to himself as the King of Pop (which he is, debate your mother). And he’s doing it by exporting a new sound to the world, by throwing genres like reggaetón and dembow into a blender to make infectious music that moves the body and stirs up the souls of Latinos across the globe — filling them with pride whether they grew up in the Greater Antilles or Washington Heights. — A.D.

Mariah the Scientist ::: Burning Blue ::.name: Burning Blue
Mariah the Scientist ::: Burning Blue ::.extracted_quote: [Her] lithe, yet resolute voice slices through the scraped-metal electronics and blown-out drums ... putting a beating heart at the center of its industrial chill
Mariah the Scientist ::: Burning Blue ::.review: Mariah the Scientist’s lithe, yet resolute voice slices through the scraped-metal electronics and blown-out drums on her ballad “Burning Blue,” putting a beating heart at the center of its industrial chill. She’s up-front about the way a lover awakened long-dormant feelings. But she’s also quick to let her intended know just how deeply her passion runs: “If you open fire, then it’s treason,” she warns, a reminder that even the most beautiful flame can quickly turn into something more dangerous. — M.J.

Skrilla & Lil Yachty ::: Rich Sinners (f.name: Rich Sinners (feat. Lil Yachty)
Skrilla & Lil Yachty ::: Rich Sinners (f.review: After catapulting into meme lore last summer with “Doot Doot (6 7),” Philadelphia rapper Skrilla spent the rest of 2025 proving that he’s more than a one-hit wonder. “Rich Sinners,” which finds him trading bars with Lil Yachty, marks a step forward. “I’m from the bottom, Bikini Bottom, who knew Patrick be a star?” raps Skrilla. But leave it to Yachty to offer the track’s most outrageous — and potentially offensive — line: “I’m the one call all the shots, I feel like Putin.” — Mosi Reeves

KAROL G ::: LATINA FOREVA ::: descriptio.name: LATINA FOREVA
KAROL G ::: LATINA FOREVA ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: blends old-school reggaetón with a girl-power ethos, crafting an anthem that's equal parts feisty and contagious
KAROL G ::: LATINA FOREVA ::: descriptio.review:
There’s something familiar about “Latina Foreva.” It nods to N.O.R.E., Daddy Yankee, and Nina Sky’s classic “Oye Mi Canto,” but doesn’t rely on nostalgia as a crutch. Instead, Karol G blends old-school reggaetón with a girl-power ethos, crafting an anthem that’s equal parts feisty and contagious.

There’s a brutal efficiency to it: the song is just over two minutes long, but Karol breezes through two verses and an earworm chorus you couldn’t shake if you tried. In some ways, it feels like a return to basics for her—which might explain why, when she unveiled the song, she did it showcasing her natural brown hair. — Dimas Sanfiorenzo

Tate McRae ::: Sports car ::: descriptio.name: Sports car
Tate McRae ::: Sports car ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: a minimalist sex song of tire squeaks, engine revs, and ASMR-whispered findom demands
Tate McRae ::: Sports car ::: descriptio.review: You’d be happy to let Tate McRae drain your wallet after hearing “Sports car,” her minimalist sex song of tire squeaks, engine revs, and ASMR-whispered findom demands. Atop a chord progression that is so canny that at least one classical virtuoso has marveled over its use of the Phrygian mode, McRae is a much chillier coquette than her button-loosened forebears . Her blunt message here is that there are few greater pleasure enhancers than a fat wallet, particularly if you can uh-uh in its spoils. –Owen Myers

Mariah the Scientist ::: Burning Blue ::.name: Burning Blue
Mariah the Scientist ::: Burning Blue ::.extracted_quote: what makes this track resonate is how approachable and repeatable the singing feels
Mariah the Scientist ::: Burning Blue ::.review: There’s been plenty of online discourse about Mariah’s vocal chops, but what makes this track resonate is how approachable and repeatable the singing feels. It’s a joint you can belt in the shower and feel like you’re almost nailing it, even if you’re not a singer. — Miki Hellerbach

Riley Green ::: Worst Way ::: descriptio.name: Worst Way
Riley Green ::: Worst Way ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: "Worst Way" doesn't need large-scale production to make listeners melt
Riley Green ::: Worst Way ::: descriptio.review: Riley Green set some fans to swooning with this sultry, seductive ballad, which reached No. 1 on Billboard ‘s Country Airplay chart. Built on a framework of straightforward country songcraft and Green’s soulful country voice, “Worst Way” doesn’t need large-scale production to make listeners melt. Green earnestly sketches a scene of anticipating a night of romance with a lover, and his status as the song’s sole writer further elevates the lived-in intimacy. — JESSICA NICHOLSON

Bad Bunny ::: NUEVAYoL ::: description_v.name: NUEVAYoL
Bad Bunny ::: NUEVAYoL ::: description_v.extracted_quote: the sensitive combination of old-school salsa and contemporary reggaeton allowed for a spirited showcase
Bad Bunny ::: NUEVAYoL ::: description_v.review: It shouldn’t be considered a subversive act to have to remind citizens and even leaders that Puerto Rico is an American territory, but that is where we find ourselves with the bizarre controversy over Bad Bunny being booked for the Super Bowl. As if he saw it coming, the artist put together a remarkable album, “DeBÍ TiRAR MáS FOToS,” that spoke to Puerto Rico’s independence, interdependence and pride through both its bold lyrics and fascinating musical hybrids. There was no better example of all of this coming together in rich fashion than “‘NuevaYol,” a salute to Puerto Ricans starting new and different lives in NYC in the past and present — with a nod in the music video, as you see in the image above, to the 1977 unfurling of a flag from the crest of the Statue of Liberty. Meanwhile, the sensitive combination of old-school salsa and contemporary reggaeton allowed for a spirited showcase that made room for actual callouts to Willie Colón, Washington Heights, “Un verano en Nueva York” by El Gran Combo, Frida Kahlo, Jamaican dancehall, rappers El Lápiz Conciente and Big Pun, and Juan Soto. And, oh yeah, to Donald Trump, with a vocal imitator heard on a faux radio broadcast apologizing for his attitude toward immigrants. As if! Bad Bunny’s massive popularity even among non-Spanish speakers means you didn’t have to catch all this backstory to find something thrilling in the way “‘NuevaYol” moves back and forth between traditionalism and sounds that more predictably tickle the ears of today. — WIllman

Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.name: I Want You (Fever)
Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.extracted_quote: The thrill of deception heightens that desire, a flourishing queer love egged on by a fuzzy guitar riff and jittery shakers
Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.review: Momma learned firsthand that being the cheater in the relationship is as cruel as it is perversely liberating. Etta Friedman and Allegra Weingarten—the alt-rock band’s primary songwriters—manipulate a clandestine hookup into something more, delivering their wishes as a breathy demand: “Pick up and leave her/I want you/Fever.” The thrill of deception heightens that desire, a flourishing queer love egged on by a fuzzy guitar riff and jittery shakers. Momma always courted the ’90s in sound, but “I Want You (Fever)” goes further to revive the decade’s tabloid infidelity, too. –Nina Corcoran

Wednesday ::: Townies ::: description_np.name: Townies
Wednesday ::: Townies ::: description_np.extracted_quote: catchy, country-influenced storytelling and the rock-star ability to stretch the word "died" into nine syllables
Wednesday ::: Townies ::: description_np.review: When you flee your hometown, there's a tendency to forget what's in your rearview mirror. But if you stick around, you might find yourself extending an olive branch to your high school frenemies and even your teenage self. North Carolinian Karly Hartzman captures that sentiment here with catchy, country-influenced storytelling and the rock-star ability to stretch the word "died" into nine syllables. —Elle Mannion, NPR

Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.name: I Want You (Fever)
Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.extracted_quote: delivers the punch of an album opener
Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.review: It may be song two on Welcome to My Blue Sky , but it delivers the punch of an album opener. A worthy addition to any '90s alt-rock playlist with its dizzying guitar riffs, dreamy vocal harmonies and an endless catchy chorus sandwiched between Garbage and Pixies. Pure slacker attitude, no poseurs allowed. — Shawn Lucero , Colorado Public Radio's Indie 102.3

Joshua Idehen ::: Mum Does the Washing :.name: Mum Does the Washing
Joshua Idehen ::: Mum Does the Washing :.review: An electrifying burst of joy. The world will always need people like Joshua . -- Bruce, Rough Trade East

Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.name: I Want You (Fever)
Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.extracted_quote: a hypercharged pop-rock anthem that plows through the noise of messy love triangles
Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.review: Sometimes the elaborate, verbose romance ballads aren’t nearly urgent enough for your beating heart, and you just need to cut to the chase. Enter Momma's "I Want You (Fever)," a hypercharged pop-rock anthem that plows through the noise of messy love triangles, gossip, and whatever dissenting opinions lie in their wake: "Everybody knows that this is going down/ We're the talk of the town," core duo Allegra Weingarten and Etta Friedman sing with a convincing, flirty lilt. "I Want You (Fever)" maintains all the thrill of a will-they-won’t-they plotline in spite of the outcome's abundant predictability. — Abby Jones

Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_conseque.name: Taxes
Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_conseque.extracted_quote: lit by tribal percussion, skewed coos, and an explosive mid-point swing — drawing you in with joy even as it crushes with weighty religious imagery
Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_conseque.review: The first sign of an era-defining effort was lit by tribal percussion, skewed coos, and an explosive mid-point swing — drawing you in with joy even as it crushes with weighty religious imagery. — B. Kaye

Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_pas.name: Afterlife
Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_pas.extracted_quote: Led by bright mandolin strums, he recreates that feeling of being a kid and enjoying the simplicity of life
Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_pas.review: Alex G is in the big leagues now. After scoring Jane Schoenbrun’s films and producing Halsey’s latest record, it was inevitable for the Philly musician to graduate from “indie star” to the mainstream. He signed with Sony imprint RCA Records in 2024 and shared Headlights this year. It’s a crapshoot when a beloved indie artist makes this shift. Will they lose the spark that makes them special to appease the masses and suits, disregarding the sound that caused this breakthrough in their career? Thankfully, that’s not the case with Alex G. “Afterlife” is an Americana pop track that retains the magic touch present in his previous work. Led by bright mandolin strums, he recreates that feeling of being a kid and enjoying the simplicity of life. In the lyrics, he looks back at feeling that childlike wonder (“Let me run on afterlife / Filling up the tank with it / Like a kid I ran it past / Rolling in the tiger grass”) as he reflects on beginning a new life “when the light came,” seemingly referencing his new role as a father. — Tatiana Tenreyro

Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.name: I Want You (Fever)
Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.review: Ah, desire. It can feel like you're on fire and completely numb at the same time. Being one-half of a "Will they or won't they?" situation is butterfly-inducing enough, but when one (or both) of you is already in a relationship, the stakes are shot through the roof. That moment of crossing over from friends to lovers, of shutting one door and opening another, takes a lot of guts. Momma imbue "I Want You (Fever)" with the rush of finally making that call, and it sounds like an epiphany. "Pick up and leave her/ I want you, fever" Allegra Weingarten and Etta Friedman command on the chorus, arm-in-arm, ready for destruction. The emotions behind it may be murky and opaque, but "I Want You (Fever)" stands as one of Momma's purest concoctions. — P. Ragusa

Zack Villere, Phoenix James, & Mulherin.name: Issy
Zack Villere, Phoenix James, & Mulherin.extracted_quote: A breath of fresh air vocally and sonically, like the first sunny day of snow
Zack Villere, Phoenix James, & Mulherin.review: A breath of fresh air vocally and sonically, like the first sunny day of snow. -- Sage, Rough Trade NYC

Lily Seabird ::: Arrow ::: description_r.name: Arrow
Lily Seabird ::: Arrow ::: description_r.extracted_quote: snarling with innocence, threatening to collapse at any moment
Lily Seabird ::: Arrow ::: description_r.review: Lily Seabird's second full-length release fuzzes beautifully and burns slowly, but Arrow is a real highlight - snarling with innocence, threatening to collapse at any moment. -- Stan, Rough Trade East

Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.name: I Want You (Fever)
Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.extracted_quote: the shoegaze revival needed its own "Call Your Girlfriend"
Momma ::: I Want You (Fever) ::: descrip.review: Hats off to the Brooklyn-based indie band Momma for realizing the shoegaze revival needed its own “Call Your Girlfriend.”

Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.name: Pussy Palace
Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.extracted_quote: Allen's diaristic, head-turning storytelling is sharp, funny, and affecting
Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.review: Lily Allen dropped what may be the divorce album of the millenium at the end of October, a vulnerable record filled with cathartic, genuinely moving tracks about an open marriage gone wrong. The British artist's confessional West End Girl is based, at least partly, on her split from Stranger Things star David Harbour in 2024, and she co-wrote and recorded it over the course of just 10 days. Despite that accelerated timeline, Allen's diaristic, head-turning storytelling is sharp, funny, and affecting, never more so than on the addictive "P---y Palace," in which she details the "Duane Reade bag with the handles tied / Sex toys, butt plugs, lube inside" and the "hundreds of Trojans" she unearths in her husband’s secret f--- cave. Its chorus — "I didn't know it was your p---y palace" — is still impossible to scrub from our brains. Unlike her doomed relationship, it'll live on forever. — Tiffany Kelly

Cameron Winter ::: Love Takes Miles :::.name: Love Takes Miles
Cameron Winter ::: Love Takes Miles :::.extracted_quote: sounds like the effervescent, anxious, manic spirit that comes alongside overwhelming love
Cameron Winter ::: Love Takes Miles :::.review: It feels crazy to say (though even crazier not to say), but "Love Takes Miles" already seems to have cemented itself as one of the great love songs of the 2020s. Not only does it boast Cameron Winter's usual scattershot, poignant writing at its best ("Love will make you fit it all in the car," anyone?), but the damn song sounds like the effervescent, anxious, manic spirit that comes alongside overwhelming love. Beyond Winter's powerhouse voice and emotive piano playing, the rest of the tune never sits still throughout its three minutes and change. Warped vocal tracks, one-off instrumental lines, and spurts of percussion bubble up throughout, resulting in a swirling production that may very well be romance incarnate. — J. Krueger

Miley Cyrus ::: End of the World ::: des.name: End of the World
Miley Cyrus ::: End of the World ::: des.extracted_quote: [It's] a sparkling, disco-inflected pop song from a star in her sparkling pop-song era
Miley Cyrus ::: End of the World ::: des.review: Despite its dire name, “End of the World” is on the dance-y side of Miley Cyrus’ concept album Something Beautiful . Written for her mom, Tish Cyrus, it shows Cyrus is ready for some lighthearted fun instead of focusing on her negative thoughts and feelings. She’s ready to go to Paris and Malibu and “throw a party like McCartney with some help from my friends.” It’s a sparkling, disco-inflected pop song from a star in her sparkling pop-song era. — Brittany Spanos

Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_pit.name: Afterlife
Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_pit.extracted_quote: he cranks up his music's cinematic scope ... counterweighs the newfound polish by doubling down on his characteristic strangeness
Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_pit.review: Alex G’s musical evolution always feels like one step forward, one step into another dimension. On “Afterlife,” the first single from his major-label debut, he cranks up his music’s cinematic scope: a bright swell of synths; a couple layers of mandolin; his enunciation clearer and more effusive than ever. But he counterweighs the newfound polish by doubling down on his characteristic strangeness: a fake-out ending, a ghostly chorus, a funny little yelped note. As on all of his best tracks, he evokes an emotion whose outlines are blurry—is it nostalgia? Yearning? Regret? It gives you the feeling of trying to describe your earliest childhood memory. But when he sings the chorus, his delivery makes the track disarmingly optimistic. “The light came big and bright/I began another life,” he repeats, like he’s imbuing his songcraft with the glory of the Great Beyond. –Marissa Lorusso

Daryl Johns ::: I'm So Serious ::: descr.name: I'm So Serious
Daryl Johns ::: I'm So Serious ::: descr.extracted_quote: assembles Johns' virtuosity and melodic skills into an irresistible pop-rock singalong
Daryl Johns ::: I'm So Serious ::: descr.review: Jazzy lofi feel-good pop nostalgia (and technically released in 2024). This guy has got chops. It's hard to pick a single song from Mac DeMarco's bass player: Daryl Johns ' self-titled album, but I'm So Serious assembles Johns' virtuosity and melodic skills into an irresistible pop-rock singalong. -- Jacob, Rough Trade Concession (Selfridges)

Miley Cyrus ::: End of the World ::: des.name: End of the World
Miley Cyrus ::: End of the World ::: des.extracted_quote: embraces her affection for glossy '80s pop on what deserved to be as big a hit as her Grammy-winning "Flowers"
Miley Cyrus ::: End of the World ::: des.review: Cyrus embraces her affection for glossy ‘80s pop on what deserved to be as big a hit as her Grammy-winning “Flowers.” The breezy melodic backdrop full of disco swirls and strings complement the song’s point – that we aren’t promised any tomorrows, so best to dance through the apocalypse. Besides, we’d never miss a chance to praise a song that casually name drops Paul McCartney.

Smerz ::: You got time and I got money :.name: You got time and I got money
Smerz ::: You got time and I got money :.extracted_quote: a sing-speaky declaration of unadulterated lust over a Dean Blunt-esque groove
Smerz ::: You got time and I got money :.review: This March, the Norwegian electronic music duo Smerz (Catharina Stoltenberg and Henriette Motzfeldt) released one of the year’s coolest and most sensual ballads, a sing-speaky declaration of unadulterated lust over a Dean Blunt-esque groove. And while the track’s spring release ushered in the airy thrill of a fresh-blooming infatuation, November’s reimagined edit featuring Clairo evokes a lounge singer crooning onstage in a smoky room whose desire has become their demise. — Leah Lu

Miley Cyrus ::: End of the World ::: des.name: End of the World
Miley Cyrus ::: End of the World ::: des.extracted_quote: A disco queen shoegazes into the void
Miley Cyrus ::: End of the World ::: des.review: A disco queen shoegazes into the void. — M.W.

Tyler Childers ::: Dirty Ought Trill :::.name: Dirty Ought Trill
Tyler Childers ::: Dirty Ought Trill :::.extracted_quote: Written in Appalachian style with a roundelay element towards the end, it is perfect.
Tyler Childers ::: Dirty Ought Trill :::.review: Dirty Ought Trill is about a friend of Tyler's called Dylan , a dog trainer and his dog. There are many characters on Snipe Hunter , but this is one of the best, need I say more? Written in Appalachian style with a roundelay element towards the end, it is perfect. -- Locks, Rough Trade East

Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.name: '06 wayne rooney
Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.extracted_quote: Converting inner-city turmoil into pillowy singalong hooks is something that comes natural for Jim Legxacy
Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.review: While Lewisham's Jim Legxacy is often framed as a genre-splicing rapper, he's at his best when he's singing syrupy emo harmonies. See: "'06 wayne rooney," a bright, bouncy pop song that sounds more like the giddy menu music on a Super Monkey Ball game than a grime song. Despite the care-free atmosphere — which echoes the sky-high confidence of the Manchester United footballer Wayne Rooney back in the mid-2000s — Legxacy bleeds his heart out, reminiscing on sleeping on floors and having dirt on his jeans. Converting inner-city turmoil into pillowy singalong hooks is something that comes natural for Jim Legxacy. — Thomas Hobbs

Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_pitchfor.name: Taxes
Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_pitchfor.extracted_quote: "Taxes" was a reckoning with American violence from the nation's largest and loudest city
Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_pitchfor.review: Watching Geese play an impromptu album release show behind The Lot Radio felt like witnessing the moment a band becomes generation-defining. Beyond just the obvious wheres and whens (Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in the fall), it bore a striking resemblance to the parking lot concert the Yeah Yeah Yeahs headlined almost one year after 9/11. Much like “ Our Time ” became a latent command for a city to rise from the ashes, “Taxes” was a reckoning with American violence from the nation’s largest and loudest city—the city that birthed the current face of American authoritarianism, as well as one of the most important rock bands of his second term. Thousands sang along, sweaty open palms and smartphone cameras aloft, swearing that they too would only pay their taxes under threat of crucifixion.

Creeper ::: Headstones ::: description_r.name: Headstones
Creeper ::: Headstones ::: description_r.extracted_quote: explodes in a gloriously singable chorus
Creeper ::: Headstones ::: description_r.review: A darkly playful goth-rock track that explodes in a gloriously singable chorus. It’s the kind of hook that makes you want to belt it out, even in the middle of a spooky night. -- Sam, Rough Trade Office

HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_e.name: Relationships
HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_e.extracted_quote: HAIM doesn't miss when it comes to lead singles, and 'Relationships' proves it once again
HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_e.review: “HAIM doesn’t miss when it comes to lead singles, and ‘Relationships’ proves it once again. With a bass line that lends itself perfectly to a sidewalk strut, it was the ideal kickoff to their unofficially trademarked ‘single summer.’ Complete with a music video starring none other than beloved internet Adonis Drew Starkey, it’s almost like this song was tailor-made for me. Released the day after I went through a breakup of my own, it couldn’t have arrived at a better time—and I highly recommend it.” —Burake Teshome, senior social media editor

lavender ::: lowlight:slowlight ::: desc.name: lowlight:slowlight
lavender ::: lowlight:slowlight ::: desc.extracted_quote: shimmers with lush textures and a euphoric lift
lavender ::: lowlight:slowlight ::: desc.review: lowlight:slowlight shimmers with lush textures and a euphoric lift. It's a dream-pop reverie that blooms in slow motion. Selected for our Rough Trade On The Rise curation, lavender confirmed their rising star status with a mesmerising, close-knit set at our Denmark Street store. One to watch. -- Emily, Rough Trade Office

Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.name: '06 wayne rooney
Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.extracted_quote: takes his sound to stadium rock levels – in a very good way
Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.review: Coming off like a lost cut from a mid-00s FIFA game soundtrack, the standout cut from Jim Legxacy’s brilliant black british music (2025) mixtape sees the UK artist take his sound to stadium rock levels – in a very good way. Set amidst the backdrop of the making of the tape – in the wake of his little sister’s death and other family trauma – the track’s lyrics are a painful and refreshingly open insight into the effects of the chaos that life throws at us, and the ways in which we deal with it (“Mum, I just came from a war / There was a party in my head, I’m breathing all of the cold”). The song, along with the mixtape from which it is lifted, is evidence that Jim Legxacy is one of the most exciting young and upcoming artists working within British music today.

Justin Bieber ::: YUKON ::: description_.name: YUKON
Justin Bieber ::: YUKON ::: description_.extracted_quote: The original track is slinky, sly and easy on the ears ... Bieber's agile falsetto is still manna from pop heaven
Justin Bieber ::: YUKON ::: description_.review: You can partly measure the greatness of a song by the strength of its covers, and “YUKON” produced countless. The original track is slinky, sly and easy on the ears. And then there’s that voice: Over 15 years after his teenybop debut, Bieber’s agile falsetto is still manna from pop heaven. — Tobias Hess

Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.name: '06 wayne rooney
Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.extracted_quote: Over a bedrock of dreamy, emo-tinged alt-pop, [Legxacy] recounts his days of being houseless and unemployed and the ensuing mental toil.
Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.review: How did Jim Legxacy get here? It’s the question the London singer-rapper-producer asks himself repeatedly in the chorus of “‘06 wayne rooney,” the best song from his most recent mixtape, black british music (2025) . Over a bedrock of dreamy, emo-tinged alt-pop, Legxacy recounts his days of being houseless and unemployed and the ensuing mental toil. Thinking through his prior travails leads him to wonder where all the success came from. Rather than relishing the accolades, Legxacy sounds woeful, haunted by something like survivor’s guilt. It’s a poignant reminder that “making it” isn’t always a salve for old wounds. — Grant Sharples

Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.name: '06 wayne rooney
Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.extracted_quote: the perfect example of Jim's power in evoking an era, producing nostalgia and reflecting on real life shit
Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.review: "Kids today will never understand how great Rooney actually was." Except Jim Legxacy . Whilst no explicit reference to Wayne Rooney throughout these lyrics, this track is the perfect example of Jim's power in evoking an era, producing nostalgia and reflecting on real life shit — something which runs across the whole concept of black british music , Jim's third mixtape and debut on XL Recordings. This emo-pop leaning number was a sleeper hit for me amongst a project full of no-skips brilliance. Following the release of the FIFA 06 themed accompanying music video (directed by LAUZZA ), the song received a co-sign from no less than Wayne Rooney himself, cementing the track as a fan favourite and straight into my on repeat playlist. -- Georgia, Rough Trade Office

mark william lewis ::: Brain ::: descrip.name: Brain
mark william lewis ::: Brain ::: descrip.extracted_quote: So atmospheric, and [I] love the fuzzy guitar weaving throughout
mark william lewis ::: Brain ::: descrip.review: My favourite song from one of the best albums of the year. So atmospheric, and I love the fuzzy guitar weaving throughout. -- Jack, Denmark Street

HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_s.name: Relationships
HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_s.extracted_quote: the fattest ass-shaking funk groove of their careers ... Leave those guys in the dust and just dance
HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_s.review: This is hardly the first time the Haim sisters have written a song about being sick to death of “fuckin’ relationships.” But while the vocals and lyrics may scan as weary or worn out, the answer to their woes, delivered over the fattest ass-shaking funk groove of their careers, becomes clear: Leave those guys in the dust and just dance. Winograd

Saiming & styllunknown ::: 2 lungs ::: d.name: 2 lungs
Saiming & styllunknown ::: 2 lungs ::: d.extracted_quote: 2 lungs is the track of the year
Saiming & styllunknown ::: 2 lungs ::: d.review: what's the alternative? dropped in April this year, and this song is one I keep coming back to. Saiming's pen just gets sharper as time goes on, 2 lungs is the track of the year, easy. -- Zak, Rough Trade East

Hayley Williams ::: True Believer ::: de.name: True Believer
Hayley Williams ::: True Believer ::: de.extracted_quote: Rage ... wielded with such an exacting long view ... Over unsettling production that recalls Nine Inch Nails
Hayley Williams ::: True Believer ::: de.review: Rage has always been in Hayley Williams' songwriting toolbelt, but never wielded with such an exacting long view. Over unsettling production that recalls Nine Inch Nails, Paramore's frontperson weeps and seethes for Nashville, a city built on religious systems that still justify colonization and racism. A modern Southern gothic masterpiece. —Lars Gotrich, NPR

Haley Heynderickx & Max Garc\u00eda Cono.name: Boars
Haley Heynderickx & Max Garc\u00eda Cono.extracted_quote: Folk infused cosied by warm guitars and thematically charged lyrics, with a driving rhythm
Haley Heynderickx & Max Garc\u00eda Cono.review: Haley Heynderickx and Max Garcia Conover are back following their 2018 collaboration Among Horses . Folk infused cosied by warm guitars and thematically charged lyrics, with a driving rhythm to bring forward the new year. This song marks a late addition to the year's album releases, but absolutely not one to be missed! -- Kerenza, Rough Trade East

aya ::: off to the ESSO ::: description_.name: off to the ESSO
aya ::: off to the ESSO ::: description_.extracted_quote: nauseating dubstep-meets-gabber ... [with] timbres [that] squelch and burst
aya ::: off to the ESSO ::: description_.review: On her latest full-length for Hyperdub, hexed!, South Londoner aya polishes an unforgiving strain of digital punk. Heavily influenced by emoviolence, it is shaped by phobias, sorcery, and recovery from substance abuse. "off to the ESSO" is nauseating dubstep-meets-gabber. Physically modeled timbres squelch and burst, laying a framework for rapid-fire screaming. It seems to be crafted from rust and oil. — Ted Davis

Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.name: Pussy Palace
Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.extracted_quote: proving what happens when you cross a famously outspoken woman
Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.review: In which Lily Allen lays the smackdown on David Harbour , the ex-husband and Stranger Things actor widely believed to have inspired her monumental comeback album ‘West End Girl’ . “Am I looking at a sex addict?” she wonders over serene synths, proving what happens when you cross a famously outspoken woman. What was he thinking ? JB

Justin Bieber ::: YUKON ::: description_.name: YUKON
Justin Bieber ::: YUKON ::: description_.extracted_quote: a slow-burning soul groove ... proves he's no longer the innocent dreamer, becoming an R&B radio hit in the process
Justin Bieber ::: YUKON ::: description_.review: More than 15 years ago, Justin Bieber burst onto the scene with “Baby” – a pop confection about first love and heartbreak.
