HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.extracted_quote: the vocal lines on "Golden" are the stuff of pop dreams
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.review: This is what it sounds like when a pop culture tidal wave crashes across mediums. It's increasingly rare for this sort of phenomenon to exist outside of a social media bubble that pops as soon as it gets too big. KPop Demon Hunters and "Golden" earn their shine not just because of likes and reshares that pleased the algorithm gods, but because they're good — like, really good . As the big single from the soundtrack, the vocal lines on "Golden" are the stuff of pop dreams, the only shame being that Audrey Nuna doesn't have longer solo contributions as Mira. Even if the Hollywood-ified beat is a bit pre-international-breakout K-pop, it's so undeniable that it'll be heard at b'nai mitzvah, school dances, weddings, gyms, big-box stores, and just about everywhere else for years — at least until KPop Demon Hunters 2 delivers the next big hit. — B. Kaye

Infinite Coles ::: Dad & I ::: descripti.name: Dad & I
Infinite Coles ::: Dad & I ::: descripti.extracted_quote: a heartbreaking but remarkably gracious one-sided dialogue
Infinite Coles ::: Dad & I ::: descripti.review: Misread by some as an angry dis at Infinite Coles’s father, Ghostface Killah, “Dad & I” is a heartbreaking but remarkably gracious one-sided dialogue. “You never talk to me, said I’m not living right/You tell me to man up, yeah/When I put on makeup,” Coles sings over a midtempo beat and spare turntable scratches. The raw emotions at work here are enhanced by the smoothness of the music, which suggests a victory over his father’s homophobia and rejection. Steve Erickson

Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.name: Sugar On My Tongue
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.extracted_quote: Not a second of the funky two-and-a-half-minute track is wasted, as Tyler guides it with ruthless efficiency from tense verse and swelling chorus to simmering bridge and cathartic climax – a pop masterclass from one of its most enthusiastic innovators.
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.review: Periodically, Tyler, The Creator likes to remind his listeners of a couple key facts: he’s extremely horny and, specifically, he’s an oral sex conoisseur. This muse inspired 2021’s outstanding “DOGTOOTH,” and it’s the driving force behind this standout track from Tyler’s clubby surprise album Don’t Tap the Glass . Not a second of the funky two-and-a-half-minute track is wasted, as Tyler guides it with ruthless efficiency from tense verse and swelling chorus to simmering bridge and cathartic climax – a pop masterclass from one of its most enthusiastic innovators. — E.R.B.

HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.artist: HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & KPop Demon Hunters Cast
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.name: Golden
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.extracted_quote: the most gigantic pop song in memory ... a deceptively complex song that never stays in one place for long
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.review: Love it, hate it, will projectile-vomit if you hear it one more time in this or the next lifetime — whichever describes your reaction, you can’t deny “Golden,” the most gigantic pop song in memory. It was practically genetically engineered to be a hit (with seven songwriters and four producers on a song that lasts 3:14) and, as on-the-street evidence from parents, elementary schools and block parties will attest, it’s a bullseye for the same spot in the brain as irresistible candy; not since “Let It Go” has a song so enraptured the under-12 set. Yet that appeal belies its deep songcraft: From the celestial reprise that begins and ends the song to its slalom-like verses leading inexorably to the tease of the “No more hiding” pre-chorus and then into the release of the sky-scraping chorus — which is really, really difficult to sing on key — it is a deceptively complex song that never stays in one place for long. Yet most of all, the indestructible optimism of the lyrics — with their emphasis on self-belief, overcoming obstacles and togetherness, and verses in Korean, no less — dovetails with the music to create a song that’s as powerful as its message. — Jem Aswad

Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.name: Sugar On My Tongue
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.extracted_quote: a slice of wildly horny Italo disco ... the joy of hearing him cut this loose
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.review: Tyler, the Creator’s Don’t Tap the Glass has the feel of a quick corrective, rebounding from the thematic sprawl of Chromakopia to something more focused and fun. “Sugar on My Tongue” is its anti-thesis statement, a slice of wildly horny Italo disco carried, in large part, by the force of Tyler’s personality, the joy of hearing him cut this loose. If there was any doubt about his intentions, he spends the entire self-directed video unlocking a paramour’s inner freak before grooving butt naked in the corner. — C.P.

Dijon ::: Yamaha ::: description_billboa.name: Yamaha
Dijon ::: Yamaha ::: description_billboa.extracted_quote: [A] hug in audio form ... giving off the vibe of someone skipping down the street fresh after making love to their soulmate
Dijon ::: Yamaha ::: description_billboa.review: A hug in audio form, “Yamaha” is surely the highlight of Dijon’s rightly acclaimed Baby LP, with its sparkly piano and sugary vocals (“I’m in love with this particular emotion… and it’s sweet,” he sings, tellingly) giving off the vibe of someone skipping down the street fresh after making love to their soulmate. Towards the end of the song, the drums get heavy and start to sink, while raucous hip-hop ad libs and misfiring synths take over. This tonal shift is reflective of an artist – just like his heroes Prince and D’Angelo – who enjoys creating a chill atmosphere just as much as they enjoy watching it go up in flames. — THOMAS HOBBS

Gabriel Jacoby ::: baby ::: description_.name: baby
Gabriel Jacoby ::: baby ::: description_.extracted_quote: a slow-gem ... feeling Jacoby enunciate every promise like it might be his last
Gabriel Jacoby ::: baby ::: description_.review: Gabriel Jacoby has a rare kind of voice — the kind that, like Pop Smoke's or GIVEON's, only he can manage. “Baby” is a slow-gem from his debut EP gutta child , and I’ve played it in every setting, each time feeling Jacoby enunciate every promise like it might be his last. — KW

Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.name: Sugar On My Tongue
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.extracted_quote: a carnal Italo disco jam buzzing with laser synths, rumbling 808s, and Tyler crooning about cunnilingus like an emo Rick James
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.review: Coming off the ego-death sprawl of last year’s CHROMAKOPIA , Tyler, the Creator’s DON’T TAP THE GLASS is pure body music—horny, kinetic, and unserious by design. The funhouse mirror within is “Sugar on My Tongue,” a carnal Italo disco jam buzzing with laser synths, rumbling 808s, and Tyler crooning about cunnilingus like an emo Rick James. The video—a latex-heavy, kink-positive freakout that climaxes in a body-horror gag—pushes the bit further, turning lust into campy performance art. It’s funny, filthy, and strangely tender, Tyler finding liberation through movement and box-munching his way to nirvana. –Bhanuj Kappal

HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.artist: HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & KPop Demon Hunters Cast
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.name: Golden
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.extracted_quote: a song that gave us hope
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.review:
In the midst of all the political turmoil of 2025, there came a song that gave us hope.

“Golden,” released in early July off the K-Pop Demon Hunters soundtrack, debuted at No. 81 on the Billboard Hot 100 and shot to No. 1 in just six weeks, becoming the breakout hit of 2025.

Co-written and performed by Ejae, the success of the song is even more meaningful, as she trained as a K-Pop idol under SM Entertainment for almost a decade before pivoting her career to behind the spotlight as a songwriter. There are many factors that contribute to the song’s success, like the “Good trumps evil” story plot of K-Pop Demon Hunters and the ever-growing popularity of the genre, but this definitely marks another significant breakthrough in K-Pop. —Shinnie Park

Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.name: Sugar On My Tongue
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.extracted_quote: a showcase for Tyler as a producer, with an irresistible Pharrell-esque elastic beat, plinking synth lines and an increasingly busy arrangement that morphs as the song progresses
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.review: Tyler’s “Don’t Tap the Glass” is ostensibly a dance-music album, but it’s really just vintage Tyler with bouncier beats. “Sugar on My Tongue” is the set’s standout track and also a showcase for Tyler as a producer, with an irresistible Pharrell-esque elastic beat, plinking synth lines and an increasingly busy arrangement that morphs as the song progresses, even incorporating some synthesizer tones we last heard from the Human League — not to mention (conceptual link) what sounds like someone tapping on glass. — Aswad

Dove Ellis ::: Pale Song ::: description.name: Pale Song
Dove Ellis ::: Pale Song ::: description.extracted_quote: [Pale Song is] a showcase for a gifted young singer brimming with gravitas
Dove Ellis ::: Pale Song ::: description.review: Don’t discount the beauty and graceful propulsion of the sophistipop arrangement, but primarily, "Pale Song" is a showcase for a gifted young singer brimming with gravitas. With the sublime, swooning elegance of Jeff Buckley (and hints of Thom Yorke’s neurosis at the peak of his Buckley worship), Dove Ellis summons maudlin electricity here. Not that we should get too caught up in precedents when processing the young Irishman’s lightning-in-a-bottle talent; after all, "The past is like a sign/ A sign it never talks/ A sign you think you've lived/ But it's just stone with a little chalk." — Chris DeVille

JID, Ciara, & EARTHGANG ::: Sk8 (with Ci.name: Sk8 (with Ciara & EARTHGANG)
JID, Ciara, & EARTHGANG ::: Sk8 (with Ci.extracted_quote: a kinetic blast of Atlanta lineage and hometown ambition
JID, Ciara, & EARTHGANG ::: Sk8 (with Ci.review: JID's "Sk8" is a kinetic blast of Atlanta lineage and hometown ambition. Over elastic, ass-shaking bass that nods directly to Kilo Ali's regional classic Organized Bass , JID, Ciara, and EarthGang set a breakneck tempo while honoring the place that shaped them. The crew maps out intercity rivalries and neighborhood tensions through the familiar geography of skating rinks, turning local lore into high-stakes storytelling. Even as they glide through nostalgia, the theme remains survival: who makes it out and who circles back. Ultimately, "Sk8" is a testament to how Atlanta’s culture keeps pushing its most ambitious artists toward greatness. — K. Fitzgerald

Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.name: Sugar On My Tongue
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.extracted_quote: a horny disco-funk groove with Prince-like swagger ... playful, provocative, and steeped in his own brand of futuristic nostalgia
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.review:
Tyler, the Creator operates like an auteur, building entire universes simply because he can. With his ninth studio album, the low-stakes Don’t Tap the Glass , he aimed to make people move.

“Sugar on My Tongue” became the streaming hit from the album. It’s a horny disco-funk groove with Prince-like swagger, paired with a BDSM-themed video that already belongs in the pantheon of great Tyler visuals. He doubled down on his favorite lane: playful, provocative, and steeped in his own brand of futuristic nostalgia. — Kia Turner

Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.name: Sugar On My Tongue
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.extracted_quote: It feels like a hyper candy rush in the best way
Tyler, The Creator ::: Sugar On My Tongu.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of July 2025 : “Surprise! It’s a new album from Tyler, the Creator. The rapper dropped DON’T TAP THE GLASS while still touring his last LP, Chromakopia, and he’s pivoting to ’80s and electronic influences. After all, he made clear that this album is ‘not for sitting still.’ DTTG is an exciting blend of raucous energy from opening track ‘Big Poe’ to the woozy ‘Ring Ring Ring.’ But ‘Sugar on My Tongue’ is a standout for me. It feels like a hyper candy rush in the best way.” —EG

Rachel Platten ::: Begin Again (From The.name: Begin Again (From The Vault)
Rachel Platten ::: Begin Again (From The.extracted_quote: the passion she brings to her vocals ... [Begin Again] showcases that beautifully
Rachel Platten ::: Begin Again (From The.review: It’s hard to believe ten years have passed since the release of Rachel's massive hit “Fight Song.” Inspired by Taylor Swift, Rachel released an EP featuring re-recordings of “Fight Song” and other tracks from her debut album. One of Rachel’s greatest strengths is the passion she brings to her vocals, and the bonus track “Begin Again” showcases that beautifully.

HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_p.name: Relationships
HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_p.extracted_quote: a frustrated loop of hope still bloody from experience
HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_p.review: Three steps forward; two steps back; spinning and spinning; hoping your partner will carry you through the dip—and if they don’t, that you won't get bruised too badly on the way down. On “Relationships,” the Haim sisters go through the motions of the world’s oldest dance. The only problem? Haim (and everyone they know) have been put through these paces before. The song is a frustrated loop of hope still bloody from experience, the beat chopping and stuttering as old wounds color new beginnings. Every element from the babbling samples to the bounce of Este’s bass makes the track’s ground floor incredibly shifty and dynamic, which maps onto the song’s struggle to find its footing. Despite our better judgment, we can’t help falling hard, crashing out, and limping back for more, and from their place in the middle of the dancefloor, Haim are here to commiserate. –Harry Tafoya

Sofia Kourtesis ::: Coraz\u00f3n ::: des.name: Corazón
Sofia Kourtesis ::: Coraz\u00f3n ::: des.extracted_quote: serving smooth dance beats that can easily lull someone into a state of ecstasy
Sofia Kourtesis ::: Coraz\u00f3n ::: des.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of August 2025 : “DJ and producer Sofia Kourtesis has a winner with her new EP Volver. ‘Corazón’ is a sublime taste of the project, serving smooth dance beats that can easily lull someone into a state of ecstasy. It feels like a quick break from the dance floor, while you’re hunched over picnic tables smoking a cigarette outside of the club.” —SM

Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_rs.name: mangetout
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_rs.extracted_quote: a guitar band whose one-liners snap just as hard as its riffs
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_rs.review: You gotta love a guitar band whose one-liners snap just as hard as its riffs. Wet Leg’s new album, Moisturizer , crackles with searing guitars and brash jokes that distill their “make a mess now and worry about it later” philosophy. “Mangetout” chugs out of the gate as Rhian Teasdale makes quick work of a “bottom feeder” with the devastating line, “You wanna fuck me, I know most people do.” If the casual contempt here wasn’t so fun, you’d almost kind of feel bad for the poor fool. — J.D.

Miley Cyrus & Naomi Campbell ::: Every G.name: Every Girl You've Ever Loved (feat. Naomi Campbell)
Miley Cyrus & Naomi Campbell ::: Every G.extracted_quote: Miley Cyrus delivers a fashion anthem with Naomi Campbell, whose spoken word ignites the track
Miley Cyrus & Naomi Campbell ::: Every G.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of May 2025 : “This song completely altered my brain chemistry, and rest assured, I will be posing to it for the remainder of the year. Miley Cyrus delivers a fashion anthem with Naomi Campbell, whose spoken word ignites the track. It’s a true standout on Cyrus’s Something Beautiful , and if she plays her cards right, it could be her next big hit.” —SM

RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.name: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND!
RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.extracted_quote: RAYE sounds even better live than in the studio
RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.review: "I would like a ring!" If you're on TikTok, chances are you've been unable to escape RAYE's viral hit. An incredible performer, RAYE sounds even better live than in the studio. The bridge is a seriously impressive display of vocal ability and breath control — I would love to know how she can get all those words out!

Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_ny.name: mangetout
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_ny.extracted_quote: a grinning kiss-off with sass to spare
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_ny.review: On this grinning kiss-off with sass to spare (“Get lost forever!”), Wet Leg’s Rhian Teasdale leaves the target of her ire staring a little too long at a bag of snow peas before the pun finally dawns on him: Man. Get. Out .

Rauw Alejandro ::: El Cuc0.0 ::: descrip.name: El Cuc0.0
Rauw Alejandro ::: El Cuc0.0 ::: descrip.extracted_quote: a club, reggaeton, and pop track all in one
Rauw Alejandro ::: El Cuc0.0 ::: descrip.review: “This song is addictively perfect. From Rauw Alejandro’s newest project, Cosa Nuestra: Capítulo 0 , it’s a club, reggaeton, and pop track all in one. Consider me absolutely hooked on one of Puerto Rico’s finest.” —SM

Dijon ::: Yamaha ::: description_ew :::.name: Yamaha
Dijon ::: Yamaha ::: description_ew :::.extracted_quote: the most euphoric expression of desire and devotion this year
Dijon ::: Yamaha ::: description_ew :::.review: On "Yamaha," Dijon is in love, but he's also in love with being in love — the irrepressible power it has over him, the way it makes him see the world differently, the ineffability of it. "Bang bang, Annie / I want it more / And more than I can explain / So let's explore," he announces at the start of the track like a thesis statement. What follows is a feat of sonic wizardry as he tries to articulate just how moony and enraptured he is. "Write me in for Friday through Tuesday / I am on call!" he sings over a whirlpool of panting synthesizers, fuzzed-out guitar, chopped-up samples, and thumping percussion straight out of Prince's playbook. Like the myriad thoughts churning in his head, the final product is dizzying, the most euphoric expression of desire and devotion this year. Annie, if you don't call this man, we will. —Jason Lamphier

RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.name: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND!
RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.extracted_quote: a jazzy, soul-pop bop ... theatrical and deliriously addictive
RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.review: Subtlety is the last thing on RAYE’s mind on this jazzy, soul-pop bop, whether she’s rapid-firing cheeky demands for “a diamond ring on my wedding finger” or showing off her formidable vocal chops with the help of a larger-than-life brass band. It’s theatrical and deliriously addictive. ZWP

Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_cr.name: mangetout
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_cr.extracted_quote: The track sizzles with sharp wordplay ... and lands with twanging riffs, chugging guitars and peak burn-book lyrics
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_cr.review: Wet Leg , those Isle of Wight outliers who never looked totally comfortable being the centre of attention, returned in 2025 with the kind of confidence that comes from owning your weirdness. Mangetout , a standout from their bristling second album, Moisturizer , is Wet Leg’s ultimate anti-love song. Don’t be hoodwinked by Rhian Teasdale’s cooing affectations: she serves sardonic sass straight to the jugular of her hapless target, the “ bottom feeder ”, saying: “ You wanna fuck me, I know most people do, ” but “ I really hope you’re gonna get out soon .” Brutal? Oh, for Teasdale, it’s earned. The track sizzles with sharp wordplay – the humble mangetout, her ‘magic beans’ casually handed to the loser, or a phonetic pun, man-get-out – and lands with twanging riffs, chugging guitars and peak burn-book lyrics. In under four minutes, Wet Leg prove they can sting, seduce and mock you all at once. -- Amelia Fearon

Jensen McRae ::: Savannah ::: descriptio.name: Savannah
Jensen McRae ::: Savannah ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: blends Phoebe Bridgers-esque vocals with country-inspired storytelling
Jensen McRae ::: Savannah ::: descriptio.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of March 2025 : “Jensen McRae blends Phoebe Bridgers-esque vocals with country-inspired storytelling on ‘Savannah,’ the kind of acoustic post-breakup ballad that’ll have you look wistfully out the window on car rides. She’s one to keep on your radar.” —EG

Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_nme.name: blade bird
Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_nme.extracted_quote: Glitchy acoustic guitars elevate this song, equally beautiful and despondent, about the pains of yearning
Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_nme.review: In ‘Blade Bird’, Oklou unsheathes her heart. Glitchy acoustic guitars elevate this song, equally beautiful and despondent, about the pains of yearning. Having had to rethink her perceptions of love , the French singer-songwriter leans into stasis and learns that, though it’s a comfortable place to be, the hurt still remains. DP

Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_nm.name: mangetout
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_nm.extracted_quote: with its surreal imagery ... saucy lyrics and sassy pay-off, this indie anthem is quintessential Wet Leg
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_nm.review: A lost Strokes classic? A forgotten ‘Youth & Young Manhood’-era Kings Of Leon banger? ‘Mangetout’ could have passed for either. Except, of course, with its surreal imagery (seemingly inspired by Jack and the Beanstalk), saucy lyrics and sassy pay-off ( “Get lost forever” ), this indie anthem is quintessential Wet Leg . Chef’s kiss! JB

Doechii ::: Nosebleeds ::: description_e.name: Nosebleeds
Doechii ::: Nosebleeds ::: description_e.extracted_quote: Its bold flow and unshakable triumph helped capture a rapper and singer who's fully owning her moment
Doechii ::: Nosebleeds ::: description_e.review: “‘Nosebleeds’ dropped the day after Doechii won her first Grammy, and you can feel that confidence radiate here. Sure, her viral track ‘Anxiety’ was wildly popular this year—and rightfully so—but in terms of the artist staking her claim as one of the sharpest voices in rap right now, I’d venture to say that ‘Nosebleeds’ made a bigger statement. Its bold flow and unshakable triumph helped capture a rapper and singer who’s fully owning her moment.” —BC

Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_el.name: mangetout
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_el.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of July 2025 : “Between this track and ‘Catch These Fists,’ I’m loving the get-the-fuck-away-from-me vibes of Wet Leg’s latest album, Moisturizer. ‘You’re in our way, get lost forever,’ the English duo sings in the chorus—and that’s not the only quotable lyric in this song.” —EG

RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.name: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND!
RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.extracted_quote: She skillfully disassembles the traditional pop song structure with gleeful abandon
RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.review: When Raye plays live, she always performs barefoot with as many band members as she can fit onstage, like a jam session at a crowded, jazzy cocktail party. “Where Is My Husband!” distills that feeling into just over three minutes. She skillfully disassembles the traditional pop song structure with gleeful abandon, ditching lead vocals on the verses and indulging in dramatics on the chorus and bridge with a cameo from her grandmother. Nothing can burst her big band bubble — not even this elusive husband of hers. — L.P.

Lily Allen ::: Ruminating ::: descriptio.name: Ruminating
Lily Allen ::: Ruminating ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: an earworm that perfectly captures that wide-awake, obsessing-over-every-detail feeling
Lily Allen ::: Ruminating ::: descriptio.review: “Lily Allen dropped what is quite possibly the most scorching breakup album of all time in October. West End Girl, her first album in seven years, is a raw, diaristic account written and produced in 10 days during the end of her marriage to actor David Harbour, whom she divorced earlier this year after learning he had been cheating on her. (As she divulges in the album, he talks her into opening their marriage when she’s away for work, but then goes on to break the rules they set; he also kept a secret apartment, despite owning an insanely beautiful brownstone .) It’s hard to pick a favorite song, especially as Allen designed the album to be consumed beginning to end like a storybook, but the one that’s been stuck in my head is the aptly named ‘Ruminating,’ an earworm that perfectly captures that wide-awake, obsessing-over-every-detail feeling we all know too well. Allen’s marriage may have crashed and burned, but as she said , ‘Heartbreak is also a fucking gift,’ especially when it results in music like this.” — Kayla Webley Adler, deputy editor and features director

HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_n.name: Relationships
HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_n.extracted_quote: the song jerks forward and back, questions itself then speeds forward, just like, well, a relationship
HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_n.review: "What's all this talk about relationships?" feels like the question an alien would ask if it came to Earth and didn't get what was going on. But after listening to HAIM's "Relationships," I am also that alien, wondering what the word even means, what the thing even means, what the real deal is with relationships as the song jerks forward and back, questions itself then speeds forward, just like, well, a relationship. — Zoe Kurland , Marfa Public Radio

Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.artist: Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, & DJ Spinz
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.name: Take Me Thru Dere
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.extracted_quote: blends the unabashed fun of Atlanta's 2010s Futuristic Era with two bright, new female rap voices, making for one of the most natural party anthems of the year
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.review: People tried to play like A Futuristic Summa didn’t have bangers when Metro Boomin dropped the mixtape in August — but within a few weeks, Breskii’s infectious “Take Me Thru Dere” proved inescapable. Aided by football touchdown celebrations and the always-reliable college campus scene, “Take Me Thru Dere” blends the unabashed fun of Atlanta’s 2010s Futuristic Era with two bright, new female rap voices (Breskii and YKNIECE), making for one of the most natural party anthems of the year. — K.D.

Oklou ::: thank you for recording ::: de.name: thank you for recording
Oklou ::: thank you for recording ::: de.extracted_quote: a twinkly, futuristic-sounding track that proves simple melodies can still make a big impact
Oklou ::: thank you for recording ::: de.review: “French musician Oklou (born Marylou Vanina Mayniel) made waves this year on the indie scene with her debut album Choke Enough, which is full of sounds that make your ears perk up. One of them is ‘Thank You for Recording,’ a twinkly, futuristic-sounding track that proves simple melodies can still make a big impact.” —EG

Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_bil.name: blade bird
Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_bil.extracted_quote: elegant, ethereal bedroom pop, with each stately hook, chopped-up vocal and gentle drum tap coalescing into a hypnotic blend
Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_bil.review: Although placed as the final track on her debut album Choke Enough , “Blade Bird” serves as the perfect introduction to the French artist’s brand of elegant, ethereal bedroom pop, with each stately hook, chopped-up vocal and gentle drum tap coalescing into a hypnotic blend. Dig deeper into the lyrics, though, and you’ll find plainspoken sorrow on the tension between loving someone and letting them go. — J. Lipshutz

Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.artist: Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, & DJ Spinz
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.name: Take Me Thru Dere
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.extracted_quote: a fun, kinetic number that charts a path of bustin' down and getting ratchet in the club
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.review: Hosted by DJ Spinz, Metro Boomin’s A Futuristic Summer revisits Atlanta’s iconic trends with the city’s latest crop of voices. On “Take Me Thru Dere,” he united Quavo from all-time ATL greats Migos with newcomer YKNIECE (who broke through this year with “Whim Whamiee” alongside PLUTO) for a homage to ATL’s mid-aughts snap-music sound, with Breskii chanting the chorus. It’s a fun, kinetic number that charts a path of bustin’ down and getting ratchet in the club . — M.R.

BANKS & Doechii ::: I Hate Your Ex-Girlf.name: I Hate Your Ex-Girlfriend (feat. Doechii)
BANKS & Doechii ::: I Hate Your Ex-Girlf.extracted_quote: The bass in this track is irresistible, giving the song a swagger that perfectly matches BANKS's sharp, witty lyricism.
BANKS & Doechii ::: I Hate Your Ex-Girlf.review: “There’s something deliciously defiant about ‘I Hate Your Ex-Girlfriend.’ The bass in this track is irresistible, giving the song a swagger that perfectly matches BANKS’s sharp, witty lyricism. It’s cathartic, bitterly relatable, and instantly stuck in my head—which made it the perfect song of choice for many dance sessions I had around my apartment.” —BC

Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.name: Headphones On
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.extracted_quote: a perfect closed loop to get lost in ... a searching sense of awe skimmed from the outer atmosphere of Madonna's Ray of Light
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.review: If you’re gonna make a song about music’s ability to tranquillise pain, it has to live up to that premise itself. Headphones On nails the brief: it’s a perfect closed loop to get lost in, an absent-minded Möbius strip of glassy chillout, a perfectly Britney-like sugary-sad vocal that goes to the kind of emotional truths she was denied – “Wish my mum and dad could’ve been in love / Guess some things weren’t meant to last for ever” – and a searching sense of awe skimmed from the outer atmosphere of Madonna’s Ray of Light. The weightlessness of it seems entirely the point, untethering the year’s finest new pop star from her earthly concerns. LS

Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.artist: Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, & DJ Spinz
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.name: Take Me Thru Dere
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.extracted_quote: this baptism by fire ... belongs to Breskii's rallying cry of a hook and YKNIECE's twerk-positive, all-booties-matter verse
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.review: Rising from the smoldering ash of prolonged RICO trials and premature deaths did not come easy for Atlanta in 2025. The city had to get scrappy. More dirty bird than mythological phoenix. It took a retro reinvention by way of ATL's futuristic past, plus a slew of young, bout-it women shouldering the load, to take us thru dere. Leading the home team in assists is Metro Boomin and Quavo, but this baptism by fire — and all 12 million-and-counting YouTube views — belongs to Breskii's rallying cry of a hook and YKNIECE's twerk-positive, all-booties-matter verse. Yup. Atlanna dun dunn it again. —Rodney Carmichael, NPR

Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.name: Headphones On
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.extracted_quote: Stick this on when you want to romanticise your life
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.review: We always need a pop girlie guilty pleasure song of the summer, and this was the one for me in 2025. Stick this on when you want to romanticise your life. Shout out when Addison Rae visited us at Rough Trade East too! -- Georgia, Rough Trade Office

Addison Rae ::: Money is Everything :::.name: Money is Everything
Addison Rae ::: Money is Everything :::.extracted_quote: [Addison Rae] is asking the right question on 'Money Is Everything': 'Can't a girl have fun?'
Addison Rae ::: Money is Everything :::.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of June 2025 : “Addison Rae is asking the right question on ‘Money Is Everything’: ‘Can’t a girl have fun?’ She can, apparently, and does throughout her star-making debut album, Addison. If you’ve got it, you better flaunt it.” —SM

Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.artist: Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, & DJ Spinz
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.name: Take Me Thru Dere
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.extracted_quote: a beat that will make your ass shake, and a hook built for standing on couches
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.review:
The last few years in Atlanta have been marked by losses, court cases, and cultural wounds. Yet Metro Boomin brought the city back to its heartbeat with “Take Me Thru Dere,” the standout from his retro Futuristic Summa tape.

The track drops listeners right back into the late 2000s, with snap-era energy, a beat that will make your ass shake, and a hook built for standing on couches. Newcomers Breskii and YKNIECE channel a modern Crime Mob spirit, while Quavo and Breskii’s tag-team chorus solidifies it as one of the year’s undeniable party starters. — Kia Turner

Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_npr.name: blade bird
Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_npr.extracted_quote: a grounded outlier and also its best
Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_npr.review: The French artist oklou's album choke enough is full of eerie, nostalgic electronica, but its last song, "blade bird," is a grounded outlier and also its best. A twisted acoustic lullaby, the song's image of a bird with a blade held to its feathers as an allegory for not stifling those we love in a relationship lingers long after choke enough 's end. —Hazel Cills, NPR

Maisie Peters ::: Audrey Hepburn ::: des.name: Audrey Hepburn
Maisie Peters ::: Audrey Hepburn ::: des.extracted_quote: 'Love was a myth, now it's my morning coffee,' she sings
Maisie Peters ::: Audrey Hepburn ::: des.review: “British pop girly Maisie Peters, queen of the breakup bop, ventured into a more mature, folk-tinged sound this year on three singles from her upcoming third album. The biggest surprise of ‘Audrey Hepburn’ is not Peters’s stellar songwriting—her ability to craft specific lyrics around universal emotions has always been top-tier—but her sweet sense of contentment. ‘Love was a myth, now it’s my morning coffee,’ she sings, ‘the one you leave me by my bed.’ Try not to sigh.” — Sara Austin, executive editor

Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.artist: Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, & DJ Spinz
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.name: Take Me Thru Dere
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.extracted_quote: [a] big white tee, Bape-coded Atlanta anthem
Metro Boomin, Quavo, Breskii, YKNIECE, &.review: The hook of this song is something Soulja Boy could crank to, Gucci Mane could go “BRRRR” on, and where Quavo’s hardest ad-libs live. It is a big white tee, Bape-coded Atlanta anthem where the mandate is to throw that wham in a circle “even if it’s lil.” — Kylah Williams

Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.name: Headphones On
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.extracted_quote: smoky, trip-hop bounce brilliantly backing Rae's meditation on the healing power of music
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.review: On her 2023 self-titled EP, Tik Tok microceleb-turned-unlikely pop star Addison Rae proved she was capable of making more than just cheeky viral dances. A clutch feature on a Charli XCX remix and one debut studio album later, Rae went even further in subverting expectations by showing she could deliver bops with depth on top of ones that already dazzled. “Headphones On,” the blissfully downtempo closer on Addison , is one such case, its smoky, trip-hop bounce brilliantly backing Rae’s meditation on the healing power of music amid her turmoil over her parents’ domestic drama. Though it unabashedly wears its influences on its sleeve (Madonna, Britney, Björk), “Headphones On” makes a strong argument for Rae as an artist who can pave her own way, using the sounds and textures of pop’s past not as a crutch but as fuel. Sometimes, escapism is the answer to life’s woes, and Rae’s simple yet elegant acknowledgment of its ephemerality makes the song all the more bittersweet and authentic. — Sam Rosenberg

JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_pit.name: Plastic Box
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_pit.extracted_quote: this one has a rare serving of self-awareness
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_pit.review: The difference between a fine pop song and an excellent one sometimes comes down to attitude. “Plastic Box,” the fourth single from ex-Little Mix artist JADE’s solo debut THAT’S SHOWBIZ BABY! , exists within a long tradition of obsessive love songs, but this one has a rare serving of self-awareness. Atop a rhythm track so arpeggiated it could crimp hair and a piano line that drips like glycerin tears, Jade’s narrator compares her current relationship to her partner’s past ones. Naturally, despair ensues: “It’s irrational and impossible/‘Cause I know you had a life before me.” Still, she persists, asking her object of desire, “Can I have your heart in a plastic box?” a suffocating and unnatural image that’s as touching as it is disconcerting. –Rich Juzwiak

Tame Impala ::: Dracula ::: description_.name: Dracula
Tame Impala ::: Dracula ::: description_.extracted_quote: run from the sun like Dracula ... and stay out all night partying
Tame Impala ::: Dracula ::: description_.review: “A Tame Impala anthem for spooky season? Sign me up. Kevin Parker beckons us to ‘run from the sun like Dracula,’ and stay out all night partying. You don’t have to be a vampire to sink your teeth into this groove.” —EG

JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_npr.name: Plastic Box
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_npr.extracted_quote: A spiritual cousin of Robyn's "Dancing on My Own" with the roles swapped
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_npr.review: A spiritual cousin of Robyn's "Dancing on My Own" with the roles swapped: Our narrator's new relationship is going great, or at least it would be if she could just stop thinking about her lover's glamorous ex. JADE's girl-group pedigree is key here, expertly balancing tones as she admits the truth: "I'm jealous, obsessive, and I wanna burn all your history." —Daoud Tyler-Ameen, NPR

Ariana Grande ::: past life ::: descript.name: past life
Ariana Grande ::: past life ::: descript.extracted_quote: The strings on 'Past Life' make it a particularly enticing song, quickly propelling the track into this editor's Ariana top five.
Ariana Grande ::: past life ::: descript.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of March 2025 : “On eternal sunshine deluxe: brighter days ahead, Ariana Grande dives deeper into the world she began creating last year. All six additional tracks scratch a different Grande itch. The strings on ‘Past Life’ make it a particularly enticing song, quickly propelling the track into this editor’s Ariana top five. She’s done it again.” —SM

Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.name: Headphones On
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.extracted_quote: capturing both the collective yearning for hedonism in pop music in 2025 and the carefree mantra of her debut album in one distant, breathy vocal
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.review: “Life’s no fun through clear waters,” Addison Rae almost sighs on ‘Headphones On’, capturing both the collective yearning for hedonism in pop music in 2025 and the carefree mantra of her debut album in one distant, breathy vocal. With notes of dreamy ’90s R&B and Madonna’s ‘Ray Of Light’ era, pop’s brightest new star gives us plenty of reason to tune in. LM

Justin Bieber & Dijon ::: DEVOTION ::: d.name: DEVOTION
Justin Bieber & Dijon ::: DEVOTION ::: d.extracted_quote: a swooning ode to true love that'll make you ask yourself, 'Me and who?'
Justin Bieber & Dijon ::: DEVOTION ::: d.review: “‘Devotion’ topped my Spotify Wrapped with an embarrassing number of plays. The collab with the insanely talented Dijon is a swooning ode to true love that’ll make you ask yourself, ‘Me and who?’” — Claire Stern Milch, digital director

JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_gua.name: Plastic Box
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_gua.extracted_quote: Her account of feeling irrationally insecure about your relationship compared with what your partner may have had with their ex is crushingly well observed
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_gua.review: It’s been 84 years since Robyn released new music – actually, seven, now concluded by the Swede’s great comeback Dopamine , which came out after we voted. But until then, aficionados of cry-as-you-dance pop were well fed by this stomping synth weepie from Jade’s ( largely much wilder ) debut album. Her account of feeling irrationally insecure about your relationship compared with what your partner may have had with their ex is crushingly well observed – as is her honesty about torturing yourself over it by obsessively reading their old love letters. LS

Sudan Archives ::: DEAD ::: description_.name: DEAD
Sudan Archives ::: DEAD ::: description_.extracted_quote: a visceral, vibrant, and hypnotic declaration ... capturing Sudan Archives' fearless blend of violin-infused exploration and dance-floor energy
Sudan Archives ::: DEAD ::: description_.review: “From the very first note, ‘Dead’ feels like a visceral, vibrant, and hypnotic declaration. It captures Sudan Archives’ fearless blend of violin-infused exploration and dance-floor energy, making it one of the year’s most inventive tracks. It’s dynamic and emotionally charged, giving me reason to return to the song again and again.” —BC

RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.name: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND!
RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.extracted_quote: blending the universal quest for eternal love with big band jazz and Motown aesthetics
RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.review: It’s nearly impossible to go wrong when blending the universal quest for eternal love with big band jazz and Motown aesthetics — especially when RAYE (alongside co-producer Mike Sabath) is in the driver’s seat . Steered by a relentless rap-sung cadence that plays into the frantic search for a life partner, RAYE blitzes through three-and-a-half jam-packed minutes of thrilling live instrumentation, evanescent lyrical quips and an ambitious mix that’s mostly devoid of a proper lead vocal. At once timely and timeless, “Where Is My Husband” proves RAYE can fashion a banger (and a hit!) out of virtually any sound. — K.D.

JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_pas.name: Plastic Box
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_pas.extracted_quote: reveals a vulnerable and headstrong performer beneath the shiny costume and contagious dance moves
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_pas.review: The vibe of JADE’s debut album bursts open on “Plastic Box,” a song confirming her pop diva status. It’s an emotional upheaval charged with cunty beats, written by JADE at the beginning of her current relationship with singer Jordan Stephens once she discovered love letters he’d written for an ex-girlfriend. “Plastic Box” fits right into That’s Showbiz Baby! ’s splashy maximalism but reveals a vulnerable and headstrong performer beneath the shiny costume and contagious dance moves. Perhaps an antidote to the great divide, “pop star” means the same thing in every language. In my brief lifetime, I’ve been lucky enough to see dozens of them mean the world to someone around me. You can’t really describe what that’s like. You just have to be there and remember it. I can’t believe “Plastic Box” exists and that I get to remember it. Its place on an album as provocative, contrasting, and tastefully egotistical as Showbiz is a reminder that JADE excitingly embraces playful, purposeful strains of dance music. As she told me in the summer, “every single song is something I’ve wanted to say.” On “Plastic Box,” her pop brilliance and loving obsessions needfully vibrate from every rooftop. — Matt Mitchell

Eli ::: Glitter ::: description_elle :::.name: Glitter
Eli ::: Glitter ::: description_elle :::.extracted_quote: With a hook as catchy as any '90s girl-group anthem, the pop princess's latest single breaks the themes and sonic landscape of her debut album, wide open.
Eli ::: Glitter ::: description_elle :::.review: “Get ready for Eli world domination in 2026. With a hook as catchy as any ’90s girl-group anthem, the pop princess’s latest single breaks the themes and sonic landscape of her debut album, Stage Girl, wide open. It’s an earworm I never want to go away! Replay after replay, your insides are sure to shimmer. And in case you needed another reminder to break up with that man, just give this song a listen and ‘wash the boy right out of your clothes.’” —BT

Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.name: Headphones On
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.extracted_quote: echoing Janet Jackson and Madonna deep cuts, with a breathy spoken-word bridge that channels Britney's In the Zone
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.review: Headphones On sounds like a lost late-90s radio hit, echoing Janet Jackson and Madonna deep cuts, with a breathy spoken-word bridge that channels Britney’s In the Zone . Rae has never shied away from referencing pop’s greats, nor from wanting to join their ranks. The mantra-like song reads like an inner monologue as she reaches for their world, romanticising her reality and daydreaming her worries away – whether it’s her parents’ unhappy marriage or fears of being eclipsed by a new It Girl on the block. “Addison gets it. She gets us ,” one comment reads on its video, depicting a pink-haired Rae riding an imaginary horse through Reykjavík’s stark landscapes as she escapes into her own world after a shift at the supermarket. After proving this year that she really can reinvent herself as a pop star, Headphones On casts her as a vessel for her own fantasy – and her listeners’ too. -- Rosie Byers

JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_nme.name: Plastic Box
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_nme.extracted_quote: taps into Robyn's disco-desolation, torturing herself by comparing herself to a partner's exes
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_nme.review: On this glorious happy-sad banger, new maximalist pop standard-bearer JADE taps into Robyn’s disco-desolation, torturing herself by comparing herself to a partner’s exes and wishing she could erase his relationship history like lines from an Etch-a-Sketch. Her emotive vocals sell the feeling of irrational thoughts turning to knives. GR

Laufey ::: Tough Luck ::: description_el.name: Tough Luck
Laufey ::: Tough Luck ::: description_el.extracted_quote: stepping out of her comfort zone while staying true to her signature, romantic sound
Laufey ::: Tough Luck ::: description_el.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of May 2025 : “Laufey told ELLE that her next album, A Matter of Time, would have ‘more extroverted’ sounds, and this single proves it. After teasing that climactic bridge on TikTok ahead of the release, the jazz-loving artist unveiled the full song and showed her stepping out of her comfort zone while staying true to her signature, romantic sound. With rhythmic guitar strums and dreamy orchestrations and harmonies, Laufey calls out an ex’s tendency to ‘lie and cheat just like you did to the actress before me, oops, she doesn’t even know.’ Tea! Has a diss track ever sounded this beautiful?” —EG

Zukenee ::: BROMANCE ::: description_fad.name: BROMANCE
Zukenee ::: BROMANCE ::: description_fad.extracted_quote: a bouncy synth ode to getting money and treating it like a brother
Zukenee ::: BROMANCE ::: description_fad.review: Atlanta’s Zukenee had the kind of year that makes you feel good for betting on him early. One of the earliest songs he can thank for that is “BROMANCE,” a bouncy synth ode to getting money and treating it like a brother. Combined with knocking production from Desmos, sxprano, and Cade, what more could a rising star want? — DG

PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.name: WHIM WHAMIEE
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.extracted_quote: a no-frills, in-your-face riot ... the undisputed soundtrack for unadulterated fun
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.review: When PLUTO and YKNIECE dropped “Whim Whamiee” on the hip-hop world, they gave the genre a burst of much-needed adrenaline. The punchy club banger is a no-frills, in-your-face riot that rocketed both women into overnight celebrity status. Social media devoured “Whim Whammie,” as the phrase morphed into a cultural siren for unfiltered debauchery. Whether women needed a reason to “get a bag” or throw it back in the club, “Whim Whamiee” became the undisputed soundtrack for unadulterated fun in 2025. — C.L.

PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.name: WHIM WHAMIEE
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.extracted_quote: it's Pluto and YK Niece's chemistry swirling in the background that cemented the Atlanta anthem as song of the summer
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.review: My favorite comment buried in the recesses of the official video for Pluto and YK Niece’s smash hit reads as follows: “I play this when the homies ain’t around,” punctuated with various laughing and shrugging emojis, and driven home with four flames to boot. Overpowering the latent shame of insecure men is just a sliver of the addictive power “WHIM WHAMIEE” holds. The duo bounds alongside an inspired Zaytoven beat that would have made D4L break into tears of joy, spitting with delirium about putting their men in Lululemon, letting the Draco sing with reckless abandon, and throwing it in dudes’ faces without a second thought. The bars could stand as magnetic quotables on their own, but it’s Pluto and YK Niece’s chemistry swirling in the background that cemented the Atlanta anthem as song of the summer: the endless stream of ad-libs leaves phrases that stick in your hippocampus like you’re the Manchurian Candidate. This all to say: fellas, play this when the homies are around—it’s OK, we’re all doing it. –Matthew Ritchie

PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.name: WHIM WHAMIEE
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.extracted_quote: Her homage is intergenerationally infectious, the mix of icy Zaytoven production and buoyant, drawled flows conjuring the spirit of Freaknik
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.review: "WHIM WHAMIEE" feels like Atlanta trap kismet: A 21-year-old hairstylist stumbling upon a YouTube beat that sampled D4L rapper Mook B's "Whim Wham," a song traced back from her favorite local dance. Her homage is intergenerationally infectious, the mix of icy Zaytoven production and buoyant, drawled flows conjuring the spirit of Freaknik. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Youth Lagoon ::: Gumshoe (Dracula From A.name: Gumshoe (Dracula From Arkansas)
Youth Lagoon ::: Gumshoe (Dracula From A.extracted_quote: poignantly strings together fragments from his youth into a yarn that reflects how children process the world and all of its darkness
Youth Lagoon ::: Gumshoe (Dracula From A.review: On “Gumshoe (Dracula from Arkansas),” a standout cut from Youth Lagoon’s Rarely Do I Dream , Trevor Powers poignantly strings together fragments from his youth into a yarn that reflects how children process the world and all of its darkness: “It was the world I had/Scenes I wish I never saw/The summer taught me that/Life’s a baseball bat to the jaw.” Eric Mason

Dave ::: The Boy Who Played the Harp :::.name: The Boy Who Played the Harp
Dave ::: The Boy Who Played the Harp :::.review:
Real bravery lies in recognizing the moments when you’ve acted out of fear. Dave leans into those uncomfortable truths on the title track of The Boy Who Played the Harp . The song centers on a simple question: “What would I do in the next generation?” He traces his family lineage, measuring the struggles of his ancestors against the challenges he faces today.

He acknowledges that he has the ability to speak out against oppressive regimes, yet hesitates because doing so could jeopardize his livelihood. The reality is that more people might stand for something if they first understood the roots of their own fear. –Jordan Rose

PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.name: WHIM WHAMIEE
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.extracted_quote: channels the golden age of Atlanta trap rap reimagined for a new generation—this time with women at the forefront
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.review: This year desperately needed a song that made you want to dance on tables, scream-rap the lyrics, and engage in random acts of violence. Enter Pluto and YKNiece. Built around a sample of OJ da Juiceman’s “Wham Bam,” Pluto and YKNiece gave the girls another anthem while inspiring a wave of remixes, from Sexyy Red’s official version to Lizzo’s mega-viral stab at it. Their ass-shaking, fist-swinging single channels the golden age of Atlanta trap rap reimagined for a new generation—this time with women at the forefront. — Jade Gomez

Veeze ::: L.O.A.T ::: description_rs :::.name: L.O.A.T
Veeze ::: L.O.A.T ::: description_rs :::.extracted_quote: a two-minute showcase for the Detroit rapper to flip imaginative metaphors
Veeze ::: L.O.A.T ::: description_rs :::.review: “You better stop doing that pocket watchin’, keep a good eye on your hoe,” Veeze warns in his typically slurred vocal style on “L.O.A.T.” Set over skittering 8-bit digital production by Rocaine, the track — an acronym for “lamest for all time” — is a two-minute showcase for the Detroit rapper to flip imaginative metaphors, from comparing himself to Iron Man to referencing Destiny Child’s “Cater 2 U,” while satiating fans eager for a follow-up to his acclaimed 2023 breakout, Ganger . — M.R.

Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.name: Headphones On
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.extracted_quote: four minutes of dreamy, breathy, downtempo heaven that seems designed to play on repeat
Addison Rae ::: Headphones On ::: descri.review: In an interview with Variety, flanked by producers Luka Kloser and ELVIRA, Addison Rae revealed that the recording session for “Headphones On” was immediately followed by an emergency flight to the doctor. Not that you can tell by the song itself: four minutes of dreamy, breathy, downtempo heaven that seems designed to play on repeat. “But if you listen to the song, compared to the rest of the music…” she explained. “It’s a little bit more, like, on the verge of tears.”

PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.name: WHIM WHAMIEE
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.extracted_quote: "WHIM WHAMMIE" still seems destined for canonization alongside "F.N.F.," "Poundtown," and "Munch"
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.review:
It’s ironic, though not unprecedented, that the runaway success of an anthem about rolling “deep as fuck” with your girls drove a wedge between rising Southern rappers YK NIECE and PLUTO; seeing the pair awkwardly reunite in Atlanta a couple months ago offered a window into the lives of Fleetwood Mac stans circa 1976. Despite the off-wax drama, “WHIM WHAMMIE” still seems destined for canonization alongside “F.N.F.,” “Poundtown,” and “Munch” — breakout singles that catapulted hip-hop unknowns into national fame seemingly overnight.

Over a ridiculous Zaytoven flip, PLUTO and YK Niece feed off and amplify each other, a cascade reaction between the former’s wicked pengame and the latter’s undeniable energy. Though the duo has clearly decided they’re happier apart, for two adrenalizing minutes they were invincible together. — VM

RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.name: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND!
RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.extracted_quote: an electrifying masterclass in vocal delivery
RAYE ::: WHERE IS MY HUSBAND! ::: descri.review: In a year that Vogue declared that having a boyfriend is officially embarrassing, RAYE has boldly announced that she is on the hunt for The One. Accompanied by her unrivalled big-band jazz meets pop drama production style, RAYE pleads with the listener: “Where the hell is my husband? What is taking him so long to find me?” before she manifests a big rock for her wedding finger, and laments the “lonely acrobatics” of singledom. It is an electrifying masterclass in vocal delivery: she jabbers and scats through her tongue-twisting lyrics, all while channelling the seemingly collective feeling among young women right now that it is becoming harder than ever to find Mr Right. One thing is clear: RAYE’s future husband must make himself known immediately. Ellie Muir

Saba, No ID, Love Mansuy, Ogi, & Smino :.artist: Saba, No ID, Love Mansuy, Ogi, & Smino
Saba, No ID, Love Mansuy, Ogi, & Smino :.name: a FEW songs (feat. Love Mansuy, Ogi, and Smino)
Saba, No ID, Love Mansuy, Ogi, & Smino :.extracted_quote: loops and bounce; stabs of a half-dozen different keys pierce through a soul-stirring vocal harmony
Saba, No ID, Love Mansuy, Ogi, & Smino :.review: From the Private Collection of Saba and No ID is a family album—a vault of a Midwestern great’s most trusted collaborators. The beats scoring its closer, “a FEW songs,” loop and bounce; stabs of a half-dozen different keys pierce through a soul-stirring vocal harmony from Ogi. Love Mansuy’s “shit is temporary” chorus bridges Saba’s verse into Smino’s, as they rap about their long search for a come-up in a changing ‘hood (“We been on our way—fashionably late, past tense”). “Back in the day, we was on blogs and searching for different perspectives,” Saba spits. “And Benjamins and Jacksons, ‘cause it was a recession.” Smino picks up the story down the road, talking about going “from North Side to Porsche rides to courtside to sold-out shows” and flashes a double entendre of “We bae” and Wee-Bay from The Wire . “a FEW songs” spans a decade or two and ends in affirmative revelation: “It’s okay to change it all, so beautiful,” Ogi hums on a piano fadeout. Saba and his counterpart No ID should make a thousand songs together. But if I can only have one for the rest of my life, I’ll pick “a FEW songs” every time. — Matt Mitchell

dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.name: Special
dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.extracted_quote: full of grace and fully imagined, as if it had always been with us
dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.review: dexter in the newsagent’s “Special” arrived as few songs do: full of grace and fully imagined, as if it had always been with us, waiting for the right artist to fulfill its inevitability. The London singer floats over finger-picked acoustic guitar and muted Jersey club percussion, detailing a love strong enough to upend her sense of self. “I would give up so much in my life/Just so I can say you’re mine,” she declares with the airy confidence of the truly obsessed. “Special” is a patient and entrancing romantic opus that’s as sure of itself as dexter is of the love she’s set to stake her life on. –Brady Brickner-Wood

Samia ::: Bovine Excision ::: descriptio.name: Bovine Excision
Samia ::: Bovine Excision ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: a slow-burning odyssey into the indie rocker's mind
Samia ::: Bovine Excision ::: descriptio.review: This standout off Samia’s excellent LP Bloodless has it all: Diet Dr. Pepper, Raymond Carver, leeches, and Degas dancers. It’s a slow-burning odyssey into the indie rocker’s mind — she sings that she wants to “be impossible” before the song culminates in the refrain, “And drained, drained bloodless.” Samia uses the bizarre concept of cattle mutilation to explore themes of patriarchal society and purity — as she put it, “this clinical pursuit of emptiness.” The result is the prettiest song about slaughtered livestock to date. — Angie Martoccio

Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_ste.name: blade bird
Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_ste.extracted_quote: "blade bird" is the project's strongest performance of both emotional tension and instrumental weightlessness
Oklou ::: blade bird ::: description_ste.review: Choke Enough is paradoxically both effervescent and ash grey, and closer "blade bird" is the project's strongest performance of both emotional tension and instrumental weightlessness. Plucked acoustic guitar, cyborgian bird squeaks, and soft backing vocals echo while Oklou sings a moving parable about possession’s temptation. Throughout, she fights the instinct to cage what she loves, remembering the wildness that initially enchanted her. "I need you now, and I'll miss you when/ The wings I fell in love with take you away again," she tenderly sings. She has to let things go to experience the joy of their return. — Margaret Farrell

Treaty Oak Revival ::: Bad State of Mind.name: Bad State of Mind
Treaty Oak Revival ::: Bad State of Mind.extracted_quote: hits new levels of self-loathing catharsis on the inspired chorus
Treaty Oak Revival ::: Bad State of Mind.review: The year’s best hard rock song came courtesy of West Texas country boys Treaty Oak Revival, with an uncanny understanding of musical dynamics, lyrical tension, and how to make those crunchy guitars really f–kin’ crunch . “Bad State of Mind” is arresting from frontman Sam Canty’s a cappella lead-in, and hits new levels of self-loathing catharsis on the inspired chorus: “You and I in a room is a bad combination/ And any call after two is a bad conversation.” Call it southern-fried grunge, or just call it some of the most exciting guitar-based (like, really guitar-based) music happening right now. — A.U.

dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.name: Special
dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.extracted_quote: a delightful, patient, encouraging and nourishing whisper of a love song
dexter in the newsagent ::: Special :::.review: What a delightful, patient, encouraging and nourishing whisper of a love song from a London newcomer with big ideas about R&B hovering just below a very unassuming mien.

corook ::: THEY! ::: description_slant :.name: THEY!
corook ::: THEY! ::: description_slant :.extracted_quote: emotionally direct yet layered lyrics and seamless command of songcraft reveal talents well beyond their years
corook ::: THEY! ::: description_slant :.review: At first glance, “They!”—like much of self-described “serious person” Corook’s output—seems straightforward: brightly melodic, instrumentally stripped-back, structurally simple. But appearances can be deceiving: The artist’s emotionally direct yet layered lyrics and seamless command of songcraft reveal talents well beyond their years. That these gifts are deployed in service of such a humane, celebratory—and, depressingly, much-needed—message of acceptance is a welcome bonus. Attard

Rauw Alejandro ::: Carita Linda ::: desc.name: Carita Linda
Rauw Alejandro ::: Carita Linda ::: desc.extracted_quote: a soulful bomba yubá rhythm that never lets up
Rauw Alejandro ::: Carita Linda ::: desc.review: Rauw Alejandro’s 2024 album, Cosa Nuestra — an exploration of his boricua roots and the rich Nuyorican culture of decades past — ushered in a new era of maturity for the multitalented artist. The opening track of its companion album, Capítulo 0 , combines the romanticized lore of being crazy in love and a soulful bomba yubá rhythm that never lets up. Shot in spectacular natural scenery, the song’s video evokes the placid spirituality of a childhood spent in Puerto Rico — an antidote to loneliness . — E.L.

Jerskin Fendrix ::: Jerskin Fendrix Free.name: Jerskin Fendrix Freestyle
Jerskin Fendrix ::: Jerskin Fendrix Free.extracted_quote: Half-rapped, backed by an insane jazz-punk instrumental, and boasting lyrics about washing your dick in the sink and looking like George Clooney, "Jerskin Fendrix Freestyle" might hold the title for the most bananas track of 2025
Jerskin Fendrix ::: Jerskin Fendrix Free.review: Half-rapped, backed by an insane jazz-punk instrumental, and boasting lyrics about washing your dick in the sink and looking like George Clooney, "Jerskin Fendrix Freestyle" might hold the title for the most bananas track of 2025. — J. Krueger

Jason Schmidt ::: 7 Stars ::: descriptio.name: 7 Stars
Jason Schmidt ::: 7 Stars ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: blends acoustic and folk elements with story-driven lyrics and Jason's charismatic vocals
Jason Schmidt ::: 7 Stars ::: descriptio.review: After seeing Jason’s performance as Sodapop Curtis in Broadway’s The Outsiders (if you haven't seen this musical, you must!), I immediately dove into his original music. "7 Stars" blends acoustic and folk elements with story-driven lyrics and Jason's charismatic vocals. To learn more about his time on Broadway and his approach to songwriting, check out my interview with Jason.

Cameron Winter ::: Drinking Age ::: desc.name: Drinking Age
Cameron Winter ::: Drinking Age ::: desc.extracted_quote: sounds like crying on your birthday ... a flatlining realization that this is life for the time being
Cameron Winter ::: Drinking Age ::: desc.review: Cameron Winter is 23 years old, and that fact seems more relevant when listening to “Drinking Age,” the most harrowing track on Heavy Metal . “Today I met who I’m gonna be / from now on and he’s a piece of shit,” he laments over the faintness of his piano, with the same stinging actuality that Johnny Cash spoke from in “Hurt.” Winter accepts adulthood, tackling the underbelly of a coming of age tale. “Drinking Age” sounds like crying on your birthday and taking your line of the MTA routinely each day—a flatlining realization that this is life for the time being. At the end, Winter’s voice ruptures into unintelligible wailings and vibrating lip smacks, a beautifully cathartic way of dealing with the avalanche of awareness that is hitting him all at once. As his generation begins to enter the workforce and grapples with this reality, myself included, the song is both painfully relatable but comforting to know that someone is searching for the meaning behind it all. — Alli Dempsey

Pearly Drops & Cub Sport ::: Mermaid :::.name: Mermaid
Pearly Drops & Cub Sport ::: Mermaid :::.extracted_quote: an operatic coda that transforms "Mermaid" into something of edenic proportions
Pearly Drops & Cub Sport ::: Mermaid :::.review: Helsinki’s Sandra Tervonen and Jusso Malin bring their grooviest, murkiest pop fable yet: one of a recluse who’s descended into the underbelly of Los Angeles because she “needs to be weird for the next few years.” Then, Cub Sport’s Tim Nelson delivers an operatic coda that transforms “Mermaid”’s manhole into something of edenic proportions. — SM

Factory Floor ::: Tell Me ::: descriptio.name: Tell Me
Factory Floor ::: Tell Me ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: the throb of 'Tell Me', with its weirdly catchy stab of a melody line
Factory Floor ::: Tell Me ::: descriptio.review: After their return for the 2024 MUTEK festival, Factory Floor have kept it slow and steady with occasional gigs and releases on Erol Alkan’s Phantasy label. Their set at Corsica Studios was a live highlight of the year, with the venue’s always thunderous PA and the addition of a second drummer, alongside Gabe Gurnsey and Nik Void, turning the crowd into a sweating mess. It was all well and good hearing the likes of ‘Two Different Ways’ and ‘Fall Back’, but it was the throb of ‘Tell Me’, with its weirdly catchy stab of a melody line, that was the highlight.

Oli XL & Chanel Beads ::: LOVE & POP :::.name: LOVE & POP
Oli XL & Chanel Beads ::: LOVE & POP :::.extracted_quote: a love song rendered through shimmering scraps of signal
Oli XL & Chanel Beads ::: LOVE & POP :::.review: This collaboration between Stockholm producer Oli XL and Chanel Beads feels like a dream half-corrupted by static. Sharing its name with Hideaki Anno’s 1998 coming-of-age classic – and echoing the film’s handheld, lo-fi aesthetic in its video – the track leans into a kind of enjoyably warped digital intimacy, where affection arrives blurred or half-processed. Oli’s scratchy, glitchy hijinks – think bright folktronica, skittish IDM and Dilla wonkiness – warp and twist the New York band’s sad romance and playful lyrics, flipping a sped-up sample from Chanel Beads’ Idea June from cloud-soft vocal into something approaching a proper pop hook. With longing, desirous lyrics – “ I heard that you’re bad now/ I think I’m glued onto your back now ” – set against warped, erratic beats, this is a love song rendered through shimmering scraps of signal. -- Hollie Hilton

Silvana Estrada ::: Dime ::: description.name: Dime
Silvana Estrada ::: Dime ::: description.extracted_quote: the sound of the freedom that emotional realization enables
Silvana Estrada ::: Dime ::: description.review: Before writing “Dime,” Silvana Estrada thought of anger as wholly unproductive. But, making the song, which expresses her deep frustration at a lover’s inability to invest completely in a relationship, she learned to appreciate and embody the emotion. “Dime,” from Vendrán Suaves Lluvias , is jubilant, a symphony of strings, horn, and Estrada’s lilting, poised falsetto. It is the sound of the freedom that emotional realization enables: to understand and respect exactly how you feel and why, to be yourself fully. –Vrinda Jagota

Coco Jones ::: Taste ::: description_rs.name: Taste
Coco Jones ::: Taste ::: description_rs.extracted_quote: samples and interpolates rather brilliantly ... [as she] gives herself over to a lover, pushing past the more classic R&B of her previous work
Coco Jones ::: Taste ::: description_rs.review: “I figured it was gonna ruffle feathers, because of course it’s something so sacred,” Coco Jones told Rolling Stone ‘s Brian Hiatt recently . The sacred text in question? Britney Spears’ “Toxic,” which the rising R&B star samples and interpolates rather brilliantly on this single. Some pop fans may have been bothered, but Jones sounds confident and convincing as she gives herself over to a lover, pushing past the more classic R&B of her previous work in the process. — Christian H oard

Silvana Estrada ::: Dime ::: description.name: Dime
Silvana Estrada ::: Dime ::: description.extracted_quote: carries us through an emotional unraveling that hits home for so many
Silvana Estrada ::: Dime ::: description.review: Love, heartbreak and loss can sit so heavy on the mind, but Silvana Estrada's way of releasing all those layered feelings is special. "Dime" carries us through an emotional unraveling that hits home for so many. She's giving herself and us permission to let go, so let go. — Kenny Perez , Radio Milwaukee

billy woods, Bruiser Wolf, & SadhuGold :.name: BLK XMAS
billy woods, Bruiser Wolf, & SadhuGold :.extracted_quote: the most compelling gut punch you'll hear this year
billy woods, Bruiser Wolf, & SadhuGold :.review: billy woods' magnificent album GOLLIWOG plays like a horror movie, with this song as its most harrowing scene. Detroit poet and MC Bruiser Wolf sets the stage, describing the constant perils of life in the hood, before woods tells in heartbreaking detail the story of a family evicted a week before Christmas: the cold, arduous crosstown trek to a shelter, the neighbors scavenging the personal effects left behind. It's the most compelling gut punch you'll hear this year, from two of hip-hop's most talented writers. — Michael Pollard , WNXP

billy woods, Bruiser Wolf, & SadhuGold :.name: BLK XMAS
billy woods, Bruiser Wolf, & SadhuGold :.extracted_quote: vividly detailing the struggle to get by in poor Black neighborhoods ... deployed in service of harrowing real-life scenes
billy woods, Bruiser Wolf, & SadhuGold :.review: "Nightmares didn't come during dreams," Bruiser Wolf recollects up top. Over wobbling piano chords and a woozy backbeat, "BLK XMAS" finds him vividly detailing the struggle to get by in poor Black neighborhoods, his cartoonish diction this time deployed in service of harrowing real-life scenes. Then billy woods swings in to detail the aftermath of the inevitable crash, when a life's worth of possessions are spread out on the sidewalk to be picked through by passersby. Like all of GOLLIWOG , it's worth thinking long and hard about; just don't add it to your holiday playlists. — Chris DeVille

No Joy ::: Garbage Dream House ::: descr.name: Garbage Dream House
No Joy ::: Garbage Dream House ::: descr.extracted_quote: uses those familiar rushes of feedback to create something bucolic in its prettiness, before upending entirely into a thunderous plunge
No Joy ::: Garbage Dream House ::: descr.review: Much has been made of the growing resurgence of shoegaze within the contemporary indie palette, but few are making quite such interesting use of it as No Joy does on her latest record Bugland . ‘Garbage Dream House’, the album’s opener, uses those familiar rushes of feedback to create something bucolic in its prettiness, before upending entirely into a thunderous plunge.

Friendship ::: Tree of Heaven ::: descri.name: Tree of Heaven
Friendship ::: Tree of Heaven ::: descri.extracted_quote: a lightly twangy, almost funereal anecdote of an impermanent relationship with a lingering impact
Friendship ::: Tree of Heaven ::: descri.review: Despite their relatively short lifespan, trees of heaven are a notoriously invasive species; even in less lush conditions, like a concrete-packed metropolis, their roots can still grow hastily right up until death. Philly-based Friendship frontman Dan Wriggins reflects on the tree of heaven's pervasiveness on his song named for the plant, a lightly twangy, almost funereal anecdote of an impermanent relationship with a lingering impact. But as Wriggins recalls all these streets he’s wandered and the stoops he’s chilled on, "Tree Of Heaven" feels less like it's about a singular person, instead personifying the city from which so many of his relationships grew as if those stories, too, were forever fossilized in the concrete: "You know you changed me, babe," he howls, emanating the same type of reverence you might bestow to the great loves of your life. — Abby Jones

food house, Gupi, & Fraxiom ::: now 2 ::.name: now 2
food house, Gupi, & Fraxiom ::: now 2 ::.extracted_quote: pure bubblegum with an abrasive edge and absurdist charm
food house, Gupi, & Fraxiom ::: now 2 ::.review: If you took the last half-decade of hyperpop and internet culture and distilled them into just over three minutes, the end result would resemble Food House’s hyperactive “Now 2.” The track is self-aware to a fault, yet it’s pure bubblegum with an abrasive edge and absurdist charm. Where else will you hear “Doompy” rhymed with “poopie” and have it all somehow land without being totally cringeworthy? Attard

MAVI & Earl Sweatshirt ::: Landgrab (fea.name: Landgrab (feat. Earl Sweatshirt)
MAVI & Earl Sweatshirt ::: Landgrab (fea.extracted_quote: ends up saying more in 90 seconds than most other MCs say across entire albums
MAVI & Earl Sweatshirt ::: Landgrab (fea.review: With rhymes about cortisol, John Henry, and Michael Olowokandi, this reflection on two very specific rappers' very specific brands of success observes that victory is almost a physical sensation — and in the process ends up saying more in 90 seconds than most other MCs say across entire albums. — D. Caffrey

MAVI & Earl Sweatshirt ::: Landgrab (fea.name: Landgrab (feat. Earl Sweatshirt)
MAVI & Earl Sweatshirt ::: Landgrab (fea.extracted_quote: the unbothered finesse of the two emcees ... [on] a pure heater
MAVI & Earl Sweatshirt ::: Landgrab (fea.review: MAVI and Earl Sweatshirt understand the power of brevity. The hop-in-hop-out mentality that drives “Landgrab,” the sub-90-second highlight from the former rapper’s latest tape, The Pilot , emphasizes the unbothered finesse of the two emcees. Both at the top of their games, MAVI and Earl reunite for a pure heater. The acolyte-and-master dynamic that infused their first collaboration, 2019’s “EL TORO COMBO MEAL,” assumes a different energy here. On “Landgrab,” the duo trades bar after bar, never letting up the momentum for even a second. No longer the mere protege, MAVI is just another master at work. — Grant Sharples

Gabito Ballesteros & Tito Double P ::: 7.name: 7 DIAS
Gabito Ballesteros & Tito Double P ::: 7.extracted_quote: "7 Días" combines Tito's gruff delivery and Ballesteros' poetic vocalizing, juxtaposing storytelling rawness with melodies seeped in a tender, understated elegance
Gabito Ballesteros & Tito Double P ::: 7.review: One of the reasons why música mexicana is thriving is its tendency to talk about real life, warts and all. Here Tito Double P and Gabito Ballesteros spin a tale of a man who hasn’t heard from his ex in seven days and drowns his pain in prostitutes and alcohol, as one does. A study in contrasts, “7 Días” combines Tito’s gruff delivery and Ballesteros’ poetic vocalizing, juxtaposing storytelling rawness with melodies seeped in a tender, understated elegance. — E.L.

41, Kyle Richh, Jenn Carter, TaTa, & A B.artist: 41, Kyle Richh, Jenn Carter, TaTa, & A Boogie Wit da Hoodie
41, Kyle Richh, Jenn Carter, TaTa, & A B.name: Naked (feat. A Boogie wit da Hoodie)
41, Kyle Richh, Jenn Carter, TaTa, & A B.extracted_quote: An unrelentingly sad drill-R&B collaboration that can't decide if it's trying to heal the wound of a breakup or dig in deeper and make it bleed even more.
41, Kyle Richh, Jenn Carter, TaTa, & A B.review: An unrelentingly sad drill-R&B collaboration that can’t decide if it’s trying to heal the wound of a breakup or dig in deeper and make it bleed even more.

AD\u00c9LA ::: SUPERSCAR ::: description.name: SUPERSCAR
AD\u00c9LA ::: SUPERSCAR ::: description.extracted_quote: "Superscar" doubles as a thrashing club banger and a commentary on the puppetry, sexualization, and exploitation she's faced in the music industry
AD\u00c9LA ::: SUPERSCAR ::: description.review: Ex-KATSEYE contestant Adéla wasn't girl group material, but her arrival onto the pop scene confirms that she primed for solo stardom. “Superscar" doubles as a thrashing club banger and a commentary on the puppetry, sexualization, and exploitation she's faced in the music industry. Her anti-conformist edge is her greatest asset, setting the bar high for what’s to come. — IR

underscores ::: Do It ::: description_pa.name: Do It
underscores ::: Do It ::: description_pa.extracted_quote: conjuring mid-aughts Justin Timberlake and the Philly Club underground while merging Pink Tape hyper-pop with Skrillex worship
underscores ::: Do It ::: description_pa.review: April Harper Grey’s songcraft is inexhaustible. Under the banner of underscores, Grey has made pop-punk songs, country songs, and post-rock songs, even dabbling in brostep and SoundCloud EDM. Her last album, Wallsocket , gets better with every listen, and its pedigree has put her in rooms with Oklou and Danny Brown. The newest underscores single, “Do It,” checks a different box completely, conjuring mid-aughts Justin Timberlake and the Philly Club underground while merging Pink Tape hyper-pop with Skrillex worship.
