AJ Tracey & Jorja Smith ::: Crush (feat..extracted_quote: clever, streamlined bars that make a pretty undeniable case for hitting repeat
AJ Tracey & Jorja Smith ::: Crush (feat..review: For their first official collaboration, U.K. staples AJ Tracey and Jorja Smith flip Brandy’s 2002 deep cut “Love Wouldn’t Count Me Out” into a grime hit. The London rapper and R&B star trade verses about second chances throughout the track, including one in which Smith slips into a silky-smooth rap cadence herself, crafted in her distinct Walsall accent. Tracey matches his collaborator’s reluctant tone with clever, streamlined bars that make a pretty undeniable case for hitting repeat. — L.P.

BigXthaPlug ::: The Largest ::: descript.name: The Largest
BigXthaPlug ::: The Largest ::: descript.extracted_quote: treats the 1971 classic like a demolition derby, steamrolling past his haters with brute, unapologetic force
BigXthaPlug ::: The Largest ::: descript.review: “Safe to say, I’m the biggest, the largest” was one hell of an opening declaration for BigXthaPlug when he bulldozed his way into stardom in 2024 with “The Largest.” Powered by a sample of War’s “Slippin’ into Darkness,” Big X treats the 1971 classic like a demolition derby, steamrolling past his haters with brute, unapologetic force. “The Largest” not only found a home on the Hot 100 — peaking at No. 71 — but even earned the Texas powerhouse a well-deserved cameo during Beyoncé’s Cowboy Carter Tour. — C.L.

Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_bi.name: mangetout
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_bi.extracted_quote: the band upshifts to an exhilarating buzz-off banger finale
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_bi.review: Wet Leg have cornered the market on f—k-off songs. “Ur Mom” on their first album, and “Catch These Fists,” on their follow-up, Moisturizer , are snarky gems, but “Mangetout” is the group’s best yet. Broken down, the title is “man get out,” and that’s as subtle as things get: “Get lost forever,” Rhian Teasdale sings in her punky-but-alluring voice over a bullet train of bass and drums, with a synth-and-guitar vapor trail. Those vocals turn sweet and light for the bridge, but the lyrics don’t: “You’re washed up, irrelevant and standing in my light,” Teasdale says, before the band upshifts to an exhilarating buzz-off banger finale. — F.D.

BIG SPECIAL ::: SHOP MUSIC. ::: descript.name: SHOP MUSIC.
BIG SPECIAL ::: SHOP MUSIC. ::: descript.review: Class to listen in the shop. No better soundtrack for it. -- David, Rough Trade Berlin

Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_billboar.name: NOKIA
Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_billboar.extracted_quote: a vintage performance ... as he offers breezy one-liners ... and a slithery beat-switch that feeds the feet of dance-happy listeners
Drake ::: NOKIA ::: description_billboar.review: After his lyrical skirmish with Kendrick Lamar overwhelmed his 2024, Drake sought retribution in 2025 for those eager to write his obituary. Not only did he carve out his 14th Billboard 200 No. 1 album with his PARTYNEXTDOOR collab, $ome $exy $ongs 4 U , but he silenced doubters with this immediately unforgettable earworm, “NOKIA.” It’s a vintage performance by The Boy, as he offers breezy one-liners (“Imma ice both of y’all like Gretsky”) and a slithery beat-switch that feeds the feet of dance-happy listeners — and hooked enough of ’em to climb to No. 2 on the Hot 100. — C.L.

Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_nm.name: mangetout
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_nm.extracted_quote: surreal imagery ... saucy lyrics and sassy pay-off
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_nm.review: A lost Strokes classic? A forgotten ‘Youth & Young Manhood’-era Kings Of Leon banger? ‘Mangetout’ could have passed for either. Except, of course, with its surreal imagery (seemingly inspired by Jack and the Beanstalk), saucy lyrics and sassy pay-off ( “Get lost forever” ), this indie anthem is quintessential Wet Leg . Chef’s kiss! JB

Sudan Archives ::: DEAD ::: description_.name: DEAD
Sudan Archives ::: DEAD ::: description_.extracted_quote: a visceral, vibrant, and hypnotic declaration
Sudan Archives ::: DEAD ::: description_.review: “From the very first note, ‘Dead’ feels like a visceral, vibrant, and hypnotic declaration. It captures Sudan Archives’ fearless blend of violin-infused exploration and dance-floor energy, making it one of the year’s most inventive tracks. It’s dynamic and emotionally charged, giving me reason to return to the song again and again.” —BC

Headache & Vegyn ::: Nineteen Sixty Five.name: Nineteen Sixty Five
Headache & Vegyn ::: Nineteen Sixty Five.review: The collaboration between Vegyn and AI-voiced lyrics of the enigmatic Francis Honsby Clark yields a distinctive, trip-hop-influenced sound. The lyrics and AI delivery give a perfect dissonance for modern life. -- Lawrence, Rough Trade Office

Ludwig G\u00f6ransson, Sinners Movie, &.artist: Ludwig Göransson, Sinners Movie, & Miles Caton
Ludwig G\u00f6ransson, Sinners Movie, &.name: Magic What We Do (Surreal Montage) (feat. Miles Caton)
Ludwig G\u00f6ransson, Sinners Movie, &.extracted_quote: drawing together past, present, and future for a song that truly transcends
Ludwig G\u00f6ransson, Sinners Movie, &.review: The best movie of 2025 also featured some of the year's best music, including this mash-ups drawn directly from the Sinners soundtrack, drawing together past, present, and future for a song that truly transcends. — L.S. Miller

Revival Season ::: 8'3 ::: description_c.extracted_quote: channeling his mounting frustration into peace and positivity
Revival Season ::: 8'3 ::: description_c.review: Yet another banger from Revival Season, "8'3" finds Brandon "Bez" Evans channeling his mounting frustration into peace and positivity over Jonah Swilley's fusion of garage rock and Funkadelic influences. — E. Fu

Dove Ellis ::: Love Is ::: description_p.name: Love Is
Dove Ellis ::: Love Is ::: description_p.extracted_quote: pop music caught in the bardo
Dove Ellis ::: Love Is ::: description_p.review: Dove Ellis released his first-ever single, like, three months ago—arriving with nothing but a co-sign from Geese and comparisons to Thom Yorke. Not a bad start, I’d say. I liked “To the Sandals” quite a lot, but I like “Love Is” even better. Inaugurated by a sparse piano melody, the song erupts into this wonderful, erratic flush of rock and roll. The drums sound like they’re being pounded on in the next room over, and Ellis’ voice vibrates nearly into a falsetto. But beneath all the fundamental stuff is this undertow of curdling distortion, attic noise, and skinny, bursting strings. None of it ever erupts, only the guitars and the phantom of Ellis’ refrain. This is pop music caught in the bardo. I think I’ll come back and visit “Love Is” again and again. — Matt Mitchell

Thirteendegrees \u00b0 ::: Da Problem So.name: Da Problem Solva
Thirteendegrees \u00b0 ::: Da Problem So.extracted_quote: woozily maximalist anthems ... greater than the sum of their parts
Thirteendegrees \u00b0 ::: Da Problem So.review: At first blush, Tumblr-obsessive turned underground superstar Thirteendegrees might seem derivative, thanks to his Young Thug-inflected flows and Impact font aesthetics. But as he puts it, “ everything comes from something, it’s just about how you twist it .” His woozily maximalist anthems are greater than the sum of their parts, thanks to his playfully glamorous bars and savvy instinct for ultra-wailable hooks. On “Da Problem Solva,” the Chicago rapper yowls about playing mind games with a shawty who “suck my dick so good, had to saaaaang ” over a bed of fizzing synths courtesy of his right-hand producer Gyant. Thirteen’s delivery makes relatively mundane anecdotes about swiping across his girl’s profile on the apps (“Why’d I caught her on Hinge?”) and hitting the studio to make rent money feel larger than life; but it’s the call-and-response style hook, where he waltzes around the track’s infectious Stevie V flip, that proved Thirteendegrees knows how to make the familiar feel fresh. –Vivian Medithi

Lorde ::: Hammer ::: description_consequ.name: Hammer
Lorde ::: Hammer ::: description_consequ.extracted_quote: Lorde achieves the transcendence she so desperately seeks
Lorde ::: Hammer ::: description_consequ.review: Even though it's the first song on the album, Lorde achieves the transcendence she so desperately seeks throughout Virgin on "Hammer." — P. Ragusa

Justin Bieber ::: FIRST PLACE ::: descri.name: FIRST PLACE
Justin Bieber ::: FIRST PLACE ::: descri.extracted_quote: One of the world's most popular musicians hired both to help write and produce his critically acclaimed comeback album
Justin Bieber ::: FIRST PLACE ::: descri.review: The improbable rise of alt-pop auteurs Mk.gee and Dijon is best summed up by the paradox at the heart of this track: One of the world's most popular musicians hired both to help write and produce his critically acclaimed comeback album, SWAG , and the song that hews closest to their off-kilter aesthetics didn't involve either of them . That's what you call influence. —Otis Hart, NPR

Laufey ::: Lover Girl ::: description_bi.name: Lover Girl
Laufey ::: Lover Girl ::: description_bi.review: Laufey displays an appealingly light touch on this this lilting, bossa nova-inspired track from her third studio album, A Matter of Time . Handclaps add to the playful mood. Laufey co-wrote the song in Tokyo during her Bewitched Tour in August 2024, and returned there to film the video. A clever You Tube fan wrote that the video is the very definition of globalization: “An Icelandic-Chinese [artist] sings a story set in Japan with a Brazilian rhythm in English.” — PAUL GREIN

Clipse, Tyler, The Creator, Pusha T, & M.artist: Clipse, Tyler, The Creator, Pusha T, & Malice
Clipse, Tyler, The Creator, Pusha T, & M.name: P.O.V.
Clipse, Tyler, The Creator, Pusha T, & M.extracted_quote: Malice ... crashes in on a beat switch that detonates beneath him to uncork some hair-raising bars
Clipse, Tyler, The Creator, Pusha T, & M.review: Pusha T dices through his verse on “P.O.V.” like he’s settling a score, his voice twisting against itself during the chorus so that it sounds like two narrators sharing the same deranged conscience. Tyler, the Creator drops in like the lifelong Clipse acolyte that he is, delivering the track’s coldest verse. But besting them both is Malice, who crashes in on a beat switch that detonates beneath him to uncork some hair-raising bars. Kyle Kohner

Saba, No ID, Love Mansuy, Ogi, & Smino :.artist: Saba, No ID, Love Mansuy, Ogi, & Smino
Saba, No ID, Love Mansuy, Ogi, & Smino :.name: a FEW songs (feat. Love Mansuy, Ogi, and Smino)
Saba, No ID, Love Mansuy, Ogi, & Smino :.extracted_quote: [A] vault of a Midwestern great's most trusted collaborators
Saba, No ID, Love Mansuy, Ogi, & Smino :.review: From the Private Collection of Saba and No ID is a family album—a vault of a Midwestern great’s most trusted collaborators. The beats scoring its closer, “a FEW songs,” loop and bounce; stabs of a half-dozen different keys pierce through a soul-stirring vocal harmony from Ogi. Love Mansuy’s “shit is temporary” chorus bridges Saba’s verse into Smino’s, as they rap about their long search for a come-up in a changing ‘hood (“We been on our way—fashionably late, past tense”). “Back in the day, we was on blogs and searching for different perspectives,” Saba spits. “And Benjamins and Jacksons, ‘cause it was a recession.” Smino picks up the story down the road, talking about going “from North Side to Porsche rides to courtside to sold-out shows” and flashes a double entendre of “We bae” and Wee-Bay from The Wire . “a FEW songs” spans a decade or two and ends in affirmative revelation: “It’s okay to change it all, so beautiful,” Ogi hums on a piano fadeout. Saba and his counterpart No ID should make a thousand songs together. But if I can only have one for the rest of my life, I’ll pick “a FEW songs” every time. — Matt Mitchell

Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_bil.name: Afterlife
Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_bil.extracted_quote: imbues his impressionistic lyrics ... with a world's worth of emotion
Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_bil.review: On “Afterlife,” one of best songs Alex Gianmnascoli has ever recorded, the prolific singer-songwriter imbues his impressionistic lyrics – “We were clean like kerosene/ Candy and porno magazines” – with a world’s worth of emotion, communicating the track’s themes of mortality and nostalgia through not just his words, but his vocal delivery too. Also contributing to the track’s wistful vibe: its twinkling instrumental, which conjures R.E.M.’s Automatic for the People with its mandolin and accordion. — E.R.B.

Esau Ortiz ::: Triple Lavada ::: descrip.name: Triple Lavada
Esau Ortiz ::: Triple Lavada ::: descrip.extracted_quote: a viral smash that followed precious few of the trends powering most current Latin pop hits
Esau Ortiz ::: Triple Lavada ::: descrip.review: With a swaggering slow-disco bass line and one of the year’s most brain-sticking sing-song melodies, Esau Ortiz pulled off quite the feat by landing his “Triple Lavada” — scoring a viral smash that followed precious few of the trends powering most current Latin pop hits, but which was such an undeniable party-starter that a whole bunch of hitmaker peers jumped on their own versions. Some of them also ended up on the song’s delightfully overstuffed remix , but the original is the one that leaves you wanting more, then taunts you with the “Arabian riff” while you reach to start it over. — ANDREW UNTERBERGER

William Tyler ::: Star of Hope ::: descr.name: Star of Hope
William Tyler ::: Star of Hope ::: descr.extracted_quote: a 5-minute stretch of nirvana born out of Tyler's "macro-tragic" montages of grief
William Tyler ::: Star of Hope ::: descr.review: Time Indefinite cushions William Tyler’s guitar with disorienting ambience and crunchy, expired cassette tones. The music is as sylvan as it is ominous, as Tyler unearths manipulated arrangements that flutter between bright and terrifying. A hiss of cosmos becomes his toolkit, as he replicates the non-linear path of healing in guitar volleys, piecemeal synth patches, and strangled found-sounds. “Star of Hope” is Time Indefinite ’s greatest transmission—a 5-minute stretch of nirvana born out of Tyler’s “macro-tragic” montages of grief. Milky samples of choir-singing are chopped up beneath his strumming, emulating what it must sound like when the noise of the living is cut silent by the closing of a casket lid. Gone are the space-rock fusions of Secret Stratosphere and the fatalistic, micro-orchestras of Impossible Truth. “Star of Hope” aches with uncertainty and a flavor unbound to just one page of the American folk songbook. Hymns fall apart note by note; instrumental breaks feel deliberately sun-faded; heirlooms sound inaudible. Tyler has never sounded so boldly adrift. — Matt Mitchell

Lady Gaga ::: Abracadabra ::: descriptio.name: Abracadabra
Lady Gaga ::: Abracadabra ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: two house beats made for a gay club at peak sweatiness
Lady Gaga ::: Abracadabra ::: descriptio.review: After her Bruno Mars duet Die With a Smile put her firmly back in the centre of the pop cultural firmament after some years drifting to its edges, Gaga used her 2025 album Mayhem to consolidate that position by giving everyone what they most love about her. There are double helpings on the big, brilliant single Abracadabra: two Gagas in the video (one good, one evil) and two house beats made for a gay club at peak sweatiness (one piano, one acid). There are even two choruses, both of them using the nonsense syllables that defined her biggest hit Bad Romance – the type of thing a particularly hammy musical theatre star would do for their vocal warm-up exercises. It all adds up to double the fun. BBT

mark william lewis ::: Brain ::: descrip.name: Brain
mark william lewis ::: Brain ::: descrip.extracted_quote: So atmospheric ... I love the fuzzy guitar weaving throughout
mark william lewis ::: Brain ::: descrip.review: My favourite song from one of the best albums of the year. So atmospheric, and I love the fuzzy guitar weaving throughout. -- Jack, Denmark Street

FKA twigs ::: Girl Feels Good ::: descri.name: Girl Feels Good
FKA twigs ::: Girl Feels Good ::: descri.extracted_quote: [She] synthesize[s] the track's '90s reference points into something sublimely contemporary
FKA twigs ::: Girl Feels Good ::: descri.review: The breezy “Girl Feels Good” is an ode to the simplicity of female pleasure whose sonic palette falls somewhere between Madonna’s Ray of Light and that Dust Brothers song from the opening credits of David Fincher’s Fight Club . It’s a testament to FKA twigs’s singular vision that she manages to synthesize the track’s ’90s reference points into something sublimely contemporary. Lyons-Burt

Cardi B ::: Bodega Baddie ::: descriptio.name: Bodega Baddie
Cardi B ::: Bodega Baddie ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: a deliriously fun, sub-two-minute blast of adrenaline
Cardi B ::: Bodega Baddie ::: descriptio.review: On this deliriously fun, sub-two-minute blast of adrenaline, Cardi B hops on a sample of Magic Juan and El Prodigio’s frenzied 2001 single “Ta’ Buena” and injects it with her own Bronx baddie attitude. Cardi B merengue album when?

Just Mustard ::: WE WERE JUST HERE ::: d.name: WE WERE JUST HERE
Just Mustard ::: WE WERE JUST HERE ::: d.review: I was expecting them to carry on exploring the dark textures from 2022's Heart Under , so to see them go the other way and make a record brimming with... optimism?... is really inspiring. Also, shout out to David Wrench , the whole album is mixed so well! -- Matt, Denmark Street

Wet Leg ::: catch these fists ::: descri.name: catch these fists
Wet Leg ::: catch these fists ::: descri.extracted_quote: electric pacing, razor wit, and a punchy confidence that marks the band's explosive return
Wet Leg ::: catch these fists ::: descri.review: "I don’t want your love, I just want to fight." Catch These Fists c omes out swinging with electric pacing, razor wit, and a punchy confidence that marks the band’s explosive return. Unmistakably Wet Leg and all the more refined for the wait, plus a bucket load of big fun energy. -- Emily, Rough Trade Office

Larry June, 2 Chainz, & The Alchemist ::.name: Bad Choices
Larry June, 2 Chainz, & The Alchemist ::.review:
2 Chainz had a strange start to the decade. After being a fixture in the 2010s trap scene, the lukewarm reception to his 2020s albums Dope Don’t Sell Itself and Collegrove 2 put him at an artistic crossroads. So he parted ways with Def Jam and went indie.

Now the College Park rapper brings his laid-back flow to the Bay Area’s favorite cool uncle, Larry June, alongside the cinematic brilliance of the Alchemist’s sample-filled production . “Bad Choices” is the pinnacle of yacht rap , with 2 Chainz’s effortless bravado sounding right at home on Alc’s soothing grooves and June’s relaxed delivery. Tity has always been a great rapper; he just needed to board the yacht and sip a green juice to remind everyone. — Josh Svetz

Lorde ::: What Was That ::: description_.name: What Was That
Lorde ::: What Was That ::: description_.extracted_quote: jolting pop listeners awake with bleary images of late city nights and perfect cigarettes
Lorde ::: What Was That ::: description_.review: A dozen years ago, Lorde broke through by greeting the end of the turbo-pop era by declaring “I’m kind of tired of being told to put my hands up in the air — so there”; a lifetime later, the former teen star is a different person with a wider range of sonic interests, but the same instinct to upend expectation. True to its title, “What Was That” served as an immediate course correction from 2021’s blissed-out Solar Power , jolting pop listeners awake with bleary images of late city nights and perfect cigarettes, and saving its main hook for a post-chorus synth squiggle. — J. Lipshutz

DESTIN CONRAD ::: KISSING IN PUBLIC :::.name: KISSING IN PUBLIC
DESTIN CONRAD ::: KISSING IN PUBLIC :::.extracted_quote: hot and flirty ... [it] celebrates queer love
DESTIN CONRAD ::: KISSING IN PUBLIC :::.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of April 2025 : “Summer feels within reach on this hot and flirty Destin Conrad single that celebrates queer love. It’s seductive but also brings the party vibes with echoes of Lionel Richie’s ‘All Night Long’ in the melody.” —EG

Sabrina Carpenter ::: Manchild ::: descr.name: Manchild
Sabrina Carpenter ::: Manchild ::: descr.extracted_quote: knowing a man is emotionally stunted but still caring enough to sing a whole song about him
Sabrina Carpenter ::: Manchild ::: descr.review: One of the great indignities of dating men is that you’ll be snot-nosed crying under the unforgiving light of an AMC theater bathroom about how you will never love again and your friend has to gently remind you… He doesn’t own a bed frame. He didn’t know what garlic was before he met you. It doesn’t really help, but you do have to laugh at the absurdity of feeling so much for someone who’s capable of giving so little. On the glitzy country-pop track “Manchild,” Sabrina Carpenter writes with characteristic wit about this experience, of knowing a man is emotionally stunted but still caring enough to sing a whole song about him. She adopts an air of blasé disdain—“ Whole outfit you’re wearing, God, I hope it’s ironic ”—that eventually reveals itself as a facade as her claims become less and less believable: “ I like my men all incompetent / And I swear they choose me, I’m not choosing them .” She’s invested but at a remove, singing like she’s lost the love of their life but knew it was never going to last anyway. –Vrinda Jagota

CMAT ::: Take A Sexy Picture Of Me ::: d.name: Take A Sexy Picture Of Me
CMAT ::: Take A Sexy Picture Of Me ::: d.extracted_quote: campy, vampy indictment of impossible beauty standards
CMAT ::: Take A Sexy Picture Of Me ::: d.review: A perfect soundtrack to the pendulum swing away from women's liberation and toward universal face-lifts, this campy, vampy indictment of impossible beauty standards shows the Irish phenom born Ciara Mary-Alice Thompson at her wittiest and most righteously enraged. —Ann Powers, NPR

Remember Sports ::: Bug ::: description_.name: Bug
Remember Sports ::: Bug ::: description_.extracted_quote: muscular in both its gnarly distortion and insectual (and very lovelorn) imagery
Remember Sports ::: Bug ::: description_.review: Whether born in a literal or metaphorical garage, so much scrappy indie punk can get real chintzy real fast, so good on Remember Sports for positing that maybe their moniker isn't just a cute name and writing a tune that's muscular in both its gnarly distortion and insectual (and very lovelorn) imagery. — D. Caffrey

Lucius ::: Gold Rush ::: description_var.name: Gold Rush
Lucius ::: Gold Rush ::: description_var.extracted_quote: hearing the blood-level harmony they continually pull off is as sweet a treat as any you can regularly count on in modern music
Lucius ::: Gold Rush ::: description_var.review: Not-quite-twin singers Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig blend their voices nearly full-time as the frontwomen of Lucius, and hearing the blood-leavel harmony they continually pull off is as sweet a treat as any you can regularly count on in modern music. It’s so easy to focus on the miracle of their preternaturally paired singing that it can be easy to forget that Lucius is a great band, too, and not just a chosen-sister act. You won’t lose sight of that, though, listening to what for them is an unusually gnarly mid-tempo rocker with a wonderfully cutting guitar lick. The “rush” they describe may be down to the singers’ partners or to their respective infants, but you believe them when they swear “I’ll never leave, I’ll never leave,” since Laessig and Wolfe have already proven so steadfast at not leaving each other’s sides, even for a few notes. — WIllman

HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.artist: HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & KPop Demon Hunters Cast
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.name: Golden
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.extracted_quote: [That] ascending pre-chorus melody is already ubiquitous enough to feel like a modern pop standard
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.review: Sometimes, a pop song is so undeniable that it’s destined to be a smash, regardless of whether it’s sung by a familiar supergroup or an unknown and fictitious group of computer-animated demon hunters. “Golden” takes its structure from Broadway’s most showstopping “I Wish” numbers and gives it a fresh coat of K-pop gloss, escalating toward the tippy-top of the singer Ejae’s range as it reaches a high note that talent show contestants will be attempting for the rest of our lives. That ascending pre-chorus melody is already ubiquitous enough to feel like a modern pop standard. My condolences to the Archies.

Amaarae, Bree Runway, & Starkillers :::.name: Starkilla (with Bree Runway & Starkillers)
Amaarae, Bree Runway, & Starkillers :::.extracted_quote: made to be blasted on the way to the party
Amaarae, Bree Runway, & Starkillers :::.review: This empowering “bad bitch” anthem was made to be blasted on the way to the party. — S. Noor

aya ::: off to the ESSO ::: description_.name: off to the ESSO
aya ::: off to the ESSO ::: description_.extracted_quote: a terrifying, upsetting portrait of drug addiction
aya ::: off to the ESSO ::: description_.review: Last year at Primavera Sound, I saw aya terrorize a crowd of unsuspecting young Europeans: As the West Yorkshire producer DJ’d and sang, she started to climb onto the decks and scream-sing directly into the faces in the crowd. This is what “off to the ESSO” feels like: aya reaching towards you, Spy Kids 3D -style, grabbing you by the throat, and forcibly pulling you into her nightmare. It is a terrifying, upsetting portrait of drug addiction. Paranoid non-linear thoughts crash into each other; the beat pounds into every inch of your body; and then suddenly it’s off to the gas station for more cash. It hammers its message home with brutal efficiency: Even hell would feel better than this. –Shaad D’Souza

daydreamers ::: Good Intentions ::: desc.name: Good Intentions
daydreamers ::: Good Intentions ::: desc.review: A few months ago, I had the opportunity to attend a showcase for UK-based group, daydreamers. I was immediately impressed by their natural charisma and feel-good sound, especially on new single, “Good Intentions.” If you’re looking for an indie-pop band with catchy melodies to brighten your playlist, they’re a perfect pick. Keep an eye out for their debut album in 2026.

YoungBoy Never Broke Again ::: Shot Call.name: Shot Callin
YoungBoy Never Broke Again ::: Shot Call.extracted_quote: a generation-defining artist finally basking in well-earned glory
YoungBoy Never Broke Again ::: Shot Call.review:
No rapper had a bigger year than YoungBoy Never Broke Again. The controversial superstar went on a nationwide, sold-out arena tour that was a victory lap for all the years of accomplishments he never got to celebrate while behind bars.

“Shot Callin” emerged as the anthem of the tour, often receiving the loudest reactions from fans. Though the track carries the fiery defiance YoungBoy is known for, a sense of jubilance radiates as he croons “wipe me down” on the singalong chorus. While not explicitly a “first day out” track, the NOLA bounce–tinged keys and 808s perfectly complement YoungBoy’s animated, exuberant delivery. The result is a sound brimming with new possibilities,a generation-defining artist finally basking in well-earned glory with the people who believed in him. — Josh Svetz

Sabrina Carpenter ::: House Tour ::: des.name: House Tour
Sabrina Carpenter ::: House Tour ::: des.extracted_quote: an effortlessly slinky funk bop, an extended come-on set to a sticky Janet Jackson-esque beat
Sabrina Carpenter ::: House Tour ::: des.review: Pop’s reigning queen of innuendo sums up her M.O. on this effortlessly slinky funk bop, an extended come-on set to a sticky Janet Jackson -esque beat. When Sabrina Carpenter sings “ I spent a little fortune on the waxed floors” , she isn’t complaining about the cost of polished mahogany. NL

caroline ::: Total euphoria ::: descript.name: Total euphoria
caroline ::: Total euphoria ::: descript.extracted_quote: spotlights the English post-rock band's boundless creativity, compositional experimentation, and, above all, their emotional grace
caroline ::: Total euphoria ::: descript.review: The lead single from caroline 2, Caroline's "Total euphoria" spotlights the English post-rock band's boundless creativity, compositional experimentation, and, above all, their emotional grace. — J. Krueger

Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_nme :::.name: Taxes
Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_nme :::.extracted_quote: an inspired aural collage that merges stream-of-consciousness lyrics ... with a musical release that conjures pure euphoria
Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_nme :::.review: “Hype is really dumb,” mercurial Geese frontman Cameron Winter told NME when the New York five-piece appeared on The Cover in 2023 . And yet this year’s five-star album ‘Getting Killed’ proved that the buzz around them was more than justified. Here was an experimental rock record that’s at once familiar and alien, summed up by ‘Taxes’, an inspired aural collage that merges stream-of-consciousness lyrics ( “Doctor! Heal yourself!” ) with a musical release that conjures pure euphoria. We’ve no idea what it’s about, but it’s a lot of fun coming up with your own interpretation. No wonder Nick Cave’s a fan. JB

Vundabar ::: Spades ::: description_cons.name: Spades
Vundabar ::: Spades ::: description_cons.extracted_quote: an indie rock banger worth throwing on again and again
Vundabar ::: Spades ::: description_cons.review: Thanks to ferocious guitar lines and creative construction, Vundabar's "Spades" is an indie rock banger worth throwing on again and again. — J. Krueger

Tyler Childers ::: Bitin' List ::: descr.name: Bitin' List
Tyler Childers ::: Bitin' List ::: descr.extracted_quote: if there ever come a time I got rabies, you're high on my bitin' list
Tyler Childers ::: Bitin' List ::: descr.review: Alt-country superstar Tyler Childers is a man of many unusual extremes. For instance, his latest album, like some of his sold-out concerts, includes elements of a Hare Krishna chant and other Indian influences, which would seem to be a long way from his Appalachian origins. But he hasn’t gone total peacenik on us, at least not when it comes to “Bitin’ List,” which became a viral hit off the “Snipe Hunter” record. “I just don’t like you,” he announces in the song, “and if there ever come a time I got rabies, you’re high on my bitin’ list.” It’s meant playfully, naturally, but it would not have become one of the year’s defining Americana songs if there weren’t a lot of folks out there able to identify someone they’d like to take down with them if they contracted a communicable disease. So sing or growl along, and then atone with 20 Hare Krishnas. — WIllman

Full Blown & Yung Bredda ::: The Greates.name: The Greatest Bend Over (Take It Easy)
Full Blown & Yung Bredda ::: The Greates.extracted_quote: The riddim? Seductive. Chorus? Catchy. Who's in charge? Ladies.
Full Blown & Yung Bredda ::: The Greates.review: "Sir, you're gonna let me cook and you're gonna love it." That's the vibe of Yung Bredda's collaboration with celebrated production duo Full Blown, creators of the Big Links Riddim . This runaway hit, set to the most popular soca instrumental of 2025, eclipsed hot singles by its producers, Machel Montano and Kes. The riddim? Seductive. Chorus? Catchy. Who's in charge? Ladies. Small wonder it bent knees and wound waistlines all carnival season. —Nikki Birch, NPR

Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.name: The Subway
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.extracted_quote: a soundtrack for coming out the other side – a moment of pure cathartic release
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.review: If there’s still any doubt about Chappell Roan’s star power, just ask the tourism board in Saskatchewan. On The Subway, Roan fantasises about moving to the Canadian province to escape a devastating breakup, a reference that prompted the Saskatchewan tourism board’s website and social media to be inundated in the week following its release. The tongue-in-cheek humour buried in lovelorn yearning that inspired it is a hallmark of Roan’s songwriting. She told Vogue that its release was delayed because she found it “too painful”, but online her powerhouse cry of “ she’s got away ” has soundtracked countless uplifting stories of moving on. Awash with dreampop guitars, dramatic violin and percussion juddering like a train, her soaring vocals mine the moments in early-stage heartbreak when even smelling their perfume is enough to send you spiralling. Despite its melancholy introspection, The Subway is a soundtrack for coming out the other side – a moment of pure cathartic release. -- Sophie Lou Wilson

Hamish Hawk ::: So Hard ::: description_.name: So Hard
Hamish Hawk ::: So Hard ::: description_.extracted_quote: Hawk's wonderful take on the track makes that most cutting of lines ... even more poignant
Hamish Hawk ::: So Hard ::: description_.review: As well as releasing albums of smart and increasingly libidinous chamber pop music, Hamish Hawk is a dab hand at reinterpreting the work of his heroes. Only a couple of weeks ago he wrote for tQ about his love of Ivor Cutler, and earlier this year, he released an EP of covers of songs by Eurythmics (‘Sweet Dreams’), Madonna (‘Burning Up’), Sheryl Crow (‘If It Makes You Happy’) and, best of the bunch, Pet Shop Boys’ cheating anthem, ‘So Hard’. Hawk’s wonderful take on the track makes that most cutting of lines, “We’ve both given up smoking ‘cos it’s fatal / So whose matches are those” even more poignant.

james K ::: Play ::: description_fader :.name: Play
james K ::: Play ::: description_fader :.extracted_quote: gossamer banger ... helping me achieve something rare: actual and glorious dematerialization
james K ::: Play ::: description_fader :.review: This song soundtracked one of my most euphoric live music moments this year: I was crammed inside a wartime cell at Philly’s Making Time festival, screaming the lyrics to james k’s gossamer banger with abandon. The air was hot, the lights too bright, and the guy next to me definitely wasn’t wearing deodorant but that didn’t stop “Play” from helping me achieve something rare: actual and glorious dematerialization. — SW

Wednesday ::: Pick Up That Knife ::: des.name: Pick Up That Knife
Wednesday ::: Pick Up That Knife ::: des.review: This song is insanely addictive. As a weird Southern girl, Karly makes me feel seen. -- Jess, Rough Trade NYC

Hilary Duff ::: Mature ::: description_b.name: Mature
Hilary Duff ::: Mature ::: description_b.extracted_quote: appropriately cutting and therapeutic ... given muscle by the kind of windows-down guitar-pop groove that made the world fall in love with Carly Rae Jepsen
Hilary Duff ::: Mature ::: description_b.review: “She looks like all of your girls but blonder/ A little like me, just younger,” Hilary Duff seethes in the chorus to her long-awaited return single “Mature.” The mild twist of the song is that Duff isn’t decrying her ex for upgrading to the newer model, she’s singing to her own earlier self, back when she was “flattered to hear you say, ‘ You’re so mature for your age, babe .'” The song feels appropriately cutting and therapeutic, given muscle by the kind of windows-down guitar-pop groove that made the world fall in love with Carly Rae Jepsen a decade ago, but with enough of a personally detailed touch from Duff — including pop’s all-time most-unexpected “Strawberry Letter 23” reference — that excitement should be at a fever pitch for her full comeback in 2026. — A.U.

The Mar\u00edas ::: Back To Me ::: descr.name: Back To Me
The Mar\u00edas ::: Back To Me ::: descr.extracted_quote: achingly pleas for her lover to return ... over menacing reverb
The Mar\u00edas ::: Back To Me ::: descr.review: With “Back to Me,” dream poppers the Marías add another chapter to the story they told on their 2024 LP, Submarine. On Submarine ’s closing track, “Sienna,” lead singer Maria Zardoya accepts that the child and house she once hoped to share with her departed lover will never become a reality. Here, in the band’s first single since Submarine, Zardoya achingly pleas for her lover to return, breathlessly promising “I’ll be all that you need” over menacing reverb. — M.G.

Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.name: The Subway
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.review: The prospect of potentially not hearing a new Chappell Roan album for five more years is a hard pill to swallow, but it’s made easier by how utterly resplendent “The Subway” is. The sumptuous single finds Roan trying to banish the memory of an ex, and the writing excels at balancing the moment’s melodrama (“Made you the villain, evil for just moving on”) with pure comedy (“f—k this city, I’m moving to Saskatchewan”). While the familiar dream-pop production certainly helps vault this song over the top, the clincher is Roan’s singular vocal performance: Even in a catalog filled with all-time performances like “Good Luck, Babe!” and “Casual,” Roan’s got a way with her voice here as she belts that “she got away” on the sublime outro. — S.D.

Laufey ::: Snow White ::: description_us.name: Snow White
Laufey ::: Snow White ::: description_us.extracted_quote: [The] delicately plucked guitar and cinematic strings provide a pillow-y landing spot for Laufey's emotions
Laufey ::: Snow White ::: description_us.review: Laufey’s third album, “A Matter of Time,” nudged the Icelandic hybrid artist – call her pop-jazz-classical – into the Billboard Hot 100 for the first time (albeit at No. 91) with “Lover Girl.” But, much like her affecting “Letter to My 13 Year Old Self,” which was so beautifully rerecorded this year with Barbra Streisand , “Snow White” speaks to insecurities (“I don’t think I’m pretty/it’s not up for debate”) and trying to live up to impossible beauty standards (“Skinny always wins/and I don’t have enough of it”). The delicately plucked guitar and cinematic strings provide a pillow-y landing spot for Laufey’s emotions.

The Mar\u00edas ::: Back To Me ::: descr.name: Back To Me
The Mar\u00edas ::: Back To Me ::: descr.extracted_quote: sometimes lost loves linger and haunt you
The Mar\u00edas ::: Back To Me ::: descr.review: As featured in ELLE’s best songs of April 2025 : “Moody and bass-y, the verses of The Marías’ latest single creep in with lead singer María Zardoya’s delicate vocals. The resulting effect is eerie, but it makes sense for a breakup song—sometimes lost loves linger and haunt you.” —EG

HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.artist: HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & KPop Demon Hunters Cast
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.name: Golden
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.extracted_quote: it goes up, and that's what it does
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.review: Says it goes up, and that’s what it does. — M.W.

Eli ::: Glitter ::: description_elle :::.name: Glitter
Eli ::: Glitter ::: description_elle :::.extracted_quote: a hook as catchy as any '90s girl-group anthem
Eli ::: Glitter ::: description_elle :::.review: “Get ready for Eli world domination in 2026. With a hook as catchy as any ’90s girl-group anthem, the pop princess’s latest single breaks the themes and sonic landscape of her debut album, Stage Girl, wide open. It’s an earworm I never want to go away! Replay after replay, your insides are sure to shimmer. And in case you needed another reminder to break up with that man, just give this song a listen and ‘wash the boy right out of your clothes.’” —BT

Addison Rae ::: Times Like These ::: des.name: Times Like These
Addison Rae ::: Times Like These ::: des.extracted_quote: a floaty, ambient quality highlighting her angelic vocals and sharp production choices
Addison Rae ::: Times Like These ::: des.review: Ever since “Diet Pepsi,” I’ve been a fan of Addison’s ethereal synth-pop (my top Spotify artist of the year!). Her June debut, Addison, stands as one of the year’s finest pop releases and does an impressive job defining her sound and artistic identity. My favorite track, "Times Like These," has a floaty, ambient quality highlighting her angelic vocals and sharp production choices. I’m truly excited to see what’s next for the Grammy-nominated Best New Artist.

Hannah Cohen ::: Dusty ::: description_p.name: Dusty
Hannah Cohen ::: Dusty ::: description_p.extracted_quote: a bossa nova-inflected groove wraps around her lilt like a plush blanket
Hannah Cohen ::: Dusty ::: description_p.review: “Everywhere you go, now, there you are,” Hannah Cohen repeats in the “Dusty” chorus. It’s a piece of advice we’ve all heard so often that it can go in one ear and right out the other, but Cohen takes time to really sit with the phrase, stretching the words to their limits to see how they taste on her tongue, before chirping them out in one breath—as though a revelation has suddenly hit her, sparking an unexpected jolt of bliss to ripple throughout her core. Evocative of the peace she’s found in solitude, a bossa nova-inflected groove wraps around her lilt like a plush blanket, while delicate flute notes twirl around her like birds in an unobstructed sky. In this serene soundscape, she finds that her own thoughts flutter and fade as naturally: “You won’t believe the things you’ll find / Laying around there with your mind,” she muses, the notion dripping from her lips like a sweet, golden nectar. There’s a sparkle of sincerity to her voice that easily gains your trust. — Anna Pichler

Destroyer ::: Cataract Time ::: descript.name: Cataract Time
Destroyer ::: Cataract Time ::: descript.extracted_quote: uncommonly direct ... as [Dan Bejar] confronts the indignities of aging
Destroyer ::: Cataract Time ::: descript.review: With its jazzy filigrees, including a lengthy sax solo, the eight-minute “Cataract Time” would fit nicely on Destroyer’s 2011 album Kaputt . But it stands out on Dan’s Boogie for how uncommonly direct it is, as singer Dan Bejar confronts the indignities of aging and approaches criticism by strangers by seeing the virtues of simply living past them. Erickson

Debbii Dawson ::: Chemical Reaction :::.name: Chemical Reaction
Debbii Dawson ::: Chemical Reaction :::.extracted_quote: a dreamy, glittery country-disco song made to soundtrack an old-school romantic Western
Debbii Dawson ::: Chemical Reaction :::.review: Imagine a dreamy, glittery country-disco song made to soundtrack an old-school romantic Western movie and you’ll get Debbii Dawson’s magnetic ‘Chemical Reaction’. The Giorgio Moroder -esque synths are hypnotising and the lyricism is evocative, but it’s the NME Cover star’s ethereal, otherworldly vocals that steal the show. ZWP

Craig Finn ::: Bethany ::: description_p.name: Bethany
Craig Finn ::: Bethany ::: description_p.extracted_quote: a song this good is enough to turn you into a believer
Craig Finn ::: Bethany ::: description_p.review: It’s been four years since the War on Drugs’ last album, but their presence looms large among today’s musical landscape. In-between touring with his main band, Drugs frontman Adam Granduciel has put on his producer cap for some of 2025’s best new music: Lucius, Sam Fender, and the Hold Steady’s Craig Finn. Always Been , Finn’s latest, was not only produced by Granduciel, but he and most of his War on Drugs compadres play on the whole thing. While it scratches that itch that’s been getting louder for War on Drugs fans as they await new music, Always Been also provides an intriguing new vessel for Finn’s narrative songwriting. “Bethany” was the first song he brought to Granduciel. It’s a door-opener—a tale about a pastor whose heart wasn’t much in religion in the first place. He loses it all and tries to pick up the pieces of his life while living at his parents’ old house in Delaware. Like much of Finn’s work, he spins a captivating narrative; this time, the War on Drugs provide his ideas a bed of dreamy Heartland rock before whirring the song to life when Granduciel lays down one of the best guitar solos of his entire career. “Bethany” may not be much of a spiritual guide, but a song this good is enough to turn you into a believer. — Jeff Yerger

Amaarae ::: S.M.O. ::: description_stere.name: S.M.O.
Amaarae ::: S.M.O. ::: description_stere.review: For Ghanaian artist Amaarae, influences are an act; she is deliberate and purposeful about who she lets into her sound. She can tell you the exact highlife artists (obscure-until-recently Ata Kak) and R&B touchstones ("The Pleasure Principle") that animated her music, and exactly to which (and whose) ends she turned them. This allows her to make "S.M.O." (first word: "slut") surprisingly cohesive, even understated, for how much she's kaleidoscoping in; everything is flowing toward one single purpose already answered by the title. Amaraae's vocal is pitched into the uncannily blank, as if she's already half-dissolved into her woman of choice. And her horniness is holistic; she makes lyrics about absolute penetrative filth sound as reverent as "I want to meet the God that made you" and makes orchestra hits and Donna Summer-y moans seem equally charged. She even manages to take Lexapro — an SSRI known for doing pretty much the sexual opposite of this — and make it seductive. — Katherine St. Asaph

Gelli Haha ::: Bounce House ::: descript.name: Bounce House
Gelli Haha ::: Bounce House ::: descript.extracted_quote: absurdist electro-pop ... between spangled disco and truly out-there psychedelia
Gelli Haha ::: Bounce House ::: descript.review: Gelli Haha’s absurdist electro-pop lives somewhere between spangled disco and truly out-there psychedelia, but it’s her goofy sense of humor that keeps everything in check. On “Bounce House,” the bubbly lead single from her debut album Switcheroo , the Los Angeles–based singer and producer born Angel Abaya crafts a spinning carousel with appetites bounding freely between a “Tommy” and a “Sally.” “I’ve been hoppin’ on the honest train,” she sings sweetly to the former, “Don’t love you less just because I got off without ya.” By the time the song ends in a chatter of giggly, excited voices engaging Abaya in a call-and-response about “drumming like a battery bunny,” it’s impossible to stop the giant smile from forming on your face. –Eric Torres

Gelli Haha ::: Bounce House ::: descript.name: Bounce House
Gelli Haha ::: Bounce House ::: descript.extracted_quote: bouncy Kate Bush meets LCD Soundsystem weird pop anthem
Gelli Haha ::: Bounce House ::: descript.review: This bouncy Kate Bush meets LCD Soundsystem weird pop anthem made me feel buoyant and blissed out all Summer. In fact, I fell so hard I nearly bought a trampoline. -- George, Rough Trade New York

509 BMG ::: Special Request to All Nice.name: Special Request to All Nice and Decent Real Niggaz (Stop Hatin)
509 BMG ::: Special Request to All Nice.extracted_quote: Eleven-and-a-half minutes of Orlando trash-talker 509 BMG sliding through shape-shifting dancehall beats
509 BMG ::: Special Request to All Nice.review: The internet’s ephemeral phrase of the moment seems to be “flow state,” so lemme show you what that really looks like: Eleven-and-a-half minutes of Orlando trash-talker 509 BMG sliding through shape-shifting dancehall beats. Atop flowery marimbas and mesmeric rhythms, BMG lets plosives and punchlines detonate like molotovs. Yeah, maybe the breezy, carefree production invokes pool parties at golden hour and daiquiris on the beach, but BMG tackles each arrangement like he woke up pissed off: “These crackas act like I’m a dumbass, I’m a easy target,” he spits with vitriol. “Always tryna talk between the lines, hiding behind the jargon.” Last time a Zoe ran it up like this, he almost won the Heisman . –Olivier Lafontant

Sammy Virji & Skepta ::: Cops & Robbers.name: Cops & Robbers
Sammy Virji & Skepta ::: Cops & Robbers.extracted_quote: makes you wanna run through a wall
Sammy Virji & Skepta ::: Cops & Robbers.review: This song makes you wanna run through a wall whenever it comes on. You’d be hard pressed to find a rapper more versatile than Skepta, as he loses his mind over Sammy Virji’s garage sample of Brandy’s “I Wanna Be Down ,” laid over some absolutely epic strings. It’s one of those winners that didn’t leave the rotation for me at all this year. — A.D.

KAROL G & Feid ::: Verano Rosa ::: descr.name: Verano Rosa
KAROL G & Feid ::: Verano Rosa ::: descr.review: “Verano Rosa” was famously left on the cutting-room floor during Karol G’s sessions for Mañana Será Bonito ( Bichota Season ); the star revealed the song was a collaboration with fellow Latin music titan Feid in her 2023 Rolling Stone cover story . After two years, Karol and Feid delivered with a wistful, summer-ready track. Against a sunny reggaeton beat, the two musicians embody former flames who long for each other over drunken mid-party phone calls, liquor bottles in hand, and remember their unmatched love. — Maya Georgi

Agriculture ::: Bodhidharma ::: descript.name: Bodhidharma
Agriculture ::: Bodhidharma ::: descript.review: Between passages of wailing distorted guitars, dreamy moments of relief, and even sections of full-on static, Agriculture's "Bodhidharma" is a true black metal odyssey. — J. Krueger

Lady Gaga ::: Abracadabra ::: descriptio.name: Abracadabra
Lady Gaga ::: Abracadabra ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: two house beats made for a gay club at peak sweatiness ... using the nonsense syllables that defined her biggest hit Bad Romance
Lady Gaga ::: Abracadabra ::: descriptio.review: After her Bruno Mars duet Die With a Smile put her firmly back in the centre of the pop cultural firmament after some years drifting to its edges, Gaga used her 2025 album Mayhem to consolidate that position by giving everyone what they most love about her. There are double helpings on the big, brilliant single Abracadabra: two Gagas in the video (one good, one evil) and two house beats made for a gay club at peak sweatiness (one piano, one acid). There are even two choruses, both of them using the nonsense syllables that defined her biggest hit Bad Romance – the type of thing a particularly hammy musical theatre star would do for their vocal warm-up exercises. It all adds up to double the fun. BBT

Circuit des Yeux ::: Canopy of Eden :::.name: Canopy of Eden
Circuit des Yeux ::: Canopy of Eden :::.extracted_quote: "I can make a radio break," [she] sings on "Canopy of Eden," and with the brooding, darkwave instrumental, we believe her
Circuit des Yeux ::: Canopy of Eden :::.review: "I can make a radio break," Haley Fohr sings on "Canopy of Eden," and with the brooding, darkwave instrumental, we believe her. — J. Krueger

Matt Berninger ::: Bonnet Of Pins ::: de.name: Bonnet Of Pins
Matt Berninger ::: Bonnet Of Pins ::: de.extracted_quote: disorienting intimacy that is begging for the full band treatment
Matt Berninger ::: Bonnet Of Pins ::: de.review: Deftly woven, craftily esoteric lyricism from The National frontman delivers disorienting intimacy that is begging for the full band treatment. — B. Kaye

AZ Chike ::: Whatx2 ::: description_cons.name: Whatx2
AZ Chike ::: Whatx2 ::: description_cons.extracted_quote: ultra-confident "Whatx2," closing it out with a boast delivered like a victory lap
AZ Chike ::: Whatx2 ::: description_cons.review: The self-proclaimed "Best Feature on GNX ," AZ Chike started 2025 at a sprint with the ultra-confident "Whatx2," closing it out with a boast delivered like a victory lap: "Ain't nobody screaming, 'Free me,' 'R.I.P. me.'" — K. Fitzgerald

Olivia Dean ::: Man I Need ::: descripti.name: Man I Need
Olivia Dean ::: Man I Need ::: descripti.extracted_quote: The fizzy pop track sees the 26-year-old British singer solidify her sophisticated sound
Olivia Dean ::: Man I Need ::: descripti.review: Olivia Dean's breakout moment has been pending for half a decade. She showed promise with 2020's "The Hardest Part," then teased her evolution with 2023's "Dive," but thanks to "Man I Need" she has officially arrived. The fizzy pop track sees the 26-year-old British singer solidify her sophisticated sound as she makes the case for owning how you want to be loved and insisting your lover rise to the occasion. Still, as yearning and exasperated as her lyrics are ("I'd like to think you feel the same way / But I can't tell with you sometimes"), Dean is hopeful and flirty, leaning into brassy soul influences and giddy melodies, pulling it all together with a seductive hook. —Shania Russell

Spiritbox ::: No Loss, No Love ::: descr.name: No Loss, No Love
Spiritbox ::: No Loss, No Love ::: descr.extracted_quote: An absolute crushing track ... offering a few quiet moments in which Courtney LaPlante delivers hypnotic spoken-word passages
Spiritbox ::: No Loss, No Love ::: descr.review: An absolute crushing track from the rising Canadian metal act, offering a few quiet moments in which Courtney LaPlante delivers hypnotic spoken-word passages. — S. Kaufman

Anna Shoemaker ::: Back Again ::: descri.name: Back Again
Anna Shoemaker ::: Back Again ::: descri.extracted_quote: "Back Again" builds a rich internal world ... through an arrangement that's always shifting
Anna Shoemaker ::: Back Again ::: descri.review: Although Anna Shoemaker's ask here is simple (pleading for an ex-lover to take them back or at least out), "Back Again" builds a rich internal world for its narrator through an arrangement that's always shifting: simple fingerpicking transmuting to punchy power chords to electronic kick pedal and so on. — D. Caffrey

Charley Crockett ::: Crucified Son ::: d.name: Crucified Son
Charley Crockett ::: Crucified Son ::: d.extracted_quote: Straight country — with shades of Strait Country — from one of the bigger characters in the genre's bustling underground
Charley Crockett ::: Crucified Son ::: d.review: Straight country — with shades of Strait Country — from one of the bigger characters in the genre’s bustling underground. — W. Graves

Waxahatchee ::: Mud ::: description_cons.name: Mud
Waxahatchee ::: Mud ::: description_cons.extracted_quote: Cast-off tracks are rarely this good
Waxahatchee ::: Mud ::: description_cons.review: Cast-off tracks are rarely this good, but what else would you expect from one of the top purveyors of twanged indie? — B. Kaye

Destroyer ::: Hydroplaning Off the Edge.name: Hydroplaning Off the Edge of the World
Destroyer ::: Hydroplaning Off the Edge.extracted_quote: makes fake-choral keyboards and cryptic non-sequiturs about decay sound like joyous poetry
Destroyer ::: Hydroplaning Off the Edge.review: From the mini-MIDI orchestra of Your Blues to the coked-out soft rock of Kaputt , Dan Bejar has long been interested in mining sincerity from traditionally artificial-sounding sonic landscapes, so it's no surprise that he (yet again) makes fake-choral keyboards and cryptic non-sequiturs about decay sound like joyous poetry. — D. Caffrey

Mood Bored ::: Wet Faced & Ugly ::: desc.name: Wet Faced & Ugly
Mood Bored ::: Wet Faced & Ugly ::: desc.extracted_quote: manage to stand out via lyrics that revel in so much codependency and self-pity ... that it's almost charming
Mood Bored ::: Wet Faced & Ugly ::: desc.review: I'm a sucker for whatever the shoegaze-revival du jour is, and these contemplative upstarts manage to stand out via lyrics that revel in so much codependency and self-pity/flagellation that it's almost charming (sample lyric: "Crying baby in a buggy / Wet faced and ugly / Pick me up / Low-eyed and druggy / Now you can love me"). — D. Caffrey

The Vices ::: How Does It Feel ::: descr.name: How Does It Feel
The Vices ::: How Does It Feel ::: descr.extracted_quote: the borderline-militaristic drumming gives "How Does It Feel" an unease that makes the song perfect end-credits music
The Vices ::: How Does It Feel ::: descr.review: Gentle and groovy, sure, but the borderline-militaristic drumming gives "How Does It Feel" an unease that makes the song perfect end-credits music exported straight from the Netherlands ("And the Oscar for Best International Feature Film goes to…"). — D. Caffrey

Zelooperz & Zack Fox ::: Push Me Around.name: Push Me Around
Zelooperz & Zack Fox ::: Push Me Around.extracted_quote: bass so blown out that it sounds a hair distorted — but deliciously aggressive nonetheless
Zelooperz & Zack Fox ::: Push Me Around.review: Two of underground hip-hop's most idiosyncratic voices come together to deliver interweaved bars about what won't happen ("Bet you a n***a won't push me around!"), over bass so blown out that it sounds a hair distorted — but deliciously aggressive nonetheless. — K. Fitzgerald

TAKAAT ::: Amidinin ::: description_cons.name: Amidinin
TAKAAT ::: Amidinin ::: description_cons.extracted_quote: seamlessly fuses Tuareg music with punk rock
TAKAAT ::: Amidinin ::: description_cons.review: Mdou Moctar’s bandmates reintroduce themselves with this high-energy track that seamlessly fuses Tuareg music with punk rock. — S. Noor

Rene\u00e9 Rapp ::: Leave Me Alone ::: d.name: Leave Me Alone
Rene\u00e9 Rapp ::: Leave Me Alone ::: d.extracted_quote: the people need anthems that convince us we're trashy nightlife superheroes
Rene\u00e9 Rapp ::: Leave Me Alone ::: d.review: Painstakingly curated with nearly half a dozen songwriters, the club-lite schtick is never as authentically raw as it wants it to be, and therein lies the charm; the people need anthems that convince us we're trashy nightlife superheroes rather than the normies most of us probably are (Reneé Rapp included). — D. Caffrey

Lamb of God ::: Sepsis ::: description_c.name: Sepsis
Lamb of God ::: Sepsis ::: description_c.extracted_quote: the band at its sludgiest, paced by slow, curdled riffs
Lamb of God ::: Sepsis ::: description_c.review: A tribute to Lamb of God’s home scene of Richmond VA, “Sepsis” is the band at its sludgiest, paced by slow, curdled riffs that tempt frontman Randy Blythe to reach to his deepest gutturals. — J. Hadusek

HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.artist: HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & KPop Demon Hunters Cast
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.name: Golden
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.extracted_quote: synth-draped "Golden" feels made for self-actualization sessions
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.review: The animated K-pop fantasia KPop Demon Hunters was one of 2025’s pop-cultural bright spots, and its giddy lead single — which spent eight weeks atop the Hot 100 — only amped up the joyful frenzy surrounding it. Credited to the titular stars-slash-slayers HUNTR/X and performed by Audrey Nuna, Rei Ami, and co-writer EJAE, the synth-draped “Golden” feels made for self-actualization sessions, its spirited chorus getting even more oomph after its bridge takes down the tempo and offers listeners a moment to reflect on, and eventually cast off, darker moments in their past. — M.J.

Parcels ::: Sorry ::: description_conseq.name: Sorry
Parcels ::: Sorry ::: description_conseq.extracted_quote: strip their sound down to offer a clever, passive-aggressive message
Parcels ::: Sorry ::: description_conseq.review: On this surprisingly profound cut, Parcels strip their sound down to offer a clever, passive-aggressive message: "I'm sorry that it hurts to be loved." — P. Ragusa

Rico Nasty ::: TEETHSUCKER (YEA3x) ::: d.name: TEETHSUCKER (YEA3x)
Rico Nasty ::: TEETHSUCKER (YEA3x) ::: d.extracted_quote: delivers a rowdy, high-octane banger with punk rock energy — a hype song from start to finish
Rico Nasty ::: TEETHSUCKER (YEA3x) ::: d.review: Rico Nasty delivers a rowdy, high-octane banger with punk rock energy — a hype song from start to finish. — S. Noor

HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.artist: HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & KPop Demon Hunters Cast
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.name: Golden
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.extracted_quote: [A] pop song is so undeniable that it's destined to be a smash, regardless of whether it's sung by a familiar supergroup or an unknown and fictitious group of computer-animated demon hunters
HUNTR/X, EJAE, AUDREY NUNA, REI AMI, & K.review: Sometimes, a pop song is so undeniable that it’s destined to be a smash, regardless of whether it’s sung by a familiar supergroup or an unknown and fictitious group of computer-animated demon hunters. “Golden” takes its structure from Broadway’s most showstopping “I Wish” numbers and gives it a fresh coat of K-pop gloss, escalating toward the tippy-top of the singer Ejae’s range as it reaches a high note that talent show contestants will be attempting for the rest of our lives. That ascending pre-chorus melody is already ubiquitous enough to feel like a modern pop standard. My condolences to the Archies.

Tropical Fuck Storm ::: Moscovium ::: de.name: Moscovium
Tropical Fuck Storm ::: Moscovium ::: de.extracted_quote: pure catharsis done the way only these Aussie psych-rock-freaks can pull off
Tropical Fuck Storm ::: Moscovium ::: de.review: The final track of Tropical Fuck Storm's excellent, insane Fairyland Codex , "Moscovium" is pure catharsis done the way only these Aussie psych-rock-freaks can pull off. — J. Krueger

The Pretty Reckless ::: For I Am Death :.name: For I Am Death
The Pretty Reckless ::: For I Am Death :.extracted_quote: a monster riff and an infectiously powerful chorus that sucks you in like vacuum cleaner
The Pretty Reckless ::: For I Am Death :.review: Taylor Momsen and company hit us with their first single in four years, and it absolutely slaps, with a monster riff and an infectiously powerful chorus that sucks you in like vacuum cleaner. — S. Kaufman

Mclusky ::: people person ::: descriptio.name: people person
Mclusky ::: people person ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: a riff-hitting jam, with droning, sludged-out guitars barreling forward
Mclusky ::: people person ::: descriptio.review: Sardonic as all hell, the song “people person” is a riff-hitting jam, with droning, sludged-out guitars barreling forward as singer Andrew Falkous delivers a tirade in his unwavering deadpan delivery. — Jon Hadusek

Flyte ::: Emily and Me ::: description_c.name: Emily and Me
Flyte ::: Emily and Me ::: description_c.extracted_quote: explore the beauty and mythos of Los Angeles against a backdrop of climate-induced destruction
Flyte ::: Emily and Me ::: description_c.review: On this gorgeous ode, Flyte explore the beauty and mythos of Los Angeles against a backdrop of climate-induced destruction. — P. Ragusa

My Morning Jacket ::: Time Waited ::: de.name: Time Waited
My Morning Jacket ::: Time Waited ::: de.extracted_quote: a state of peace that's rare for a group this long-running
My Morning Jacket ::: Time Waited ::: de.review: Jim James and his band have reached a state of peace that's rare for a group this long-running, and "Time Waited" best captures the wordly understanding they present on is . — B. Kaye

Monaleo ::: Dignified ::: description_co.name: Dignified
Monaleo ::: Dignified ::: description_co.extracted_quote: delivers a cinematic experience that unravels the irrevocable consequences of drunk driving
Monaleo ::: Dignified ::: description_co.review: Houston singer-rapper Monaleo employs both of her skills as an artist to deliver a cinematic experience that unravels the irrevocable consequences of drunk driving: "We turning up, I hate to be a party pooper/ Don't you know that Death is on the prowl and he could scoop ya?" — K. Fitzgerald

Rocket ::: Another Second Chance ::: des.name: Another Second Chance
Rocket ::: Another Second Chance ::: des.extracted_quote: a terrific demonstration of Rocket's dynamic rock sound
Rocket ::: Another Second Chance ::: des.review: From its shout-along chorus to its dreamy outro, "Another Second Chance" is a terrific demonstration of Rocket's dynamic rock sound. — P. Ragusa

Home Is Where ::: migration patterns :::.name: migration patterns
Home Is Where ::: migration patterns :::.extracted_quote: Contemplations on mortality could only be this invigorating and catchy if approached with a gallows glee — and a lot of harmonica
Home Is Where ::: migration patterns :::.review: Contemplations on mortality could only be this invigorating and catchy if approached with a gallows glee — and a lot of harmonica. — B. Kaye

SPELLLING ::: Portrait of My Heart ::: d.name: Portrait of My Heart
SPELLLING ::: Portrait of My Heart ::: d.review: The title track to one of the year's best efforts perfectly sums up its operatic cyberpunk tension — confirming that SPELLLING undoubtedly belongs here. — B. Kaye

Miley Cyrus ::: Easy Lover ::: descripti.name: Easy Lover
Miley Cyrus ::: Easy Lover ::: descripti.extracted_quote: of all her attempts, it's certainly the most sincere, effective, and catchy
Miley Cyrus ::: Easy Lover ::: descripti.review: Certainly not the first time Miley's made her Madonna bid (what white female pop star hasn't?), but of all her attempts, it's certainly the most sincere, effective, and catchy. — D. Caffrey

deBasement & Marie Davidson ::: Juicy Ju.name: Juicy Juice (feat. Marie Davidson)
deBasement & Marie Davidson ::: Juicy Ju.extracted_quote: a fiery, sweaty, and hedonistic anthem that'll keep you coming back for more
deBasement & Marie Davidson ::: Juicy Ju.review: The dance pop duo join forces with Quebecoise producer Marie Davidson for a fiery, sweaty, and hedonistic anthem that’ll keep you coming back for more. — S. Noor

Lord Spikeheart, Iggor Cavalera, & Jonas.artist: Lord Spikeheart, Iggor Cavalera, & Jonas Karsten
Lord Spikeheart, Iggor Cavalera, & Jonas.name: REIGN
Lord Spikeheart, Iggor Cavalera, & Jonas.review: The powerful title track to Lord Spikeheart’s most recent EP unites two notable figures in the global metal scene for a chaotic, boundary-pushing track. — S. Noor

Etran de L'A\u00cfr ::: Agadez ::: descr.name: Agadez
Etran de L'A\u00cfr ::: Agadez ::: descr.extracted_quote: an invitation to dance and a celebration of their hometown
Etran de L'A\u00cfr ::: Agadez ::: descr.review: After over a quarter century mastering the art of making people dance on the Saharan wedding circuit, Etran De L'Aïr finally released their most-requested song — an invitation to dance and a celebration of their hometown. — T. Franklin

Water Damage ::: Reel 25 ::: description.name: Reel 25
Water Damage ::: Reel 25 ::: description.extracted_quote: locking into a groove that lasts longer than an episode of a network sitcom
Water Damage ::: Reel 25 ::: description.review: Listen, I know that a 20-minute, wordless drone rock track isn't going to be everyone's cup of tea, but for those who enjoy locking into a groove that lasts longer than an episode of a network sitcom, "Reel 25" has the potential to be song of the year. — J. Krueger

Dretti Franks ::: Style Watching ::: des.name: Style Watching
Dretti Franks ::: Style Watching ::: des.extracted_quote: uses "Style Watching" to raise his concerns about the state of the game
Dretti Franks ::: Style Watching ::: des.review: Dretti Franks, a Texas rapper-producer with over a decade of experience, uses "Style Watching" to raise his concerns about the state of the game ("N***a, how does a producer need producers to produce?") and call out the copy cats who have unabashedly bitten his style. — K. Fitzgerald

Florist ::: This Was A Gift ::: descript.name: This Was A Gift
Florist ::: This Was A Gift ::: descript.extracted_quote: "This Was a Gift" stands as one of their most moving compositions yet
Florist ::: This Was A Gift ::: descript.review: Florist's Emily Sprague has written more beautiful indie folk tunes than we can count, and even amongst all of that competition, "This Was a Gift" stands as one of their most moving compositions yet. — J. Krueger

Tems ::: Mine ::: description_consequenc.name: Mine
Tems ::: Mine ::: description_consequenc.extracted_quote: crafting love songs that could be equally suited for a physical partner or a higher power
Tems ::: Mine ::: description_consequenc.review: The warm, undulating "Mine" sees the Nigerian alté artist continuing down her path of crafting love songs that could be equally suited for a physical partner or a higher power. — K. Fitzgerald

Morgan Nagler ::: Cradle The Pain ::: de.name: Cradle The Pain
Morgan Nagler ::: Cradle The Pain ::: de.extracted_quote: plants a melodic seed in a garden of crackling, fuzzy guitar tones ... one of the catchiest indie rock jams of the year
Morgan Nagler ::: Cradle The Pain ::: de.review: Morgan Nagler plants a melodic seed in a garden of crackling, fuzzy guitar tones on "Cradle the Pain," out of which grows one of the catchiest indie rock jams of the year. — J. Krueger

Robb Bank$ ::: Eyez Red ::: description_.name: Eyez Red
Robb Bank$ ::: Eyez Red ::: description_.extracted_quote: finds the MC slipping into Jamaican Patois, as well as literally woofing and growling about his status as a big dog
Robb Bank$ ::: Eyez Red ::: description_.review: A dancehall detour from Robb Bank$'s usual flavor of menacing South Florida rap, "Eyez Red" finds the MC slipping into Jamaican Patois, as well as literally woofing and growling about his status as a big dog in independent hip-hop. — K. Fitzgerald

Sabrina Carpenter ::: When Did You Get H.name: When Did You Get Hot?
Sabrina Carpenter ::: When Did You Get H.extracted_quote: Catchy, witty, and almost painfully horny
Sabrina Carpenter ::: When Did You Get H.review: Catchy, witty, and almost painfully horny, “When Did You Get Hot?” is Carpenter at her drooling best. — W. Graves

Nine Inch Nails ::: As Alive As You Need.name: As Alive As You Need Me To Be
Nine Inch Nails ::: As Alive As You Need.extracted_quote: defined how good a fit Reznor and Ross were for the game world
Nine Inch Nails ::: As Alive As You Need.review: The very best thing about Disney's definitely necessary Tron: Ares was the soundtrack from Nine Inch Nails, led by this first single that defined how good a fit Reznor and Ross were for the game world. L.S. Miller

Anxious ::: Bambi\u2019s Theme ::: descr.name: Bambi’s Theme
Anxious ::: Bambi\u2019s Theme ::: descr.extracted_quote: rushes forward with a captivating urgency
Anxious ::: Bambi\u2019s Theme ::: descr.review: Even when it takes a turn towards the sweet and melodic in its verses, the (kinda) title track from Anxious' Bambi rushes forward with a captivating urgency. — J. Krueger

The Beaches ::: Touch Myself ::: descrip.name: Touch Myself
The Beaches ::: Touch Myself ::: descrip.extracted_quote: the dreamy guitars and get knocked on your ass by The Beaches' brutal honesty, vivid details, and Jordan Miller's high-stakes performance
The Beaches ::: Touch Myself ::: descrip.review: Come for the dreamy guitars and get knocked on your ass by The Beaches' brutal honesty, vivid details, and Jordan Miller's high-stakes performance. — P. Ragusa

Saya Gray ::: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON\u201.name: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON’T SPRING 4 LOVE )
Saya Gray ::: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON\u201.extracted_quote: a rewarding shift to a more accessible, anthemic sound
Saya Gray ::: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON\u201.review: Saya Gray's experimental impulses are a joy to follow, but "..THUS IS WHY" is a rewarding shift to a more accessible, anthemic sound. — P. Ragusa

I'm With Her, Sarah Jarosz, Aoife O'Dono.artist: I'm With Her, Sarah Jarosz, Aoife O'Donovan, & Sara Watkins
I'm With Her, Sarah Jarosz, Aoife O'Dono.name: Ancient Light
I'm With Her, Sarah Jarosz, Aoife O'Dono.extracted_quote: this track alone puts them in the supergroup pantheon
I'm With Her, Sarah Jarosz, Aoife O'Dono.review: I'm With Her could have been a fondly remembered one-off folk collaboration, but this track alone puts them in the supergroup pantheon. — B. Kaye

Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.name: The Subway
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.extracted_quote: balancing the moment's melodrama with pure comedy
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.review: The prospect of potentially not hearing a new Chappell Roan album for five more years is a hard pill to swallow, but it’s made easier by how utterly resplendent “The Subway” is. The sumptuous single finds Roan trying to banish the memory of an ex, and the writing excels at balancing the moment’s melodrama (“Made you the villain, evil for just moving on”) with pure comedy (“f—k this city, I’m moving to Saskatchewan”). While the familiar dream-pop production certainly helps vault this song over the top, the clincher is Roan’s singular vocal performance: Even in a catalog filled with all-time performances like “Good Luck, Babe!” and “Casual,” Roan’s got a way with her voice here as she belts that “she got away” on the sublime outro. — S.D.

Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.name: The Subway
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.extracted_quote: a moment of pure cathartic release
Chappell Roan ::: The Subway ::: descrip.review: If there’s still any doubt about Chappell Roan’s star power, just ask the tourism board in Saskatchewan. On The Subway, Roan fantasises about moving to the Canadian province to escape a devastating breakup, a reference that prompted the Saskatchewan tourism board’s website and social media to be inundated in the week following its release. The tongue-in-cheek humour buried in lovelorn yearning that inspired it is a hallmark of Roan’s songwriting. She told Vogue that its release was delayed because she found it “too painful”, but online her powerhouse cry of “ she’s got away ” has soundtracked countless uplifting stories of moving on. Awash with dreampop guitars, dramatic violin and percussion juddering like a train, her soaring vocals mine the moments in early-stage heartbreak when even smelling their perfume is enough to send you spiralling. Despite its melancholy introspection, The Subway is a soundtrack for coming out the other side – a moment of pure cathartic release. -- Sophie Lou Wilson

Brandon Lake & Jelly Roll ::: Hard Fough.name: Hard Fought Hallelujah (with Jelly Roll)
Brandon Lake & Jelly Roll ::: Hard Fough.extracted_quote: Imagine salvation were a W.W.E. match.
Brandon Lake & Jelly Roll ::: Hard Fough.review: Imagine salvation were a W.W.E. match.

Blondshell ::: T&A ::: description_conse.name: T&A
Blondshell ::: T&A ::: description_conse.extracted_quote: A good alternate title for this lyrical confessional could be "Red Fucking Flags," given the way Blondshell describes the nameless gentlemen at its center
Blondshell ::: T&A ::: description_conse.review: A good alternate title for this lyrical confessional could be "Red Fucking Flags," given the way Blondshell describes the nameless gentlemen at its center. — L.S. Miller

CMAT ::: The Jamie Oliver Petrol Station.name: The Jamie Oliver Petrol Station
CMAT ::: The Jamie Oliver Petrol Station.extracted_quote: why did she have to make spite sound so goddamn fun (and funny)?
CMAT ::: The Jamie Oliver Petrol Station.review: If CMAT meant for this soaring (and unapologetically Irish) piece of indie pop to be an interrogation of her own irrational spite toward another celebrity, why did she have to make spite sound so goddamn fun (and funny)? — D. Caffrey

Wet Leg ::: catch these fists ::: descri.name: catch these fists
Wet Leg ::: catch these fists ::: descri.review: It's quick, spiky, and surprisingly heavy: "catch these fists" is Wet Leg returning with a bang and reminding us how much fun they can be. — P. Ragusa

Jason Isbell ::: Good While It Lasted ::.name: Good While It Lasted
Jason Isbell ::: Good While It Lasted ::.extracted_quote: let us in on the emptiness, with the hopes that one day he'll grow from this perspective
Jason Isbell ::: Good While It Lasted ::.review: Jason Isbell knows that, at another time in his life, “Good While It Lasted” would have been an easier song to write. “I wish I still smoked cigarettes and acted tough,” he sings over the earnest strum of his acoustic guitar. To write a breakup song now, he chooses not to rely on the novelistic character studies that once brought him acclaim, and he’s uninterested in the tender, fatherly wisdom that blossomed across his past decade of solo work. “Last night I didn’t sleep at all,” he confesses. “I found another empty wall/And I couldn’t get past it.” His goal here is to let us in on the emptiness, with the hopes that one day he’ll grow from this perspective, too. –Sam Sodomsky

Teethe ::: Holy Water ::: description_co.name: Holy Water
Teethe ::: Holy Water ::: description_co.extracted_quote: has a hook as heavenly as holy water itself
Teethe ::: Holy Water ::: description_co.review: One of the noisier cuts from Teethe's Magic of the Sale , "Holy Water" has a hook as heavenly as holy water itself. — J. Krueger

Charli xcx & John Cale ::: House featuri.name: House featuring John Cale
Charli xcx & John Cale ::: House featuri.extracted_quote: The poem and the gothic soundscape build to a jump-scare of a climax, as more and more terror seeps into the refrain
Charli xcx & John Cale ::: House featuri.review: The poem and the gothic soundscape build to a jump-scare of a climax, as more and more terror seeps into the refrain, “I think I’m gonna die in this house.” — W. Graves

Lorde ::: What Was That ::: description_.name: What Was That
Lorde ::: What Was That ::: description_.extracted_quote: jolting pop listeners awake with bleary images of late city nights and perfect cigarettes
Lorde ::: What Was That ::: description_.review: A dozen years ago, Lorde broke through by greeting the end of the turbo-pop era by declaring “I’m kind of tired of being told to put my hands up in the air — so there”; a lifetime later, the former teen star is a different person with a wider range of sonic interests, but the same instinct to upend expectation. True to its title, “What Was That” served as an immediate course correction from 2021’s blissed-out Solar Power , jolting pop listeners awake with bleary images of late city nights and perfect cigarettes, and saving its main hook for a post-chorus synth squiggle. — J. Lipshutz

Black Country, New Road ::: Besties :::.name: Besties
Black Country, New Road ::: Besties :::.extracted_quote: Maintaining the creative spirit of Black Country, New Road 1.0 while completely altering the sonic approach makes 2.0 a different kind of intriguing
Black Country, New Road ::: Besties :::.review: Maintaining the creative spirit of Black Country, New Road 1.0 while completely altering the sonic approach makes 2.0 a different kind of intriuging. — B. Kaye

Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.name: '06 wayne rooney
Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.extracted_quote: Channeling the spirit of mid-aughts landfill indie and a myriad of bangers from FIFA soundtracks, [the song] shows [he] can hang with the best of the UK's alt-rock messiahs
Jim Legxacy ::: '06 wayne rooney ::: des.review: Channeling the spirit of mid-aughts landfill indie and a myriad of bangers from FIFA soundtracks over the years, Jim Legxacy shows he can hang with the best of the UK's alt-rock messiahs. — P. Ragusa
