The Beths ::: Mother, Pray For Me ::: de.review: Elizabeth Stokes's clear vocals draw tears from any child treading the gulf waters between themselves and their parents. — B. Kaye

Royel Otis ::: moody ::: description_con.name: moody
Royel Otis ::: moody ::: description_con.extracted_quote: how damn catchy this song is
Royel Otis ::: moody ::: description_con.review: Yeah, we kinda hate how damn catchy this song is, too, but dammit that worm doth ear. — Ben Kaye

Thirteendegrees \u00b0 ::: Da Problem So.name: Da Problem Solva
Thirteendegrees \u00b0 ::: Da Problem So.extracted_quote: Thirteen's delivery makes relatively mundane anecdotes ... feel larger than life ... it's the call-and-response style hook ... that proved Thirteendegrees knows how to make the familiar feel fresh
Thirteendegrees \u00b0 ::: Da Problem So.review: At first blush, Tumblr-obsessive turned underground superstar Thirteendegrees might seem derivative, thanks to his Young Thug-inflected flows and Impact font aesthetics. But as he puts it, “ everything comes from something, it’s just about how you twist it .” His woozily maximalist anthems are greater than the sum of their parts, thanks to his playfully glamorous bars and savvy instinct for ultra-wailable hooks. On “Da Problem Solva,” the Chicago rapper yowls about playing mind games with a shawty who “suck my dick so good, had to saaaaang ” over a bed of fizzing synths courtesy of his right-hand producer Gyant. Thirteen’s delivery makes relatively mundane anecdotes about swiping across his girl’s profile on the apps (“Why’d I caught her on Hinge?”) and hitting the studio to make rent money feel larger than life; but it’s the call-and-response style hook, where he waltzes around the track’s infectious Stevie V flip, that proved Thirteendegrees knows how to make the familiar feel fresh. –Vivian Medithi

Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_co.name: Spike Island
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_co.extracted_quote: A synth-y comeback single about the compulsive need to come back despite the critical disinterest ... is so fucking Pulp
Pulp ::: Spike Island ::: description_co.review: A synth-y comeback single about the compulsive need to come back despite the critical disinterest in you going away in the first place is so fucking Pulp. — B. Kaye

EsDeeKid, fakemink, & Rico Ace ::: LV Sa.name: LV Sandals
EsDeeKid, fakemink, & Rico Ace ::: LV Sa.extracted_quote: It's the one grimy fried bass hit that suddenly cuts off on the third beat ... the little noisy artifacts at the beginning and end connect to form a perfect loop in case you wanted to live in this song forever
EsDeeKid, fakemink, & Rico Ace ::: LV Sa.review: It’s just one bar of production, but it’s a perfect bar. It’s the one grimy fried bass hit that suddenly cuts off on the third beat. And it’s also how the bass seems to trigger the synth siren swell. And it’s also the silence on the fourth beat before the bar repeats. And it’s also how, if you have the song on repeat, the little noisy artifacts at the beginning and end connect to form a perfect loop in case you wanted to live in this song forever. fakemink, EsDeeKid, and Rico Ace are all swag, but producer Wraith9 is the show. –Jeremy D. Larson

Wet Leg ::: davina mccall ::: descriptio.name: davina mccall
Wet Leg ::: davina mccall ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: disarm herself and invite a new partner to come inside in an honestly love-besotted rock song like this one
Wet Leg ::: davina mccall ::: descriptio.review: Wet Leg has an image for songs that are either arch (the debut album’s “Chaise Longue”) or aggressive (the latest release’s “Catch These Fists”). But if lead singer Rhian Teasdale can devote herself on the excellent “Moisturizer” album to defensively singing “Mangetout” — as in, “man, get out” — she can also disarm herself and invite a new partner to come inside in an honestly love-besotted rock song like this one. Of course, she and the band have to come at it from an odd angle, which is naming this song of devotion for a TV presenter in London, singing, “I’ll be your Davina… never gonna let you go.” What exactly that connotes, us Yanks can only guess, but it sure sounds flattering. And it sure is sweet to have a few love songs that rock as hard as the handful on their sophomore effort. — Willman

Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_bi.name: mangetout
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_bi.extracted_quote: Broken down, the title is "man get out," and that's as subtle as things get ... the band upshifts to an exhilarating buzz-off banger finale
Wet Leg ::: mangetout ::: description_bi.review: Wet Leg have cornered the market on f—k-off songs. “Ur Mom” on their first album, and “Catch These Fists,” on their follow-up, Moisturizer , are snarky gems, but “Mangetout” is the group’s best yet. Broken down, the title is “man get out,” and that’s as subtle as things get: “Get lost forever,” Rhian Teasdale sings in her punky-but-alluring voice over a bullet train of bass and drums, with a synth-and-guitar vapor trail. Those vocals turn sweet and light for the bridge, but the lyrics don’t: “You’re washed up, irrelevant and standing in my light,” Teasdale says, before the band upshifts to an exhilarating buzz-off banger finale. — F.D.

Justin Bieber ::: YUKON ::: description_.review: Bieber will never escape the power of his high-pitched voice, whether he’s 15 years old singing “One Time” or 31 in this meditation on his favorite SUV. — C.D.

Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_con.review: As one of indie rock's great chameleons, Alex G's tell is always his shambolicism, which suits his flirtations with country music (not to mention its imagery) even more so than other genres. — D. Caffrey

Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_bil.name: Afterlife
Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_bil.extracted_quote: imbues his impressionistic lyrics with a world's worth of emotion, communicating the track's themes of mortality and nostalgia through not just his words, but his vocal delivery too
Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_bil.review: On “Afterlife,” one of best songs Alex Gianmnascoli has ever recorded, the prolific singer-songwriter imbues his impressionistic lyrics – “We were clean like kerosene/ Candy and porno magazines” – with a world’s worth of emotion, communicating the track’s themes of mortality and nostalgia through not just his words, but his vocal delivery too. Also contributing to the track’s wistful vibe: its twinkling instrumental, which conjures R.E.M.’s Automatic for the People with its mandolin and accordion. — E.R.B.

Chat Pile & Hayden Pedigo ::: Radioactiv.review: Hey, you got a little bit of your instrumental, finger-picked guitar composition in my sludge metal song vs. Hey, YOU got a little bit of your sludge metal song in MY instrumental, finger-picked guitar composition! — J. Krueger

Amaarae ::: S.M.O. ::: description_stere.name: S.M.O.
Amaarae ::: S.M.O. ::: description_stere.extracted_quote: she makes lyrics about absolute penetrative filth sound as reverent as "I want to meet the God that made you"
Amaarae ::: S.M.O. ::: description_stere.review: For Ghanaian artist Amaarae, influences are an act; she is deliberate and purposeful about who she lets into her sound. She can tell you the exact highlife artists (obscure-until-recently Ata Kak) and R&B touchstones ("The Pleasure Principle") that animated her music, and exactly to which (and whose) ends she turned them. This allows her to make "S.M.O." (first word: "slut") surprisingly cohesive, even understated, for how much she's kaleidoscoping in; everything is flowing toward one single purpose already answered by the title. Amaraae's vocal is pitched into the uncannily blank, as if she's already half-dissolved into her woman of choice. And her horniness is holistic; she makes lyrics about absolute penetrative filth sound as reverent as "I want to meet the God that made you" and makes orchestra hits and Donna Summer-y moans seem equally charged. She even manages to take Lexapro — an SSRI known for doing pretty much the sexual opposite of this — and make it seductive. — Katherine St. Asaph

daydreamers ::: Good Intentions ::: desc.name: Good Intentions
daydreamers ::: Good Intentions ::: desc.extracted_quote: their natural charisma and feel-good sound, especially on new single, "Good Intentions"
daydreamers ::: Good Intentions ::: desc.review: A few months ago, I had the opportunity to attend a showcase for UK-based group, daydreamers. I was immediately impressed by their natural charisma and feel-good sound, especially on new single, “Good Intentions.” If you’re looking for an indie-pop band with catchy melodies to brighten your playlist, they’re a perfect pick. Keep an eye out for their debut album in 2026.

KAROL G & Feid ::: Verano Rosa ::: descr.name: Verano Rosa
KAROL G & Feid ::: Verano Rosa ::: descr.extracted_quote: a wistful, summer-ready track ... the two musicians embody former flames who long for each other
KAROL G & Feid ::: Verano Rosa ::: descr.review: “Verano Rosa” was famously left on the cutting-room floor during Karol G’s sessions for Mañana Será Bonito ( Bichota Season ); the star revealed the song was a collaboration with fellow Latin music titan Feid in her 2023 Rolling Stone cover story . After two years, Karol and Feid delivered with a wistful, summer-ready track. Against a sunny reggaeton beat, the two musicians embody former flames who long for each other over drunken mid-party phone calls, liquor bottles in hand, and remember their unmatched love. — Maya Georgi

Shallowater ::: Highway ::: description_.name: Highway
Shallowater ::: Highway ::: description_.review: All of Shallowater's great God's Gonna Give You a Million Dollars is prime driving music — at least for us emotional cowboys and "dirtgazers" — and that goes double for the record's centerpiece, "Highway." — J. Krueger

Sabrina Carpenter ::: Manchild ::: descr.name: Manchild
Sabrina Carpenter ::: Manchild ::: descr.extracted_quote: a sugary No. 1 smash ... admits a certain culpability
Sabrina Carpenter ::: Manchild ::: descr.review: Sabrina Carpenter’s latest three-and-a-half-minute stand-up set disguised as a sugary No. 1 smash seems at first to be an unsparing roast of a Neanderthal-esque ex: “Why so sexy if so dumb, and how survive the Earth so long?” But by the bridge, Carpenter admits a certain culpability, chasing the admission “I like my men all incompetent” with a flirty wink at some potential man-children in waiting: “Hey, men!”

Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.name: Pussy Palace
Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.extracted_quote: the staggeringly specific details ... and catchy earworm of a chorus that made this the immediate centrepiece of the record
Lily Allen ::: Pussy Palace ::: descript.review: When Lily Allen’s West End Girl album dropped earlier this year, spilling all the gory details of a marital breakdown, it was a cultural moment like no other. The days that followed felt like a return to the golden age of terrestrial television-based water cooler chat – back when everyone was dying to gossip about the same cliff-hanger episode of a TV show they’d watched the night before. My WhatsApp group chats began popping off in real time not long after the album’s release, as friends from all walks of life swapped lyrics and exchanged suggestive emojis. Though the whole thing is a masterpiece, designed to be listened to in full as it tells the story of a woman first heartbroken, then scorned, then released, the stand-out track is undoubtedly “Pussy Palace”. It’s the staggeringly specific details – that infamous Duane Reade bag and its mucky contents, for example – and catchy earworm of a chorus that made this the immediate centrepiece of the record and one of the most undeniably zeitgeist songs of 2025. Helen Coffey

kwn ::: do what i say ::: description_co.name: do what i say
kwn ::: do what i say ::: description_co.extracted_quote: kwn's breakthrough single that grabbed the R&B world's attention
kwn ::: do what i say ::: description_co.review: Steeped in the most carnal of desires, "do what i say" stands as East London songwriter-producer kwn's (pronounced kay-one) breakthrough single that grabbed the R&B world's attention. — K. Fitzgerald

Cate Le Bon & John Cale ::: Ride ::: des.name: Ride
Cate Le Bon & John Cale ::: Ride ::: des.review: The Welsh musician and songwriter has a knack for crafting profoundly moving songs, and this track brims with emotional intensity. — S. Noor

Monaleo ::: Dignified ::: description_co.name: Dignified
Monaleo ::: Dignified ::: description_co.extracted_quote: a cinematic experience that unravels the irrevocable consequences of drunk driving
Monaleo ::: Dignified ::: description_co.review: Houston singer-rapper Monaleo employs both of her skills as an artist to deliver a cinematic experience that unravels the irrevocable consequences of drunk driving: "We turning up, I hate to be a party pooper/ Don't you know that Death is on the prowl and he could scoop ya?" — K. Fitzgerald

Joanne Robertson & Oliver Coates ::: Dou.name: Doubt
Joanne Robertson & Oliver Coates ::: Dou.review: When it comes to Joanne Robertson's ambient-leaning folk, there's nothing to doubt. — J. Krueger

Black Country, New Road ::: Besties :::.name: Besties
Black Country, New Road ::: Besties :::.extracted_quote: Maintaining the creative spirit of Black Country, New Road 1.0 while completely altering the sonic approach
Black Country, New Road ::: Besties :::.review: Maintaining the creative spirit of Black Country, New Road 1.0 while completely altering the sonic approach makes 2.0 a different kind of intriuging. — B. Kaye

Rico Nasty ::: ON THE LOW ::: descriptio.name: ON THE LOW
Rico Nasty ::: ON THE LOW ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: a pop-punk-rap song that feels like a new chemical compound
Rico Nasty ::: ON THE LOW ::: descriptio.review: Has there been a more potent combo of a G-rated chorus and blush-worthy bars? The DMV rapper, who has been known to call herself "Trap Lavigne," is Disney material one second and Skinemax the next. Throw in the hook's Satriani synths and you have a pop-punk-rap song that feels like a new chemical compound. —Otis Hart, NPR

Brandee Younger ::: Gadabout Season :::.name: Gadabout Season
Brandee Younger ::: Gadabout Season :::.extracted_quote: merges Alice Coltrane-inspired cosmic swirls with precise, pop-like bursts to boldly tip-toe around a modern framework
Brandee Younger ::: Gadabout Season :::.review: In a continually updated interpretation of jazz — and of the harp within that context — this lilting tidal flow displays that of a restless seeker set on the discovery of new frontiers. Younger merges Alice Coltrane-inspired cosmic swirls with precise, pop-like bursts to boldly tip-toe around a modern framework. — Liz Warner , WDET

Fust ::: Spangled ::: description_npr25.name: Spangled
Fust ::: Spangled ::: description_npr25.extracted_quote: invisible and transcendent, as the guitars rise like a monument
Fust ::: Spangled ::: description_npr25.review: The ghost buildings of the American South, disappeared by redevelopment, echo with lost voices. North Carolina's Fust goes fully anthemic in this elegy for a torn-down hospital sung by a soul who once lay in one of its adjustable beds. "I feel like a sparkler that's been thrown off a roof," he wails, invisible and transcendent, as the guitars rise like a monument. —Ann Powers, NPR

Madison McFerrin ::: Ain't It Nice ::: d.name: Ain't It Nice
Madison McFerrin ::: Ain't It Nice ::: d.extracted_quote: The sensual house beat, paired with her unmistakable vocals, layered harmonies and seductive lyrics get your body moving
Madison McFerrin ::: Ain't It Nice ::: d.review: On her sophomore album, independent artist Madison McFerrin encompasses the passion, transformation and rebirth that Scorpio season is known for. The sensual house beat, paired with her unmistakable vocals, layered harmonies and seductive lyrics get your body moving and make you notice that Madison made it through "on the other side." — Margarita Azucar , KALW

Ledisi ::: BLKWMN ::: description_npr25.name: BLKWMN
Ledisi ::: BLKWMN ::: description_npr25.extracted_quote: A powerful anthem honoring the strength, resilience and emotional depth of Black women
Ledisi ::: BLKWMN ::: description_npr25.review: A powerful anthem honoring the strength, resilience and emotional depth of Black women. Ledisi celebrates the historic and ongoing fight for dignity, love and visibility, acknowledging both pain and triumph. The song insists that Black women deserve respect, recognition and freedom to exist fully, boldly and unapologetically. —Bella Scratch, The Drop (Rocky Mountain Public Media)

Natalia Lafourcade & El David Aguilar ::.name: Como Quisiera Quererte
Natalia Lafourcade & El David Aguilar ::.extracted_quote: this story of tragic love is so artfully done that Lafourcade's name should now be mentioned alongside the most iconic of Mexican bolero songwriters
Natalia Lafourcade & El David Aguilar ::.review: Cancionera translates to "singer," but it's also the name of Natalia Lafourcade's alter ego and an achingly beautiful collection of songs that sway between jazz ballads and Mexican boleros. "Como Quisiera Quererte" pulses along to a classic Mexican waltz, and this story of tragic love is so artfully done that Lafourcade's name should now be mentioned alongside the most iconic of Mexican bolero songwriters. —Felix Contreras, NPR

yeule ::: Dudu ::: description_npr25 :::.name: Dudu
yeule ::: Dudu ::: description_npr25 :::.extracted_quote: vocals raw and out front, but singing a childlike hook with a Casio's cold resolve, smearing messy heartbreak scenes into the shape of a nursery rhyme
yeule ::: Dudu ::: description_npr25 :::.review: Nat Ćmiel has always been an enigma on-mic, their emotional identity merged hazily with the machines that warp and crush their voice. "Dudu" inverts the formula: vocals raw and out front, but singing a childlike hook with a Casio's cold resolve, smearing messy heartbreak scenes into the shape of a nursery rhyme. —Daoud Tyler-Ameen, NPR

Jane Remover ::: Dreamflasher ::: descri.name: Dreamflasher
Jane Remover ::: Dreamflasher ::: descri.extracted_quote: "Dreamflasher," which is like strapping subwoofers to a slot machine, and then experiencing the whole bass-boosted phantasmagoria as a zonked-out AR video game simulation
Jane Remover ::: Dreamflasher ::: descri.review: It is such a perfect twist of fate that digicore, the hyperpop offshoot defined by its chaotic, cybernetic maximalism, was born on a platform called Discord. And there is no grander ambassador than Jane Remover, who turns that dissonance into a flood of dopamine hits. Just take "Dreamflasher," which is like strapping subwoofers to a slot machine, and then experiencing the whole bass-boosted phantasmagoria as a zonked-out AR video game simulation. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.name: Sue me
Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.extracted_quote: a pulsing beat that somehow makes a line like "sue me I wanna be UH! / sue me I wanna be YEAH!" hit so hard
Audrey Hobert ::: Sue me ::: description.review: As any good rule follower knows, "Being a saint is exhausting." Avant-garde pop newcomer Audrey Hobert sings that line in the "Sue me" pre-chorus before detailing her messy desires. The cheeky verses are delivered stream-of-consciousness style over a pulsing beat that somehow makes a line like "sue me I wanna be UH! / sue me I wanna be YEAH!" hit so hard. —Elle Mannion, NPR

John Oswald & Marc-Andr\u00e9 Hamelin ::.name: Tip
John Oswald & Marc-Andr\u00e9 Hamelin ::.extracted_quote: has seamlessly stitched several dozen colorful threads of classical, pop and jazz themes into this piece
John Oswald & Marc-Andr\u00e9 Hamelin ::.review: This brilliantly executed musical puzzler asks us to "name that tune" throughout its gently rollicking nine minutes. With utmost taste and a sly, precise performance by pianist Marc-André Hamelin, composer John Oswald has seamlessly stitched several dozen colorful threads of classical, pop and jazz themes into this piece. From Beethoven's "Moonlight" sonata to "Nature Boy," I spot around 20 references, but it seems like just the tip of the iceberg. How many do you hear? —Tom Huizenga, NPR

S.G. Goodman ::: Snapping Turtle ::: des.name: Snapping Turtle
S.G. Goodman ::: Snapping Turtle ::: des.extracted_quote: takes Laurel Canyon-style confessional songwriting to the hollers of Kentucky
S.G. Goodman ::: Snapping Turtle ::: des.review: No song this year was more brutally honest, or more sublime, than this one, which takes Laurel Canyon-style confessional songwriting to the hollers of Kentucky. A childhood scene of cruelty and punishment underpins a rageful lament about what and who gets stuck in the small towns whose exit lanes lead nowhere. "Small town is where my mind gets stuck," sings Goodman, surveying the damage, wondering what it takes to heal. —Ann Powers, NPR

Zach Top ::: Between The Ditches ::: des.name: Between The Ditches
Zach Top ::: Between The Ditches ::: des.extracted_quote: delivers sentiment that transcends the years in a simple, emotive and meaningful telling
Zach Top ::: Between The Ditches ::: des.review: The latest addition to country music's time-honored confessional canon. Like George Strait and Keith Whitley before him, Top delivers sentiment that transcends the years in a simple, emotive and meaningful telling of a hard-lived life ("I've been woke up by more than one guard rail"). — Jessie Scott , WMOT

Rolf Lislevand ::: Passacaglia al modo m.name: Passacaglia al modo mio
Rolf Lislevand ::: Passacaglia al modo m.extracted_quote: the quiet, yet astonishing colors and textures of the lute
Rolf Lislevand ::: Passacaglia al modo m.review: In our noisy, agitated world, Rolf Lislevand asks us to slow down and listen to the quiet, yet astonishing colors and textures of the lute — specifically in this song, the traditional Renaissance lute's beefier, longer-necked sibling, the archlute. Inspired by the 17th century theme and variations passacaglia, the Norwegian lutenist crafts a smoldering, mocha-colored descending bassline and, near the close, pays homage to a few of his faves by plucking fragments of Bach, Beethoven and Keith Jarrett. —Tom Huizenga, NPR

Saint Levant ::: WAZIRA / \u0648\u0632\u.name: WAZIRA / وزيرة
Saint Levant ::: WAZIRA / \u0648\u0632\u.extracted_quote: blends Palestinian rhythms and a shake of desert blues into a romantic celebration infused with the joy of returning from exile
Saint Levant ::: WAZIRA / \u0648\u0632\u.review: After 2024's explicitly political album, Diera , the Palestinian Algerian pop star Saint Levant returned to his loverboy roots this year, but with new depth and awareness. Cowritten with Palestinian percussionist Fares Anbar and Egyptian guitarist Khafage, this ode to a female "ambassador but for feelings" blends Palestinian rhythms and a shake of desert blues into a romantic celebration infused with the joy of returning from exile. —Ann Powers, NPR

Little Simz ::: Free ::: description_npr.name: Free
Little Simz ::: Free ::: description_npr.extracted_quote: a reminder of one's true essence, often masked by societal pressures and personal fears
Little Simz ::: Free ::: description_npr.review: Every time this song played this year, I was inspired to embrace my true self in all aspects of life. It reflects on love and freedom, serving as a reminder of one's true essence, often masked by societal pressures and personal fears. It's a call to live authentically in order to succeed. — Aaron Monty , WNXP

Robert Forster ::: Tell It Back to Me ::.name: Tell It Back to Me
Robert Forster ::: Tell It Back to Me ::.extracted_quote: a jangly pop gem with taut guitar melodies and the nuance of an entire romantic life sketched in minutes
Robert Forster ::: Tell It Back to Me ::.review: Nearly five decades into his career, Forster has written dozens upon dozens of great songs in The Go-Betweens and solo, some of them even perfect. Count this among the latter — a jangly pop gem with taut guitar melodies and the nuance of an entire romantic life sketched in minutes. —Lars Gotrich, NPR

Sharp Pins ::: I Can\u2019t Stop ::: des.name: I Can’t Stop
Sharp Pins ::: I Can\u2019t Stop ::: des.extracted_quote: Heart-warmingly retro and refreshingly modern; expertly-crafted, yet never too fussy
Sharp Pins ::: I Can\u2019t Stop ::: des.review: Sharp Pins is the jangly GBV-esque project of Chicago's Kai Slater (also of post-punk project Lifeguard). This song comes from the expanded version of the glum-yet-glimmering Radio DDR , where Slater's "home-punk" songs roll just right. Heart-warmingly retro and refreshingly modern; expertly-crafted, yet never too fussy. — Erin Wolf , Radio Milwaukee

Terri Lyne Carrington, Christie Dashiell.artist: Terri Lyne Carrington, Christie Dashiell, Weedie Braimah, Milena Casado, Morgan Guerin, Simon Moullier, & Matthew Stevens
Terri Lyne Carrington, Christie Dashiell.name: Freedom Day (Part 2)
Terri Lyne Carrington, Christie Dashiell.extracted_quote: If you are free, you are not predictable or controllable.
Terri Lyne Carrington, Christie Dashiell.review: "If you are free, you are not predictable or controllable." That comes from a spoken word section of this insightful update to 1960's protest album We Insist! Carrington and Dashiell bring an urgency to this Max Roach and Oscar Brown classic, which more than stands up to the inevitable comparisons. — Andy O , KUVO Jazz

Turnstile ::: LOOK OUT FOR ME ::: descri.name: LOOK OUT FOR ME
Turnstile ::: LOOK OUT FOR ME ::: descri.extracted_quote: hairpin turns that previously defined Turnstile's genre-agnostic hardcore come into prismatic view, gliding from anthemic riffs and gossamer shoegaze to dreamy R&B and blissed-out techno
Turnstile ::: LOOK OUT FOR ME ::: descri.review: The ambitious scope of NEVER ENOUGH in composite. In under seven minutes, the hairpin turns that previously defined Turnstile's genre-agnostic hardcore come into prismatic view, gliding from anthemic riffs and gossamer shoegaze to dreamy R&B and blissed-out techno. —Lars Gotrich, NPR

Resavoir, Matt Gold, & Mei Semones ::: D.name: Diversey Beach
Resavoir, Matt Gold, & Mei Semones ::: D.extracted_quote: mundane worries like "buying a couch" evoke the lovely ebb and flow of a vast freshwater sea
Resavoir, Matt Gold, & Mei Semones ::: D.review: Resavoir is Chicago producer, trumpeter and composer Will Miller. In this jazzy, Latin-tinged groove, mundane worries like "buying a couch" evoke the lovely ebb and flow of a vast freshwater sea (in this case, Lake Michigan, where you can find the song's namesake harbor). The suggested scale makes most problems feel small. — Ayana Contreras , KUVO Jazz

Lana Del Rey ::: Henry, come on ::: desc.name: Henry, come on
Lana Del Rey ::: Henry, come on ::: desc.extracted_quote: Lana often makes tragedy sound like romance ... amid chamber pop musings, the mystifying trance of a pastoral fantasy slowly comes undone
Lana Del Rey ::: Henry, come on ::: desc.review: No shocker that Miss Americana would embrace the Yeehaw Agenda; even less so that her sweeping country panorama revolves around a restless cowboy who can't (or more likely won't) settle down. Lana often makes tragedy sound like romance. Here, amid chamber pop musings, the mystifying trance of a pastoral fantasy slowly comes undone. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Olivia Dean ::: Man I Need ::: descripti.name: Man I Need
Olivia Dean ::: Man I Need ::: descripti.extracted_quote: jazzy pop and soulful grooves paired with Dean's calm and collected vocals
Olivia Dean ::: Man I Need ::: descripti.review: Regardless of scenery or demographic, this song is infectious. Its jazzy pop and soulful grooves paired with Dean's calm and collected vocals deliver lyrics about not being afraid to ask to be loved. Be prepared to hear this song at weddings from this day forward if you haven't already. — Marquis Munson , WNXP

Royel Otis ::: moody ::: description_npr.name: moody
Royel Otis ::: moody ::: description_npr.extracted_quote: heavy Primal Scream vibe, creeping verses that explode into a soaring refrain
Royel Otis ::: moody ::: description_npr.review: Just put it on repeat — or even better, give me an endless extended remix. With its heavy Primal Scream vibe, creeping verses that explode into a soaring refrain and the cheeky lyrics from a character who's done no wrong, the Sydney duo absolutely nail it. Haven't you lived this couple's quarrel? I have! — Delphine Blue , WFUV

Saya Gray ::: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON\u201.name: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON’T SPRING 4 LOVE )
Saya Gray ::: ..THUS IS WHY ( I DON\u201.review: The start of spring isn't always romantic: To get vibrant blooms and golden leaves, you sometimes have to endure dark days and freezing rain. But if you stay present through it all, you can learn something about commitment. "You woke up yesterday," the inventive artist Saya Gray sings of heartbreak on this folk-pop song. "I watched the seasons change." —Elle Mannion, NPR

PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.name: WHIM WHAMIEE
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.extracted_quote: intergenerationally infectious, the mix of icy Zaytoven production and buoyant, drawled flows conjuring the spirit of Freaknik
PLUTO & YKNIECE ::: WHIM WHAMIEE ::: des.review: "WHIM WHAMIEE" feels like Atlanta trap kismet: A 21-year-old hairstylist stumbling upon a YouTube beat that sampled D4L rapper Mook B's "Whim Wham," a song traced back from her favorite local dance. Her homage is intergenerationally infectious, the mix of icy Zaytoven production and buoyant, drawled flows conjuring the spirit of Freaknik. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Big Thief ::: Los Angeles ::: descriptio.name: Los Angeles
Big Thief ::: Los Angeles ::: descriptio.extracted_quote: a warmth tinged with regret, an understanding colored by experience ... the sweet vocal harmonies and bright layers of guitar on this track can do it for us
Big Thief ::: Los Angeles ::: descriptio.review: On this sunkissed and unhurried rocker, Adrianne Lenker sings of a love that transcends time, space, speech and sight. It's a warmth tinged with regret, an understanding colored by experience, a feeling that can't be described with words. Good thing the sweet vocal harmonies and bright layers of guitar on this track can do it for us. — Lukas Harnisch , WBUR

I'm With Her, Sarah Jarosz, Aoife O'Dono.artist: I'm With Her, Sarah Jarosz, Aoife O'Donovan, & Sara Watkins
I'm With Her, Sarah Jarosz, Aoife O'Dono.name: Ancient Light
I'm With Her, Sarah Jarosz, Aoife O'Dono.extracted_quote: taps into a rare kind of magic ... immediately draws us in with warm, timeless tones
I'm With Her, Sarah Jarosz, Aoife O'Dono.review: I'm With Her taps into a rare kind of magic. "Ancient Light" immediately draws us in with warm, timeless tones and angular, geometric rhythm. The coven of master musicians brings everything into focus with a cryptic, lyrical meditation on surrender and our place in the natural world. — John Inghram , Mountain Stage

Florry ::: First it was a movie, then it.name: First it was a movie, then it was a book
Florry ::: First it was a movie, then it.extracted_quote: draws on Crazy Horse guitar energy disguised as an Americana Southern indie-rock rager, with lead singer and guitarist Francie Medosch's beautiful off-kilter vocals front and center
Florry ::: First it was a movie, then it.review: On the opening song of their recent album, Sounds Like…, the Philly rockers of Florry continue to wear their Neil Young influences on their sleeves in only the best way. It draws on Crazy Horse guitar energy disguised as an Americana Southern indie-rock rager, with lead singer and guitarist Francie Medosch's beautiful off-kilter vocals front and center. — Bruce Warren , WXPN

Silvana Estrada ::: Dime ::: description.name: Dime
Silvana Estrada ::: Dime ::: description.extracted_quote: carries us through an emotional unraveling that hits home for so many
Silvana Estrada ::: Dime ::: description.review: Love, heartbreak and loss can sit so heavy on the mind, but Silvana Estrada's way of releasing all those layered feelings is special. "Dime" carries us through an emotional unraveling that hits home for so many. She's giving herself and us permission to let go, so let go. — Kenny Perez , Radio Milwaukee

The Beths ::: Mother, Pray For Me ::: de.name: Mother, Pray For Me
The Beths ::: Mother, Pray For Me ::: de.extracted_quote: explores her relationship with her mother, her mother's faith and her own relationship to religion in a song that is perhaps the quartet's most deeply personal ... yet
The Beths ::: Mother, Pray For Me ::: de.review: Anchored by a contemplative guitar arpeggio and just a touch of organ pads, the eponymous Elizabeth Stokes explores her relationship with her mother, her mother's faith and her own relationship to religion in a song that is perhaps the Auckland, New Zealand, quartet's most deeply personal (and beautiful) yet. — Michael Pollard , WNXP

Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.name: Doot Doot (6 7)
Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.extracted_quote: the song is undeniable ... drill dressed up in a Jason Voorhees mask
Skrilla ::: Doot Doot (6 7) ::: descript.review: Surely you've heard of "6 7," even if you haven't heard "Doot Doot (6 7)." The in-joke of the year originates here, with Philly trap so inescapable it spawned an unkillable monster, with Skrilla even popping up as the special guest at a Natasha Bedingfield show. However you feel about the trend, the song is undeniable, and honestly probably intrinsic to whatever humor may be derived from the meme itself — campy and creepy, like the best classic horror cinema, it's drill dressed up in a Jason Voorhees mask. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.name: Sex Life
Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.extracted_quote: These skull-rattling subs and celestial synths are what hi-res audio was made for
Tracey & Riko Dan ::: Sex Life ::: descr.review: We've chosen the slightly less profane version of this carnal mantra for all you pearl-clutchers out there. While the salacious lyrics elevate "Sex Life" from tune to chuuuune! , the anonymous electronic duo from London earned a spot on this list thanks to their production skills. These skull-rattling subs and celestial synths are what hi-res audio was made for. —Otis Hart, NPR

Cate Le Bon & John Cale ::: Ride ::: des.name: Ride
Cate Le Bon & John Cale ::: Ride ::: des.extracted_quote: a knack for crafting profoundly moving songs
Cate Le Bon & John Cale ::: Ride ::: des.review: The Welsh musician and songwriter has a knack for crafting profoundly moving songs, and this track brims with emotional intensity. — S. Noor

Fuerza Regida ::: Marlboro Rojo ::: desc.name: Marlboro Rojo
Fuerza Regida ::: Marlboro Rojo ::: desc.extracted_quote: smolders with Fuerza Regida's signature blend of gritty corridos, smoky swagger and lived-in storytelling
Fuerza Regida ::: Marlboro Rojo ::: desc.review: "Marlboro Rojo" smolders with Fuerza Regida's signature blend of gritty corridos, smoky swagger and lived-in storytelling. Rooted in the ranchos and trenches that shaped the group, the track moves between heartbreak and defiance, its hypnotic groove and raw vocals making it an addictive, unfiltered standout. — Eryka , KALW

Lucius ::: Gold Rush ::: description_npr.name: Gold Rush
Lucius ::: Gold Rush ::: description_npr.extracted_quote: With a funk-fueled, thumping bassline and fearless two-part harmonies, they dish on the sugar high and inevitable crash of love and obsessions
Lucius ::: Gold Rush ::: description_npr.review: Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig, the two singers at the center of Lucius, have always had a gift for crafting earworm melodies. But "Gold Rush," which comes nearly 20 years after they started working together, is one of their all-time best. With a funk-fueled, thumping bassline and fearless two-part harmonies, they dish on the sugar high and inevitable crash of love and obsessions. —Robin Hilton, NPR

Dijon ::: Yamaha ::: description_npr25 :.name: Yamaha
Dijon ::: Yamaha ::: description_npr25 :.extracted_quote: a straightforward expression of desire and an ode to desire itself
Dijon ::: Yamaha ::: description_npr25 :.review: Dijon does his best Prince impression, if the ghost of Prince was resurrected through the warping circuitry of a motherboard. "Yamaha" is at once a straightforward expression of desire and an ode to desire itself. "I'm in love with this particular emotion," Dijon sings, deconstructing his own feelings with the same eccentric verve that he does the sounds of popular music. — Amelia Mason , WBUR

Sabrina Carpenter ::: Manchild ::: descr.name: Manchild
Sabrina Carpenter ::: Manchild ::: descr.extracted_quote: nudges her pop sound in the direction of vintage country with a perfectly balanced symphony of light-as-air synths, barroom fiddle and riffs worthy of a broken cassette deck
Sabrina Carpenter ::: Manchild ::: descr.review: On this ode to dudes stuck in second gear, the bawdiest, funniest, most successful of 2024's pop breakthroughs proves that her act was no fluke. Carpenter nudges her pop sound in the direction of vintage country with a perfectly balanced symphony of light-as-air synths, barroom fiddle and riffs worthy of a broken cassette deck. She delivers setups and punchlines worthy of the rimshot in the chorus and rolls her eyes adorably through one of the year's best videos. Possibly her best song yet. Definitely the calling card of a pop star who intends to stick around. —Jacob Ganz, NPR

HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_n.name: Relationships
HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_n.extracted_quote: the song jerks forward and back, questions itself then speeds forward, just like, well, a relationship
HAIM ::: Relationships ::: description_n.review: "What's all this talk about relationships?" feels like the question an alien would ask if it came to Earth and didn't get what was going on. But after listening to HAIM's "Relationships," I am also that alien, wondering what the word even means, what the thing even means, what the real deal is with relationships as the song jerks forward and back, questions itself then speeds forward, just like, well, a relationship. — Zoe Kurland , Marfa Public Radio

Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.name: It's a Mirror
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.extracted_quote: few more intimate depictions of such seclusion: as twinged Americana opens upon a self-lacerating performance
Perfume Genius ::: It's a Mirror ::: des.review: Mike Hadreas wrote this song in a headspace of self-isolating loops, retreating into dark thoughts that only made him want to withdraw further from the world. Rinse and repeat, until the loop becomes an ouroboros. There are few more intimate depictions of such seclusion: as twinged Americana opens upon a self-lacerating performance. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_npr.name: Afterlife
Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_npr.extracted_quote: breathing new life into old sounds, and at its best pulls off the trick of making indie rock feel ephemeral and eternal
Alex G ::: Afterlife ::: description_npr.review: If you were old enough to tune a radio during the early '90s, which Alex Giannascoli was not, the mandolin riff wrapped around "Afterlife" like a well-worn flannel will inevitably recall R.E.M.'s "Losing My Religion." It's a typically self-aware move for our preeminent alt-rock revivalist, who made the jump to a major label this year. But there's a deeper link to the heartbeat of the whole Alex G project, which has always been about breathing new life into old sounds, and at its best pulls off the trick of making indie rock feel ephemeral and eternal. —Jacob Ganz, NPR

Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_npr25 ::.name: Taxes
Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_npr25 ::.extracted_quote: lead singer Cameron Winter is a martyr, begging for crucifixion over the banal act of filing his taxes
Geese ::: Taxes ::: description_npr25 ::.review: Geese was a cult phenomenon in 2025. Even Nick Cave said "all worry is laid to waste" when listening to the rock band. Here, lead singer Cameron Winter is a martyr, begging for crucifixion over the banal act of filing his taxes. The band rips the sky open, hitting the punchline. — Justin Barney , Nashville Public Radio

Joanne Robertson & Oliver Coates ::: Dou.name: Doubt
Joanne Robertson & Oliver Coates ::: Dou.review: When it comes to Joanne Robertson's ambient-leaning folk, there's nothing to doubt. — J. Krueger

Sports Team ::: Boys These Days ::: desc.name: Boys These Days
Sports Team ::: Boys These Days ::: desc.extracted_quote: Oh, you youngins with your iPhones and Starbucks and instant convenience
Sports Team ::: Boys These Days ::: desc.review: Oh, you youngins with your iPhones and Starbucks and instant convenience — back in my day, everything was harder, so God forbid anything be easier for you! — P. Ragusa

Valerie June ::: Endless Tree ::: descri.name: Endless Tree
Valerie June ::: Endless Tree ::: descri.extracted_quote: From the drumbeat that sounds like a beating heart to the uniqueness of her voice, there's a lot to love about this song
Valerie June ::: Endless Tree ::: descri.review: From the drumbeat that sounds like a beating heart to the uniqueness of her voice, there's a lot to love about this song. The message about hope and the possibility of peace resonates, particularly in a year like 2025. "May you feel moved after hearing this song," she sings. Absolutely, Valerie June! — Jon Adler , Radio Milwaukee

Tanishk Bagchi, Faheem Abdullah, Arslan.artist: Tanishk Bagchi, Faheem Abdullah, Arslan Nizami, & Irshad Kamil
Tanishk Bagchi, Faheem Abdullah, Arslan.name: Saiyaara
Tanishk Bagchi, Faheem Abdullah, Arslan.extracted_quote: With its oceanic melody and a soul-ripping vocal performance, it truly achieves "I'll never let go, Jack" pathos
Tanishk Bagchi, Faheem Abdullah, Arslan.review: With nearly 850 million combined streams on Spotify and YouTube, this title song from the melodrama that swept Bollywood this year is the "My Heart Will Go On" of South Asia. With its oceanic melody and a soul-ripping vocal performance from Kashmiri newcomer Faheem Abdullah, it truly achieves "I'll never let go, Jack" pathos. —Ann Powers, NPR

Patrick Watson ::: Peter and the Wolf ::.name: Peter and the Wolf
Patrick Watson ::: Peter and the Wolf ::.extracted_quote: flutters about in magical ways, full of wondrous sounds and a fairytale narrative, bristling with both a creeping unease and profound beauty
Patrick Watson ::: Peter and the Wolf ::.review: After suffering a vocal chord hemorrhage at the end of 2022, Patrick Watson was told he might never speak again, let alone sing. But after a year and a half of uncertainty, his voice came back — and it sounds as beguiling as ever. "Peter and the Wolf," like much of his music, flutters about in magical ways, full of wondrous sounds and a fairytale narrative, bristling with both a creeping unease and profound beauty. —Robin Hilton, NPR

Gelli Haha ::: Bounce House ::: descript.name: Bounce House
Gelli Haha ::: Bounce House ::: descript.extracted_quote: turns growing pains into glitter, blending wobbling analog effects with a rush of playful chaos
Gelli Haha ::: Bounce House ::: descript.review: "Bounce House" turns growing pains into glitter, blending wobbling analog effects with a rush of playful chaos. It feels like a kid's party viewed through a kaleidoscope, but beneath the silliness is a sharp songwriter arriving with total confidence. A bright, addictive debut that refuses to tone itself down. — Alejandro Cohen , KCRW

Summer Walker, Latto, & Doja Cat ::: Go.name: Go Girl (with Latto & Doja Cat)
Summer Walker, Latto, & Doja Cat ::: Go.extracted_quote: "Go Girl" is the self-love mantra of a woman ready to flaunt her worth
Summer Walker, Latto, & Doja Cat ::: Go.review: When R&B singer-songwriter Summer Walker channels her inner rapper, it might be time to put your man on a shorter leash. "Eat it up / Whole plate / Got your hook / I'm bait," she rhymes over a seductive beat. Baby-mama drama and sidepiece antics aside, independence has always been Walker's calling card — but demonstrating the power of the P is not a solitary mission, with Latto and Doja contributing equally sticky verses. If Finally Over It is Walker's emancipation proclamation, "Go Girl" is the self-love mantra of a woman ready to flaunt her worth. —Rodney Carmichael, NPR

Theo Croker, Malaya, & D'LEAU ::: high v.name: high vibrations
Theo Croker, Malaya, & D'LEAU ::: high v.extracted_quote: Amapiano and garage meet jazz in the club
Theo Croker, Malaya, & D'LEAU ::: high v.review: Amapiano and garage meet jazz in the club. Someone pours a stiff cocktail. The heady results of that convergence are evidenced in this song. Trumpeter Croker dances electric with vocalist Malaya, while D'LEAU, whom I first encountered decades ago through his work in J*Davey, adds just the right je ne sais quoi . — Ayana Contreras , KUVO Jazz

Bad Bunny ::: BAILE INoLVIDABLE ::: desc.name: BAILE INoLVIDABLE
Bad Bunny ::: BAILE INoLVIDABLE ::: desc.extracted_quote: The song comes alive in a complex expression of communal pain
Bad Bunny ::: BAILE INoLVIDABLE ::: desc.review: " Mientras uno está vivo, uno debe amar lo más que pueda ," Jacobo Morales challenges before this track explodes into big band glory, invoking a question that has perplexed and propelled generations of salseros: Can heartbreak catch you if cut to the beat of chest-thumping clave and tumbao? In improvised moments, musicians perform nuanced replies. The song comes alive in a complex expression of communal pain, revealing the answer. "You taught me to love," the chorus laments and, worse, "You taught me to dance." In salsa, there's no getting over that. —Anamaria Sayre, NPR

Tyler Childers ::: Bitin' List ::: descr.name: Bitin' List
Tyler Childers ::: Bitin' List ::: descr.extracted_quote: contracting a fatal, brain-inflaming, fury-inducing virus would occasion an opportunity for carefully planned payback
Tyler Childers ::: Bitin' List ::: descr.review: I nearly choked laughing the first time I heard Childers' poisonous IOU. Certainly the only song of 2025 to include the lyric "seizure-fraught spinal rot," "Bitin' List" imagines a scenario in which contracting a fatal, brain-inflaming, fury-inducing virus would occasion an opportunity for carefully planned payback as a final act. You really have to piss someone off good to earn ire this specific and elaborately conceived. —Jacob Ganz, NPR

Noname & Devin Morrison ::: Hundred Acre.name: Hundred Acres
Noname & Devin Morrison ::: Hundred Acre.extracted_quote: a liberatory bop for colored folk sick of compromising their get up and go
Noname & Devin Morrison ::: Hundred Acre.review: Ain't no freeing the land without breaking free of the shackles on our imagination. For Noname, touching grass, raising a blunt and "eating honey with Winnie on Hundred Acre Woods" is the ultimate escapist manifesto. Blurring the line between fantasy and friction on the first single from her forthcoming album, Cartoon Radio , she delivers a liberatory bop for colored folk sick of compromising their get up and go. We outside. —Rodney Carmichael, NPR

Taj Mahal, Keb' Mo', & Ruby Amanfu ::: R.artist: Taj Mahal, Keb' Mo', & Ruby Amanfu
Taj Mahal, Keb' Mo', & Ruby Amanfu ::: R.name: Room On The Porch [Feat. Ruby Amanfu]
Taj Mahal, Keb' Mo', & Ruby Amanfu ::: R.extracted_quote: a bold yet laid-back statement on inclusivity, delivered with a warm, playful melody
Taj Mahal, Keb' Mo', & Ruby Amanfu ::: R.review: A bold yet laid-back statement on inclusivity, delivered with a warm, playful melody. The Americana stalwarts, along with co-writer Ruby Amanfu's joyful, inviting voice, paint a picture of real Southern hospitality; people gathering to celebrate honesty among friends, family and anyone who happens by. Let this be our aspiration for 2026. — Ana Lee , WMOT

Natalie Bergman ::: Lonely Road ::: desc.name: Lonely Road
Natalie Bergman ::: Lonely Road ::: desc.extracted_quote: a '60s sad-girl ballad swinging with the groove of bottomless yearning
Natalie Bergman ::: Lonely Road ::: desc.review: The other half of Wild Belle, Natalie Bergman goes full retro in this '60s sad-girl ballad swinging with the groove of bottomless yearning. As the promise to never love another gets more assured, the keys, strings and stacks of vocals rise atop the bass to fulfill her words with a satisfying, ascending-into-heaven ending. — Tshego Letsoalo , KALW

Mystery Tiime, The Maghreban, & Emanativ.name: Everything
Mystery Tiime, The Maghreban, & Emanativ.review: Ayman Rostom (aka The Maghreban) takes the plunge and sings for the first time under his new alias, Mystery Tiime. Featuring percussion from Emanative and saxophone by Kotoa, "Everything" is a sentimental take on death and escape. Rostom's influences of jazz and new wave fuse together for a refreshing, danceable ride. — Barry Leonhard , WYSO

Wednesday ::: Townies ::: description_np.name: Townies
Wednesday ::: Townies ::: description_np.extracted_quote: catchy, country-influenced storytelling and the rock-star ability to stretch the word "died" into nine syllables
Wednesday ::: Townies ::: description_np.review: When you flee your hometown, there's a tendency to forget what's in your rearview mirror. But if you stick around, you might find yourself extending an olive branch to your high school frenemies and even your teenage self. North Carolinian Karly Hartzman captures that sentiment here with catchy, country-influenced storytelling and the rock-star ability to stretch the word "died" into nine syllables. —Elle Mannion, NPR

Machel Montano ::: PARDY ::: description.name: PARDY
Machel Montano ::: PARDY ::: description.extracted_quote: the sort of energy boost that typically requires skirting the law
Machel Montano ::: PARDY ::: description.review: No one makes Caribbean anthems like Machel Montano, whose biography is appropriately titled King Of Soca. "PARDY," the winner of this year's Trinidad and Tobago Carnival "road march" competition, is the sort of energy boost that typically requires skirting the law. If you want a real taste of the chaos of Carnival, check out the seven-minute "Road Mix" version. — Otis Hart, NPR

Moses Sumney, Syd, & Meshell Ndegeocello.name: Hey Girl(s)
Moses Sumney, Syd, & Meshell Ndegeocello.extracted_quote: a flirty, blushworthy wink that leans into the delicious tension between passion, restraint and consent
Moses Sumney, Syd, & Meshell Ndegeocello.review: With desire dripping from every sultry syllable, this unexpected trio conjures a scene where trust and patience promise pleasure fulfilled. It's a flirty, blushworthy wink that leans into the delicious tension between passion, restraint and consent by delicately interweaving the signature styles of these three inimitable artists. —Nikki Birch, NPR

Monaleo ::: We On Dat ::: description_np.name: We On Dat
Monaleo ::: We On Dat ::: description_np.extracted_quote: Throwin' them 'bows is its own distinct artistry, and brings greater satisfaction to boot
Monaleo ::: We On Dat ::: description_np.review: Sun Tzu said that the acme of skill is to subdue the enemy without fighting. Monaleo ain't buyin' it. This song reaffirms her personal position: Throwin' them 'bows is its own distinct artistry, and brings greater satisfaction to boot. Splitting the difference between Ludacris' "Move B****" and Slim Thug's "Like a Boss," the cut's thumping bass and slap-happy delivery seems to mime the force behind an impending beatdown. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Model/Actriz ::: Doves ::: description_n.name: Doves
Model/Actriz ::: Doves ::: description_n.extracted_quote: Cole Haden tells a self-conscious confessional so haunting and mesmerizing that the brash pulse becomes nothing but a light metronome
Model/Actriz ::: Doves ::: description_n.review: It's hard not to focus on the incessant, industrial drone that Model/Actriz wields so well. But here, Cole Haden tells a self-conscious confessional so haunting and mesmerizing that the brash pulse becomes nothing but a light metronome. "Doves," he repeats through labored breathing, whispering the word with envy. Maybe he wants to fly — but ultimately he decides to sit instead and "make a rapture out of waiting." —Dora Levite, NPR

Kehlani ::: Folded ::: description_npr25.name: Folded
Kehlani ::: Folded ::: description_npr25.extracted_quote: her R&B bag is full of music that makes us feel something
Kehlani ::: Folded ::: description_npr25.review: "Folded" is infectious, and Kehlani is showing us all that her R&B bag is full of music that makes us feel something. The multi-layered track makes you reassess your own love life, as you dissect the lyrics for this ambiguous love. "Folded" has set the tone to expect nothing less than R&B supremacy in 2026. — Jason "SugaBear" Harris , The Drop (Rocky Mountain Public Media)

Mocky ::: Music Will Explain ::: descrip.name: Music Will Explain
Mocky ::: Music Will Explain ::: descrip.extracted_quote: "Music Will Explain," both as a mantra and as the title of one of the year's most infectious celebrations of the human voice
Mocky ::: Music Will Explain ::: descrip.review: Like many of us, multi-instrumentalist, arranger and producer Mocky has been thinking about AI a lot lately. As he pondered the point of it all, he came up with "Music Will Explain," both as a mantra and as the title of one of the year's most infectious celebrations of the human voice. — Brian Burns, WUNC Music

monte booker & Nami ::: defense ::: desc.name: defense
monte booker & Nami ::: defense ::: desc.extracted_quote: a warm, woolly sweater with prickly, off-kilter beats and the coziest embrace
monte booker & Nami ::: defense ::: desc.review: More world-builder than record producer, monte booker's full-length studio debut, noise ( meaning ) , unfolds like a cinematic score. Or a warm, woolly sweater with prickly, off-kilter beats and the coziest embrace. Approaching cult status in recent years, the Chicago native's soulful sonics pair best with a tight-knit circle of collaborators (see: Zero Fatigue, Soulection). Nami adds to that mix with a taunting vocal, as he breaks down his lover's "defense" on a hook that proves love is dope. Pun intended. —Rodney Carmichael, NPR

Tyler Childers ::: Bitin' List ::: descr.name: Bitin' List
Tyler Childers ::: Bitin' List ::: descr.extracted_quote: you're high on my bitin' list
Tyler Childers ::: Bitin' List ::: descr.review: Alt-country superstar Tyler Childers is a man of many unusual extremes. For instance, his latest album, like some of his sold-out concerts, includes elements of a Hare Krishna chant and other Indian influences, which would seem to be a long way from his Appalachian origins. But he hasn’t gone total peacenik on us, at least not when it comes to “Bitin’ List,” which became a viral hit off the “Snipe Hunter” record. “I just don’t like you,” he announces in the song, “and if there ever come a time I got rabies, you’re high on my bitin’ list.” It’s meant playfully, naturally, but it would not have become one of the year’s defining Americana songs if there weren’t a lot of folks out there able to identify someone they’d like to take down with them if they contracted a communicable disease. So sing or growl along, and then atone with 20 Hare Krishnas. — WIllman

rusowsky ::: SOPHIA ::: description_npr1.name: SOPHIA
rusowsky ::: SOPHIA ::: description_npr1.extracted_quote: no one's nailed quiet vulnerability quite like Madrid's classically trained, experimentally driven producer Rusowsky
rusowsky ::: SOPHIA ::: description_npr1.review: It's been a big year for boys making pop hits about yearning. But no one's nailed quiet vulnerability quite like Madrid's classically trained, experimentally driven producer Rusowsky. Lyrically, "SOPHIA" has all the makings of a 2002 Aventura track: sugary sweet, almost overly sappy in its pleas for a kiss. But filtered through layers of Y2K synths and drum machines, it becomes a shimmery, retrofuturistic ballad fit for sparking a stealthy dancefloor makeout session. —Isabella Gomez Sarmiento, NPR

googly eyes, Joy Oladokun, & August Pont.artist: googly eyes, Joy Oladokun, & August Ponthier
googly eyes, Joy Oladokun, & August Pont.name: Jesus and John Wayne
googly eyes, Joy Oladokun, & August Pont.extracted_quote: This devastating song documents the singers' decisions to leave the church.
googly eyes, Joy Oladokun, & August Pont.review: What would Jesus do? The question is more necessary than ever, for reasons you already know and that we won't be getting into here. This devastating song, by three conflicted Christians, borrows its title from Kristin Kobes Du Mez's book about their evangelical brethren's support for President Trump and documents the singers' decisions to leave the church. The most memorable line, delivered with profanity for impact, is something you'll need to hear to appreciate. —Otis Hart, NPR

Mereba ::: Phone Me ::: description_npr1.name: Phone Me
Mereba ::: Phone Me ::: description_npr1.extracted_quote: a chorus so strong, so infectious, so memorable
Mereba ::: Phone Me ::: description_npr1.review: Marian Mereba, a gauzy R&B singer who releases music under her last name, came up with a chorus so strong, so infectious, so memorable, that this song barely bothers with verses. (There are six renditions of the former and just one of the latter.) It hardly matters when Mereba delivers the lyrics with the sort of reassurance only a best friend can provide. —Otis Hart, NPR

\u00d3lafur Arnalds, Talos, Niamh Regan,.artist: Ólafur Arnalds, Talos, Niamh Regan, & Ye Vagabonds
\u00d3lafur Arnalds, Talos, Niamh Regan,.name: We Didn’t Know We Were Ready (feat. Niamh Regan & Ye Vagabonds)
\u00d3lafur Arnalds, Talos, Niamh Regan,.extracted_quote: a breathtaking and luminous appreciation of life's uncertainty and the anchoring weight of gratitude
\u00d3lafur Arnalds, Talos, Niamh Regan,.review: This soaring meditation on the impermanence and fragility of life took on a tragic new meaning when its singer, the Irish artist known as Talos, died at the age of 36. Co-written with Icelandic composer Ólafur Arnalds and the Irish folk artists Ye Vagabonds and Niamh Regan, it features a radiant choir of friends who gathered to pay tribute on this posthumous recording. It's a breathtaking and luminous appreciation of life's uncertainty and the anchoring weight of gratitude. —Robin Hilton, NPR

Kokoroko ::: Just Can't Wait ::: descrip.name: Just Can't Wait
Kokoroko ::: Just Can't Wait ::: descrip.extracted_quote: radiating with blissful anticipation and sweeter than candy rain
Kokoroko ::: Just Can't Wait ::: descrip.review: In Urhobo, Kokoroko means "be strong" or "hard to break." Similar words of encouragement breathe a collective understanding into Tuff Times Never Last , honoring the dualities we face in life. "Just Can't Wait" celebrates a lighter note: a love long savored, radiating with blissful anticipation and sweeter than candy rain. — Abi Clark , KUVO

Jeff Tweedy ::: New Orleans ::: descript.name: New Orleans
Jeff Tweedy ::: New Orleans ::: descript.extracted_quote: the moody atmosphere and mystic meditation depict a funeral parade, but if you let that squiggly guitar wriggle its way beyond sadness and fear, the Earth opens wide
Jeff Tweedy ::: New Orleans ::: descript.review: One of those songs that means more the less you think about it. The moody atmosphere and mystic meditation depict a funeral parade, but if you let that squiggly guitar wriggle its way beyond sadness and fear, the Earth opens wide. —Lars Gotrich, NPR

Durand Jones & The Indications & Aaron F.artist: Durand Jones & The Indications & Aaron Frazer
Durand Jones & The Indications & Aaron F.name: Paradise
Durand Jones & The Indications & Aaron F.extracted_quote: Durand Jones' buttery falsetto ... forges its own luscious path to a whole new Shangri-La
Durand Jones & The Indications & Aaron F.review: I love a good two-step track. Add in Durand Jones' buttery falsetto and some effect-drenched backup vocals, and I'm floating. This record clearly worships at the throne of Sade, but isn't a cover of the 1988 hit: This "Paradise" forges its own luscious path to a whole new Shangri-La. — Ayana Contreras , KUVO Jazz

Asher White ::: Beers with my name on th.name: Beers with my name on them
Asher White ::: Beers with my name on th.extracted_quote: White sprints breathlessly from fuzzy guitar rock to jazz and crushing, four-on-the-floor electro pop
Asher White ::: Beers with my name on th.review: Younger artists have been obliterating genres for years, but few can keep you guessing or leave you wanting more quite like Asher White. On "Beers with my name on them," White sprints breathlessly from fuzzy guitar rock to jazz and crushing, four-on-the-floor electro pop, before landing back down in some sort of uneasy organ ballad. If 2025 was a year of mental and emotional whiplash, then this was its soundtrack. —Robin Hilton, NPR

Ken Pomeroy ::: Stranger ::: description.name: Stranger
Ken Pomeroy ::: Stranger ::: description.extracted_quote: hits like the kind of stray insight that changes your life
Ken Pomeroy ::: Stranger ::: description.review: This subdued account of inching toward resilience from 23-year-old Cherokee singer-songwriter Pomeroy shows why she's a generational talent. As carefully constructed as beading on a belt, it hits like the kind of stray insight that changes your life — starting with the most devastating couplet I heard all year: "The wind keeps on hitting me like my mother used to / Unlike her, I feel it doesn't want to." —Ann Powers, NPR

Bucle Lunar ::: Subi\u00f3 El Maldito Do.name: Subió El Maldito Dolar
Bucle Lunar ::: Subi\u00f3 El Maldito Do.extracted_quote: With Eva Rojas' piercing vocals and Sebastián Lucerowsky's gloomy guitar, Bucle Lunar strikes a fine line between melancholy and defiance
Bucle Lunar ::: Subi\u00f3 El Maldito Do.review: Leave it to a couple of teenagers from a city in Venezuela's Andes Mountains to make one of the most heart-shattering rock songs of 2025. With Eva Rojas' piercing vocals and Sebastián Lucerowsky's gloomy guitar, Bucle Lunar strikes a fine line between melancholy and defiance: an anthem for a disillusioned generation, moshing their way through a dollarized economy that's driving their friends out of the country. —Isabella Gomez Sarmiento, NPR

Bassvictim ::: Mr. President ::: descrip.name: Mr. President
Bassvictim ::: Mr. President ::: descrip.extracted_quote: an optimistic beat drop built on the back of some aching strings
Bassvictim ::: Mr. President ::: descrip.review: There's nothing quite like hearing an optimistic beat drop built on the back of some aching strings — or even an apathetic mantra of heartbreak layered over a shimmering synth — to remind you that sometimes it's OK to accept the fact that the 2010s are back and so is Tumblr-era depression. —Dora Levite, NPR

Ben Williams & MAE.SUN ::: Ballet (for t.name: Ballet (for the Elephant in the Room)
Ben Williams & MAE.SUN ::: Ballet (for t.extracted_quote: jazz bassist Ben Williams gives the song's parenthetical idiom a pseudo-classical, "sort of political satire" soundtrack
Ben Williams & MAE.SUN ::: Ballet (for t.review: Accompanied by the pensive woodwinds of Hailey Niswanger, jazz bassist Ben Williams gives the song's parenthetical idiom a pseudo-classical, "sort of political satire" soundtrack, punctuated by some kitchen-table reflections on racism, division and the Black political movement by his mother, Bennie Barnes. —Nikki Birch, NPR

Cuco ::: Para Ti ::: description_npr125.name: Para Ti
Cuco ::: Para Ti ::: description_npr125.extracted_quote: Dripping with a Latin soul sound of yesteryear ... made me want to be outside
Cuco ::: Para Ti ::: description_npr125.review: Cuco released the album Ridin' at a perfect time. Dripping with a Latin soul sound of yesteryear, "Para Ti," in particular, made me want to be outside, which is quite a feat to pull off in a Texas summer. Especially as we get closer to the colder part of the year, it's a song to remember summer — and look forward to the next one. — Jackson Wisdorf , KXT

Hope Tala ::: Phoenix ::: description_np.name: Phoenix
Hope Tala ::: Phoenix ::: description_np.extracted_quote: a skeletal paean to BFFs could melt the internet's coldest hearts
Hope Tala ::: Phoenix ::: description_np.review: This simple, skeletal paean to BFFs could melt the internet's coldest hearts. And if you don't have a BFF, "Phoenix" is a far better substitute than ChatGPT. Hope Tala will have you back on your feet in 2 minutes and 39 seconds. It's no wonder that three of her songs have appeared on Barack Obama's annual playlists. —Otis Hart, NPR

George Xiaoyuan Fu ::: Passacaglia on a.name: Passacaglia on a Theme by Radiohead
George Xiaoyuan Fu ::: Passacaglia on a.extracted_quote: a thorough deconstruction of the material throughout his cavalcade of adventurous variations, concussive climaxes and evaporating trills
George Xiaoyuan Fu ::: Passacaglia on a.review: The searing guitar riff that opens Radiohead's "Airbag" was stuck in George Xiaoyuan Fu's head for some time and eventually became the foundational bass line for the pianist's own rigorous reworking of the song. Fu offers a thorough deconstruction of the material throughout his cavalcade of adventurous variations, concussive climaxes and evaporating trills. Within this eight-minute tour de force, you keep wondering: Where will he take us next? —Tom Huizenga, NPR

Charley Crockett ::: Lonesome Drifter ::.name: Lonesome Drifter
Charley Crockett ::: Lonesome Drifter ::.extracted_quote: navigating the highway with the rhythm section's propulsive groove as his guide
Charley Crockett ::: Lonesome Drifter ::.review: Charley Crockett's output this year alone is a testament to the hard work and dedication he brings to his craft. Lonesome Drifter is one of two full-length albums he released in 2025, with a third one to round out the conceptual trilogy on the way. Crockett embodies the namesake of the record's title track, navigating the highway with the rhythm section's propulsive groove as his guide, and you can't help but feel like you're riding shotgun. — Desire Moses , WNRN

Jobi Riccio ::: Wildfire Season ::: desc.name: Wildfire Season
Jobi Riccio ::: Wildfire Season ::: desc.extracted_quote: "Wildfire Season" smolders and sparks, its central riff resurfacing and finally overtaking everything
Jobi Riccio ::: Wildfire Season ::: desc.review: All year I watched this song convert audiences to Riccio's brainy revitalization of heartland rock, in concert and across the internet. A cry of passion inspired by the threat climate crisis poses to her native Colorado, "Wildfire Season" smolders and sparks, its central riff resurfacing and finally overtaking everything. Protest music at its finest. —Ann Powers, NPR

caroline & Caroline Polachek ::: Tell me.name: Tell me I never knew that
caroline & Caroline Polachek ::: Tell me.extracted_quote: a dizzying swirl of duetting Carolines flows from a fragile confession to a celestial choir, splashed with hi-hats, blurts of brass and plucked guitars
caroline & Caroline Polachek ::: Tell me.review: If a song were a murmuration of starlings, shadowing an evening sky, it would be the British octet's mesmerizing vortex. Featuring fellow shapeshifter Caroline Polachek, this dizzying swirl of duetting Carolines flows from a fragile confession to a celestial choir, splashed with hi-hats, blurts of brass and plucked guitars. A feverish final chant is an infinite truth. — Kara Manning , WFUV

Blood Orange ::: Vivid Light ::: descrip.name: Vivid Light
Blood Orange ::: Vivid Light ::: descrip.extracted_quote: the track is warm, propelling us forward with the very emotion he couldn't face
Blood Orange ::: Vivid Light ::: descrip.review: Devonté Hynes explores a creative process defined by grief, a theme that anchors his album Essex Honey . Dev sings, "I wasn't falling for the hope." With vocals from Zadie Smith, the track is warm, propelling us forward with the very emotion he couldn't face. —Sonali Mehta, NPR

Carter Faith ::: Betty ::: description_n.name: Betty
Carter Faith ::: Betty ::: description_n.extracted_quote: a comic twist on Dolly's classic "Jolene" — except in this case, the wronged blonde fully appreciates the allure of the gal who got her man
Carter Faith ::: Betty ::: description_n.review: From the best old-school country revivalist to emerge on Nashville's music row this year comes this foot stomper, a comic twist on Dolly's classic "Jolene" — except in this case, the wronged blonde fully appreciates the allure of the gal who got her man. —Ann Powers, NPR

Jon Batiste ::: PINNACLE ::: description.name: PINNACLE
Jon Batiste ::: PINNACLE ::: description.extracted_quote: swaggers and shouts with joy in this greasy boogie ... its hooks practically leap out of the speakers to make you smile, shimmy and shake
Jon Batiste ::: PINNACLE ::: description.review: Musical chameleon and award magnet Jon Batiste swaggers and shouts with joy in this greasy boogie that evokes the grooves of Freddie King and North Mississippi hill country blues. Part self-affirmation and part strutting exclamation, its hooks practically leap out of the speakers to make you smile, shimmy and shake. — Joe Kendrick , WNCW

JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_npr.name: Plastic Box
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_npr.extracted_quote: I'm jealous, obsessive, and I wanna burn all your history
JADE ::: Plastic Box ::: description_npr.review: A spiritual cousin of Robyn's "Dancing on My Own" with the roles swapped: Our narrator's new relationship is going great, or at least it would be if she could just stop thinking about her lover's glamorous ex. JADE's girl-group pedigree is key here, expertly balancing tones as she admits the truth: "I'm jealous, obsessive, and I wanna burn all your history." —Daoud Tyler-Ameen, NPR

Carrie Rodriguez ::: Miles Away ::: desc.name: Miles Away
Carrie Rodriguez ::: Miles Away ::: desc.extracted_quote: sings of those who owe allegiance to cultures on either side of the border even when they're "miles away"
Carrie Rodriguez ::: Miles Away ::: desc.review: In early 2025, musician Carrie Rodriguez collaborated with author Oscar Cásares and photographer Joel Salcido to chronicle life along the southern border in the stage production and album Postcards from the Border . Rodriguez said she wanted the language on her songs to flow from English to Spanish just as the Rio Grande flows from the U.S. and Mexico. "Miles Away" sings of those who owe allegiance to cultures on either side of the border even when they're "miles away." —Felix Contreras, NPR

Bryce Leatherwood ::: Where The Bar Is :.name: Where The Bar Is
Bryce Leatherwood ::: Where The Bar Is :.extracted_quote: straddles the line between bro-country and the neotraditional appeal of George Strait
Bryce Leatherwood ::: Where The Bar Is :.review: Country music, at its core, is an empathetic soundtrack for working people of all stripes. And there's nothing more relatable than blowing off steam at the end of a long week. This after-hours anthem by a former champion of The Voice straddles the line between bro-country and the neotraditional appeal of George Strait, complete with a key-change crescendo. —Otis Hart, NPR

Lola Young ::: SPIDERS ::: description_n.name: SPIDERS
Lola Young ::: SPIDERS ::: description_n.extracted_quote: her raw, dark performance on the brokenhearted "Spiders" is one of the most memorable of the year
Lola Young ::: SPIDERS ::: description_n.review: The 24-year-old British singer-songwriter Lola Young is best known for endearingly quirky and candid pop hits like the viral "Messy," on which she brushes off anyone who tries to curb her too-muchness. But her raw, dark performance on the brokenhearted "Spiders" is one of the most memorable of the year, as she transforms a simple request to kill spiders in her bedroom into a desperate plea for a love to finally make her whole. —Hazel Cills, NPR

CA7RIEL & Paco Amoroso ::: RE FORRO :::.name: RE FORRO
CA7RIEL & Paco Amoroso ::: RE FORRO :::.extracted_quote: blending jazz, disco and bossa nova ... The catchy hook and dancey beats disguise the darker lyrics reflecting internalized pressures of unexpected success
CA7RIEL & Paco Amoroso ::: RE FORRO :::.review: Fresh off their Tiny Desk's viral success, this Argentine duo offers an upbeat tempo, blending jazz, disco and bossa nova on "RE FORRO." The catchy hook and dancey beats disguise the darker lyrics reflecting internalized pressures of unexpected success, unable to measure up to idealized expectations, feeling empty and fixated on one's internal, unlikeable self. They make emo sound fun! — Margarita Azucar , KALW

Jim Legxacy ::: stick ::: description_np.name: stick
Jim Legxacy ::: stick ::: description_np.extracted_quote: the ascendant U.K. rapper is an aerial dancer here, whirling between half-sung catch phrases on a ribbon of hummed chords
Jim Legxacy ::: stick ::: description_np.review: "No More 'I Love You's'," but make it drill? Delivering on the genre collectivism of his "Black British music" rallying cry, the ascendant U.K. rapper is an aerial dancer here, whirling between half-sung catch phrases on a ribbon of hummed chords and never seeming to touch the ground for long. —Daoud Tyler-Ameen, NPR

El Cousteau & Niontay ::: Rose Ave. (fea.name: Rose Ave. (feat. Niontay)
El Cousteau & Niontay ::: Rose Ave. (fea.extracted_quote: a new and improved strain of lo-fi loop music that has bled into swag rap
El Cousteau & Niontay ::: Rose Ave. (fea.review: El Cousteau and Niontay represent a new and improved strain of lo-fi loop music that has bled into swag rap, occupying a middle distance between the grumbling sage MIKE and the low-key go-getter Tony Shhnow. Here, they toss the mic back and forth like a hot potato, their run-on flows spilling into each other, all snowballing toward one striking street proverb: "To afford the cost of living, that's what a n**** do crime for." —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Justin Bieber ::: FIRST PLACE ::: descri.name: FIRST PLACE
Justin Bieber ::: FIRST PLACE ::: descri.extracted_quote: One of the world's most popular musicians hired both to help write and produce his critically acclaimed comeback album, and the song that hews closest to their off-kilter aesthetics didn't involve either of them. That's what you call influence.
Justin Bieber ::: FIRST PLACE ::: descri.review: The improbable rise of alt-pop auteurs Mk.gee and Dijon is best summed up by the paradox at the heart of this track: One of the world's most popular musicians hired both to help write and produce his critically acclaimed comeback album, SWAG , and the song that hews closest to their off-kilter aesthetics didn't involve either of them . That's what you call influence. —Otis Hart, NPR

Arvo P\u00e4rt, Vox Clamantis, & Jaan-Ei.artist: Arvo Pärt, Vox Clamantis, & Jaan-Eik Tulve
Arvo P\u00e4rt, Vox Clamantis, & Jaan-Ei.name: Nunc dimittis
Arvo P\u00e4rt, Vox Clamantis, & Jaan-Ei.extracted_quote: ethereal music ... creates a supernatural portal between this world and the next
Arvo P\u00e4rt, Vox Clamantis, & Jaan-Ei.review: A low drone ushers us into Arvo Pärt's transportive choral work, based on a tiny but moving scene in the Bible where an elderly man, having finally seen the Christ child, can die in peace. Pärt's ethereal music, with the registers in the Vox Clamantis choir delicately folding into one another, creates a supernatural portal between this world and the next, depicted with childlike wonder and reverence, yet tinged with apprehension that creeps into dissonant harmonies. —Tom Huizenga, NPR

Annie DiRusso ::: Back In Town ::: descr.name: Back In Town
Annie DiRusso ::: Back In Town ::: descr.extracted_quote: elevated by an undercurrent of sadness; by a sense of longing for a deeper connection
Annie DiRusso ::: Back In Town ::: descr.review: At first, "Back in Town" registers as a horny anthem about secret hook-ups and a boi who can only be counted on for one thing. But as funny and profane as it is — and those brash, crashing choruses are great big joy dispensers — it's also elevated by an undercurrent of sadness; by a sense of longing for a deeper connection that's nowhere in sight. —Stephen Thompson, NPR

Gabriel Jacoby ::: the one ::: descripti.name: the one
Gabriel Jacoby ::: the one ::: descripti.extracted_quote: sultry and distinctly country-fried, visceral but polished, funky yet oh so clean
Gabriel Jacoby ::: the one ::: descripti.review: There's some kind of voodoo taking place within this song's sound world, which is sultry and distinctly country-fried, visceral but polished, funky yet oh so clean. As the song casts its spell, you can almost feel the magnetic pull that Jacoby's feeling. "Come get invasive," he chirps, seeking a closeness so unavoidable it comes to be nearly symbiotic. —Sheldon Pearce, NPR

Bon Iver ::: Everything Is Peaceful Love.name: Everything Is Peaceful Love
Bon Iver ::: Everything Is Peaceful Love.extracted_quote: [The track is] an instant classic with warm, layered production
Bon Iver ::: Everything Is Peaceful Love.review: From the beginning of the first single from SABLE, fABLE , Justin Vernon digs deep to deliver his finest without getting lost in the usual dense production loops. This indie soul-pop track is an instant classic with warm, layered production. Its simple message feels believable rather than cliché — that we're all surrounded by love. — Kyle Smith , WYEP

Adrian Quesada & Mireya ::: Cuatro Vidas.name: Cuatro Vidas (with Mireya)
Adrian Quesada & Mireya ::: Cuatro Vidas.extracted_quote: Mireya Ramos' heartbreaking take on "Cuatro Vidas" recalls Eydie Gormé's '60s classic while giving it a contemporary, tearful shimmer
Adrian Quesada & Mireya ::: Cuatro Vidas.review: At one point, Adrian Quesada needed four bands to match his creative output; nowadays, he picks and chooses carefully. This year, he released a second volume of Boleros Psicodélicos , jammed with Alt.Latino faves on vocals. Hard to choose one, but Mireya Ramos' heartbreaking take on "Cuatro Vidas" recalls Eydie Gormé's '60s classic while giving it a contemporary, tearful shimmer. —Felix Contreras, NPR

Lauren Henderson, Sullivan Fortner, Joel.artist: Lauren Henderson, Sullivan Fortner, Joel Ross, Dezron Douglas, & Joe Dyson
Lauren Henderson, Sullivan Fortner, Joel.name: Bold
Lauren Henderson, Sullivan Fortner, Joel.extracted_quote: conveying sensuality and directness without guile or affectation
Lauren Henderson, Sullivan Fortner, Joel.review: Featuring first-call musicians in pianist Sullivan Fortner, vibraphonist Joel Ross and bassist Dezron Douglas, Sonidos is Lauren Henderson's finest recording to date. The singer and composer's soulful yet understated voice is demonstrated on the original composition "Bold," which she sings at barely above a whisper, conveying sensuality and directness without guile or affectation. — Kim Berry , KUVO Jazz

GIV\u0112ON ::: MUD ::: description_npr1.name: MUD
GIV\u0112ON ::: MUD ::: description_npr1.extracted_quote: Crisp, clean and worth playing in the dirt for, the opening track on Beloved brings all the drama
GIV\u0112ON ::: MUD ::: description_npr1.review: Crisp, clean and worth playing in the dirt for, the opening track on Beloved brings all the drama. Confronting an ex-lover who sullied his name, the artist sets the mood with strings that seem to be attached directly to his own heart.
